Sensing a shadow flicker in flames above me, I roll sideways. The Royal Guard jumping the gap stabs his blade into the wooden floor, expecting to carve me in half, not anticipating this span of flooring would carve off with him instead.

He screams on the way down until another scalding log follows and puts him to permanent rest. The wreckage spans all the way to the cavern, and after untwisting my stomach, I leap to the other side where Lyra fends off the remaining two. This side of the room is no longer safe. I can feel the floorboards give on this island, so without a warning, I drag the child with me to the other side.

The second Royal Guardsmen is just about to land a surprise blow on Lyra when I catch his blade with my open-faced sickle, and I jerk it backwards, flinging it out of his hand. His body follows, bashing me to the ground, my upper back and head suspended directly over the crevasse.

Like all the other sick bastards above, he'd rather make me suffer than let me die an unceremonious death. With his gloves charred off from kicking him into the flaming debris, he tries to dig his thumbs into the sockets of my eyes, but quickly gives up, unable to get the leverage he needs to crush them in my skull. I feel an amethyst anguish ravage my brain instead: his brute force crushing my head as I helplessly thrash over the divide.

But I thank the Carmine they embellish their children with tombstone courage. A loud, hollow thunk resonates the crackling air as this intruder's eyes roll into his sockets, and he collapses forward, rolling directly off me as the last remaining child stands over me with a shovel.

"For Talia," the young cadet says. He reaches to try to catch me as I slide from the edge, and reclined backwards, I realize there's nothing my arms can reach, trying to twist and grasp the edge when inertia longs to drag me to my brimstone demise.

"You stupid rat," a voice exclaims, as I slide off the edge and into the ravine to join my mother. But the hood of Lyra's Carmine cloak snares on the sharp edge of a cast-iron pipe, suspending me there helplessly beneath the floor like an upright spit-roast.
I hear a short cry before the tearing of flesh and bone. A wetness saturates the cloak, dripping beneath the floorboards and across my soot-stained flesh, blinding my eyes.
I claw at my eyes, too late to see the two figures float past me before being impaled on the metal shelf two stories below: one tall, one short.

The fourth wall finally gives. All that's left is this peninsula of splintered, charred wood one-and-a-half stories above the basement, reinforced by the thick iron pipes that once led to the washbasin, draining scalding city water on the floorboards.
A hand reaches from above the floor. It's also the first time I hear the sound of anything beyond this warehouse, all the onlookers gathered there to just stand and watch as Lyra throws a rope.

"We need to get out of here," she says. I lift myself back to the surface, my hands black and red and slit with fresh blood, riding the last wave of adrenaline that staves off all this pain. "Nobody can know we were here. Or else all of this, and I mean everything that happened tonight, will be our fault!"

I cough black mucus from my lungs, drawing pained and trembling breaths, most of my clothes charred off. By either an act of the Gods or selfishness, Lyra still has the bag slung over her shoulder. While I chose the last child to defend, she wasted her chance to defend my grandfather's last secrets.
She coughs as she tensions her grasp around my wrist again. We make off into the woods behind the gaping hole of refuse, just as the real Merlotan guards turn the corner.
I hear a familiar voice behind me. It's booming and bewildered.
"Titus? Titus, what are you doing here?" Romin cries. "Stop!"

But we've already disappeared into the woods. Without a chance to shake off Lyra, our fates are bound now. There is only one place we can go, and together—just as lighttime flashes in the street lamps.
"You gambled with intel over innocent lives, of course I'm upset! Nothing in that bag can atone for the those kids we let die."
"They were marked for death. You tried. And you might have even saved two of them," Lyra insists.

We speak in hushed voices, almost to the childhood home where I pray Ellie waits for me. A column of smoke dissolves into the smog somewhere behind us. We're still covered in the aftermath, blending seamlessly into the night.
"It's because you acted that we were spotted in the first place," she says. "I saved your damn life! Act a little more grateful," she says.
I clench my fists and march in front of her. Some people just can't be convinced—and I don't care much for the facade I've held up for her anymore.
"Where are we going, anyways?"
"My home," she says.
"You mean where you're staying for now. Is it First Red sanctioned?"
"It's my actual home," I tell her, "and my sister is waiting for me."
"I don't understand—you live in the city?"

"I'm not with the First Red!" I tell her. "Leave me, try to kill me, do whatever you want if you feel disappointed or betrayed. I don't care anymore. I just want to see my sister.  You probably won't believe me when I say we're on the same side. Because I hate those genocidal pukes in the Afterlife as much as you do."

"Fletcher, then . . ." She says, her voice trailing off. As I climb the porch steps, I hear her dash behind me. She grabs my coat, slamming me to the ground on my back, dragging an ashen print in the white layer of snow on the porch. "You lied to me! You son of a bitch, you told me he was still alive!"

She withdraws her dagger, but I don't resist her. She just sits there on top of me, ready to drive the steel through my neck or eye socket, but I can feel her hesitation as she trembles there in rage, knowing I know so much that she doesn't, and so instead she huffs and screams, throwing the blade to the side.

She grabs what remains of the lapel of my coat. My back freezes where the scorched holes of my coat let fresh skin touch snow. "How did you know? How did you know their names, Titus? Just me. Just me and my father, we should be the only people that know his name!"
"You wouldn't believe me if I told you, urgh—" her grasp is right around my neck. "You'd believe that lie long . . . before you believed . . . the truth!"
I can feel her tremble with fury. But her curiosity ultimately wins over. She steps off me. "If the mercenaries were with me right now, I'd let them peel your flesh," she insists.

"You have every right to be angry. But you're also short on time, and so am I. So are we going to figure out what's in this bag, and will you let me care for my sister? Or are you going to cause a scene and get us both dragged away?"

She wipes the charred snow from what remains of her jacket. "Fine, then," she says. She extends a hand, unwittingly, and I take it. But as soon as I'm just about to raise myself to her height, she lets go.
I stumble, my head cracking the entryway window in spiderwebs before I fall again.
"Get your own damn self up," she insists, shouldering the bag, trying the handle of the door to find only I have the key.
Grasping my head, I open the door to find Ellie terrified, brandishing a kitchen knife like I taught her in case of intruders.
She drops the knife in tears.
"Tie!"

She embraces my waist as I bend down to hug her, smothering soot and blood over her white jacket before I realize I'm still a mess. I feel emotional, too: as Lyra stomps past us to throw the bag on the kitchen island, Ellie weeps as I embrace her on my knees in the kitchen entryway.
"I was so scared," she says, "you were late!"
"I know. I'm sorry," I tell her, as Lyra watches from the other side of the house, lost in a memory. "I promise I'll never leave you alone, never again."
She buries her head in my shirt and I'm filled with love again.
"Whoa there, I need a bath," I tell her.

I laugh when she withdraws her face covered in soot, sneezing as she drags her hand against her face. I grab a towel from the kitchen and douse it with water, wiping away at her cheeks, coated in ink like a stamp after use. The ash must have acted like a coagulant, because when the water seeps into my cuts, I grasp them in sudden anguish.
I choke back curses in the presence of my sister. My hands are sliced open from jagged metal and splintered wood: other than that, I've been fortunate to evade anything grievous.
"That friend of yours. He called your name. What does he know of any of this?" Lyra asks.

"Nothing. His name is Romin, one of the highest Brothers in this province of Carmine." I will never forget the white anger when he saw the aftermath of the attack. It sends chills down my spine imagining him now. "We'll be in a world of trouble if he thinks I did it."
"Would he tell anyone?"
"I don't think so," I say. "But he's easily prone to anger."
Ellie's voice cracks with fear again."Are we endangered?" she asks.
"I don't think so. I mean . . . not at all," I say. "No. We're not in danger."
"What's the red on your hand? And what's that?" she asks.
"I took a fall coming here," I reason.
"Why?" she asks. Children ask so many questions.
"I wasn't trying to," I tell her.
"Then why's the black on you?"
"Because I tried to save someone. From a fire. It's all smoke."
"But smoke is bad! It hurts your breathing, and then you won't be good at fighting. Don't be like Clint."
Not Dad or Daddy. Kids are brutal—but after so many years, even at eight, I know she's disappointed the same way I am.
"I won't. I promise," I tell her.
Lyra is already sorting through her haul as I approach. "Was it all worth it?" I ask.
"Make yourself useful and help me find out," she says.
I sit at the table. She's already started sorting the documents. "How did you know what to pick?"
"I didn't," she says. "I picked anything that looked most-referenced or recent, on the tables, in valuable places. You didn't give me much time when you ran up there."
"Tie! I'm hungry," Ellie says.
"Sorry, let me fix you something." I wince over my cracked hands. Creasing them breaks the seal of dried blood, and they start gushing again.
"The red again," Ellie says.
"Shitt. . . .or, shoot, shoot, can you get me a towel? And the first-aid box, you know where that is, right?"
"You said a bad word," she says.

"I know, I know, can you just get it, cutie? I'll tell you a story," I say, and in seconds, she returns with a white towel, along with the unopened first aid kit my mother Moira bought many years ago. What kinda weak blood are we raising, Clint once said. If you're gonna bleed, then bleed it out like a man.
I crack it open with one hand. The excruciating pain returns as my adrenaline fades further. "Rip the pouch of wound cream for me?"
"Please," she insists.
"Please. And thank you."
She tears the perforation. I feel her hug my legs together real tight as I try to steady it over my trembling hands. Lyra laughs at the table.
"What are you doing?" I ask.
"Momma asked me to do this one time when she was leaking red too, and she cut herself," Ellie says, "so I wanna do it for you."

"Then you better hug real tight," I say. My adrenaline is fading. I can't imagine what pain awaits me. A pallid bead leaks from the packet, viscous and dense, hovering over my wound until I lower it there. The searing pain overtook me worse than when it happened, only hours before.

I groan, pressing my clean fingers into the cut, making sure the cream saturates every surface. The flesh parts like a bad haircut, and the simmering pain brings me to my knees. I feel Ellie embrace me harder. It surprises me to remember how strong she had gotten, how much she's grown up.

"Hug, hug, hug!" she exclaims. Tears leak from my eyes. But I'm not crying. It's as if I'm looking in bright sunlight, or on the verge of a sneeze, and I focus on the tightness of her grasp, huffing for breaths between clenching all my muscles to resist the feeling. The hard part is over.
"N . . . now, g-get the gauze."
"Gauss? Gloss? The lip stuff Mommy used?"
"No, n-no, the cloth wrap, the cloth wrap. White. There," I mutter.
Lyra laughs, turning it into a cough.
"Here?" she asks.
"Y-yeah," I say, "wrap it real tight."

I hold the end of the fresh roll between my thumb. Instead of standing in one place, she playfully spins in circles around my hand as if it were a streamer, ducking under my arm each time, grunting as she tightens it as tight as she possibly can. Despite everything, I feel a humor churn under my breath at how cute she is.

She presses her lips to the bandage. "All better, Tie! Momma said that will heal it faster," she chimes, with a playful skip in her night clothes as she climbs the arm of the sofa, falling backwards into the cushions.
I certainly feel at least a little better. When I stand to fix her something to eat, I hear Lyra mutter something under her breath.
"What?"
"No way, I said. Look."
She hands me a photograph from ages ago. Three still faces state back without a smile.
"That was my family," she says. "Me, my father, and my brother."
"Ullrich and Fletcher?"
"That's right."
"Is your mother behind the camera?"
"I think so," she says. "This must have been right before the attack — I was the last piece of her my father had."
"Then who was it?"
"Wait—move your finger," she says. I flip it to the back. Scrawled there are two initials and a sentence.
YOU WILL DIE WITH THE GUILT OF WHAT YOU'VE DONE. E.V.
"Everett Valensend," Lyra says. "Your grandfather and my uncle are the same person! That bastard did change his name."
"What did he feel so guilty for?" I ask.

"For leaving my brother and I to die," Lyra says. "A long time ago, we lived in a house beyond the walls. When Ullrich was out, we were attacked by Snowdrifters. The only secure room in the house was the office, high enough above the ground to be almost two stories, with a bolted door. Your grandfather hid behind that door," she says.
"Gods. It all just seems so fridging impossible," I say. "That was never the Everett I knew."
"The kindest face can mask the illest will," she says. "At least I'm sure he took that cowardice to his grave." She motions to the picture. "Please . . . Can I keep that?"
I thumb further through records. The only fastened pages are in an envelope labeled TESTS. I thumb quickly through the pages. They look like blood tests.
The folder is labeled PROJECT PURGATORY. "Wonder what that means," I say. Several pages are stuck between with drops of dried blood. THE ULTIMATE VASSAL OF BLOOD; THE HEIRESS OF PURGATORY HERSELF.

I read the lines and lines. The further I flip, the more the words dissolve to unintelligible scribbles, just like the map he left for me. The memory of Everett's eyes will forever penetrate my soul, the last time I saw him, when I brought this map and he looked back across it, as if there was something he wished to say, something he kept silent.

And then the same repeating letter: "F." I'm flipping back to front now. The cursive becomes more legible. Every trial denoted with an "E" and an "F"— code for names, dates, or trials, I'm unsure until I make it to the front, where they're referenced for the first time.
EVERETT.
FLETCHER.
"Your brother, he was down there in that basement," I tell her.
Her eyes light up, and she lunges for the document. "Where?"
It slips from my hands, giving me a paper cut as I accidentally tear out the last page.
"Gods, Lyra," I say, sticking my finger in my mouth as I look down at it. Among the intelligible scribbles of the last sessions, there's a third name I can barely make out.
MOIRA.
"Gloss," Ellie says, as she approaches with the first aid kit. "Gloss and then make me food!"
"Okay, okay," I say. She wraps my finger, and I scan through the cabinets for canned food.
"That last page you made me bleed on. It has Moira's name on it," I say.
"How long ago was all of this?" Lyra asks.
"At the end of his life, scribbling away on the last fumes of his mind? Only three years ago."
"So you're saying Fletcher was there, maybe five years ago," Lyra says.
"That's right," I tell her.
A look of relief flushes her face. My lie is true, and I see her almost crease a smile for the first time.
"Hand me that can," Lyra says. She turns to Ellie. "Do you want beans, beans, or beans?"
Ellie tilts her head.
"She doesn't know what irony is yet," I tell her.
She opens the lid, grasping the can by its bottom. In seconds, it glows red hot.
"Wow! How did you do that, Leera?" Ellie asks.
"I'm cooler than your pathetic, liar brother, here, that's why," she says. She pulls a bowl from the cupboard, adding a spoon before pouring it in.
"Thank you, thank you," she says, before retreating to the couch in the living room.

My eyes catch on a spot on the living room floor before they return to the stacks of documents. It's just a blemish of soot shen I knelt to hug Ellie, but remembering that pool of blood my father died in sets me on edge.

It was only hours after this that they came to take her away. Have I sped things up? Have I forestalled that future? Or is it seconds away, bursting through the wide glass window, swarming the building, waiting outside for us to sleep or let down our guard?

"Titus. Titus," Lyra says. I snap to attention again. Ellie is staring at me. My hand is on my heart, and I'm kneeling on the floor, heaving for air like I'm breathing through a straw. My fingers are cold. My body is frozen. I can't move my joints, and it only panics me further.
"It's happening again, Gods, please, don't take her from me," I cry.
"You're fine. You're having a small panic attack," Lyra says.

I stumble towards Ellie on stiff legs that refuse to hinge. Sparks pop in my vision. I nearly collapse to the floor. My flesh is cold. They're waiting outside again to take her, to kill me or anyone who tries to resist them.

"I won't let you go, I swear to you," I mumble, as Lyra tries to restrain me. I have to see whether the darkened splotches cover her flesh, if her skin is cold like my father's when his eyes stopped moving in their sockets and I almost wept over them.
She just sits there eating her beans, not a blemish or mark anywhere across her skin.
"See, I told you," Lyra says. "Everything is fine."
I slump to my knees and take deep breaths. After a short while, the control of my hands returns. Ellie keeps eating her beans, smacking her lips, then stands up to wash out the bowl.
"I'll take care of that, Ellie," I say. I'd prefer her upstairs where she's safe. "Go up and get ready for bed."
"But I wanna stay with your new friend Leera!"
"Go up and take a bath," I tell her. "Leera will read to you."
"Okay!" She exclaims, retreating up the stairs.
"It must be nice," Lyra says.
"Having panic attacks?" I ask.
"Of course not. Family. It's a nice thing to witness."
"You should meet my father, then," I say.
"Meet mine," she says. "A high-grade purist asshole."
Who says I haven't, I think.
"What you said earlier. When you said the word 'again.' What did you mean?" Lyra asks.
But before I can answer, a knock sounds on the door.
Lyra withdraws the Merlotan sickle she saved from the ambush. I lift Ellie's dull kitchen knife from the ground, cautiously stepping forward as a lone figure dances behind the cracked glass.
I crack the door to lighttime, expecting a great force to bash it in. I try my hands and legs. My fingers and joints still hinge. The sensation of icy death never chills my bones.
The voice knows my name, and it carries it softly,
"Titus," Sylvia says.
I crack the door further to try to meet her eyes, but she hunches in either nervousness or dismay, making herself small again.
"I was so worried when you left, Titus. You said nothing. And I got to thinking, about . . . us, and . . . I'm sorry for what I said. And I'm sorry if I'm not good enough, for you, you know, but, I—"

She finally looks at my face. I haven't seen my reflection in the mirror since I last saw her, but the way her eyes widen are enough to tell me everything of how desperate and weak I've become in such a short time.

I speak first, and it comes out as a mumble. "It's fine." I should have added more, told her that it was all a misunderstanding, but my mind is so shell-shocked by the existential fear that the words don't register. My mind short-circuits. I let her in when I should have explained the last four-and-a-half hours and sent her to safety, away from the madness we stirred in such a short time.
"Gods, Titus," she says: surprised, but even more concerned. "Are you okay?"
"I'm fine," I say. I contort enough of a smile to convince her as I step back from the door. But her eyes catch on the other woman in the room.
"Who's that?" Sylvia asks.
"I'm his girlfriend, who are you?" Lyra says. I'm too exhausted to parry with an angry glance. I hope Sylvia knows it's a joke, but knowing her, she'll probably take it as it is.
"An acquaintance," I tell her. Then Lyra cuts back on her classless mockery.
"Kidding. We're nothing. In fact, we just met, when I tried to kill him."
"You what?" Sylvia exclaims.
"But, no, we're fine. For now, at least. We're trying to find out why his grandpa is a murderer after burning down a building," Lyra says, as if that doesn't open a thousand more questions.

"You're both covered in black," Sylvia says. "What happened? When?" She takes my hand, looking at the bandage Ellie applied moments earlier. My arms are slashed, too. I smell like death, and I lean away from her, aware of how disgusting I am.
I flinch back.
"No, stop," Sylvia says, grasping my arm and pulling me back, scanning my body with her calculated medic's glare. "You're burned all over. What happened to you?" She asks.
"He almost fell two stories to his death."
"Shut up, Lyra! You're only making it worse," I say. "Go back to your papers."
"Fine. I'll let your girlfriend care for you," she says.
I take off my shirt and jacket. Sylvia traces her fingers against my chest where it itches.
"Heat blisters. Gods, Titus, have you been picking at them?"

"I'm alright," I tell her, though the stinging pain has followed me since we left. My flesh pleads for a roll around in the snow. But all I can think of is the fear of Sylvia snaring herself in this mess.
"There's something you should know," I tell her. I step back as she traces her finger on my chest. "You shouldn't be here right now."
"Why can't I be? Why are you being so distant? Everything was just fine until you awoke this morning in panic. You ran from me. And now you're telling me to go away again?"

"I can't involve you in this mess," I tell her, "you'll get hurt worse than either of us have. We almost died in that warehouse, and now the Afterlife and Carmine are out for our blood. If you don't leave right now, you'll feel the collateral damage of more fury than you can ever imagine."
She doesn't even pause for a moment to think. "No. I'm staying," she insists. "Your fight is my fight. I can never leave you."
"Are you—"
"Yes, Titus, I'm not leaving you." The confidence is unbecoming of her. "You can't change my mind."

"Alright, then," I say. She stands tall, forcing me to look up to meet her eyes. "Thank you for being there for me. I'm sorry. It was nothing against you, there was something immediate and horrendous I had to attend to."

"I trust you, Titus," she says. "You scared me because I've never seen you so afraid of anything before. You said something about 'things not happening again,' called me Khiras, and then you were gone."
"He said something about 'happening again' to you, too?" Lyra says. "You said that seconds ago. What does that mean?"
"You wouldn't believe me if I tried to explain," I tell them. "Just a figure of speech."

"Whatever," Lyra says. "We need to plan our next move. We need to get out of here. The First Red have tunnel systems only we know about — we'll take you, your sister, and your love interest somewhere safe where you'll never face the wrath of the Afterlife again."

"You'll take them," I say. "They might have seen your face, Lyra, but they know nothing of who you really are. I'm the only one putting us all in danger. I'm the only person they know. And how do we know they're not out there right now, watching us, waiting for our next move?"
"So what are you trying to say?" Sylvia says.
"I'm saying that it's my fault," I say, "and if I present myself, it's the safest course of action for all of us."
"How can an accident be your fault? What are you planning, what, to just walk out there?"
"I'll drive them away," I insist.
"You're stupid, that's what you are," Lyra says. "Is this a joke?"
"Fine, then," I say. "We'll leave in a moment. Wake Ellie upstairs and help her grab all that she needs. And Sylvia, can you help her?"
She nods, rising from the couch, but I catch her by the shoulder. "Are you absolutely sure?" I ask. But her expression is resolute, so much that it surprises me.
"I'm not that same timid girl you had to save. I can make my own choices, and I choose to stay with you," Sylvia says. "I know what you're thinking. But people can change, Titus."

But can they? Really? She couldn't even watch when I went on my incendiary tirade in the Afterlife. In the end I watched my friends lose their lives over the same weaknesses. Ellie doesn't seem to age a day or ever understand what I sacrifice to keep her safe, and Clint hasn't ever gotten over Moira's death. That eternal hopeless feeling of always being on edge is a plague that stagnates this entire city. The unknown of what lies beyond the wall, stories of Chymaeran skinwalkers who can kill you, steal your identity, and take over your life after wiping out your family, passes around like how embers of a distant fire light kindling.

And so I nod in agreement to agree to disagree. "I know. Just making sure. It's my eternal job to worry about you," I say, with half a smile so that it doesn't sound mocking or spiteful. And I guess I don't change either, but that strength I find in sacrifice is for the best of all I touch.

"Ellie, grab your things," I shout. There's a force that draws me beyond the window like flies trying to escape glass. They'll be safe without me, I think. I run a long race with no end in sight. My mind begs me to stop. But there's just enough of a stupid hope inside me that swells with the feeling of fear, reminding me of what I have to lose, and I hate that feeling so much.

I take inventory of my possessions. I still know nothing of this force that drags me back from the edge of death. If I step out there and live, then I know they're not around. Who says they think I'd end up at home? And if they get me, if I succumb to a rifle blast or die from an arrow to the head, then . . . rolling the dice on this curse of eternal life, I would know the next time around, and maybe, just maybe, we could make it out.
The adrenaline of this edge casts gooseflesh across my arms. I feel warmth like a junkie after their requited hit. It's not that I want to die or be done.

Standing in the entryway, I think I hear a stirring just beyond the door. Nobody else in the house heard it. I stand silent there, waiting for my ears to ring with enough persuasive silence that the shock of fear subsides. It's just the wind chimes beyond the door, I think.
And then a heavy thud.
An object?
Footfalls?
My anxiety overrides my fear and I reach for the handle to throw the door open again, no longer listening for quiet to quell my confusion.
The cold steel knob twists in my hands. I don't hesitate or draw it slow. And when I open the door, I'm greeted by a sight I haven't seen since the life I last lived.
I can tell he's been crying from the redness in his eyes. His expression surprises me enough that my first words stick to the back of my throat.

I figured he'd be furious. I thought he'd burn my house to ashes, or call upon the strength of his clan to capture everyone I care for, but instead he's at a loss for words, as if he'd been carefully rehearsing them since he started walking over here.
His lips part to speak, but I beat him to it. "Call the Carmine off, Romin. Please. I know what you're thinking. I had no part in what happened."
Reasoning with Romin is like moving a boulder; in most cases pushing does nothing. But he surprises me.

"They're not coming," he says. "It's just me." I can tell he musters every inch of respect he has for me to restrain himself. In place of a response, he trembles in either anger or sorrow, or both, unable to muster a reply or a question, which urges me to continue. I don't know how long the rage he's repressed for me will hold.

I'm smart enough not to mention the young cadets, which leads me to the decision: do I spin him a convincing lie or tell him the whole truth?The image of his honorless death still shakes me to the core, and just seeing his face digs up the most painful traumas of all the emotions I went through in that last life. I can't involve him. I can't let him die the same way, and as much as I long to embrace my childhood friend, no matter if he'll jokingly call me a faggot, to feel he's still alive in a time before hubris and rigor mortis decayed his corpse to maggots and bone—I feel the same repulsive force that separates me from Sylvia drive a gaping rift between the two of us.

I was told once that compassion means "to suffer with," but all I can give him is freedom from the suffering that I'll accept for him, from the pain he'll never have to know. I shut out the voice from within that screams and pleads for me to reach out. I've silenced it for as long as I can remember, at least as long as I've denied the feelings that stir within me when I try to lose myself in the tenderness of Sylvia's embrace. They're only illusions of debt she's grown since I first protected her. All I do is walk the line of the same path life has decided for me, from my loveless fight for value in the orphanage to the words of the Academy that we were all born a sacrifice to the Greater Good.
And so I find no trepidation in accepting this truth. I don't think too hard when I make the choice—I can carry that remorse.
"Clint didn't check the basement when we sold the shop to the Carmine," I say. "I still had a spare key. There's a lot of family treasure down there we couldn't afford to have disappear."

"Then why did you run? Why did you look so afraid and guilty? How could you not have known something was happening? I want to believe you," Romin insists, pausing as his mind collects the next words, "because you're my closest friend and brother. I wouldn't give anybody else, but you, the benefit of the doubt for the horrible things I saw . . . tonight. There were two young Brothers and Sisters that came to me from beneath the cellar. They said you saved them. You fought the Merlot when they tried to kill all our young cadets."
"I did, Romin. I couldn't just stand there and do nothing."
"Thank you, Titus," he says. "Those Gods-damn Merlot, fridging bastards, to think they could stoop as low as murdering innocent children!" Romin's anger has now taken a side.
"They weren't Merlot."
"And how would you know that?"
"I . . ." can't explain to him what I know. "I don't," I say instead.

"I knew it. I knew there was no way it could have anything to do with you. But those Merlot suck-ups—" he trembles with rage, growing twice his size with how he tensions his muscles, finally free to channel the vitriol— "better prepare for what's coming their way."
I don't notice when another familiar face approaches.
"Even Valentina will—"

"Will what?" Valentina says. She looks so small compared to him, even when she climbs a step higher on the porch. Valentina keeps an arm-and-a-half reach, as if Romin were a snake coiled to attack. And if I were her, I would do the same.
Romin says, "So are you always going to cover for the horrible things the Merlot has done?"

"I would only ever apologize for the things my people have done," Valentina says. "Fifteen years and you're ready to throw all of that out the window for your anger." She's not afraid, but she ought to be. I begin to wonder if this conversation happened in that life before, because all I saw was the bitter aftermath. "All I've ever asked for is just for you to just listen to me!"
I can't tell them what I really saw. I refuse to burden them. All I can do is watch as the conversation plays out.

"Your words mean nothing—how you speak so highly of the family that disowns you." Romin encroaches the territory of that secret she hides within her heart. "Paid off by Daddy to breathe air with your bastard blood," he says; "you call yourself free and strong when you're too weak to live by your own terms. Your words are just like your family: fake and hollow."
Lyra and Sylvia now approach, looking on in horror, refusing to react either. Lyra and Sylvia don't have an inkling of what Romin speaks of. But I've been cursed with that knowledge.

Valentina trembles. Her fists ball so hard on her well-manicured nails that I think they'll draw blood. Her signature eyeshadow doesn't run with streaks of black from tears: all the anger inside must have vaporized them, leaving nothing but the poisonous pathos of every scar she can re-open. Knowing Romin better than any of us, she doesn't hesitate.
In fact, she draws closer.

"I should have known better than to think you'd listen! Your head's so far up your ass living in the past, you don't even try to understand," she says, "and I thought you were different than all your Carmine cultist brothers and sisters."
I can see Romin's anger escalate. Something's gotta give.
"The only place you'll ever live and die is in the shadow of your brother."
"You fucking insolent bitch!"

Romin brandishes the back of his hand across her face. It takes so little of his force to send her flying across the porch and into the shutters, right next to the glass where my head slammed hours earlier. They snap from the force of her whole body. Romin looks on in terror as she lies on the ground, motionless, unsure of what to do or what to say, as his humored drivel can't salvage the severity of this irreversible outburst.

I should have gotten between them. I should have said something. And as Sylvia reaches to try to lift her from the ground, Romin begins to tremble, mumbling incoherent words when he sees the limpness in her body.
I have no words for Romin, just as he has no actions, drowning in his own thoughts as his head sinks in his hands. He sits on the porch, refusing to leave, but also too afraid to help her.
"What in Gods' name were you thinking, Romin?" Sylvia says. She takes Valentina inside. "All you can ever do is just solve problems with your fists!"
"I know. I know . . ." Romin mutters to himself between a sniffle, like a mantra, too focused as he stares at his open palms, wondering how such little force can cause such destruction.
"She's breathing," Sylvia says. "Just shocked."
"Take her inside," Lyra instructs. "I'll see what I can do."
"Are you medically trained? Are you in the Academy?" Sylvia asks. Lyra explains something about Essence, but I don't catch the end of their conversation.
I find myself sitting next to Romin. The lamps of lighttime flash on and I wonder how much time we have left.
"Live fast and die young, talk with your fists and burn out strong," he mutters. "No mother. No father. And only a single image of blood for me to live for."
It's only the memory of his last life that gives me a shred of sympathy. I don't give him the grace of a reply yet. All I want is to listen.

"Sometimes it feels like I could just stand up and slit my throat, and the entire world would go on without me, without a hitch. There's something I have to convince myself of, when a I've already lived longer than I ever thought I would," Romin says. His eyes leak, but he'd never call them tears.
"But why?"

"Because I keep trying to fill the shoes that were left for me. And all that happened was I kept getting smaller." He tensions his fists. "I just get so jealous of her . . . not that she didn't work to build that image of hers. But she didn't struggle. Not like us, Titus, on the ground, raised from nothing," and he turns to face me, tears in his eyes, "with no wind in our sails or a voice of love or reason to tell us what we're worth, how in the Gods' name does that not bother you?"
"Because I'm always running from it," I tell him. "I run so fast that it can't catch up."
"And how does that make you feel anywhere close to complete?"
"It doesn't," I tell him. "And I don't understand either."

I see that trademark shit-eating grin crest his face—but his expression doesn't brighten enough to make me think he dismisses his own actions. Around us, the city begins another day with the early risers. Young fireteams of pre-academy cadets run in formation. Other windows flash in with fluorescent light. But still the smog covers the city, obscuring the mountains and the beautiful world somewhere far beyond.
"Then I guess that makes two of us," he says.

"You should feel terrible for how you hurt her, but you already know that, and I don't have to tell you twice. All I want you to know is that I understand it, that pain you feel," I tell him. "Because I look at Sylvia, and with such a smog-ridden, corrupt, disgusting, lonely, agonizing world we live in, I'm still trying to figure out what lets her smile."
I look out at the civilians, wondering how much time they have left, wondering how they would react if they knew the end was approaching so soon.
"Here's to the answer," he says, raising an invisible glass. He won't leave: his guilt and disappointment trap him here. "Go in there and check on her."
"I will," I say.

"And hey—" he catches me before I turn for the door. "An angry piece of shit like me doesn't deserve a sincere friend like you, Titus. But thank you for not giving up on me. Thank you for being honest."

I nod before turning for the door. My stomach drops with that word. Honest. If I were honest, you would all be horrified, but I don't let that thought cleanse my personal sins as they chew away at my heart.
"She's fine, just a little shaken up," Sylvia insists. "Maybe a concussion."
"I did what I could with Essence," Lyra adds.

Valentina's awake, just dazed, absorbed by the pain in her head, trying to take in her surroundings. She lays on the couch, more concerned about the mud on her boots than her own condition, resting her heels on the carpeted floor.

She speaks up. "I wasn't here for Romin. I was here for you, Titus," she says, tilting her head to try to meet my eyes, but the brim of her hat conceals them. "Your panic. All the things you knew that I never told you: my secret, the cellar, and the lift. I thought it was a joke at first — I can read people well because I play them, and I know you weren't lying."
"It's about time you told us," Lyra says.
"Alright, then," I say. I look towards the door where Romin still sulks on the porch, trapped there, feeling to guilty to either leave or enter. "Can I call him in?"
Lyra and Sylvia look to Valentina.
"Go ahead. This is important," she says.
I approach the entryway, calling his name. He turns sideways to fit through the door, head bowed, afraid to meet eyes with Valentina.
"No words I say can excuse myself. I'm an angry piece of shit like always, and I'm sorry for that," Romin says.
"I instigated you," Valentina says. "But still, why . . ." Her words freeze.
Silence hangs between us for a moment before discomfort urges her to speak again.
"Anyways, Titus. Go on."

Romin sits on the couch next to me, across from Valentina, with Lyra and Sylvia directly behind her. Lighttime filters through the grand, marbled living room window, and I doubt any of them will believe me, so I dump the hardest truth all at once.

"I lived an unthinkable future and died. I saw the end of Blackwater. A great Chymaeran flood called Endogeny eviscerated every living thing, killing all the lower peoples, draining their Essence so the Afterlife could thrive."
I gauge their expressions. Romin tries to keep a straight face. Sylvia nods. Lyra looks surprisingly convinced, and Valentina's in dazed disbelief.

"Endogeny," Lyra says. "Made from the ashes of a Chymaeran God fused with the soul of a cursed Chymaeran Mask, forever hungry. Deterrable by the Essenced, and brutal to the weak-blooded. The First Red know much of it. In fact, we were almost certain it would be our end."
"Hold on a second," Romin says. "Are you telling us you came from the First Red? Of the Carmine?"
"It's true," Lyra says. "We operate in secret. We live beyond the walls, controlling the operations of the Carmine from afar. You don't see us. But we are everywhere."

"She's lying, Titus," Romin says. "That's a myth! The Blackwater Carmine is the only relic that remains of that past purpose. We pick up the pieces our founders left behind. They all died—along with my mother and father!"
"She's telling the truth, Romin," I say, "I saw them there at the summit, too late to act."

Lyra casts a flame in her hands. Romin and Valentina are dumbfounded. "There's so much all of you never learned. Those upper bastards herd you like cattle, depriving you of your birthright as Humans as a means to their sickening end."

Valentina adds: "But how could my family ever comply with that? We relay the will of the Afterlife, and they care for us. All of us! Why does Blackwater never starve, besides being in a frostbitten wasteland? The Merlot carries their will, and their will is good."
"This girl here," Lyra says. "Valentina? What's your relation?"
"I'm the daughter of the Province Twelve Merlot," she replies.
"You haven't seen her movies?" Romin says.
"No, I haven't," Lyra says. "How can you be so blind to what they're doing?"
"I don't think my mother and father even understand their full intentions. Rich as they are, they're still public servants."
"No wonder you and Beefcake don't get along," Lyra says.

"Let's stay on topic," I interject. I think of the whole truth I'm withholding from them every time our eyes meet. Valentina crushed to nothing. Romin a martyr. Vera dying alongside me, and Sylvia losing control of whatever energy it is that resides within her.
Surrounded by the friends and allies I've pleaded fate to see alive and well, I've never felt so helplessly alone.
"I believe Titus," Lyra says. "He's spoken of things nobody ever could have known. He knew the fire would destroy the trade house. He tried to save those children."
"How did you know?" Romin asks.

"The last time, all I got was a call from my father across the street," I say. "I saw the wreckage. Innocent cadets murdered before the burnings. The perpetrators dressed as Merlot though they're really the Afterlife."
"And what happened after that?"
"Chaos. Looting. Street wars that weakened the fabric of our city enough for Endogeny to destroy everything," I say.
"And the Carmine are furious. They'd have Valentina's head if they saw her on the way over here," Romin says.
Sylvia leans forward on the couch. "So when does this all happen?"
"Soon. Maybe even now," I tell her.
"And what happens next?"
"The fire. I came down as quickly as I could. Then . . . Ellie!"
How could a I have forgotten about her so easily?
"What about her?" Lyra asks. "She's safe upstairs, and we've been down here the whole time."
"Ellie!" I shout. "Ellie, are you ready?"
No reply.
"Ellie, please, say something!"
Nothing.
My stomach drops. I climb the stairs.
"Ellie! Ellie, come here," My voice wavers. But still—no reply comes from her room.
The door is closed, and I see the light on beneath the crack of the door. It's freezing: even colder than the early afternoon air outside.
I'm reassured by the crack of light.
My hands reach for the doorknob.

"Ellie, you have to respond to me. You scare me when you don't reply like that," I say, as I open the door. There's ice frosting the windows. The window is open. It looks as if dew freezes her sheets to the bed.
She sits there on the mattress. Her hair blows with the wind.
"What were you thinking, opening the window? You're going to catch a cold."

She doesn't reply, and I don't see any of the mannerisms I know. It's as if she's hollow—like the brass statues at the Academy, filled with nothing—because her soul and self has left. The more I look at her, the more I notice something is off. The uncanny resemblance is something that only I could ever notice.
I wear a thick coat, but I still shiver. That frigidness has come from within. I'm scared to speak the next words because of what might happen.
My voice flattens. "Who are you?"
And that's when I find out.
"If that amethyst travels to his heart, he'll die," says Lyra. "Steady him. On the table."
"What? Why? How do you know?" Sylvia says.
"I remember, Titus told me when we were past the walls," Romin says. "The Chymaeran Curse."
"But there's no Chymaerans in the city. How can that be possible?" Sylvia asks.
"I've never even seen one," Valentina adds. "They're almost a myth. Tales the Academy instructors tell to scare us."
"Well, they're very real, and they walk among you. Far more than you can imagine," says Lyra. "I've stabilized him. He'll be alright for a while, but—"
"But what, Lyra?" Sylvia's voice trembles.
"But he has so little Essence right now, his body can't fight it. He's going to die."
"Unless what?" Romin asks. "Unless we do what?"

"Unless we get him more. But he hasn't built the momentum of generations of Essence. Just as one doubles to two, to four, to eight, to sixteen, to . . . whatever comes after that, your body builds Essence every day. Just to build enough to do even the most basic acts can take a lineage a lifetime."
"Then it's hopeless," Valentina says.
"Don't say that," Sylvia says. "Please. Lyra — what did this to him?"
"What was in his sister's room?" Romin adds.

Lyra says, "Nothing. The room was empty seconds after I heard him scream. He's lucky he shielded himself with his arms from whatever that was. Wound to the chest and it would've taken under an hour to kill him."
"So it was Chymaeran?" says Romin.
"Obviously," Lyra says.
"So what happened to . . . his sister? Ellie?" Valentina asks.
"Gone. Gods . . . this will destroy him. I thought he screamed because he couldn't find her. I hardly noticed the purple bruised lines on his left hand when I picked him up," Romin says.
"That venom is in him, freezing his body. He can hear, but he can't think—for now. But as soon as his muscles fire and he strains awake, the clock will start for him," says Lyra.
"Then how do we stop it?" asks Valentina.
"I'll knock him out. If we can make him pass out, it could stop the spread—"
"Gods, Romin! No, absolutely not. Stop! He's on the verge of dying already, you're gonna kill him," Valentina says.
"It's actually not a bad idea. Lower heart rate means slower spread," Lyra says. "We put ours on ice. With full Essence, it gives the time the circuits need to fight it."
"If you really think so," Valentina says.
"Then we'll have to—"

I cry out in anguish. My body strains as if splintered glass runs with the blood in my veins. I heard them. I couldn't think, just listen and wait, until my body decided to awaken. Staying in one place for too long is now painful: any time my muscles break that stillness, I feel an incredible soreness resist my motion like running underwater. I try to remember. All I know is I reached out to her, to grasp her hand and take her downstairs, but she — or it — changed from that form so quickly once it recognized I could tell the difference.

Now there is nothing to stop them from destroying us. Gods, I'm so angry at the circumstance that draws Romin and Valentina and Sylvia to stay here, to face the collateral of whatever ungodly force wages war on our petty resistance. Without Ellie, there are no holds barred on taking us down.
"Titus! Titus, are you even listening?"
I'm so absorbed in that pain that saturates my muscles that I realize I wasn't listening.

"You're going to die if we don't take you there," Valentina says. The pain lessens the more my body moves, and I realize it's only because I was still for so long. Maybe this is why Everett couldn't sleep so close to the end of his life, afraid he might die when he awoke the morning after.

"No! You and Romin are not coming," I insist. They're back on speaking terms only by my suffering. "I'm not losing you again, either of you. I'm not involving you with this. You're innocent to the forces that want to destroy us."
"When it's that artifact that burned a hole in the shop's roof, I feel more than just a bystander. I'm as responsible as you are."
Lyra turns to him. "What artifact?"
"Some fancy necklace we found in a house beyond the walls. The Carmine tried to intercept it, but we were too late."
"Pure Essence? Gods —" Lyra says, "can any of you even begin to understand what this means? Why didn't you tell me earlier, Titus?"
"I had too much to handle first," I say, wincing: it takes all the will I have just to try and lift myself with my arms. Its as if my right elbow hinges on broken glass.

"Despite everything, it shouldn't matter. We're a Fireteam. We stay together no matter what," Valentina says. Her stupid optimism sickens me, speaking the line as if it's all just a play or a film. She knows nothing of the true horrors, the ones that happen far beyond the camera, and the more that annoying insistence shows in her face, the more it pisses me off.
"And I'm not leaving either. I already told you," Sylvia says.
"Gods . . . You . . ." stupid, ignorant idiots! "If only you could understand." What I saw. What I suffered through without tears to cry, what I can't tell you.

"I can't involve you in this." I can't divulge to you the demon of that past that haunts me as I see it all happen again, and "I just don't want any of you to suffer," the way I saw you all die last time. "So please, I'm begging you, while you can, just—"
Commotion outside. So much time I wasted, taken for granted.
I knew this would happen.
"TITUS NATHANIEL BERGUARD," a voice calls, reverberating through the neighborhood street. "YOU ARE UNDER ARREST FOR MURDER AND  ARSON, STEP OUT NOW OR WE WILL FORCE YOU OUT!"
"They're everywhere! Gods, I can't even see them all," Valentina says. She peers out through the marbled glass of the entry door, trying to tell scenery from smudges of motion.
The blinds are drawn shut, but we aren't fooling anyone. The rest of us stand in the kitchen, anticipating our next move.
The adrenaline returns. My pain becomes a lesser priority.

"Step out now, or else we will use force," a voice calls from the street. "Come out with your hands on your head and you'll come out of this alive!" Valentina and Sylvia's faces light up, but dimly. It's only the rest of us that know better.

I consider my surroundings. They surely have the place surrounded: there's nowhere to run now. I peek out the window blinds, and I'm surprised to see the charred face of one of the first guards to fall to the basement floor.
He must have made it out through the hatch before the roof collapsed. The bastard is dressed in all-black Royal Guard gear as if impersonating the Merlot wasn't enough.
"It's my people," Valentina says. "They'll listen to me if I go out there!"
"They're not your people. There's no insignia on the chest," Romin says, peeking through the shades drawn against the large front window.

"But it will be fine, it has to be!" I can see Valentina grasping for anything at all to reassure her that we will come out of this alive. It was her adamance on staying that lead her here, with Romin and all the others. Her eyes are wide, breaths short.
"Your title does nothing," Romin says: not a man for convincing or choosing his words carefully. It's only after speaking that he realizes what they connotate.
"You really want to do this right now?"
"No, no! That's not what I mean by that. Please, listen—"
"No, you listen, because it's really hard to tell what you mean when you resort to hitting me to get your point across," she says. "I'm not going to let you tell me what I'm worth!"

Her hand turns the knob of the front door. She knows it's stupid, thoughtless. But there's another fear within her that's far stronger. I've seen that same pain the last time we went to her estate, to find her living in the cellar: the golden bed frame and pristine sheets surrounded by soot and dust.
And it was around this time, last time, that I saw her like this.
She wears the same expression I wore when fighting for worth at the orphanage, clinging to the beatific illusion of value, suspended over a black void of apathy and learned helplessness.
But she still holds on.

The bastard blood won't define her. Her entire life has built those beliefs on the shale of self-doubt. So no matter how much we tell her to stop, to think a moment more, she has to believe her worth ties to this. And again, she has to prove it, to herself, because each time will never be the last.
But this time, it will be her last.
Romin reaches to grab her wrist and pull her back, but it's too late. She throws open the front door, hands raised, calling out to them. "I am Valentina, daughter of the Merlot! Stop this attack on—"

They're the only words she can manage before the slug round eviscerates her. Valentina's hot blood erupts on Romin's face and all over his body, blending with the crimson Carmine cloak and staining the white on his Academy uniform.

Valentina's face is indiscernible. Her head is missing. For one so well-known and cherished by the people of Blackwater, all that remains are fragments of skull and grey matter painted across the entryway to testify to her image.
I can see the fury escalate within Romin. It sparks the same irreversible rage that ushered cadets to die with him beyond the gates.

He trembles. Sylvia weeps, gasping for air as panic overtakes her. The sickness in my stomach that carried through the anguish of that last life returns to me, and I feel as if my soul detaches from my body, and I watch myself from the corner of the room, the only act that can keep my sanity.

"Remember me," he mutters. The same words seem to sit on his tongue waiting for every fated end. He nods for us to escape. He plans to leave us a distraction. My mind floods through options of how we can survive while Sylvia and Lyra desperately plead for him to stay.
I failed them again. I allowed them to die, when I knew how all of this would unfold.
"Romin! Please," Sylvia pleads.

I can't continue on until I save all of them. I can't imagine a world without the people I love and cherish—without them, there would be no soul in the fight. I owe my everything. I am nothing but a waste without my actions to speak for me. And so time passes — paying no heed to the panic of Lyra and Sylvia, who scrounge for anything to save their foolish lives. It slips away, wiping any chance we had to escape when the Royal Guard first enters the door, stepping over Valentina's desecrated corpse and whatever ungodly sight Romin left on the porch.

I can feel how thin the veil of time is that separates us, as if its breadth were tangible. I pray to Gods for the deliverance to return back, and I swear on the lives of the lost that I will stop at nothing to keep them alive. If I can go back, if I can just return to that night with Sylvia again, then I have the chance to make something of this all. I'll hold so tightly to my sister that I'll never let her go. I'll let nothing distract me from keeping her safe. We'll run — I don't know where we'll run, but we'll run — as far and long as it takes.
I watch my friends die. I'm coming back to them. And when I refuse to tell the Royal Guardsmen anything, I don't flinch when the trigger pull sends me back.

The same force pulls me back in a direction beyond space. I'm getting used to this privilege, no matter how long it may last, but the force is weaker now. The images don't flash as quickly as they did last time. There's a resource within me that can only manage so little. I can see it this time: the reversal of the muzzle flashes that collapse Lyra and Sylvia. Entropy rewinds. The incendiary pellets return to the barrel. A dark figure re-emerges from the door, uttering words in reverse. The hot blood vacates his skin, returning back to the tender spaces inside Valentina, as she mutters her last testament in reverse.

As the reversal slows, I realize how much of a fool I was to believe this bedlam could have ever been fully fixed. I have no voice to scream as it exits my throat in reverse, as if my petty cries bellow into me rather than out.

I can't return to that time because I don't have enough Essence to make it there. And the permanence is enough to make me curse the Gods in spiteful hatred — at the eternity I realize I'll spend reliving this endless loop.
"It's the Merlot," Valentina says. "My people. They'll listen to me if I go out there."
"They won't," I say, as I stumble across the floor. "Please, please, don't go . . ." I beg, but my persuasion is no use.
"I have to, Titus, just trust me. They'll listen. I'm the Daughter of—"

"No, no," I cry, curling my body into itself as I crumple on the floor. The helplessness finally breaks the wall of pressure behind my eyelids. Tears flood from my eyes: unhelpful, petty tears; as useless as I am to saving the people I love. And then I remember how it felt every time I was ever rejected. The vitriol of that same self-hatred runs in my veins as an incurable disease, and for so long my mind has rendered it latent, just waiting like the dormant magma beneath Blackwater to erupt at the right provocation.
And here it is. The pain my childhood bared to me can't even begin to hold back the flood of pure sorrow and defeat.
It happens again. Valentina. Then Romin. Then Sylvia and Lyra who are inconsolable, pleading me to motion, begging the soulless Royal Guard to spare their lives.
But it's that image that allows me to cry, how badly I want it, how more and more the blackness of death convinces me of the value of life.

And that's when I realize that I still can feel: because if this narrow, fleeting window of time is to leave me forever — to pass beyond the reach of my limited Essence, then it must drag it from my soul.
"It's the Merlot," Valentina tells me again.
"I know, I know, just please, please," I beg, but she still doesn't listen.
"Remember me," Romin says, but this won't be the last time his life is taken.

I persist. Over and over. Trying anything that will produce the smallest change because I have to hold on. Every time I reach for Valentina, it's always too late before she opens the door. And every time the delicate parts of her erupt across the floor from the shotgun blast, Romin is inconsolable, so far beyond reason that he even throws aside my embrace when I try to grab him, to desperately calm him down, even just to feel his warmth.

"It's the Merlot," Valentina insists again. She won't change. They never will. So stuck and set in their weakness that they can't see the full picture the way I can, the way it kills them, how Valentina and Romin's desecrated image of self-worth drags them to die in atonement for their fatal flaws.

"Remember me," Romin says, again, and I begin to heed his words. These people are long gone. They were always gone. And the more the persistence of these cycles drag on and on, the more I feel myself detach from that connection to life.

My body always refills with tears to cry. They fall back in my eyes so I can shed them all over again every time, helpless and panicked, ground further and further like a machine tool in the Academy shop far beyond its expected life: how does it not break?

I lose track of the cycles. I only know this pass by the fact that my tears now refuse to fall, and that the thread now encompasses so much of my arm. It's also the first time I consider how to escape without them.
"It's the Merlot. My people."
But I've heard this so many times, like reruns of Valentina's feature films in the theater. I check the stove. The gas still runs.
"Titus, please, say something!" Sylvia pleads.
"She's beyond reasoning," I say, restraining the sob I nearly choke on. I turn on all the burners. Not enough to light. I wonder how much time it will take before the house incinerates.

"You can't! Please, Val," Sylvia says, distracted, unable to discern the smell of gas filling the air. Lyra doesn't notice either: too absorbed in the commotion of Romin and Valentina, playing out the same drama I can no longer bring myself to watch.

Valentina flips the handle of the door. I'll come back for you, I promise, somewhere deep in my mind, pinning that thought to the only piece of humanity I might have left. I'll get the Essence I need from far beyond the walls, and when I return I'll embrace you all. We'll laugh and cry! We'll all graduate together! We'll live beautiful lives. Our children will play together. I promise, I swear to the Gods, I promise I won't waste another second in that room, consumed by my addiction to darkness and sorrow.
I will live for you all and cherish everything!
The shotgun blast erupts Valentina's brains across the wall, the same splatter I've seen countless times before. And when Romin's anger crescendoes to his last two words, I throw open the hatch.
Fighting Sylvia's tenacious resistance is enough to shatter my soul: her cry, thrashing as I drag her towards the hatch and she pieces together my selfish plan for survival.

She curses me for giving up on them. I accept her words because she knows nothing of how many times I fought to try to save them. I have to throw her to force her down into the cellar. Falling on her back knocks the wind out of her.

It's when Romin tensions his fists that I prime the match. Lyra looks on with acceptance and understanding, but Sylvia, dazed at the bottom of the bootlegger's cellar, shrieks with indiscernible cries. "Gods, Titus, you're going to kill them!"
"They're already dead," I say.
I flick the match against the box like Ellie's purple crayons on a texture rubbing, quick to throw the hatch down as soon as Romin vanishes behind the door frame.
The air combusts on a pulse of thunderous air. Scalding heat burns the metal latch as I tug at the rope, ears ringing from the sudden spike in pressure, lungs burning from the dying oxygen.

Fragments of the childhood home crash all across the ground. I realize somewhere beyond this liminal space Valentina is entombed again in rubble, just the way I last left her. The suction no longer yanks at the trap door. The rope snaps. I fall to the ground on top of Sylvia, shielding my face as jars of long-preserved produce shatter across the floor.
"You bloody damn . . . coward," Sylvia manages, struggling to move as I lay on top of her, so exhausted that I'm unable to lift myself. Lyra says nothing: impressed by my sudden resourcefulness.
"There was no other choice," Lyra says. "Titus made the best move possible."
"He let them die!" Sylvia insists, shoving me aside as my face saturates in sour pickle brine. For her, this is the first time seeing any of this.
"What's done is done," Lyra says.

Sylvia can't even look at me, but I deserve it. I'll be the conducting rod for all of her anger if it makes her feel better. She can hate me all her life. Because now, all we can do is wait: hoping the wreckage conceals the small hatch; that they give up on trying to find our bodies; that enough oxygen fills this claustrophobic, musty space to last us at least half of a day before we can escape.

I don't reach to touch her. All I can do is marinate in the mixed marmalade of shattered jars, saturating in the sorrow of my sins, considering the debts I have yet to pay to the ones I so helplessly allowed to die.
The horizon of death's return passes, and I'm certain it's too late.

I count them in twos, and then threes, and then fives, and then tens, over and over and over again. One hundred and thirty seven. But it's not jars, strands of coarse hair in my jet-black beard, or the number of curses Sylvia still holds against me.
Two hundred and ninety-three lines decorate my arm. It's too dark to see. There's no light to adjust to beyond the thick steel hatch that sealed out the soot and smoke.

For hours, touch, taste, and the oddness of that sixth spatial sense tell me the full story of my surroundings. Logic tells me I made an irreversible choice. Hope tells me there's a way home where Lyra will take us. My ears hear heaving sobs from Sylvia, still hours after we were trapped down here. The sense of space says Lyra and Sylvia are spaced out evenly before me. Panic wonders if they can sense the Amulet. I feel Lyra reach out her hands, and I give it to her.

I still taste the brine of preserved pickle juice in my mouth, salty and dry, and my mouth begs for a drink of water. My lungs still irradiate with the faintness of smoke. And Gods, the Chymaeran Curse — consuming me with each passing second, like feet falling asleep re-urged to motion with a stabbing pain instead of a prickle, makes me wonder how much time I have left.
The City Guard arrived within the first hour, closing off the scene. News travels fast, but not just by the way of information — the column of smoke must have drawn observers from all around.

They searched through the wreckage for signs of life. The hatch must be concealed by a slab of concrete or a cross-beam of wood, because the inspectors passed over us, discussing the remnants of the fire.

"Four bodies," a female voice said. "Two look like Academy cadets, so disfigured it's impossible to tell who they were. One crushed under the rubble, must not have been able to escape the fire. Another on the porch. Two more are Merlot. This must have been another arson attempt," she concluded.
A brief pause. Then a male voice spoke up. "Stop. No notes, no paperwork. This gets swept under. Orders from above."
"From above?"
"Don't ask questions. Just let this go, Detective," the male voice said.
"But the insignia. Wait, look — there's no way this was Merlot!"
"I said enough! Let it go. This goes under as Merlot arson."
"But—" she had no power or words to change his mind. The case is way above both of their heads.
"Let's go. Now," he said. "We're here just to say we were here. All for show. The targets are dead."

Another hour passed. The air started running thin, and my head was light. The absence of noise and voices told us that the scene largely cleared out, besides a couple bystanders curious of the morbid sight.
"Stop! Hey, what are you doing?"
"This was my house! Gods . . ." a familiar voice said. "Titus, Ellie . . . You, tell me! Where are the bodies?"
"This is an ongoing investigation. No information—"

"Like hell it is!" Things were getting rough. I could hear the thud of someone falling to the floor, either punched or pushed. "My son and my daughter were here! I checked the Academy, went all the way up there. Nothing." His breaths heaved through his mouth. There was nothing I could say or do.
"I'm sorry," the other person said.
"No you aren't," Clint said. "But if you do anything, leave me here alone. There's already no bodies to bury or mourn."
Clint sobbed. The same regret I remembered from my first life overwhelmed him. He thought he was alone — he wouldn't let anyone catch him in a moment of weakness like this.
Again, a door separated us and I remained silent.
"Who is that?" Lyra asked. "Your father?"
I nodded, but she didn't see it in the darkness. She took my silence as confirmation.
I couldn't see how either of them responded. So I decided to react. I pounded my fists on the metal trap door.
"Stop it! We're better off dead. In everyone's minds, at least," Lyra said. Sylvia sat there in the corner, still too angry and overcome with emotion to react.

"We'll be trapped if we do nothing," I told her. "Do you want to suffocate or do you want to live?" I heard him shuffle, getting closer to the ground, taking in the old footprint of the destroyed house. I noticed the moment he remembered the bootlegger's cellar. The motion surprised me, coming from a man of little action, often too depressed to drag himself to his son's graduation, or to meet his son for dinner on-time when he tries to plan for them to go out.

But I saw a whole different side of him return in that moment of sudden hope, outweighing the darkness of his desperation. His hands dragged at the rubble until they drew blood, frantically scraping until he reached the metal. All he could muster was just a sliver of the hatch to open, jamming some wreckage for a crack to aerate the lightless space, to listen again for that weak voice he thought he heard.
He listened, afraid if he spoke my name that he'd jinx the fortune he prayed for, that it was all another delusion of a dilapidated old man.
But my voice called to him.
"Dad," I said. I wanted to believe that he earned that title.
"Son. Son, you're really there," Clint said.
"Don't let us out yet. You have to wait. Wait until nobody else is here. This was no accident," I said, coughing on a mouthful of words with a dry throat.
"What? What do you mean by that?"
"Just trust me. Please," I tell him. "Trust no one. Not even the people combing the scene. Let nobody know we're under here. We have to be dead to them."
He had to believe me. It didn't matter that he understood nothing. "Okay. Okay, son," he said, rising from the ashen ground.

Clint found a sheet of singed carpet to cover the hatch, leaving minute space for the outside air to cycle. And after his footsteps faded away, the minutes dragged on to hours again, and we felt the day pass us in blind oblivion.
The darktime arrived with flurries of winter. Few snowflakes siphoned through the crack: I could count on the strained fingers of my bad hand the number I saw through the faintest sliver of light.

Lyra leaned against me. We huddled for warmth: there were no blankets or straw or sacks to shield ourselves from the bitter cold. Just the sweaty warmth we saved through hours of breathing each other's air, slowly wasting away as the heat always loses to the cold.

But Sylvia shivered there in the corner, the names of our dead friends frozen to her blue lips, and the more I watched her suffer with that harrowing truth, the more I sold myself to that promise I wagered with the value of my life.

And so we shiver here now. All I can think of are all the expenses I've incurred, indebted to the guilt of this cursed blessing, and the more I yearn to reach out and embrace her, to warm her with that irrational light that comes from nowhere, the more the voice tells me I don't deserve to relish in those acts of peace.

That fear of death has left me for now. It's not the sin itself that fills me with bitter dread, but the parts of me that broke to get here. A river slices rock by a billion narrow cuts. And so the dimensions of my soul shear their edges on the endless cycle of living and dying.
I always believed I was born to be a sacrifice: too broken to thrive, but just strong enough to gust winds into the sails of others. And so maybe that self-fulfilling prophecy has come home.
There's a part of me that so deeply wishes I could be proven wrong. But life and the laws of nature don't care about emotion.

So in that moment, six feet deep beneath the surface of the earth in a communal coffin, I found my rebirth in letting go. A part of me died the moment I made that deliberate decision — to let Romin and Valentina march to their deaths alone, without remorse or any tears left to cry — and I will bury that piece here when the hatch opens.
No longer will the atrophy of grief and sorrow withhold me from my eternal duty.
After so much time in darkness, it feels as if this body is no longer my own, that the whole world is just a dream.

The ceiling of Clint's shop is covered with a cheap tarp. It does nothing to keep the cold out. This building was once a house, like many others on the commercial block of Blackwater. Clint stokes the fire, separated from his busywork in the office, but not missing it.

Sylvia spoke her first words when we left. The only time before that she interacted with me was to close her eyes and grab the tail of my overcoat when we walked through the smoldering wreckage, still glowing with hot embers, refusing to see the bodies.
Now she sits beside the fire with Clint: their shadows cast on the shelves of timeless tools and trinkets, making them look as if they're alive.
"I can keep you safe here," Clint insists. "I already lost a daughter. I only got you back just to lose you again, but for what? What's out there?"
"More than charges for a crime we didn't commit," I say. "They want us dead for being in the wrong place at the wrong time."
Clint says, "You'll be in danger out there. This ain't just a Snowdrifter run, you can't just throw away your life like that!"

Pot meet kettle. You sure know about throwing your life away, I almost say, but I don't want to argue. The image is still fresh in my mind: my father bleeding out in the same room we came together as a family.
"I forbid you from leaving, Titus, do you hear me? You already lost my daughter, and I'm not letting you lose yourself to your grave delusions!"

It takes all my restraint not to hit him in front of Lyra and Sylvia. All the hate I've built against him rises to the surface. It's the feel of a natural habit, like his smoking, edging me closer to the endless cycle of conflict where nobody wins and nobody listens.

In the absence of words, Clint continues. "It's been a matter of days and you've changed so much. You used to be open about things. I mean, you're still shit at asking for help, but you won't tell me at all what you're going through. You haven't even told me what happened in the house," he adds.
"You aren't exactly the best at opening up either," I say. "I wasn't trying to lose her."
"I didn't say that, you bastard," Clint says. Lyra and Sylvia cringe at the last word. "So don't put words in my mouth."

Regardless of how badly I want to tell him off, to raise the room a couple degrees with all the spiteful phrases I've rehearsed after our arguments, I still hold to the image of him fighting alongside me when I tried to give myself to Endogeny. I can feel the depth of the regret he feels, and I'm sure every day it feels like he digs himself deeper and deeper.

My composure is strange to him, and the awkward silence drags to the point it feels like three against one. I spent so much of my time with him in anger that I never noticed the way his wrinkles crease on frown lines, worn to sorrow like aged leather. My anger dissolves and all I feel is bad for him.

"Keep your coat on. Let's go outside for a moment, Titus," he says, turning to the other two. "Sorry, ladies. I need to talk to my son in private." Clint gestures out the back. From the way he tensions his fists, I can tell we're going to fight again. But this isn't like ten years ago when he had the advantage of strength. I'm bigger, stronger, and faster than him, so I harden myself to take his blows.
"Here," he says, gesturing towards a weathered bench in the backyard. "Siddown."

I wipe off a faint layer of dirty, ashen snow for us to sit. He draws a cigarette from his pocket, flicking the lighter several times before the smoke blends with his clouds of breath, and after he's satisfied, he starts.
"You're just as stubborn a son of a bitch as I am," Clint says.
I open my mouth to respond, but he catches me first.

"This will work better if you just listen, son," he says, as if the feeling behind his words will evaporate if he fails to get them out. "Look — I know I can't change your mind. You nearly raised yourself. And Ellie, too, I'll admit . . . so I recognize I have little power over that compass inside you."
He sits close to me. The smells of smoke and damp pine bark bring me straight back to my childhood: he started smoking again shortly after my mother died. He quit shortly after I was adopted.

"I hate how much of myself I see inside you," he says. "Every parent wants their child to be better than them. You graduated at the top of your class. Your combat scores are nearly unmatched. Believe me, son, I've watched, even if it never felt like it. I'm proud of you. But the more you grind yourself down, the more I see the way that you, well . . ."
"What do you mean?" I ask.

He takes a long breath. "Ever since your mother died, ever since that night, it seems like me — or the world — tore something out of you." He pauses for effect as I cross my legs. "And it's like you never filled it with something real." He digs deep into a part of me I'm uncomfortable with, but this time it isn't insults or allegations. "I can tell because I have it, too. And I think I passed it on to you, as much as I tried to be better than my father was."
"But we're different," I try to say.

"You really think? I see this shop as the only relic of my past that remains the way she left it," he says, "and I hold on to this. You hold on to work, combat training, school, and Ellie, and I understand why, but your friends? Your youth? Those are all so important. I didn't have that, I never did, because I had to grow up fast. But look at you — young and handsome like I was. You shouldn't have those limitations."
"I take care of Ellie because you say you can't," I say.
"But if you dig deep, you know neither of us can . . . or could, Gods . . . give her the love she deserved."

I sit with the silence that follows. I won't deny his words. I don't want to admit it out loud, but he's right: I chalked all of Ellie's frustrations up to adolescent drama without ever really listening to her.
"What I'm trying to say here is: I don't want you to make the same mistake I did, to carry that same weakness my own father left in me."
He takes a long pause, failing to find a way to summarize the scars of his past in a handful of words.
"It was awful," Clint says.
He bites his lip.
"Go on," I say.
"Your grandfather, Everett," Clint starts. "He was a weak man. Something in his past still hurt him, and he never quite got it out."
I lean forward, mesmerized by his words. I've never heard him even try to talk this much about his past.
"I didn't want to tell you since he was your only grandparent, and that connection is important, with how small our family is, you know."
I nod for him to continue, looking down, afraid that if we meet eyes he'll stop talking.

"Your grandmother died at a young age, much like what happened with Moira. And that's why it hurts so much this time. But I remember my early life in Blackwater, living in a house that wasn't even close to the size we had, far on the outskirts, close to the Snowdrifter holes. He'd disappear for days, sometimes. And when I came home from Seminary, he'd just be lying there on the couch, passed out."
"Asleep?" I asked.
"No. Black-out drunk. And I spent so much of my life just sitting there in that empty house, just staring."
"At what?"
"At his breath. His chest, up and down, up and down, just watching."
"To make sure he was alive," I guess.

"Right, and . . . some nights I'd curl up next to him: thirsty and starving. I'd lift his arm and put it around me, and Gods, Titus, his body was so fridging cold," Clint says. "And all I could think was how I never wanted to bring some bastard child into the world, to suffer the same way. But then Everett found you at the orphanage. He insisted we raise you, that there was something special, and then Moira saw that same light when she worked at the orphanage."
"What do you mean by that? Everett found me?"

"He brought you to the Orphanage, but he never said from where, just that he had a 'debt to pay.' Moira and Everett are the only reason you're here with me. But you, son — you proved me wrong that I didn't want a child. You're the reason that Ellie is here. Or was . . . " He takes another draw of his cigarette, adjusting his position on the bench.
