"Gods be damned. Just don't end up an old bastard like me, so full of hate, pain, and regret, and — Titus, why are you crying?"
The tears pour out of me. All those cycles wore down the barrier he created for me. "No, continue," I insist.

"Well, it takes almost losing two of yous before an old stubborn pecker like me can get the words out." He laughs before it turns into a smoker's cough. "I know I'm not going to change your mind. I know there's a part deep inside of you that hates me for what I've done — or rather, failed to do for you as a father. But if it's not me you talk to about these things, then I urge you to talk to someone. If there's one thing you remember, it's this: be better than I was, son."
"I don't hate you," I tell him."I just pity how Mom's death hurt you. I'm . . . saddened by how much it still impacts how you live."

Clint rubs under his chin before closing the cigarette pack. "Yeah," he says. "And another thing. I know you haven't forgotten what . . . what I did to you, that terrible night that your mother disappeared. But I'll be damned if I don't speak on it. I want to tell you I'm sorry, son, for how I hurt you. Physically, emotionally."

"Thank you," I say. They're tough words for him to muster, only drawn out by how temporal this last moment of ours is. Emotion is a muscle to train, and we're both weak and emaciated in those respects: it feels as if we've finished a tough workout. There's so much more to unpack between the two of us. But we both understand we're out of time.

Clint stands up. He trades clouds of smoke for clouds of breath as he stretches his sore back, and I stand alongside him. I can tell how badly he doesn't want me to leave, but it's not up to him. I'm doing this to save all of them. I'll have to hold myself to this purpose even if it destroys me, because if I fail, I will have nothing to live for.
He reaches out his hand as if we're making a business deal. But the feel of something smooth, cold, and slender surprises me between our palms.
"If I can't convince you to stay, then I want her to protect you," Clint says. "You'll need her presence more than I will."
"Thanks, Dad," I tell him.

I take the necklace pendant from my mother in my fingers. She never took it off: not even when she joined my father for bed. If Moira were watching, she'd laugh at how dislocated we are from emotion: without her bringing us together, maybe this is the first time we've ever tried.
So the two Berguard men shake hands, unable to conjure any further words, and just like always, unable to persuade the other to change their mind.

Clint's last gift is free pickings over the shop for whatever we need. It's all the things I've found over the years, anyway. He remains outside, unable to usher himself in, weeding through a full pack of his favorite cigarettes and warming his hands over a barrel of fire, waiting for us to leave.

I gather my Snowdrifter gear minus the sled while Sylvia takes one of my mother's old jackets. My fingers fondle the smooth surface of the pendant Clint gave me. Lyra returns after gathering gear she stored away somewhere; she left while Clint and I were talking.
"So your father's not coming?" Lyra asks.
"He wishes to stay here. It's better to leave him out of this, anyways," I say.
"Gods know what the Royal Guard will do with the Amulet. We have to relay this information now. The Elders can't ignore this. We're all going to return for one last fight!"

I'm surprised when I find excitement on her face. But I know exactly what happens. I'm cursed with the knowledge of everything. I have a power that might make me even stronger than the Gods, but in no way do I equate myself above them. I'm not like Ullrich and the prideful Afterlives.

"There's a major battle coming," Lyra insists, and her senses are right. Beyond the walls of the house, the infighting between the Merlot and Carmine has already begun, with or without Romin and Valentina, weakening the fabric of Blackwater for the perfect attack. "Follow me back to the First Red, and you'll be entering a hard life of conflict against the forces of pure evil. But as Academy cadets on the cusp of graduation, we all know you've steeled yourself for that life."
That path is my only means to an end.
"I'll go," I say, before I turn to Sylvia. "We will go."
"Alright, then," Lyra says. "Our Chymaeran contacts planned the quickest return home possible."
"It'll take at least three days. We don't even have enough provisions."
"Not when you travel by train," she says.
"A train?" Sylvia asks. "But it isn't our time yet. Why would they run trains?"
"This train isn't for that waste of life and effort they call service. It's for something different. It's for the service of the lower ranks, the ones they deem useless," she says.
I remember no talks of transit in my first cycle. "Where would it go? What is out there?" I ask.

"It's a far bigger world than either of you can ever imagine. It is filled with horrors far beyond anything your narrow perception of life grants you here," Lyra says. "Do you ever ask yourself why so few people starve, where the endless supply of produce comes from, and where—"
Her words halt in an instant, suddenly attuned to something we can't sense.
"What is it?" Sylvia asks.
"They're here."
"Who's here?" I ask.
"You have to promise not to be too upset. It was the perfect identity for them to keep the continuity," Lyra says.
She turns to the heavy front doors, bolted shut with a temporary hinge Clint installed after the night they were bashed open.
"Steel yourself," she tells us.
I squint my eyes to accomodate the familiar silhouettes when they enter.
I can't believe what I see. It is all so impossible: they take the form of the two childhood friends I've loved as if I never lost them.
I feel my heart skip for a second before I remember Lyra's words, and I know Sylvia reacts the same way.
A different Valentina and Romin stand at the door. Their mannerisms are convincing. Only I can tell they're slightly off.
"These are the Chymaerans that will take us," Lyra says. "They hold to the true spirit of Blackwater, long before royalty bastardized its nature."

The Romin looks on with amethyst eyes, speaking with a voice that I remember. "I'm sorry. The bodies of your friends are unidentifiable. With this form, it will be to Blackwater as if they never left."
Valentina's clone opens her mouth, and her voice is just as convincing. "Now is our window. We need to leave," she says.

I take Sylvia's hand. She tensions her fingers in mine, standing tall for the first time since I can remember, rising to that half-inch-or-so she has over me, holding my hand gently as she looks on towards the world outside. That same feeling of love comes back to me again and I allow it to flow over me, putting off the truth that whatever actions await us are meaningless and temporal if they're to be overwritten.
But I relish in it for now: I allow it to recharge my weathered soul. I'll tell her about this curse, whether she believes me or not. Even though she'll lose her memory of it when time resets.
Gods know how long peace will take, but I want to believe in the waning strength I have to continue, between my soul and the Chymaeran Curse that has stretched so far in little time.
I lead her by the hand.

For decades, the vacant shipping depot rested at the edge of the Twelfth District's outer walls:  a relic of an ancient time I passed on many Snowdrifter trips. Most don't know what the decrepit building is used for. All they've seen is that it rotted for decades, rusted from endless snowstorms blasted at the ungalvanized metal, surprised that it still sees the arrival and departure of trains at all. Enough that it became a myth, living in the dreams and speculations of everyone who has borne witness.

When we arrived hours earlier, it was flooded with activity, swarmed with Royal Guard and Merlot preparing the train cars. The two separatist Chymaerans morphed from familiar faces to random railworkers. In their hands were a keyring of blackened bone charms from their pockets, and with a surge of amethyst energy, they drew from the bone marrow with Essence, capturing their guise and gestures with near flawless accuracy. Their speech was convincing, carrying the slang and tone of the impoverished outwallers, the same style I recognized in my father.
"Us skinwalkers are mixed bloods, 'round half'a human, half'a Chyme," the blonde-haired Chymaeran said, guising as a Carmine coal miner that died in a gruesome accident four years ago.

The second Chymaeran had a great slash across their face: dark hair and piercing blue eyes. The original victim was stabbed coming home from work and died alone on the street. Though the true body is six feet under somewhere with a missing bone, it looks as if that soul hadn't missed a day of life.

Both recalled their hosts' memories of Blackwater industry, and the clothes they conjured were an extension of their bodies' Essence. The materials were astounding, so close to the true textures only touch could differentiate them. The fabrics folded like true cloth, but to the touch, every part of their disguise felt like frigid iron.

"Put 'ese on," the blonde Chymaeran said. Industry clothes, fashioned from the power of Chymaeran and Human Essence masterfully intertwined together. The scarred Chymaeran recalled their hosts' memories of childhood playing on the tracks, long enough ago that trains still ran through the station. Although a large steel-barred fence deterred scavengers and vagrants, the scarred recalled a small space dug beneath the bottom, where ages ago their guise snuck through.

The land just beyond the station was decrepit and undeveloped. Containers rotted to rust from snow and ice, and so much trash and waste sullied the dirt with rancid odors. The train station at the center was the only stone monolith to defy the slagyards, although its age showed in dusty shattered glass and worn engravings on the walls.
The Chymaerans' clothes dissolved to amorphous black, and in less than a blink they metastasized again as the fine robes of the Royal Guard.

The one that guised Romin instructed us to play along, with their tongue changed to high speech. They had a cleaner face and a refined look, despite the consistent, straggling scar slicing straight down their face.
The blonde Chymaeran turned to us. "You're a maintenance crew, performing inspection on the coupling between coffin car 46 and 47."

No one asks that many questions if you're carrying tools somewhere. I picked up a long rusted crescent wrench from atop an iron barrel to further my disguise, and our bags only added to the persuasion. We circled the perimeter of the building for the side entrance. Several technicians sat on petrified stumps just beyond the heavy-duty side door, warming their hands over a barrel. A single Royal Guard observed them.
He turned to us. "Finally, about time those bloody-damn railmen showed up," he said.
"They 'ad us prepping these cars for weeks, and you cunts show at the last minute," one railmen complains. "Still got two carts needin' a lathe, so get on it, fresh blood!"
"Lathe?" Sylvia asks. I know what it is from my time in the machine shop, but the scarred answers her first, in a hushed whisper.
"Wheel lathe, he says. Profiles the wheels before departure. Keep them round."
"But I don't know how to use it," Sylvia says.
"I got some'in you can use!" One says.
"An'ya got a bitch workin' lines?" They say, when Sylvia appears from behind me. "Fine, too.  Nice knockers — guess whorin' these days is so bad you gotta do a man's work."
"Why don't ya polish my shaft," another says.

"That's enough from you. Get back to work, shitbloods," the lone Royal Guard said. They grumbled, back to their drivel about sex and drinking. "And you two," he said, pointing to the guised Chymaerans, "what are your plans with those shitbloods?"
I spoke up. "We're maintenance crew for the—"

The Royal Guard struck me across the face without a moment's hesitation. He didn't even bother to meet my eyes, turning to the Chymaerans. "One more word and that worker is leaving its crew in a body bag," he said. "Now what are they here for?"

The scarred regurgitated my lines. "Maintenance on the couplings. Cycled strain between the forty-seven and forty-eight couplings are long overdue. Age and impulse loads stretch far beyond infinite yield."

"Enough big words. Royal Guard shouldn't partake in that feculent tongue. Do what you have to," he said, and we passed through the door, eyes down, sure to make no contact with any of the Royal Guard.
"It." Gods, I'd almost forgotten how much irrational hatred the upper scumbags have for our people. Lyra tensioned her fists, the same thought on her mind.
The blonde Chymaeran tugged my shirt. "It's best if I do the talking here," he said, and I nodded in response.
On the platform of the stabling area, where the ready trains awaited departure, the scarred approached a group of higher-level Royal Guards. He recalled the thoughts of his precious guise.
"These shitbloods are doing maintenance on the couplings. We only have time for loaded carriages since they'll take the most force. Do you know which have pre-loaded?"

One of them pointed to three cars, painted with a green dash I could only imagine meant READY FOR DEPARTURE. As they asked the Chymaerans about the logistics of the maintenance job, I listened in to the other guards discussing the details of their next move.

"Prepare the carriages for fuel. Purgatory is on the way," an intercom buzzed. Few lower tradesmen remained in the belly of the depot. Colors of jade and vermilion swarmed the spaces between the tracks like a muddle of ants carrying leaves and fruit. Purgatory? As in a place? A weapon?
"Prepare for departure. Loading will begin in one hour," the announcement spoke.

"We need to get us in the storage cars," the blonde Chymaeran said, but my mind was wrapped in the mystery of my surroundings. So many storage cars: empty, without seats or soft flooring. It couldn't be for liquid fuel. Maybe lumber? No, that wouldn't make sense — all the trees are outside these walls. That'd be like exporting water to a lake.

With an hour until departure, at a moment when the guards' eyes no longer watched our hands pretending to tinker with the machinery, we dipped into the second loaded car, throwing the heavy door aside just far enough to squeeze through. Despite the climate of our lands, the carriage was hot and stuffy, but we didn't dare open the doors again to vent. We suffered through this for hours in the bootlegger hatch, and it didn't trouble us to tough it out for a little longer.

Our Chymaerans locked the latches from the inside. Commanding shouts and screeching cars shook the floor of Carriage Forty-Eight. And as soon as the darkness concealed them, my eyes could no longer discern the shape of the Chymaerans. Just a darkness blacker than black, as if their bodies starved the space of every ribbon of light.

Our disguises dissolved faster than a fake smile without a witness, leaving us in our travel clothes. We wouldn't need our coats until rushing polar winds could breach the splintered slats, so we sat in silence for that hour, trying to discern the voices of a large crowd ushered towards the cars. What lucky bastards we were when we realized what we missed.

"I never knew there was this much sky out there," says Sylvia, captivated by the sights unfolding like pages from my grandfather's old storybooks. The light lasts just long enough to bless the world with one last flood of color, spilling all the paints across the sky before sepia swallows the world.

In my mind's eye I remember the first Snowdrifter trips with my grandfather, when I began building my stamina for long treks. He told me to absorb the sights and serenity of life unfolding around me. Listen for the static, can you hear it? He would ask, and I'd listen and listen, waiting for a sound to ring in my ears. I'd get frustrated after a time. I can't hear it, I'd say. He'd laugh and keep asking over and over, every half an hour, until it became the only thought that filled my mind.

Years later, I considered it was a genius way of getting me to shut up and stop asking if we were there yet. But as age dragged me closer to the edge of graduation, phase after phase until I now realize the true shortness of time, I've found what he really meant. The demands of my abruptly-shortened childhood threaten to swallow me alive. I find gray hairs in my beard. I lose weight from malnutrition. And responsibilities have become so severe that the pit in my stomach is a feature, not a sickness.

The older I get, the more I realize that static is just the absence; everything that isn't. It was the space between the trees when the snow crunched under my small feet. It was the drawn silence between question and answer before Everett would laugh and ask it again. And now it's the pause between rhythmic jolts of the chassis as the steel screeches against the rails, casting sparks beneath the floor.

I can detach my emotions the more I convince myself that this life is temporal. A breadth of time separates me from my loved ones only by a trail of Essence. I can feel the texture of every memory as if it still breathes, like a cherished friend waiting for me to return. And when I look at Lyra and Sylvia, I try harder and harder to separate myself from becoming attached to these afterimages of a failure that will soon be rewritten. These people are temporal too . . . I have to convince myself, I have to believe that.
"What are you thinking about?" Sylvia asks.
"Just some words from my father," I say. She rests her head against my shoulder. I let it happen, but I turn away.
"What did he tell you?" She asks.
"Words he should have said a decade ago," I say. "But welcome words — it's not too late."
"I'm glad you had that chance. You were so different," she says.
"What do you mean?"
"You're so kind and patient around your friends, but around your father, you're usually angry and short." She pauses. "In temper, not—"
"Of course," I say.

"But you were patient with him this time. I can't remember the last time I ever saw you like that."The last fight with him replays in my mind: the sincerity of his regret and the emptiness I found in his heart.
"It's just the finality of everything. Funny how it drags the words out of us, the ones we'd never say before, huh?"
My spirit longs to open up and tell her everything, but I'm so afraid that if I break apart now, I won't have the strength to sacrifice for all the ones who didn't make it: the ones I owe my life to.
"You know, sometimes I just wish I wasn't so weak," she says.
"No—" My face scrunches when I disagree. "You're not. You and I have been down a terrible, grueling path in each of our lives, yet we've both made it this far."

"Because of how needy I am. It feels like I'm always behind you, tugging at your cloak for you to lead me on, ever since the orphanage. And I feel awful for always being your . . . burden," she says. That last word parts from her lips like a curse. "And it makes me so sorry for that."
"You are never a burden," I insist, "because we depend on each other. Don't you ever think that!"
"I—I'm sorry," she says, burying her head in my arm before I notice my moment of passion was misread. But—before I can remind her to stop apologizing for things that aren't her fault, she continues.
"You'd tell me that insistence I had earlier to stay by your side was courage," Sylvia says. "Telling you I was in it no matter what. It sounded brave when I said it."
"It was brave," I say.

"But really — I was so afraid of a world without you that I couldn't bear to be alone again. The voices, Titus! All the voices of my past have lost their distinction, as those playground kids or abusive adults or . . . the others . . . I wish I could forget. The further time takes me from them and their jeers of how pathetic I am, the more that voice becomes my own. And the more I hear myself, the harder it is to hear anything else."
"What's strength to you, then? Brawn like Romin? Charisma like Valentina?"
"Resilience like you," she says. "Strong enough to carry the weight of the world. Honed and one-pointed enough to let the pain pass through you. Direction. Conviction."

And maybe that's the image that burned in her mind for the months I was asleep in the Afterlife. That's what she almost became. And maybe at the end of it she understood just like I do that the pain never passes through. It's an act of atrophy, constantly adding wax and sculpting a candle that burns from both ends. And maybe I've become convincing enough to hide it.

"And that's exactly why I find myself weak," I say. Because I fail to find the strength or words to tell her how I feel. Even now. I didn't lie when I told Romin I was always running from that feeling that drags behind me like my own shadow. And the image of my father's weakness shows me, again, that freedom I'm so afraid of.

"Sometimes it feels like you're the last light that survived from those times of innocence. You've always protected me. I just wish I could do more," Sylvia says, as she snuggles up to my arm, completely unaware of the comfort and fullness she's brought to me—though I've always fumbled on the words to tell her.
Maybe I can do it this time.
"You do enough," I mutter.
"Huh?" She says. Her beautiful crimson eyes meet mine, and for a moment, my voice wavers.
"You always do enough. Because . . . you're the reason I've made it this far, too."

"Titus," she says. My name is so sweet from her lips, and then I feel it: how something so softly opens inside me, before I can recapture it; how I spent all those years pounding at the door when all I needed was patience and clemency.
I can feel my face so magnetically drawn to hers, and I realize I've always felt it, that feeling, and the last thought I manage is to contemplate the softness of her lips.
Then the train lurches to a halt.
We don't.
The wheels no longer mask the sound of shouts and screams beyond the car. It's only then that we realize what the "fuel" is, faster than our bodies slam against the hay bales along the front wall.

I hear the voices of cadets, no older than I am, crying out into the night. Fists pound on the walls and doors of the train like lumberjacks chopping a full forest, and moments later, from the shear force of a hundred bodies pressing against the wooden panels, the walls snap, relieving several cars of imprisoned cadets like barrels of wine struck with an axe.
"Now! Run for the tree line," a weak voice calls. I can see them now: cadets of the lowest class in the Academy.

The highest class, Dragon Class, is sent beyond the walls to fight at the highest ranks, or to defend the Afterlife from unrest. The middle, Garnet Class, often ends up guarding the outer city. I always wondered what became of the lowest cadets who weren't called to the highest honors.

Their resistance is futile. The Chymaeran Royal Guards dissolve to sickly caricatures of obsidian, their limbs sharper than the branches of the leafless trees. With so much time spent in darkness my eyes cannot afford me any color, but I can see the snow runs dark, and I know on the other side of the snow banks lie the lower cadets who were foolish enough to try to escape first.
"Do we run for it? What do we do?" Sylvia asks. The panic flashes in her eyes, but Lyra remains calm, turning to the Chymaerans with a trail of blood running from her forehead.
"They'll think we're escapees that are hiding out in a storage car," Lyra says. "We can't walk from here. Not at night, and not in the cold when we have so far still to go."

A voice thunders from the front of the train. Each syllable trembles in the floorboards, shaking loose fasteners like chattering teeth. "There'a nowhere to run. Stay inside the train or else you will freeze and die."

Escape is futile without the directional sense that leads you home — or a map like the one my grandfather left me of the lands beyond the wall. No wonder they outlawed that magnetic tool Everett had that points towards the city, saying it's an "item that dishonors the unified spirit of Blackwater."

Lyra turns to the Chymaerans. "Play this off if they ever come by." They emerge from the corner, creatures of darkness whose bodies seem to soak all the light. But my eyes have adjusted and I see them now: hard-shelled flesh like steel armor, a triangle of three glowing, amethyst dots on their heads I can only interpret as eyes.

A vibration shudders from deep within their throat, as if their vocal cords were feathered by the fronds of a comb instead of a violin's bow. The sound takes shape until it morphs into human speech, and I realize the sheer range of mastery these half-blood Chymaerans have with guising.
And just like them, I've changed in an instant, too: furious now with my waning patience for how many distractions tear me from any moment of peace.
I poke my head out of the car, just enough to take in a flash of information.
"How did they get to the emergency stop?" a half-blood guard says, still in human form.
"They didn't," another says. "We found a metal rod jammed in the wheels from part of the trolley frame."
Three cabins down, the car has its door thrown open. "Run and you'll go nowhere, shitbloods! I don't have to kill you now to know you'll die out there," he says.
"Damn you! All we have to do is take this train over," a cadet says.
"Make it an example," a Guard demands.

My curiosity draws me beyond the edge of the doorframe again. The Cadet is lifted into the air, his flesh surging bright amethyst. And it's only after I notice the height his feet hang from the ground that I see how massive this Chymaeran is.

"The convenient thing about fuel like this is that it's all out of Essence. So those small diseases of the past," the Guard continues, watching the Chymaeran brute choke out the rebel as his flesh grows pale, "are enough to turn a cough to cancer."
The dark, glowing amethyst trail reaches the cadet's heart from his neck. In a matter of moments his body dissolves to blackened ash. His raw Essence is absorbed into the circuits of his abuser.

It's then that all the cadets' restraint dissolves, leaving nothing but the hatred and primal fury of fighters that were bred to die. It takes so little effort for the lone Chymaeran brute to eviscerate everything that breathes in the train car, and although I don't see the bloodbath, I can hear the sound of slender limbs slicing flesh; the drumming beat of cadets as their bodies fall, reduced to dust, filling this creature with the soul and fleeting strength of the dead.

My anger builds further, as if their last stand has spread the contagion of furious spite. I can't care for death when I know time will reset me, even if it's to this exact moment that rage primes my muscles.

The guards now approach us. I know the sacrifice I have to make, and I know I have to stop them. I won't die a martyr like Romin if I can't die: all I want is to release the vitriol that poisons my heart.
My hands tension around the shaft of a fire axe left on the ground of the train car. My mind is set. But a hand tugs on the back of my coat when I step off the platform.
"What are you doing, Titus?" Sylvia asks. "Don't just throw your life away!"

But I won't just throw it away. I can't. Not now and not ever again. I won't need warmth for the short struggle that comes next: my body burns hot with adrenaline and excitement, as if that edge of life and death is an addictive drug that I've relapsed on.
I shed the coat."You can't throw away eternal life," I say. I tried to explain it to her, to all of them, though I know she will never understand.

My hands tension further until my knuckles turn whiter than the snow, frosted skin redder than the blood of those cadets that didn't turn to ash quick enough. The Vassal skips a train car to approach, thinking me another stupid cadet that wants to die. But all I want is to leverage that unfillable, longing emptiness through my fists.
And that fury must be genetic.

The tears I shed over and over a day ago refill my eyes, trembling my voice as I cry out. And although the Chymaeran Curse scalds my flesh with violent heat, surging stronger in my veins as they approach, I know this will be a short conflict.

It's too late to turn back when the Vassal charges, still famished for Life Essence to feed, the very image of Lionshead's wickedness incarnated before me, preparing for that day atop the mountain when all of Blackwater's life Essence will flood them with the power of two races.

I scream my treasured sister's name as a battle cry, unbundling with it the curses and vitriol of helpless anger as a useless brother and worse friend. I swing first with all my might, channeling all the strength I can into the head of the axe, although the muscles in my right arm are strained from amethyst pain. I don't care that the dark roots have already crawled my arm and up my shoulder.
All I care is that this ends.

It's like swinging at a rigid metal bar when it shields itself with its arms. The clang of that strike vibrates through my hands, echoing through the forest, and I hear the cheers of cadets in a lower train car, shouting my name, as they saw me moments earlier at Graduation.

Despite a story of height, the Vassal looks genuinely scared, but that doesn't stop it from dealing eviscerating blows. Drawn back by the momentum of the large axe, I stagger backwards, taking the wooden shaft in both my hands to block.
It makes sounds as if trying to speak, surely insulting me and my pettiness.

I dive to the side when the serrated edge slashes down on me. Dirt and snow erupt from the ground like lakewater splashing from a falling boulder. My vision is consumed by powder, but I charge forward anyways, channeling all that fury into another swing at nothing.

I'm lucky when it connects. The great Chymaeran is furious now, as if it wasn't before, but it still refuses to use all its strength. Probably to put on a show of little effort for its handlers, I think, before its first connecting swing shatters the butt of the axe, nearly whacking me off my feet.
Lyra holds back Sylvia, insisting that I'm "already lost and beyond saving." I can feel the crack propagate when I strike again: the wooden shaft has hardly any metal left to hold on to.
My strike deals just as much damage as it did before. Absolutely nothing. Maybe a scratch, more just an annoyance, but my mission isn't to win.

The attack I've waited for comes after my hands strain from all hard metal contact. I reach, weakly, to block with the wooden throat of the axe, but the force behind the Chymaeran's blade shatters it like a toothpick.

I'm surprised, but not by its raw power. With such force, its downward strike never even reaches the ground. I look down at my chest: a large crimson line traces from my left shoulder to my right hip. I grasp my chest, expecting my insides to spill, but I'm surprised when the wound is only skin deep. My father always taught me to swing through your target, not just to make contact, and with all the bisected torsos of cadets in the train car I can see now, it's undeniable.
The Vassal is pulling punches.

My fight is over as soon as I fall to my back, and the great obsidian beast stands over me. I don't have the stamina to flinch when one of the sharp edges of its arms stabs into the shoulder of my bad arm, pinning me against the ground.

I expect it could dice me to shreds like all those other cadets, but all I can see is the pain of this creature. It trembles with an unsettling fear for something so large, as if it tries to speak again.

I can't move. All I can feel is the amethyst probing further into my blood. The pain subsides as my nerves no longer feel the cold of the wasteland. My arms and legs no longer hinge. My muscles refuse to budge as my breaths grow shallower, and I realize the vassal has granted me a merciful death.

I have taken in my surroundings: where the Royal Guards are and where they wait. Now that I know the purpose of this train, we will escape long before it halts, that is — if the thread can take me back far enough.
"I . . . hunger," it manages, and I don't make the words out until it leaves.
I can feel my strength wane as I lay in the snow. The Royal Guard return to their carriages as the Chymaerans, Lyra, and Sylvia rush to recover me in the last minute.

It takes several seconds before I can lift myself from the hay bales in the corner of the train car. The rhythm of the carriage returns beneath me, and when the pain of the slash across my chest comes back, I contemplate how unlucky I am to be alive.
"What were you thinking?" Sylvia asks.

"I just wanted to save you all," I said, but they don't seem to accept my version of the truth. I repeat it. "Someone had to do something. To protect all of you. I gave myself so you could live! So you can tell your people what you've learned." But Sylvia and Lyra aren't grateful.
"You weren't doing it to save us. I saw that look in your eyes," Lyra says.
"You were trying to kill yourself," Sylvia says. She tensions her fingers around my shirt, jolting me as I weakly sprawl against the hay bales. "Why, why would you do that?"

I could tell her it was the guilt from letting Romin and Valentina die, forcing them to be a sacrifice. But when Lyra saw my resolve in letting go, she knew I was resolute in my decision. They wouldn't understand. They can never understand. But I have to tell them something to get what I want, to get to that sacrifice I have to make, so that I can save everyone I love from being less than cattle to the Afterlife. If this life is so inconsequential, then why is it so hard?
Sylvia treads further on the subject I try so hard to avoid. "What did you mean when you said those words, that 'you can't throw away eternal life?'"
"I can return. Over and over and over. If I die, I can go back and change the outcome," I say. "So if I die in the process of protecting you, then it doesn't matter."
"Doesn't matter? All you're doing is just throwing yourself away," Sylvia says. "You're not a tool or a means to an end, you're a person!"

"I'm cursed with the knowledge of how everything will end. You can't even begin to understand what I carry with me when I'm responsible for everything!" I turn to Lyra. "You came to Blackwater to seek Fletcher after the column of light erupted in the sky. Ten years ago he died saving your life. I told you the trade building would be destroyed, and I wasn't lying, because I witnessed it the last time, and I did absolutely nothing because I was too afraid. And even the second time around, I still let all those innocent children die."
"Then why did you leave our friends to die without a moment of regret," Sylvia says, "flipping the hatch of the basement door and deciding for all of us if we would try to save them?"

"Because I did try," I tell her. "I lived the same ten minute period over and over, for days and days and days until it broke every part of me that still wanted to hope. How could I come up with something so crafty in so little time? Do you know how many things I tried?" My voice begins to waver but I don't care. "I held back Romin. I reached to drag Valentina. I ran out the door with them, only to be shot like a stray dog. I tried every combination of words that might ever convince them, but it was as if fate, not our friends, had polarized them on that decision. So I had to say goodbye to them. I had, and have, to be absolute in my decision—without hesitation—or else you and I will never get to see them again."

It doesn't matter whether they fully believe me. These people are just figments of a past that will soon be forgotten. All I care about is the Essence Lyra promised for joining the First Red beyond the walls, and I have to believe that is still an option.

I turn to Lyra. "I have no idea what they plan to do with the thousands of cadets they're sending beyond the walls. But I know that the great black tar of Endogeny is soon to liquidate the city of all Essence: every woman, child, and man whose generations of life were only lived to be culled like cattle. Three months from now, when Endogeny runs its full course, the Heiress of Purgatory will accept the blessing of the Gods, becoming the first cross-blood Chosen. And not a single life will be spared when all is covered in ash and lava."
All my choices have been played out, and the longer this cycle drags me, the further I stretch away from a chance of that idyllic future.
Sylvia looks at my bare arm and notices something is missing.
"It's gone," she says.
"What's gone?"
"The Chymaeran curse, it's gone!"

I look in disbelief. People always notice when pain arrives, but not when it subsides. My arm still holds the threaded slashes from all the cycles. But the scar from Ellie's room no longer saturates my flesh in a deep-purple trail.
All that remains is just the faint line where the flesh was severed.
"I've never seen a weakblood make a full recovery," Lyra says. "How can that be possible?"

I remember the Vassal's edge that stabbed me to the ground. I couldn't feel anything after the strike. All I remember was the creature's reluctance to leave, probably desiring to return for me later when I'm at full strength, when I could give it a fair fight.
"Anyways," Lyra says. "We're almost there."
"But where's the stop?" Sylvia asks.
"There is no stop," Lyra says.

By the time I raise my head, the train has already vanished into the blizzard, carrying the helpless cadets towards whatever horror awaits them. Lyra's dried Essence powder lines our gear: its warmth enough to last us for several hours. Just long enough to get within range, she says. The First Red will know we're here long before we ever find them.

The five of us tread on the virgin ice of an ancient snowstorm, our boots crunching snow sheets that were shaped by persistent winds long before our grandfathers' first breath. Lyra urges us to move faster. The snowfall inundates the space between us. The only sense we have to acknowledge each other's presence is inference, stuck in an endless white room, as if torn from existence and stranded in the space between realities.

My beard is crystallized with strands of ice, but my core is warm from the powdered dead Essence. It feels if I move any faster that my lungs will bleed. But's preferable to our fate if we don't find shelter from the storm.
My body is far beyond the walls, but I find that my mind and soul are snagged elsewhere, far up the current of this reality's stream.

This is all just a dream, I tell myself, and I have been telling myself for hours now, repeating the same mantra, never forgetting the ones I failed to save, the look on their faces before and after their souls departed for the Reservoir. This reality is not mine. I am the branch of a different tree grafted on to this one.
And when I have my chance, I will do whatever it takes to return to that true life.

I watch a shivering smudge enter my ivory headspace, walking shoulder-to-shoulder as we break the tree line of an expansive field. I expect it to be her, but I know she still hasn't fully forgiven me. Thick pine branches like eyelashes batter out a small fraction of the powder, just enough to make out her cherry-red nose beneath barricades of fabric.

"Even threatened by the end of Blackwater, I'm still not sure this will be enough to convince them." Lyra motions to the pack strapped behind her. "They find every reason to hide and wait, as if it's an act of valor."
I don't respond.
"What was Everett like to you?" She asks. Even in a rare moment of frosted peace, she still can't stand the silence.
"More of a father than Clint ever was," I say.

"The only thing my father and I have in common is how much we hate him," Lyra says. "After the Snowdrifters attacked our home, he refused to ever see Everett again. Everett fled to the city. Now we know he changed his last name over guilt, wishing to forget what he allowed to happen. And my father took me to the Afterlife, where as purebloods, we were welcomed with open arms."
"The Afterlife has anything you could want. How did you end up here?" I ask. "What could ever possibly make you want to leave that life?"

"Because of how my father began to change," she says. "Because I hadn't spent my whole life there. It wasn't normal to me. And all those desperate people I saw living on the edge of the walls, that day we made for the central peaks—the sick feeling of guilt never left me. Gods, I wonder how many of those purebloods have even seen the people whose necks they step on."
"What happened to Ullrich?" I ask.

"Ever since the day he left us in the care of our uncle and aunt to visit the Afterlife, his personality changed. It changed before his feet even reached the porch. It looked as if he aged a hundred years, though his flesh showed no new wrinkles. And these episodes. Maybe it was the grief, how much he held it inside, but he'd have these sudden panic attacks, prompted by nothing at all. And after every single one, his soul would age further, until one day it was as if he had nothing left."
She heaves for breath. Somewhere behind, Sylvia and the two Chymaerans trail us.
"And when did you leave?" I ask.

"I left at the age of seventeen,"she said. "Ullrich wasn't even looking after me anymore, so obsessed with his role as Grandmaster General that I'm sure he didn't even notice. It was so strange, though . . . you know that expression when you're reeling up to take a punch, when you harden your muscles and hold your breath? It's the only expression he wore for the last three months I was with him."
"He was afraid," I say.

"But of what? There's nothing out there. Most of the Chymaera around here are either allied to the First Red or living silently as refugees, taking the guise of the recently passed. That extremist image is more-so an invention of the Afterlife."

I check the tension of my own muscles, hardened much the same way, but not because of the cold. My back and neck haven't ached this bad since the hardest quarters of the Academy, and not even the trials of combat have strained them this far. An image haunts me just like Ullrich. She drags behind me in person and mind: the curtain call of failure, and I can feel entropy and fate draw us closer.
"How do you gain Essence?" I ask.
"Huh?" Lyra says.
"Essence. How can you get it? Is it only through taking another person's life?"

"Essence is in everything around us. It's in everything that is alive. Killing is the most efficient way: it's why our ancestors raged in wars against each other for power. But it can also be transferred — at nearly a hundredth of killing's efficiency," she says. "Why do you ask?"
I peek behind me. The snowstorm obscures her form.
"I need to get stronger."

"The First Red will make you strong. You don't need Essence to have strength," Lyra says. "It takes generations to build it. All we have now is generations of Essence built and taken by the lucky survivors of a long-past war."
"And that's it?"
"No. You can also cultivate it. We kill and consume plants and animals every day. You can take advantage of nature — putting it in the mulch and feed of plants and livestock — but it's a lot slower."
"There's just some people I need to be sure I can protect when I return," I say.
"You'll have the strength of all the Carmine and First Red when we go back," Lyra says. "We will have strength together, in our numbers."
"Sure," I tell her, though I know that strength of others will never be enough. I'm not going back with them. I'm returning alone, in my own way.
The blinding barrage of flakes begins to taper just as the dead Essence lining our clothes wears down.
"The storm is clearing," I tell her. "I've never seen the weather change this fast out here!"
"It's not nature that causes that," Lyra says. "The Afterlife would be a frostbitten wasteland if nature had its way. It means we're almost there."

She's right. Every hundred yards I feel my insulated clothes grow hotter, and after a while, the sheets of frost no longer crunch, reduced to slush. There's a clearing somewhere far past the trees, and with my eyes, I can  make out small strands of something sticking from the snowbanks.

The frost grows shallower, giving way to another change I had only ever seen riding the Academy gondola to get closer to the Afterlife. The strands are cereal grasses, dry and yellow like vagrants' teeth. Only half a day or so past that house Romin and I could barely reach, and the sight captivates me.
"Spoken-word stories tell us that this is what Blackwater looked like before the fall," Lyra says. She lifts her hands and falls to her knees, anticipating something neither Sylvia or I can see.

Their voices cry out, and I only begin to notice when I hear them. Their bodies refract the light with scales like polished, transparent glass. I blink them away at first as if they're just a smudge in my eye, but as they approach closer, I can see their footsteps: the only evidence ten of them leave behind.
We all drop to our knees, tossing our gear to the ground.
"State your business, or be executed where you stand," one calls out. "There is no return from here."
"They're with me," Lyra says.
"And what have you found?"
"We bring a message for the Elders: the message we've all been waiting for," she insists.

The villagers are restive when we pass, so accustomed to crimson cloaks and Carmine cloth that our tall-collared Academy jackets are inscrutable. Even as the highest-honored legends of Carmine lore, they cower like prey when their proxy is threatened, restlessly toeing the line between fight and flight.

They clear a path for us between the meager log buildings. Most still hold the tools of their trade, uprooted from their work by curiosity and commotion, the same expression of fright flushed across all of them, heating the ambient air more than the artificial climate ever could.
"I'll handle this," Lyra says.
I can tell we're close to whatever authority presides here from the way she slows down to collect her words. But the chieftains of the First Red approach first.
"What is the meaning of this, Lyra? Is this some kind of joke? A stunt?"
"It's none of those things," Lyra says. "Please, listen. They—"

"—Are going to be killed because of your insolence. Did you even think if they might be followed? Who are these people? You know the rules, Lyra. We don't keep twenty years of airtight silence by inviting strangers here!"
"They're the reason I'm here to bring this message." Lyra's words fall on selectively deaf ears.

"That's why I'm sorry for what we have to do, whether you are spies of the Afterlife or just poor civilians of greater Blackwater. It's one of our tenants," he says, spitefully eyeing Lyra, "that no outsider of the First Red, even brothers and sisters of the Blackwater Carmine, can ever know where we are."
I watch another familiar face approach in curiosity. I remember his name in an instant.
"Just because you have the bloodline of the Mask doesn't mean you can do whatever you want, Lyra," The Chieftain says.
"We have a message of the end of Blackwater. Please, just listen," I say.
"We get those every other month, child," he says. "But from our messengers. Chymaeran, cross-blooded Brothers and Sisters that have trained their whole lives for this. But please, go on."
I open my mouth to speak, but Lyra goes first.
"It's time for us to return. The Afterlife has made its move."
"Doubtful."
"The Afterlife is in possession of a source of Pure Essence," Lyra says.
"And so what? It does nothing to anyone without a divine lineage of blood. That's no reason for them to do anything." Raine steps forward.
"But that's the thing. They have a vassal that will accept both the Human and Chymaeran blessing of the Mask."
"But that's impossible!" Raine says. "How?"
"They found my brother," Lyra says. "They drained his blood and Essence. And they made some abomination they plan to unleash on all the city, destroying everything!"

"Your brother is dead, Lyra," Raine says. His irritation feels more like habit than a sudden outburst. "You saw them bury him. He's rotted away for years! His grave is only empty because of foxes and wolves." He turns to Sylvia and I. "What's to say these aliens aren't Chymaerans from the Afterlife, that they didn't take some poor cadet's guise and wear their flesh?" He eyes the necklace pendant my mother gave me. Surprise flushes his face, only convinced further of the story he's spun.
Raine approaches me. He reaches to the black crystal around my neck and yanks it. It snaps at the enclosure.
"Look! Why else would these strangers carry Guise Tokens if they weren't masking themselves as poor civilians?"
"That's from my mother," I tell him. "It's just a necklace!"

"This is a Guise Token. It only looks different because this is how they made them decades ago — you get a sample of the victim's flesh and bone and let it dissolve in pure Chymaeran Essence. This one's unprocessed, amateur work. This could only work two or three times before it failed."
I feel an amethyst energy that plagued me once before return to my entire body. I look to the side, and Sylvia's face flushes with the same anguish. They plan to kill us here.
"Commander Zebal, please!" says Lyra.
"Zebal?" The words escape my mouth. "Like Romin? And Ryder?"
He signals for the Chymaeran militiamen to stop. "That's right," he says, before disbelief flushes his expression again. "How would you know that?"
"Romin was in our fireteam," I say.
He scratches his beard, fumbling through faded memories. All he remembers is how much he's forgotten.
Sylvia says, "He was brave and honorable."

"Was?" Raine looks defeated. "What do you mean by that? Why isn't he with you, then?" The name is foreign and unrehearsed to him. I see a light glimmer in his eyes, and I regret being the one to snuff it out.
"He's the reason we made it here. Romin . . . died, so that the three of us could live."
Lies. His death was stupid and meaningless.
"He died a hero, honoring the Twelfth Province Carmine he gave all his soul and effort to."
He died a martyr!
I thought Raine would be heartbroken, but to him, his sons' names have almost been reduced to an anecdote.

"Names are just names, kid. You can spin any convincing yarn when you take the faces of the dead," he says, fiddling with my guise token between his fingers. "Tell me something only I would know. What do you know about my sons?"

"Romin was just as stuck-up and arrogant as you are. He made his whole life mission to take up leadership in the First Red when you died. He lived in the shadow of you and his brother Ryder, always asking himself if his efforts and achievements were enough," I say.
The Militiamen release their grasp and give us the room to stand.

"He told us his earliest memory of you," Sylvia says. "You were teaching him swordplay. He always told you it was stupid, that guns made swords obsolete. But then you told him it was a metaphor. That keeping it sharp was a symbol of renewed honor, and just that word changed his mind completely."

"I remember, too," I say. "And the next day, he found the sword you planned to give him as a gift. Early in the lighttime, he took it to the Compound's shop. You probably awoke to the loud screeching of metal and panicked Carmine trying to stop the husky kid from taking over the edge grinder. He was ruining the perfect edge of the blade, saying it would bring him more honor."
Raine's gaze grows distant, but he refuses the tears much like his own son, keeping his face stoic and humorless.
"Your son was in love," I say. "With another member of our fireteam. A Merlotan Royal, to be exact."
The Militiamen and Lyra chortle. Even the other Chieftains consider it too stupid and absurd to be false.
"Those two dysfunctional oafs were in love?" Lyra asks.
"And how in Khiras' name would that happen?" Raine asks.
"Because Fireteams were chosen at random. It was the year after he thought you died that we were assigned our fireteams," Sylvia said.
"So please. We don't plan to leave, but to stay forever and contribute to this village. Our mission is yours: to save Blackwater in any way we can."
Raine turns to the other Chieftains. "Everything they've said is true, and it checks out," he says. "Even the best-trained Chymaeran couldn't dig those details out of a guise."
"Then what do you propose?"
"Let's give them a shot," Raine says. "Lyra's reckless in bringing them here, but they know a lot that we don't."
"You just want to hear more about your boy," one whispers.

"If the worst case is that someone tailed them, we'll be handling that anyway, regardless of what we decide." He speaks louder so we can overtly hear. "If they try to escape without fear, they'll die as frosthards. And if they breach our trust, we'll put them out the same way we intended to."
The others nod.

"I call a vote among the twelve First Red Chieftains of the twelve provinces. Twelve proposes these aliens be recognized as brother and sister of the First Red." He turns to them. "What say you, 'aye' or 'nay?'"
The response is audibly settled. There's no reason not to accept us in.
"Then, for the first time in the history of the First Red, we welcome you as Brother..."
He turns to Lyra.
"Titus and Sylvia."
"Brother Titus and Sister Sylvia," he says. "Do you accept this honor?"
"I do," I respond.
"We do," Sylvia says.

"Then from this moment on, the Committee of the Twelve recognizes you as provisional trainees to the Carmine," Raine says. "As in, you must earn our trust and respect. If you fall in any breach of that—and I mean anything—your title, and life, will be subject to termination."
"Understood," I say.
"As pledges from District Twelve, I will oversee your education." He gestures to a chieftain with gray braids beside him. "The ninth chieftain, Lorne, will see to your housing in the barracks."
"Thank you for your clemency," I say.

"This will be the furthest from a life of leisure, Titus and Sylvia. The life of the furthest edgelander in Blackwater, nearest to the frigid walls of the outer lands, pales in comparison to the demand of every Backwood villager, and yours will be especially heavy."
"We understand," Sylvia says.

"Then welcome to the land of the true Carmine," Raine says. His extension of provisional trust is admirable, and though Sylvia seems contented with the freedom of a new life, I can only think of the past and everything I owe to the ones I allowed to die.

As we tour the quaint village, Lyra tells us the land of the Backwoods is filled with Carmine who have lived more than a thousand lives combined. For the pure blood humans, it's two: the life before the Royal Guard overtook their lands, and the life after. But for those with some Chymaeran blood — the rare ones split between both sides of life and death as a living paradox — they live the lives of many, providing the First Red the intel they need by borrowing the likeness of long-forgotten dead.
"So how many half-bloods are there?" Sylvia asks.

"Very few," Lyra says. "Their existence alone is an anomaly. They are the only ones that can last for years in their transitioned form." She nods to the two behind us, who still persist in the form of Valentina and Romin. "They're half-bloods, too. They've been watching over me in Blackwater for the whole trip."
"But do they remember anything of our . . . friends?" Sylvia asks. "Do they hold only the most recent memories, or just pieces of the strongest ones?"
"The longer they stay that way, the better they get. But they will never have the full likeness of the person they take."

"Because there's something I've wanted to ask. If the real ones I called my friends are . . . gone, even if it's not really them or they don't remember anything," Sylvia says, "can I say goodbye to them? One last time?"
"Sure, you can ask them," Lyra says. She's surprised as I am. The two impostors shrug, and I hate that I can almost see a sliver of my old friends inside them.

"They're not our friends, Sylvia. They can't replace them," I mutter to her, under my breath, but she ignores me. She turns to the Romin and Valentina that know so little of their pasts, as if amnesia has overtaken them. Neither have the mannerisms we remember, as their bodies are a vacant shell transplanted with a different soul. I can tell Sylvia waited for this cathartic moment since the desire came to her in the train car, a chance to fully let go.

She weeps with everything she has when she embraces them, as if she really, truly had the chance to say goodbye one last time. I hear her whisper the words she reserved for them the whole time we hid in the cellar. I live it through her. I can't bring myself to do it. Because to me they're still alive, waiting on the other side of twenty-one hours and twelve minutes, in a single frame, still completely unaware of what awaits them and frozen like insects trapped in amber.
But then she insists."You have your chance, Titus. Join us one last time to feel through that grief," Sylvia says.
"But it's not them, Sylvia. You should know that. It isn't the same."

"But your heart needs something to process. You have to grieve it all in that fleeting moment you can. Come on! Release every last ounce of that sorrow that drags at you. And finally, when you know you've tried, can you begin to heal."
"I can't. Acceptance might be your only choice, but it's never been for me." She doesn't understand the anguish that awaits me. I pity her naivety and weakness.
"Just once," she insists. "And I'll never ask again."

"Fine," I say. I approach the Chymaerans who wear the faces of my friends, and I feel those dangerous emotions surge within me. I don't deserve this opportunity to say goodbye when it was my decision that condemned them to their fate. I'm pathetic and expendable without—

Sylvia pulls me in. I can feel the warmth of Sylvia's body heat my skin although Romin and Valentina remain cold. They feel exactly like how I last abandoned them, both immortalized in a way they never expected. This Valentina feels just as small and squishy and fragile as I last remember her. Romin is the same statuesque boulder. This forbidden comfort is a catharsis I can't yet afford. Gods. This touch is a drug, but all I huff now are the fumes of the secondhand past that still follows me, and the more I stay, the less I want to let go.

Lyra's left in an uncomfortable silence. "Well . . . I've got to report in to the Chieftains.  Lorne should have prepared your space by now in the barracks. Familiarize yourself with this place: it will be your home and new life until we return. And when you're familiarized, go to the Barracks to settle in."
Sylvia and I let go. She insists on staying, though the discomfort of embracing these guising actors begs me to leave.

"Let's look around," I tell Sylvia. It's our first chance to take in the disbelief of this verdant enclave beyond the walls. The first thought I have is of all the illustrations in Everett's books of plants and lush grass. But now I can touch it. I can experience the sensation of the wild grasses and verdant spaces,  beauty far different from the over-manicured lawns of the Afterlife, and the closer I walk to the center of this place, the more I'm unable to tell where the village ends and nature begins.

The snow has melted. A radiant sun shines through with a chill breeze. I ask a local where the snow went. It's the Essence of this place: present in the circuits of the villagers, enough to raise crops at inconceivable speeds to feed the masses, the only reason they can possibly survive out here. It's vested in their own fractal of Pure Essence in the Chieftains' Lodge. And it's buried in the soil, changing the very climate of this small enclave of frozen wasteland.

He tells us that Blackwater was once this beautiful, full of pine forests that spanned for ages with huts nestled in between. It's a past he doesn't remember. All he has is the spoken word of history that's forbidden in the mainland.

We stop for a moment to hear the silence of the wind as it passes through the trees. My nose is no longer too cold and stuffed to smell, so for the first time in forever I take in the aroma of cedar and pine.

It's all so beautiful and wonderful, but I can't allow myself the comfort of enjoyment. I watch Sylvia make peace with this birthright that was taken from us, sprawled out across a field of tall grass, watching clouds pass in the sky high above. And it's a new sight for me too. It only motivates me further to bring back this experience for all of them, so that we can share the same dream.
A group of half-blood Chymaerans approach, two of them still wearing the faces of Romin and Valentina. From Valentina's hand dangles my necklace.
Their voices transition from vibrating clicks to human speech.
"You never answered at the Cheiftains' Lodge. Why do you have an identity marker?" the Romin asks.
"I never knew it was," I say. It's so strange addressing Romin when his mannerisms are entirely different. But I can see a notable change compared to when they first wore his face.
"Can I borrow this?" He asks.
A part of me is reassured they found it.
"You can have it. I don't need it or want it," I say. All I carry with me now is memory, not possessions.
But I'm still curious.
"Why do you want to borrow it?"
"I think I know the Chymaeran half-blood that used this. They mentioned they've been missing one for a long time."

"Sure," I say. I always considered its origin was somewhere beyond the walls, taken by Snowdrifters before I ever became one. None of those things ever get back to their original owner, because every run we're stealing from the dead.

"The dead deserve respect for us to borrow their lives. It's sacred to the culture of true Chymaerans," Valentina says. "To lose a guise is to lose an intimate connection — there's a lot I've learned about this girl while I guised her."
"Like what?" says Sylvia. She no longer basks in the comfort of the fields.

"When you start, it's as if you forget everything about who you really are. You have to remember that it's all just an appearance, just to separate yourself. It's brutal to remember a person's last traumas. The most recent memories come first, and so for this girl . . . " Valentina says. Her words trail off, waiting for someone to pick them up.
Sylvia asks, "Was it painless?"
"She was gone before she could think about it."
"Oh."
I turn to the Chymaeran guising Romin, but before I can ask the same question, they turn away.
I ask anyway.
They respond, "You don't want to know. It wasn't quick." They leave it at that. I don't ask further, knowing it might upset Sylvia.
"Tell us," Sylvia insists. "I want to know."
"Romin was shot several times, but it wasn't the bullets that killed him. His last thoughts were regrets."
I think of his last words in my first life, pleading to the empty air for someone to remember him.
"But why, why would he do that?" Sylvia says.
"Because I wanted the perfect reason to die," Romin says, before correcting himself. "Because he wanted . . . Gods above. Six hours and it feels like I'm already becoming him."
Sylvia asks, "How much can half-blood Chymaerans remember in a week? A month? Even years?" And I can tell where she's going with this.
"Longer than the person was alive, to achieve a fraction of their memories and personality," Valentina says. "Most recent memories first, except for their most painful traumas."
"I see," Sylvia says.

I felt the oddest comfort when I got over the initial surprise of seeing the two Chymaerans guising my cherished friends. But once they opened their mouths to speak and their joints postured in a body language I couldn't recognize, there's been a sickening uncanniness I can't shake.
The look of hope in Sylvia's eyes tells me she's on the edge of falling victim to this convincing illusion. To her, it's a chance to start over, but in reality it's the furthest thing from benign.
The Romin says, "You'll be paired with us in the living halls since we'll be training you—since so much of all our lives were spent in District Twelve."
"That's great!" Sylvia says. "And you'll be keeping this appearance?"
"If you wish," the Romin responds. I know it's hard to resist looks this good, I hear in my mind, but his face is stoic.
Oh, shut up Romin! You're the last ugly face I'd want to wake up to. I crack a smile when I imagine Valentina's response, but she's dead-serious too.

"There's an important meeting tonight held by the leaders of the First Red. You'll be introduced there. Gods above — there have been so many reports of you two as spies, it'll do us well to clear all of this up. Come to the North wall at sundown," Valentina says.
Romin spits out several parting words before they dissolve to clicks. "We'll see you there. And enjoy your last day of freedom—there's a lot to catch you up on tomorrow."

The villagers of the Backwoods work late into the night. Hunters return from the lukewarm fringe of land where animals tread. There exists no ancient wall to separate us from nature, no hard boundary, but a gradient of frost that tapers off into the shaded darkness of the treeline.

I find that like it. Unlike the hedonistic civilians that indulge themselves behind their tall cobblestone walls, these villagers directly face that boundless, all-consuming darkness every night, reminding them of all they could lose at a moment's notice. I can feel the same edge in their fears of the Afterlife that I feel grow within myself, that bitter sickness like cancer that never leaves once it comes; a permanent ailment of the mind.

"Titus," a voice calls. "I've been looking for you." It's Raine. He stands beside a great sled on the edge of the village as the darkness sets into the forest, talking with two tall hooded figures. Looking at their feet, I consider they have the strangest shoes, as if they stand on tall heels only exposing the lowest part of their toes, but the detail eludes me.
"We have some time before the meeting. I wanted to talk with you for a while."

"Sure," I offer, joining their conversation circle as they part to let me in. But my attention is fixed on the strange creatures my eyes can't reconcile, the slight hunching, looking as if dogs stand upright at full attention. Their eyes are piercing and slitted. Their bulky gloves are covered in fur. It's only when they withdraw their hoods that I realize what they are.
"Human, look as if you've seen a ghost," they say.
"You're . . . Ahkvasans," I say.
"I'm impressed," Raine says. "How do you even know that?"

"My grandfather hoarded illicit books of the old world. He insisted they weren't fairy tales, though everything that the Academy and Seminary taught us would say otherwise." I turn to them in disbelief, as if all pen-and-ink illustrations of my memory were given slender legs and angular faces. "How did you even make it here? Where do you come from?"

They motion to the sled, outfitted like a touring car with flat skis instead of wheels. "Explorers, we are. From Melenia. Sent by Ja'ada. This is the only northern village we can travel. Well-known by other lands. Supported by us. Cause is noble."
"As we're the last Humans alive. Surely," I say. They laugh to themselves, muttering something in their own sharp-tongued language.
"Walk with me," Raine says. "Where's the other girl?"
"Still exploring. I didn't mean to leave her hanging, but I wanted to return to the barracks," I say. "What do you need?"
"First is an Essence transfer. I also want to give you a quick personal tour," Raine says.
"Thank you for your time, sir," I say, but I can tell the gnawing anticipation to learn his son's past would consume him if he didn't approach me eventually.
"Call me Raine," he says.
We wave to the Ahkvasans, still chattering on and laughing in their quick tongue. He stops for a moment and turns to face me.
"I would have done this if you both were here. But you need some Essence to be helpful out here," he says.
"You can transfer Essence?"
"It takes a lot to give a little. But when the elders die, they allow us to reclaim it all in their passing. Circle of life, or something like that, right?" Raine says.
"So you kill them first?"

He laughs. "No. Gods no, absolutely not. But when they die, there's a brief period that the Essence vacates their circuits. It shimmers in the air, faintly, like crystals of snow, so clear you almost can't see it, attracted to the nearest circuit-wielder like metal dust to a magnet. But if too much time passes, it condenses to dead Essence, falling to the ground where it's absorbed into the dirt."

I recall the great liquidation of Blackwater, the moment when Essence flooded through the cavern from all the victims of Endogeny. The flood of power I felt in my circuits, though only a hundredth of a hundredth of that great plume found me.
"I've never witnessed that before," I tell him.
"I hope not," he says, laughing again.
He exposes his hand. Near the bones on both sides of his wrist, I see two series of slashes that have worn there many times before.
"Are you ready? This won't hurt too much, I promise," he insists.
"Go ahead," I say.

He withdraws a dagger. It glows hot like the can of beans did in Lyra's hand, cleansing the blade of any impurities. "We need to air our blood for the transfer to happen. Hold my forearm. Line our wrists at the joint."

We hold each other's arms like a deep handshake. He slices the blade across both of our wrists at the side. The pain is quick. A small trickle of blood pools together at the crease of our light and dark flesh. By gravity, none of it returns to the slice to cross-contaminate, but I can see the faintest glow rise between us.

Raine draws into his pocket with another hand, retrieving dead Essence, and he sprinkles it on the union of our blood. It stings of a familiar otherworldly force when it absorbs into the lesion. When the blood dries, he twists his wrist so that mine is on top, and an immense feeling of flux envelops me.

"The Chieftains hold all the Essence of the dead so that it can be distributed efficiently," he says. "But imagine this: even with all this Essence flooded in each of our circuits from the fallen, we don't even reach a tenth of what the average pureblood of the Afterlife has." His face is stoic again. "Honor their sacrifice. Return to the graves of the deceased whose Essence you took to honor them. Somewhere in the reservoir, your words will reach them, and maybe, just maybe, it will guide them back to us in another life."
"I will," I tell him. The feeling is electric. But it's nothing close to the magnitude of what I had in the Afterlife.
"Soon you'll even be able to do this. Watch," he says.
He turns his palm upward. His fingers glow like flesh pressed directly up to a flashlight, and in moments, a spark attenuates into a flame.

He finds joy in my expression of disbelief. "You remind me of my son Ryder, the first time I showed him in the basement of the Compound. He pleaded for me to teach him, but I had to swear him to secrecy," Raine says. "I never got the chance to show Romin."
"I'm sure he would have been amazed," I tell him. "It's our birthright as Humans. It's what we deserve."
"Damn right," he says. "Speaking of that, how does the Essence feel? It must be a strange new sensation to you."
"It feels nice. I won't freeze when sleeping at night anymore, I can tell you that," I say.

"Good," Raine says. He motions for me to follow him. "Look—I'm sorry how we reacted to your arrival. You have to understand how scared we were, how thin the ice is we tread on secrecy. You know why I left Blackwater?"
I shake my head.

"The First Red Chieftains phase through life terms. When one dies, another replaces them. It's a rare occurrence — you probably don't know how much a solid base of Essence prolongs the Human life — but when a chair is empty, they draw directly from the highest member of that Blackwater district."
"It happened when Romin was three or so, I think I remember from what he told me," I say. "You didn't have a choice, did you?"

"The Carmine pledge leaves no room to waver in uncertainty. You give all of yourself, everything that's asked of you. And the most taxing is time." He looks down at his weathered, cracked hands as we walk. "I gave up a relationship with my sons. I had to die to them. They had everything in place to convincingly frame it, and it doesn't take much to convince the Merlot and the Afterlife—they were probably relieved," he says. "My whole life here has been trying to make up for that. And I want you to know that, although this life will be hard, you will be safe and protected, well-taken-care-of and challenged." The words sound like they've been rehearsed in his mind for ages, for someone he knew he'd never meet.
"And I'll honor whatever you need from me, Raine," I tell him.

Raine introduces me to half the village, and to any curious passerby that stares me down like how I glared at the Ahkvasans. He shows me the grueling labor of the farmers, able to harvest fully-grown plants in a mere two weeks by cheating the ecosystem with Essence. He shows the few young Carmine much like myself, strong with corded muscle much like Romin, enthusiastic to find another friend their age. And finally, we arrive to the Chieftains' Lodge, where he takes me inside.

"And this building here is the heart of all the Carmine, all we've ever fought for. It's nothing compared to the great compounds we've erected all around Blackwater proper, of course: all we have out here is logs instead of concrete. But this is the nexus from which all decisions spring, influencing the Carmine in Blackwater though ninety-nine-point-nine percent of their ranks don't even know we exist."
In the center of the floor is the shimmering fragment of something in a case. Now that enough Essence floods my circuits, I can sense it, and Raine notices.

"A fragment of Pure Essence," he says. "Legends say the Pure Essence comes straight from the Gods, before they banished themselves from this world and all its affairs." His eyes look beyond the windows for something, and then he tugs my shirt, bringing me to the window. "You see that boulder out there? That one, by the tree."
"What about it?"
It's about knee-height in diameter.

"They say that's how much of this Pure Essence exists in the world. So much unaccounted for, so much we don't even know about, so much even locked away for safety, for mutually-assured destruction, hopefully never to be touched. It's the only fine connection we still have to the divine."
"And it's the source of the climate," I say.
"Smart," Raine says. "A great part of it. Any more and we'd stick out to the Afterlife. We have just enough to remain hidden in this endless snowstorm, the best cover we could ever ask for."
A Sister approaches from behind us, excusing her interruption before tapping me on the shoulder.

"This is yours, right?" In her hand dangles the black, crystalline identity marker, suspended from a fixed clasp after Raine tore it from me. "The Chymaeran-blooded brothers were excited for some reason after they asked to borrow it. These things are speculated about like treasures to Snowdrifters. It's part of their culture, I guess. But they gave up after they couldn't find whatever they were looking for."
"Thanks," I tell her.
"Chymaerans are strange creatures," Raine says. "But then again, I guess we're strange to them, too."
I tie the clasp back around my neck, and attuned more to the energies of the world around me, I feel the strangeness of its power as if a voice whispers in my mind.

The gathering has already begun in the amphitheater by the time Raine and I arrive. The Chieftains of the First Red scatter about the front benches as salt-and-pepper heads of hair in a sea of crimson cloaks. Behind them, villagers fill the outcropping seated on grass, rocks, or fallen logs, and to the sides of us, limestone slabs scrape the sky above the trees. The two natural walls meet at the bottom, where an outcropping of rocks have been cobbled into a stage.

Raine motions for me to sit next to him on the rear benches near the central aisle. I look for Sylvia or Lyra, the only other two faces I know, but the ruffled hair, tattered clothes, and sultry skin of the villagers blend them all into the foliage.
The twelfth chieftain's voice booms with enough resonance for us all to hear.

"Motion to discuss Essence allocation to agriculture has been tabled to next month's meeting," he says, and in a drawn pause of commotion, I ask Raine why he isn't up there with them. He tells me they switch off each week in hosting the gathering, allowing them to balance focus between provincial issues.
"Next order of business," says the secretary. The cabinet scans for propositions.
"Motion to discuss scouting literature for children," a female voice says.
"That's for subcommittee discussion," the Chieftain says. "Pressing issues. Large concerns. Thats what we discuss here. Anyone?"
"Motion to discuss housing conditions in the third barracks," another says. "There's been a roof collapse, and—"
"Again, committee issue," he says, almost bored and agitated—but then again, everyone looks jaded and depressed.
Another young voice calls out. "Motion to discuss the return to Blackwater,"
The old men groan in the audience. "No, not again. Sit down, Lyra!"
"Anyone to second this motion?"
The Secretary of the twelfth province looks around, but all we hear is the disparate answer of nature.
My eyes scan the crowd for the excited, young voice, and I find Lyra standing there in the middle: squeamish, hoping for someone to extend her motion. And right beside her is Sylvia.
"Please. Just humor me this once. Just hear me out," Lyra says.
Raine nudges me, muttering something about his annoyance.
"Will this close it, Lyra, once and for all?" the Secretary asks.
"Close the purpose we're out here? We have to . . ." Her words trail off when she looks around at all the bowed heads. But she's still adamant."Yes. This time it's definitive."
"Seconded, then," the Secretary says. "Proceed with your new business."
The old Carmine leaders all appear sour and exhausted, as if it were just yesterday that they left their old lives. They turn away in ignorance, chattering with small talk to mute her out.

"The time has finally arrived," she insists, and for such big words, they elicit no reaction, because I'm sure they've heard them before. "I've been stationed in Blackwater proper for several months with guising Chymaerans, and we witnessed something that has never happened before . . ."
She milks suspense for every ounce she can get, but still comes up dry.
"A column of crimson light broke the sky," Lyra says. "That means two things. First, that there was Pure Essence in some form. And second, that someone of the Chosen bloodline got their hands on it!"
"That's impossible," the twelfth Chieftain says.
I hear two Carmine whisper behind us.
"Just because she's related to that bastard Ullrich doesn't make her special," one says. The other laughs until it turns to a cough.
Lyra continues, "But that Pure Essence has fallen into the hands of the Afterlife."
The chieftain says, "How, then? How do you know this when our messengers haven't even returned with this information?"
"Because we beat them here," Lyra says.
"We can't act on something our messengers haven't confirmed," he replies.

I can see the frustration build inside Lyra. "But I wasn't alone! There were two Chymaerans with me that witnessed it. And Sylvia. And Titus—" she says, scanning the crowd for our faces, and she frowns when she finds me next to Raine.
