Raine turns to me. "Is this all really true?"
"Every word of it," I say.

With her argument crumbling to sand, Lyra fights to usher out her last argument before they silence her. "And if that column of light erupted — and there was Pure Essence — then that means Fletcher is alive. It had to have been him!"
Another audible groan from the audience.
"No, think about it. Good Carmine brothers and sisters, there's no other possibility."
"Impossible," I mutter: I lit that column of light. Telling them would only further confound the story and sully the waters. I'm far too young to fit Lyra's theory, anyways.

"I think we've all heard quite enough of your . . . 'possibilities,'" Raine says. He stands beside me. "Even if the Afterlife have a source of pure Essence, it's impossible that your brother is still alive."

Lyra turns to the Secretary who proposed the seconding motion in the first place. I can feel her anger towards their reverence because it begins to annoy me, too. I was almost excited when Lyra spoke so passionately about the First Red, and I was astounded when I saw their valiant efforts to survive beyond the walls.
"We've been over this so many times already, Lyra. Your brother is dead. So it doesn't matter," Raine says. "Actually, you know what? Permission to debate this topic with the other party?"
The Secretary polls. "Call to vote. How many aye?"
The amphitheater echoes with confirmation.
"And nay?"
Not a single voice responds.
"The ayes have it," the Secretary says.

"We're gonna end this discussion so we never have to have it again," he insists, and I can tell this scratches a wound that healed a long time ago. His anger isn't annoyance anymore. "Your brother doesn't matter. And even if the Purebloods have Pure Essence in their possession, that doesn't matter either!" Raine says. "What we need more than anything is patience and diligence. We need to prepare ourselves."

"We've been prepared for years, Raine. When will it ever be enough? All of you out there have grown so complacent with your lives beyond the walls. You think the busywork you preoccupy yourself with, day in and day out, can even begin to atone for how afraid you are of the real reason you're here. You hide from it. You use the excuse of your sacrifice to ignore the reason you gave up that life in the first place."

"There's a difference between giving up and having the patience to wait," Raine says. "Every day I remember the ones I left behind. My late wife wept for months, grieving the children that died to her, and so many of us have faced the same, so don't tell us we've forgotten our purpose! Unlike you, we don't have a reason to hate the life we left behind. And we anticipate, not fear, the day we get to return."
"Then what perfect moment are you waiting for? And if you are waiting, how do you know it hasn't already passed?" Lyra asks. "We are ready. We have everything we could possibly need."
"We're not ready, Lyra. And maybe you've forgotten the strength of the power they have. One of their weakest civilians has the Essence of three of our strongest men!"
"But the Weakbloods are the ones that give them their true power," Lyra says. "Its not about the Essence. It's resources. And our connections tap into every single corner of Blackwater."
If only they knew what was really going on. They wouldn't believe the words from me, an outsider to all the Carmine, and it frustrates me the more I watch Lyra drown in her ambitions.
But their debate ends when a Carmine messenger flies down the stairs from the upper entrance: a gold-sealed letter in hand that shimmers in the light.
The Secretary nearly jumps out of his chair. Lyra and Raine look on with newfound horror.
"This matter will be tabled until next meeting," the Secretary says. His voice wavers, and for a man of such power to crumple, I know exactly what truth awaits.

He wets his tongue before it dries like parchment. "As you all know, the highest Carmine in Blackwater are given seals for correspondences beyond the walls. Red are for monthly reports: each division receives twelve. Silver are for important, urgent developments, and they're only allowed one per year. But gold . . . are only to be used once, for emergencies that threaten the life of everyone in Blackwater."
Lyra's expression is torn between reassurance and fear. Both her and Raine hang on to the messenger's next words.

"District One. Six hours ago. 'Merlot siege on Carmine supply houses led to the deaths of several Brothers. Five supply houses have been burned. Massive ground war between Merlot and Carmine. Street riots in Merlot district have destroyed commercial and residential property.' End of message."
My stomach drops as I wait for the news of Endogeny. Sylvia hangs on the edge of her seat.
The Secretary says, "Only one district, Brothers and Sisters. We saw riots like these back in the 73rd year of Blackwater, no need for panic."

The message ends, but the messenger still isn't done. His hand draws into his pockets, pulling out a handful of envelopes.  The crowd gasps. He fans them out. My eyes can't count from such a far distance, but even more golden labels reflect under the sun as he raises the next.

"District two. Twelve hours ago. 'Merlot attacked and burned five Carmine safe houses. Thirty-four dead or missing. Merlot claim they are not behind the attacks. Massive infighting on streets. Carmine and Carmine-allied civilians actively destroying Merlot property, regardless of orders to stop.' End of message."
He pulls another.
"District Four. Seven hours ago. 'Sixteen dead in assault on . . . '"
The messages continue for fifteen more minutes, and the anxiety only crescendoes over that time. It's after the ninth district's gold-sealed memo that the Secretary finally calls everything to order.
"Enough! We will discuss these in private with the Executive Board," the Secretary says.
Lyra sees her chance to further her point. "You see? It's time," she says, "and together, we—"
"Take your seats, everyone! Do not leave. Do not tell anyone beyond this meeting of the news. It will only stir panic when we haven't made a decision on our response," the Secretary says.
Lyra's hand suspends in the air with the Amulet, but no one watches her. "Decision? This is the moment we've been waiting for!"
"Now's not the time," Raine tells her.
"We will call a vote, right now," the Secretary says.
There's no way they can deny it with how this trouble has brewed. The evidence is indisputable.
"Vote is now called: should the First Red return to Blackwater?" asks the Secretary.
"Point of information," Lyra says.
"Proceed," the Secretary says.
"Our people need us. They've been waiting for our return, and this is the moment that will make or break the Carmine."

Raine says, "That doesn't directly mean it's time for us to go. There have been great clashes before, but that doesn't mean the Purebloods are any weaker: in fact, it means they're stronger, now that our brothers and sisters toil with the Merlot!"
"But they weren't the Merlot," Lyra insists.
"And how would you know that?"
"Because the Afterlife was disguised as the Merlot when they attacked us both times," Lyra says. "They were sewing the seeds of discord between the Merlot and the Carmine for their own gain!"
"The Afterlife," Raine says. "If we're fighting them, then we need more time to build our strength and plan our tactics."
"Screw tactics: we've been strategizing for years. There is no perfect time. That's just an excuse to bury our heads in the snow and still keep our honor!"
The Secretary interrupts them. "We will put this matter to another vote."
"Alright, then. Do what's right. Remember what we're here for," Lyra demands, "we have to put actions to the purpose that gives us pride."
A silence awaits the vote.
"This congregation will now cast the vote of return to Blackwater. A 'aye' vote sets in motion the return protocol. A 'nay' vote withholds our return."
I look around. All their faces are set in anxious horror — the same cowardice I saw in Romin's cadets at the foothills of the afterlife.
"How many votes 'aye?'"

"Aye!" I stand. There are few young Brothers and Sisters in the audience who join me. A couple others quietly mutter from the audience, but still remain seated in the grass. Raine is silent, and with him, the rest bow their heads.

As they count the votes, I turn around, only to find that Sylvia cowers with them. Lyra stands there with her hand stretched in the air, trying to coerce her, but even in a losing fight, she still refuses.
Raine and the Secretary almost look relieved. "Alright. And how many votes 'nay?'"
The response starts quiet, but grows louder as more voices join: their weakness in numbers, and I see Lyra's disappointed anger crescendo.
"Vote has been called. The 'nays' have—"
"You spineless cowards, have you lost your edge? Your own people are dying and all you do is watch!" Lyra says.
Raine turns around, relieved. "Calm down, Lyra. A fair vote was taken."
"Do the Carmine of Blackwater who are dying under the thumb of the Purebloods get a vote? Or is it only the purposeless pricks beyond the wall that get to decide?"
"We've heard enough, Lyra!" says the Secretary.

"Chymaeran surveillance in all twelve districts. First Red Carmine, ready in a matter of hours, to press towards whatever target we set. And so many Carmine districts waiting, just waiting, for the prophecy of the First Red to come to them, to tell them it's time for the final fight."
"Get her out of here, someone," the Secretary demands, and several eagerly jump to his aid.

"They have all the protocols we've written, and all we need to do is send a single letter. I'm tired of waiting, thinking any of you are going to change when you're just cowards, obsessed with a dream of purpose you'll never — get your hands off me!"
Raine can sense I'm dissatisfied: I stood right beside him, after all. "Why didn't it pass?" I ask. "This is the time all of you have been waiting for, isn't it?"

He draws a tender look before answering, like a father lecturing his misguided son. "I'm sure you know this by now, but there are very few young Brothers and Sisters beyond the walls. Most of them look to Lyra as the image that represents them. But they're too young to understand what it means to have something to lose," he explains.
"But isn't sacrifice the very premise of what you've sworn to protect?"
"Sacrifice can only be useful if it's used wisely, Titus," he says, but his explanation only disappoints and frustrates me further.
If only they could be reminded of the people they left. The sentimental value of their lives when it's not degraded to a distant anecdote.
"Where's the other girl you came here with?" He says, just as bad at remembering girls' names as his son. "Now that the two of you are together, we can finish your orientation."
We're not quite on speaking terms after our last fight, but I scan for her anyways. I wave to her and she approaches.
"What do you want?" She asks.
"We need to finish orientation," I say.
"Of course," she tells me. Then she turns to Raine. "I'm glad that vote didn't pass."
"Same," Raine tells her. "And in time, I know your friend here will come to appreciate what we've built, and how he can contribute."

She tries to meet my eyes to confirm Raine's rationale, to say she's right and I'm wrong. If only any of them could understand what they've abandoned; how much they'll regret their dithering when they see everyone is dead. But this is their world, and it will never be mine.
"Are you ready?" Raine says. I realize he's already transferring Essence, the same way he did with me. "It's an amazing feeling. But don't let it scare you, Sylvia, or can be a lot the first time."
She closes her eyes, trying to release the tension she draws to resist the pain.
"Go ahead," she says.

I watch the blood jointly pool between their palms. That same electric sensation rises inside of her like tinnitus of the flesh. Raine twists his palm, and in an instant, Sylvia grasps her head with her other hand.
"Gods — what is that? It hurts!" She says.
"Hurts? It's not supposed to hurt," Raine says. "It feels like being under a massive waterfall, like heavy gravity pointing inside you instead of down."
Sylvia releases his hand, and I can see the inklings of a sight I could never forget. It takes only the slightest Essence to instigate that side of her.
"Is she alright?" Raine asks me. "I hardly transferred anything. I didn't even really start."
Sylvia mutters something indiscernible.
"Huh?" I bend closer to her.
"Fridging cowards," she says.
Raine still bends back: it's inaudible to his old ears.
"They are," I mutter.
"Two-hundred ninety-three times around since last time," she says. "You're lucky I can only peer through a sliver of this earthly form. Will I have to destroy this timeline, too?"
My heart short-circuits on a skip, and when I muster a breath, it feels like it won't start again.
I can feel the Essence try to surge inside her, but I'm fortunate it's not enough. I'm the only one who notices the faintest glow in her, because I've seen this all before.
"Why do you torment me?" I ask.
Sylvia grasps her head. "Wh-what are you talking about? The argument? I'm sorry—" she groans.
But I'm too focused on that panic that twists my stomach. If the air weren't so fresh, if it were sullied with the slightest smoke, I might vomit, but I manage to hold it back, clutching my chest.
"What happened to the two of you? What did you tell him, Sylvia?"
"Nothing," I tell him. "I was just really afraid for her, that's all."
"Well we don't have to do this now," Raine says. "It's been a long day for the two of you. I'd grind every ounce of effort out of you if this were another day. But today I'm in a good mood."
Of course you are, I think. Your outwaller vacation's been extended even longer!
Raine says, "Report back to the Barracks and get some sleep. We'll try all this again tomorrow."
I lift Sylvia to her feet as Raine joins the exodus of the First Red. The pain is still deep behind her eyes.
"Did it happen to you, too?"
"What?" I ask her.
"When you got the Essence transferred to you. That visceral flash of something — not quite a dream — so convincingly real. It was horrifying," she says.
"What did you see?"

"It was a dream. I was so big, and you were so small, and I . . . I couldn't resist the force behind the voice, that voice I've heard for years, that whisper . . . all I felt was the longing to protect you. You were so sad, tired, and scared, but I wasn't in control, I was a passenger, just like watching one of Val's pictures, and for the first time, that voice took control of more than just my thoughts."
"You remember that?" I ask her.
"Remember what? It was just feelings, flashes of light and sound," Sylvia says. "A dream."
"But that voice. Why can't you beat it or make it go away?" I ask her.
"Because it's resilient to anything I try," she says.
"It's not just a voice. It's you. It was all real! Don't you want to know where we came from?"
"What are you implying, Titus?" She asks. "What are my dreams to you?"
"What you saw was a past reality I witnessed. You—"
The panic returns to me when I try to remember, my lungs coughing smoke, the entirety of Blackwater wiped from existence.
"What did I do?"
"You — lost control."
"Of what?"
"Of that power inside you," I tell her. "It's divine blood. You have that . . . side, of yourself, locked away," I say.
"I don't believe it," she says, and she's getting visibly upset. "I don't believe any of that!"
"Why can't you try? We can try it again, right now. I have just enough Essence. Believe me," I say, withdrawing my pocket knife, but she shirks back.
"No. No," she says, "I'm not going through that again."
"Why are you so afraid of it?" I ask. "Why can't you try?"
"Because next time I might lose myself entirely. Let's live here instead, the two of us!"
I tension my left fist as my right fist closes the pocketknife, drawing it into my pocket. "All of you here, I swear to the Gods. You're all just cowards."
"What did you just say?" She says.

"You all just dream of a better future, thinking one day it will all be different, as if all your thoughts together could will it into existence," I say. "But if doesn't work like that. And Lyra's Gods-damn right: if someone doesn't wake you up now, you'll regret all of it when it's too late!"
I realize we've been walking towards the barracks for the last five minutes, so focused on the conversation I forgot to take in my surroundings, the loudness of my voice.
"If all that you talked about is real," Sylvia starts. "If you are killed, or kill yourself, and manage to go all the way back, then what happens to the me right now, right here?"
I pause to think. It's hard to imagine my value through other people's eyes when I'm just a resource.
"What will happen to me when I find your body? Can you live with that, knowing all that grief you'd cause me, and all your friends?"
She waits for my answer, but I don't have one for her.
"How many people have you left behind to grieve?" she asks.

"All the times before, there hasn't been a single person to remember me," I tell her. "But it doesn't matter. They can get over me. I'm just another guy whose name the world will speak one day for the last time, just like everyone else."

I duck my head as I look at my arms: how many scars have formed on my wrist. Yet I know each one of those lives, if they persist, are doomed to the very purging that Sylvia's other half condemned them to.

"It's selfish, the way you don't value yourself," she says. "And if I can't convince you of all the grief you can unwittingly cause, then all I can hope is that one day, in some reality, you can love yourself the way your friends and family truly cherish you. One day, you will realize that can be enough."
"I still have a vision," I tell her. "Maybe that day will come. But I'll never give up, I'll never be done until you, and everyone, have everything you deserve."

A breadth of silence later, we stand atop the porch, and as soon as the rusted hinges of the barracks' back door screech, our argument ends at an impasse. She'll always continue being afraid, and I'll always continue fighting to save her.

That night, I wait until Sylvia falls asleep in our tightly-packed dormitory. I sweat from the heat, restless with our window open as I stare at an unfamiliar ceiling in my cot. That anger is still inside me. The anxiety of time dragging me further and further away from that branching point sets me on eternal edge.

I'm too scared to shut my eyes and dream of their final lamentations. I've seen them enough times to remember every detail of how they died. And somewhere, up the streams of these branches spreading outwards, the real version of all these people wait.

Two hours pass before the woman sleeping next to me is a stranger. There are no brakes on this train that heads for a gorge; an unavoidable, zero-sum, ill-fated end. I don't have to ask forgiveness from anyone that won't be around to remember, so I leave my guilt and soul at the window, along with the sleeping girl.
"She never came home, so please, just tell me, I haven't heard from her in days," she says. Her fists clench the lapel of my jacket, but I sag in the corner, folded over myself.
Then he cuts in.
"She says you saw her last. She was headed to your house. The whole reason we got into this mess is because you made her disappear!"

His fist slams the metal siding harder than all the other desperate Cadets. But my eyes don't reach them. I stare at the worn rubber soles of my boots, wondering how many steps can be unwritten, and for that matter, if they still can.
I wonder if I have the strength to pull all the way through. Or else I'm no better than the ones I allowed to die.

"Calm down, Jarrett. We don't know that," Delvin insists. "How do we know she even made it there? She's Merlot royalty, and you're Carmine yourself. They were furious. You know, any one of them could have—"
"Could have what?" Vera says. "What?"
"—I-I don't know, Vera, I'm just saying," he says.

I can feel her fists tension tighter on my coat, but beneath all the anxious fury I can feel her tremble. I think I hear sobs leave her throat, but there are many that cry from helplessness in this narrow space.
"What about Sylvia? What happened to her?" Delvin asks. "And the other Carmine guy. Rohan."
"Romin," Jarrett says. "Damn it, Titus, just say something! Why did they throw you on here? Where in Khiras' name were you hiding to be this far out? And why did they stop the train so suddenly?"
"They're all waiting for us," I say. It's the first thing I've said since then.
"Where? Are they beyond the walls, too?"
"They're all waiting," I insist, and if I squint my mind's eye I can still see them.
"What is he on about?" asks Isla, too short to look over them, clenching Jarrett's mark, so easily tossed about the moving car.
"He says they're still alive," says Vera, and her grip loosens, though she still trembles. "But where is my sister?"
"Lyra. Raine. My father. And my sister, too," I continue. "They're all waiting, and I can bring you to them."

"Is she in the other car? With the rest of your Fireteam, surely, right? Sylvia and Romin?" Vera's voice cracks on the last syllable as she turns to them. "She has to be! I can't leave things the way we left them . . ."
"You're gonna see her again. You're all going to see them," I say.

Something bashes on the siding, rapping over and over like Carmine rallying drums. It startles everyone in the car, and for the first time, I can make out the faces of all the strangers in this dimly-lit space.
It's the door sliding open on its track. And over the cries and shrieks of panic-stricken prisoners, nobody noticed the train reached the end of the line.

"We can rush them," Jarrett says: words I've heard before, words that can only bring the same result of thoughtless bloodshed. "Listen. We're third-class Cadets, and you have our strength. They can't stop all of us!"

His optimism infuriates me. I envy that tactless, stupid hope they find when they're all going to die no matter what. But I don't have to speak on it. Like the First Red, they're all cowards with only enough headspace to consider themselves.
"Listen! We can—"
A voice feathers from static. "And where are you going to go, you stupid Carmine sap?"
It's a Chymaeran, guised in bright fabrics of the Afterlife.
"We're getting out of here,"Jarrett insists.

"All talk and no brains. No wonder the First Red were all blown out of their foxholes," the Chymaeran says, though Jarrett doesn't even know what the First Red are. "You'll all turn to Frosthards in the first ten seconds. We'll reap your Essence anyway!"
"Reap our Essence?" Vera asks.
"Fuel," I mutter to myself. That keyword makes sense now.
The Cadets are petrified: unsure of whether they wish to let the floor swallow them or try to run with Jarrett. Either is suicide.

"This isn't just a prison. You are not being punished for anything. You are only fulfilling your purpose, and I'm giving you an opportunity," he says, and down the line of cars, I hear other guards give the same spiel to their unwitting participants. "In the scale of this world's future, your purpose is vital: each and every one of you. You afford this world another chance at the Golden Age that was torn from us. And so you will be given a chance to choose your fate."
He sneers on a line of empty promise, one he's surely rehearsed so many times before.
"And the highest achievers will become one of the chosen ones of the Afterlife!"
"You drag us here without an option, and now you want to talk to us about choices?" A cadet says.
"All you have to tell me is if you are strong or weak," he says. Darkness spreads across his skin and clothes, morphing him from a Human puritan to a thick-shelled Chymaeran.
I forgot what it felt like to see a Chymaeran for the first time. Some cadets jump with fright, while most are so emotionally raw they stare with unblinking desperation.
The Chymaeran asks the most frightened one in front of them first.
"What are you?" The Chymaeran asks her.
"I . . ." She looks around at the others, unsure of how to answer, and yelps when the choice doesn't come to her. "I, er . . . I am . . ."
"Answer! All your fellow Cadets will freeze if we don't get through you."
"Weak," she answers. "I am weak."
"Go ahead," he says. He motions for them to pass him, and they get off just fine. Several gasp in disbelief. They thought it would be much worse.
"And you?"

The next one is another woman, younger with red hair and freckles. She looks past the Chymaeran at the other woman and her kids. Some look of reassurance crosses her face after a few seconds. She looks down at her meager Garnet-level mark before answering. "I am weak," she replies, bashful.
"Then go," says the Chymaeran.
Another Cadet steps up, a young man this time. Some guy I met once in passing, enough a sense of pride that shines far beyond his actual level.
"I think I am . . . strong," he says.
The Chymaeran sneers again.  "You think?"
"I am," he insists.
"Then step aside." He tries to exit, misunderstanding them. "No! Aside the cabin. Right here," he says, motioning to the front wall before turning to the next one. "And you? What are you?"
I can tell it's his fireteammate from the way they look at each other. Did they let these people group themselves onto the trains intentionally? Before they knew where they were headed?
The confident guy nods. His friend speaks up.
"I'm strong, too."
"Then face each other," the Chymaeran says, throwing something on the ground to each of them. "Pick it up. Now!"
And they do. I watch the terror settle in their eyes when they regret speaking those words.
"Then prove it." He says. "You have one minute to decide who's the real Champion."
"You mean—"
"Now."

The courageous one pleads. "Victor," he says, as his voice trembles. How quickly he folds on himself, and his friend does, too, once they realize there's no way out. They circle each other, idling time.
"I can't do this. I can't! I've known you since Seminary," the first says.
"We have to, Gage, come on! Come at me," Victor lunges with a hollow slash that couldn't cut a dandelion.

"No, no, no," Gage says, his eyes shifting between the impatient Chymaeran and his friend. Victor takes a further slice as Gage idles, flaying the skin of his arm, but he hesitates as soon as he realizes what he's done.
Gage screams with pain. He looks down at the slice as he drops his knife, and Victor panics, holding his hands to his ears and sobbing while the knife is still on his hands.
Victor says, "I hardly even cut you! I'm sorry, I'm sorry, please," he repeats, over and over, "I didn't mean to," before the knife slips from his fingers, stabbing into the wooden slats.
I recognize it in an instant. Gage shudders on the ground, and it's tough to make out in the shadows, but the faintest amethyst glow encapsulates his entire body.

"We learned it took too long to make you skin each other alive," the Chymaeran explains. Moments later, Gage's breathing stops when he melts into the floor. The hard parts of him become amorphous. And then, when the Amethyst absorbs him completely, leaving nothing but the Garnet-class cloak, the spectators gasp when a small trail of Essence gusts from Gage into Victor.
"This is how this world really works, shitbloods," the Chymaeran says. "Victor here learned something today. And I hope you all can learn through him, too!"

Victor still trembles. But all of a sudden he tenses, clutching his chest. In the darkness, the Chymaeran's slender arm reaches behind him, and in moments, the same Amethyst leaks like living ink down his limbs from beneath his cloak.
Gage's knife clatters to the ground.

"You'll learn that we don't tolerate hesitation," the Chymaeran says, "if you consider yourself a Champion, if you think you can equate yourselves with us." The crowd stirs in panic. They were raised as slaves, and now they'll die as them in whatever fate awaits the reluctant.
I startle Vera when I rise to my feet. "And how free will these winners be?" I ask.

"You will join the Afterlife in its mission. This is the way we've recruited the few remaining spaces every time, every passing class. Haven't you wondered what happened to all those lower-ranked losers that died in 'service' beyond the walls?"
"But why do we deserve this?" Another asks.

"Because this is what you signed up for!" the Chymaeran says. "You got a meal plan, lodging, your families taken care of with a stipend for your training. You knew this risk would come the day you signed on to the Academy. You knew the class-system and you chose to play the game, and now that the trade-off for all you've leeched from us is here, you will fulfill your true value!"
He eyes the back of the car where Isla, Jarrett, and Delvin huddle together, noting their marks.
"Dragon-class cadets? Why are you here?"
"They said it was desertion," Jarrett says. "We didn't go to the upper lands to defend against the 'Carmine,' because we were looking for someone."

"How unfortunate," the Chymaeran says. "You see, now, lowly Cadets, these Dragon-Class fighters have real strength, and they've proven enough to join the strong." He motions for them to approach, and when they do, Isla drags my shirt for me to follow.
But he stops me.
"And where do you think you're going, vagrant? How did you even get mixed in here?" He laughs. "How unfortunate."
Isla tries to defend me. "Titus was the Valedictorian of our class. He's at the same level. He's the best of all of us! Go on, tell him," Isla tells me.
I look down at the outwaller fabrics that cover my body: shoddy yet dense and warm, or they would be, if there weren't so many holes torn in them.
"Damn it, say something!"
"Are you strong or weak?" the Chymaeran asks.
"He's strong," Isla says.
"I was asking him, shitblood."
I feel my hands tension. I'm unsure whether I have the strength to do it myself this time, but I've run out of allies to expend and paths to take.
"I am strong," I say.
"Then prove yourself, vagrant," he replies.

The pencil-necked Garnet-class cadet across from me shakes like the rest of them, never having witnessed real violence in his life. I don't approach him, yet he backs himself into a corner. The car full of prisoners parts like a bad haircut to let him by.

"We don't have to do this, you know," he says, steadying the knife as his hand trembles. As I approach closer, his eyes widen and he shields himself, thinking of me as some psychotic vagrant from the city fringe. "I'm trained in combat, unlike you, vagrant. I'll cut you open!"
"Then try me," I say. My hands are perfectly steady. The same mantra of Sylvia and Lyra's last words they spoke to me cycles through my mind. Bedrock is the most solid state of all.
He lunges for a warning slice, so off-balanced that it almost carries him into the onlookers. I still stand there, passively, my body unhinged towards any defensive position.

He speaks words just to get a rise out of the Chymaeran, to idle and show his toughness, but the fear of that moral edge is something he can't ever hope to hide. I can tell, because despite everything, I still hang on the same edge. Rank means nothing when the weight of our souls is the same. Or so I tell myself. But the only way back is to cross an unforgivable line I still haven't crossed.

I begin walking towards him, and even though I'm average height, my build is intimidating enough to drive him back. He mutters something indiscernible. The Chymaeran grows impatient. And as the last moment of action passes by, I wonder if I'll be stuck in this moment forever, just like last time.
But then his heel catches on the leg of one of the prisoners. He trips. The serrated edge fumbles through his hands, almost at a half-turn before he reaches for it again.

I duck out of the way just in time to miss it again, twisting my body left as it passes me, forgetting about the knife I'm still clutching in a death grip. I feel a resistance, then hear a futile gasp, when I finally collect myself enough to step back.

When I look back at the scrawny cadet, the slice parts his jaw like a cleft chin. Just the smallest paper-cut is enough for those with no Essence, and I turn away before I can watch it cycle through him.

As I feel all of his meager Essence enter my circuits, I hear her words as they cross my mind. You will never be better. You will never deserve that perfect world with all the ones you've left behind!

The Chymaeran takes my refusal to watch as a sign of resilience. "You have a chance, vagrant," he says, stepping aside the door. Vera and her fireteam look on with disbelief: my back was to all of them when it happened, and for all they know, I murdered the Garnet-class weakling in cold blood, unaffected.

Past the steaming train cars wet with melted frost that drips from their bowed roofs, two lines form beyond each train car's door, separated by a tall fence. One of them is short and straight. The other bends and serpentines on itself, taking at least twenty times the space of the other.
I peer to my right and left. The lines are short, but both extents of the train stretch so far in an arc of repetition that they disappear into the snowstorm.
All I can see is a single building in the center, looking far too small to contain all of us: and the survivors, strong or weak, filing into it.

The few cars already emptied are being loaded with something I can't discern in the blinding white, but there's so much of it. It's the only thing that exits this place besides the elderly guards: in barrels and boxes aged for so long it almost looks like they're made of petrified wood.
The line of cowards fills with so many that they run out of space to file, but in my line only two more join. They're shaken with disbelief, refusing to believe what it took them to join us.
"One at a time. Six feet apart. Don't stop," one guard says on repeat, ushering the weak with a baton.

"So you are the fighters," another Afterlife guard says. "Do you feel this, right now? Or have you gotten too used to it? Enjoy the snow, the cold, the fresh air. Remember every feeling of it. Because it will be the last memory you'll live on for as long as you make it."
They call our car number. It numbers somewhere in the hundreds.

"Around fourteen times a year, I get to witness this," he says, to our small group of seven. "Fourteen provinces graduating, their times equally spaced, arriving on seven or eight full loads of trains — but for me, it's so much longer."

He motions for us to follow, and the closer I draw to the round-domed stone edifice, the more I feel the energy of this place vibrate in my circuits. I can't explain how I sense its direction, but something immensely powerful feels as if it will set me into seizure, twisting my stomach as we pass beneath the frame. I seem to be the only one it affects, because I'm the only one that's been afforded this much Essence.

The entrance hallway is pitch dark: only twenty meters or so long, but it feels like I've been walking in-place for minutes. It feels as if the front and back of my body are trying to meet each other in the center, constrained in a straight line by some flux that feels as if it compresses me.

The air becomes so dense that it makes us light-headed. Every time I step forward, my legs feel like they hinge slower than the hour hands of a clock, but when my feet fall behind to draw the next step, they accelerate with such speed I think I'll trip. Every sensation brought from ether behind or in front of me renders my mind as a useless gage, feeling sensations that aren't there, as if I'm being crunched and stretched and slowed and sped all at the same time, only stabilized by the head of Jarrett struggling in front of me.

The only sensation I trust next is when I know it's ended, when we arrive in the great central chamber spanning at least a hundred yards in diameter. I turn around to peer through that strange hallway I just entered, and on the other end, a new band of cadets stands nearly still. Beyond them, white snowflakes rest still in the air like stars in a photo-negative sky.

Some cadets retch from the nausea. Some vomit. Others gaze in awe at the scale of the chamber. Above us, true sunlight pours through a glassless dome where the snowflakes stick to nothing, refusing to cross the threshold of its geometry. The circular walk rims around a vacant gap in the center where turbulent winds flow upwards, and above us in the very center of the dome are concentric spinning wheels.

Something thuds directly behind me from above. On the ground I find a mess of feathers, and a bird that looks as if it's been half-consumed. The left-wing is still flushed with healthy feathers, but I can tell it snapped its neck running into something. Bisecting it is a thin line of advancing decay, and all that's left of it on the other side is just bone.

"You took that transition over the course of a couple minutes," our Afterlife chaperon says. "That's why you could take it. Up there, across that dome — the whole transition takes place across a breadth no wider than a finger."
I look behind me. The next cadets approach no faster, still as statues in the corridor.
"Then how did it snap its neck? There's nothing up there."

"It went from a speed out there to the speed in here, he says. I look closer at the head, flattened like the top of a mushroom, as if the impact happened inside itself. "From a second per second to roughly seven seconds per second. That's all it took."

We all find ourselves looking up towards the great mechanical wheels at the center of the dome: six concentric ones, the smallest one spinning so fast its just a blur. Each, in turn, spins slower and slower, until the outermost ring rotates about once a minute.

"Let this be a lesson as to why you don't jump down the pit, there," he says. "Only transition slowly. Or else the effects of dilation will flatten you, and you'll crush inwards on yourself. You're much better as a resource."
The nauseous cadets collect themselves and wipe their mouths, and after they regain their footing, the Chymaeran takes us to a room filled with white-and-red garments.

"I want each of you to take three sets of clothing. It will be all you'll have," he says, and so we filter through stacks of the garments. Most of them are tattered and aged, splotched with long-dried blood in some places, so old that the smell died with it. Others disintegrate to dust when I touch them. I pull three from the stack that look remotely clean and rejoin the group as he goads us down towards the bottom.

Jarrett pulls his fireteam aside and mutters to them, motioning for me to come over. "We can all make it out of here. I don't know where they're taking us, but there will be blood. And we know we're the strongest group out of all of them."
"But what happens when we have to face each other?" Delvin asks. "You know where this is going! Any other luck and I would have had to face one of you," he says.
"But we're too valuable to them, and they know it," Jarrett says. "They won't waste us because we're limited."

We change into our new clothes, indifferentiable from each other. Somewhere across the way, the vast majority of the cadets that came here wear black: even with the darkness of the fabric, I can tell there is no blood splotched on them. Their task is something different, though ours is certain.

All our possessions are removed next. The only thing that matters to me is people, and all the ones I care about have been torn from me, so I don't put up a fight like Vera, who insists on keeping some gift from her sister.
"You won't be needing it," an Afterlife guard says.

I relinquish my obsidian necklace. It will be of no use to me anymore. The bright memory it carries is branded inside me, along with all the faces, along with the mission whose insidious demands I'll force myself to meet. All that we're left with is the most elementary commodities to scrape our last days or months of survival — before we're fed to the great machine of the Afterlife, churning hapless youth into the Essence they need to build a false throne of the Gods.

Somewhere beyond this place, the snow hangs stagnant in the air. The Backwoods of the First Red returns to eternal winter, the thousand dead reduced to Frosthards. Even further out there, Endogeny eviscerates the innocent civilians.  A lift erupts in flames on the mountainside from Carmine intervention, not crushing the bastard daughter beneath because she was murdered too early. And above, the Afterlife celebrate the dawn of a new age, ignorant to the weight of all their actions, so focused on the light of a new Golden Age they'll destroy anything that obstructs them.

This place wasn't erected as a prison two-hundred years ago. All the ancient farming tools tell a different story of why it came to exist: purposed as a tool for infinite, bountiful harvests beyond comprehension, feeding the masses of this frozen landscape for generations. Each level is unfathomably tall and wide, spanning so high it's impossible to tell the ceiling, each floor latticed with an intricate maze of patterned walls and rooms that act as structural supports for the great openings of grass fields.

There are three great columns of light stretching from freedom to the bottomless depths below: the dome we saw was only the tip of one of them. We've counted fifty-three sleeps in lieu of days, and looking up from the second level to the sky above, it took twenty-five of them before the sun crossed the sky.

I hardly talk to Vera's fireteam. I only talk when I have to. They spend most of their time reminiscing between tending the fields and busy work. I spent a week of free time watching a single bird cross the span of the dome — the only fortunate feature of this dungeon being the boundless harvests of produce from the lower floors.

We all know we're being fattened up for the harvest. The food we produce is sent back on the trains to the main city as feed for the rest of the civilians, so much that it's almost impossible to store. On the level above, it'd be a year before another train of cadets arrived. Down here, Isla told us it would be another thirteen YEARS — just enough time for the tens of thousands of cadets to be processed here for the next batch. She uncovered the nature of this dungeon in a couple days from just water droplets. She ran the math in her head of how long it took them to fall, with some geometric math of how high the ceiling is.

The time of the floors below are unknown to us. At least for Isla's experiment, the raindrops accelerate and flatten so quickly that it's impossible to tell. Isla says that at a constant rate, the ones below us would live ten days for every one of ours, and if there's anything below that, roughly one-hundred-and-thirty days per day for them.

All we know is that cadets keep disappearing. All I can manage to guess is that nearly ten thousand are on this floor, but every week we've been here, it's been enough to notice, and it always happens at the same time.

If you stand near the exact center of the three empty columns and hold your breath, hoping the silence is enough to coax out the faintest sound, some cadets swear you hear clashing metal somewhere high above, so slow and faded like a bow drawn against strings. But the mysteries of this place don't matter me. I've been trying to steel myself for something I know is coming. I don't want to make better friends with any of them or else it will be harder. And after the endless stretches of exhausting labor, the only place I find myself is back in the room of a hundred bunk beds, guarding the few possessions I've accumulated in my time here.

The only thing I have space for is the words of the ones I betrayed. All the insanity of living and dying feels like a distant anecdote because it only lasted for two weeks of continuous time, and the threads on my wrist are the only proof of it, or else I'd believe again that death was permanent.

The same day they called us to 'Victory Row' was the same day the moon crossed the dome's threshold. We were grouped together by the train we came on: all of us the self-proclaimed 'strong' with untenable beards and longer hair. It mystifies me how Vera still preserves most of her appearance: I guess that, to her, it is all she has left to obsess over.
"Your time has come. I hope you've all trained well," our same chaperon tells us. He's far older now, telling us he's been a level lower this whole time.
I ask him about his age, and he shakes his head.
He says, "You might think we're the ones in power here. But all of us, captor or slave, are just pawns for the Afterlife."

I haven't seen Vera, Isla, or Jarrett in ages: they've mostly kept to themselves. For so long, Vera thought her sister was still alive from what I told her, that "they're all waiting," and after she realized the hollowness of my words, she refused to speak to me since.

"Two-hundred-and-fifty-six of you will enter," he says. "Most of you will lose your lives to the people next to you. But the few that persist will be the greatest champions of the Afterlife, earning your place among our ranks. This is why we raise the greatest soldiers in this entire world, the most fearsome force against all the other races. Because they're not only the best of their class: they're the best of the one percent of the one percent, hardened through learned bloodlust and vicious carnage, untouchable by any force of nature."
He points to the levels below.
"You probably still wonder what happened to the ones that said they were weak that first day. They outnumbered all of you. That detail probably slipped your mind, didn't it?"
Several of us nod.

"They were the ones that kept you, our most valuable resource, alive and fed, so that you wouldn't succumb to the diseases and starvation that killed the majority of them. They keep the city of Blackwater fed, so that the civilians can raise new cadets to take their place. You are all the losers: producers or fighters, the weakest class, but the civilians are the victors of the Academy, the top third, the ones whose blood and intellect was great enough to keep them at the top, the genes we need. And you," he says: "you are just the dirt we pan for specks of fools' gold."

Every time I shut my eyes to sleep I'm there again, and even in the face of peril, my mind refuses me a dream of peace and comfort, inching closer and closer to that unspeakable end I wrought upon them, thinking I could go back at whatever cost.

I'm not like them, and I will never be: the way the Afterlife indiscriminately kill to preserve their dream of a Golden Age, because my vision is real, and I can feel it waiting there on the other side.

How much I've given to get to this point. My guilt is just a natural flaw that holds me from that path, and the more I forget that feeling of unity, the closer I get to that certainty I can make it to the end.

I dream of that windowsill, how many hours I spent waiting there, and anytime I sit in the silent echoes of the prison cells, I clearly remember that moment the anguish of failure finally suffocated that fear of evil.

I looked at the girl sleeping next to me until she became a stranger, until I felt the truth that I was born a sacrifice, that I could field their hate and loathing forever if it meant they could be truly free.

And so I left the windowsill open, thinking she was asleep when I snuck between the buildings, unaware that I cast a silent shadow. I made the decision to act so I didn't have to later, and it made it easy: almost as easy as how defenseless the entire village was against itself.
But the memory always ends when I reach that unlocked door, when her voice picks up and stirs all the people awake, how angry I was with her that she held to that dream of another life with me.
But I did what I had to.

The cells on the second floor are shoddy. I can tell how ephemeral each cadet's stay was from the names etched into the walls as the last fading testaments that they were here. Paper scrawled in ink with last messages and poems, requests for messages to carry by those that survive. Several are names I recognized from roll call in the vast expanse below, but I'm just shocked how many of them there are.

I nurse my headache from the time dilation before I lift the ink pen from the table. So many personalities scrawled on all these pages: blocks of misspelled words in short sentences of messy letters; others with perfect, arcing cursive; some with pictures or jokes; others as replies to past prisoners that have already lost.

Dear Sylvia, I write, but then I find myself staring at the vacant space beneath, waiting for my call with no answer. There's so much I didn't tell her when I had the chance, so many things this meager corner of a page couldn't hold. Maybe today I'll die, or tomorrow, and fate will drag me right back here again to the same blank corner to write it all again, or to stare at it, to either drown in the guilt of how I left them or count how many chances I wasted in expressing myself to her.
My head sinks to the desk. My soul is exhausted when all I do is preoccupy myself with busy work — just like I always have.
A knock saves me from all that history catching up to me: it rattles on the large steel door, and a latch beneath it opens.
Strange, I think to myself. They already fed us. I expect a silver tray to stick through the metal slat, but it's something else.
The visitor has manicured nails, nothing like that of any guard's—who would take the time to style themselves when all there is to do is dig and age?
"Who's there?" I ask.
But before I can approach or catch a glimpse, the latch slams and I hear footfalls of the visitor running away.

I look down at the floor, and in the dim light I find a single slip of crumpled paper. I pull it at the edges, trying to discern the scrawlings written on both sides, and so I lift it towards the ambient light of the corridor.
There was little space to write anything, even narrower than that corner of a page I gave up on.The writing is deep purple and so neat it looks as if it were torn from a newspaper.
I read the first side.
"YOU NEVER GAVE UP," it says.
And then I flip to the other side.
"STAY ALIVE FOR ME."
But that's all the stranger could manage.
All I can imagine is that it's a mistake.
I gave up on everyone.
So I re-crumple the note and throw it back in the hall before sprawling on the sheets of the small bed, my feet hanging over the sides, the sheets more sordid and rotten than the ones at my loft.
All I can focus on now is preparing myself. And when the three hours passes, when the door unlocks and I'm brought to the first trial, I tell myself that I'm ready.
Dear Sylvia, the page reads. You were wrong.

"Decisiveness is a virtue. Only when you fully commit to anything, can you operate at your best. When you prioritize something, a people, your own life over others. Because when you hesitate, or when you make allowances for the weak, you both will die."
They blind our eyes with cloth so the words will carry resonance. To many they will fall on deaf ears. But to me, they speak the highest truth.

The only other sense I have is the coldness of my calloused feet on the ground, stripped of shoes just like all the others, and I can hear their footsteps in the jagged stone hall. At one point they counted us off in twos and divided us. When Isla figured out she was behind me, she tried calling my name to get my attention.
It was a relief when they took her away.

The turbulent draft of air grows stronger as we march through the caves. It's how I can tell we're getting closer to one of the three hollow columns. I hear the rapid clattering of tools somewhere distant, high-pitched and fast like rusted fan blades, rasping shouts and voices as quick and indiscernible as mice feeding on scraps.

It's remarkable how quickly the lower Cadets that called themselves strong adjusted to this place — even Vera and her fireteam. They built relationships with each other, and those friendships made them weak. That's why now they regress to that same level of panic. The fools built something again they knew they would have to lose, and now that the Afterlife comes to collect on their promise, they shiver and tremble, chattering the chains that bind their wrists behind them, voices wavering, calling the names of allies and estranged loved ones for comfort: people they know they'll never see again.
It's then that I hear a word, softly, inches away from my ear.
"Titus."
I nearly jump out of my skin.
"Hang in there just a little while longer," a woman says.

I try to trace back the voice, but my eyes are covered, and the hallway gets darker as we walk through the last stretch. I never saw the full extent of what I wrought upon the Backwoods, only glimpses of the aftermath when the Afterlife apprehended me.

Could it be Sylvia? No. Impossible. And not Lyra either, though this voice carries the same softness of both of theirs. Maybe I forgot its texture after all these weeks. Maybe they ended up with me, coming from a different train car, maybe they got over it all, maybe they understood—
"Use the thread. I can get you back," she insists. It catches me off guard, and when I about-face, the guards are quick to bash me back into rank.
There are few people I told this truth to, and most of them are dead.

"Sylvia? Is that you?" I ask. I feel an excitement rise in my chest—I can't remember the last time I spoke her name. But as soon as I catch myself in that moment of vulnerable sincerity, I remember the torturous hell of whatever trial awaits, and re-galvanize myself against it.
We stop when I run into the person in front of me. The wind whistles in my ears. My stomach drops, and I smell the burning of something living.

"Decisiveness, as I said," the voice says. "The ability to take action without hesitation. You will be tested on this today, whether you can prioritize strength over weakness. The losers will be mulch in the lowest gardens. Your flesh will rot to bone before the next round even begins!"

I'm near the front of the line. Through the pinhole lights I can guess four people in front of me. The smell of burning grows stronger: the same stench from the burning trade building, and the more I focus on that horrible odor, the more I have to fight to keep myself from losing it to that future memory of ash and soot; that promise of oblivion that forever hangs over my head.
"All you have to do is make it across."
I breathe deeper. I meditate on that vision I'll earn at any cost, and I tense my weakened muscles in my cadaverous form.
I hear curses of two cadets as they yelp from some sudden pain.
It has begun.
"No, no . . ."

Something sizzles like a dry scalding pan catching drops of water: one-two, one-two, as two smudges converge at full speed. Hesitating, they slow down as they approach, to the dismay of all the unblinded guards. I hear screams when they stop. The sizzling grows louder after the twelve seconds have passed, and when I hear the two cadets collide in to each other, wavering before they collapse without the balance of their bound hands, they fall headlong into oblivion, their voices high and shrill before they disappear into eternity.
"Next!"

Two more rush, and as I approach, I find I can see them easier, backlit by tendrils of moonlight and electric lamps. The nearest cadet shouts with all he has, drowning himself out of any chance of hesitation. On the far side, the other cadet stalls, but once their feet scald on the metal beam, they're forced to move without anywhere to go, jumping off the beam to hang on the side.

The closest cadet makes it to the other side without a hitch. I hear the sound of anguish when the fallen tries to left herself, only for the metal to burn her hands and cast her to the bottom along with the other two.

All that separates me from the start is one challenger. I step down as I approach into a puddle of cold water. I'm still trying to get myself to that edge. I meant to drive that knife several weeks ago. It was my intention to kill. I've changed. I'm nothing like I was, and ever since that point I threw the hatch to leave my two closest friends to die, I've been changed forever.

Another scream. I feel fingers fondle the knotted fabric of the blindfold. My stomach drops. I can feel the radiant heat of the beam, and I can't turn around no matter how much my instinct pleads me to.
"Next!"
I'm already moving before the sensation of light returns to my eyes: feet wet, like walking in coals as they sizzle in the heat, scalding that thin layer of protection.
Thirty yards and I'll be there. I can't look into the eyes of the person across from me: all I can do is go lowest, drive straight, and hope I buck them from the rail.

My breaths are heaving, and my mind obsesses over how my steps pattern with them. Left. Right. In a straight line, no room for failure or else the timeless void will crush me before I reach the bottom.
Eight steps now. My feet start to burn so I clamber on my heel and toe. I can feel the other person getting closer, driving just as fast as I do, when in a breathless shout, I hear them.
"Titus!"

It's Delvin. The skin-and-bone redhead cadet that died to Endogeny in the last life; the one that tried to take Sylvia and get further with me; the pathetic runt weaker than she is. I load up all the anger: the jokes I heard he made about me and my restless fight to get to the top of the class, calling me a "shut-in workaholic" while Sylvia stood beside me. How angry I was, though I said nothing. Thinking he and his fireteam are better than us because of their rank when he contributes nothing to them, just drags them down. This world doesn't need him. I can remove him and nobody would notice. He deserves to—
"Duck!"

Step seventeen is on my left foot. I bend down, and it's just in time for my dominant leg to push with the last ounce of fleeting strength my emaciated muscles can muster. My body is so light. I float through the air, high enough that I can almost feel time's deceleration when Delvin ducks beneath me.

I realize the source of that voice when I cork halfway through the air, flipping sideways with my hands bound behind me. My head twists forward to continue on that same straight rush; my long, overgrown hair bobbing between my eyes before it springs back like my legs; my feet begrudgingly accepting the heat of the beam when they return.
The guards guffaw. I thought they'd be angry at my moment of weakness—cast me from the beam, but all that matters is that they're amused.

I arrive on the other side, and turn around once it's safe to do so. Delvin meets my gaze and offers the slightest nod before continuing into the shadow of the tunnel. I see a hundred or so blindfolded cadets all waiting for their fate, knowing less than half of them will emerge from the shouts alone.
They push me forward as the next commencing shout reverberates. There is no comment or celebration, just the dwindling of fighters that trained their whole lives to throw it away in a pathetic game.
Somewhere my watcher witnessed everything. They told me to hold on no matter the cost but I cheated that, and despite saving threads on my recyclable life, I feel disappointed.
They return me to my holding cell. I commit the full scope of the snaking corridors to memory before they lock me away, though I know there's nothing I'll do.

On the desk sets a bountiful meal and a single apple. A tent card faces the caged window, overlooking another vacant column of air. I turn it around and read its scrawlings in the dim light, expecting it to be from my watcher, but the text is printed.
WELCOME FIREBRAND! CONGRATS ON YOUR SURVIVAL.

There's far less noise in the adjacent cells when I close my eyes to sleep, but across the hollow column I can hear sobbing of remorseful firebrands. Beyond this cell, I can make out the faintest, almond-shaped sliver of night sky, and I tell myself the bright colors of dawn are just hidden by the edges.
I trace my fingers across the threads of my wrist. How many more times will it take to be free? Is this privilege limited? And if so, can I see my loved ones again without having to return?
The cot is firm, but the static of exhaustion still rings in my ears.
My mind blesses me with a kind dream this time, and reality dissolves in the space between sleeping and waking.

I hallucinate her voice. "If you take a nap now, you're not going to be able to fall asleep at darktime, Tie," her voice says, smooth as silk. "Do you still want to meet Dad and Grandpa 'Ev at the park?"
"Where's Dad?" My voice is small.
"He's still on patrol — but if we don't catch him before he walks back, he'll come home and get all tired," Moira says. "What's wrong? Why are you crying?"
"It was terrible! They took Ellie, and everyone died, and I was all all alone at the end," I tell her.
"That was just a dream," she says.

"But it all happened! I know it did. You died, and Everett killed you. He left you in the basement of the storehouse!" Her expression remains perfectly still. How horrifying Chymaerans are when they portray their host. "It's not really you."

"It's so much more complicated than that," Moira says, "but I was forced into a role I didn't want to steal. That decision was made for me. But that doesn't change the fact I love you. In fact, by the time I had Ellie, I had already been your mother longer than she ever was."
"Where did you go?" I ask. "What caused you to leave us, was it Clint that night?"

"We're going to see them. And then you'll know everything. I know you've waited so long, suffered over and over and over again, but you need to hang on just a little bit longer. But she's coming. And she'll take you to all of us."

I feel her hand cup the side of my face. The last sensation I feel of her is the coldness of her fingers as that touch dissolves away, and I'm ripped awake on light sleep when something clatters on the floor in front of me.

The first colors of dawn are fixed in the almond-shaped sliver of sky, and orange radiates on every surface the sluggish sun shimmers. I reach for covers to throw aside, but the surface I sleep on is bare, and the left side of my face is cold from sweat.
Still half in that dream world, I squint my eyes and look at the floor, finding something black and reflective right in front of the steel door. I drop my cold feet to the floor and stumble forward.
The amethyst crystal faintly glows when I raise it, and I feel the energy of something calling to me. A scrap of paper is coupled to my necklace by the pendant's chain.
"WE WILL MEET AGAIN AT THE END," it reads, and when I finally realize the source of these messages, I realize I was a fool to think it could have been anyone I knew.

I return the necklace to its rightful place around my neck, motivation for what I have to make it home to. But that past life shows me I just might have a chance if I can defeat the sender — my watcher — waiting to challenge me after I lost our skirmish beyond the train car. The Heiress of Purgatory is flooded by the Essence of the cadets she kills, the great beast of the Afterlife, the future weapon that will bring Blackwater to its fated end.

And if I can kill them, absorbing their Essence before the Afterlife can obliterate me — then Gods know how far back I can ride the thread, maybe all the way to the beginning of everything. I just need the courage to do whatever it takes, because the next time I'll have no chance to cheat or hesitate.

They don't waste any time keeping us in the cells. We're a commodity in mass-production, pinions in the gears of this great machine; so many to process with so little that last the eternal day. And so they force us from our cells to the next challenge, without a blindfold to cover our eyes, led through a new series of twists and turns to meet at the heart of the second floor: an arena adorned with rocks and uneven terrain.

They do nothing to mask the bright crimson colors from skirmishes long past. All the rocks light enough to lift are emblazoned with dried red. Instruments of war shimmer in the eternal dawn, where their cracks and scratches speak to decades of continuous abuse.
"Form two lines," he instructs, and the firebrands swarm into two ranks: scrambling for the back, opposing the rush of any dining hall where they fought for first meal.

I'm pushed to the front again, but all I want is just to get this over with before I lose that edge. I'm too distracted with holding that mental toughness to recognize the firebrand that stands beside me, stripped of that pompous appearance granted to her by wealth and royalty. And when we realize our equal standing in both lines that approach the battlefield, she refuses to accept my camaraderie.
"Get over it, Vera," I tell her. "We don't get a say here."
"Then why didn't you tell me? You had me believe for weeks that she was still here, not dead somewhere on the streets of Blackwater!"
I'd apologize if it meant anything.
"Why, Titus? Just tell me!"

"You couldn't handle the truth of what happened to her. You can't even handle your part in it," I say. "She killed herself, alright? For absolutely nothing. Because your family made her think that's what she was worth!"

"I was the only one that reached out to her, out of all of them," Vera says. "Vanna and Virgil are far too young to understand what makes her different in their parents' eyes. You know I'm the reason she's still on the estate, did she tell you that? Or have you just decided that I'm the source of all her pain?"
The first round of Firebrands skirmishes in front of us. Two more pairs shiver in anticipation. "You should have been on that lift. But you didn't this time. Why didn't you go?"

"I couldn't leave things as they were. And that dragged all the rest of my fireteam into this mess," she says. "I don't know how you know about the lift, what you mean by 'this time,' but she was supposed to board with us, and I'm the reason she was still on the list. I would never leave my sister to die, regardless of how much my mother Victoria hates her, believe me," she says.

"All the fame and recognition. The top of her class, the star of Blackwater, and yet she died still trying to prove the value of the name she created," I tell her. "Sylvia was wrong. This isn't a reality where any of us deserve to suffer. I can't accept any of this. And we need to survive no matter what it takes."
The next group is pushed into the crucible with nothing, told to scrounge for the tools that will grant them their survival.
"Do you really think you can bring yourself to do it? I saw what happened in the train car, but, you know—"
"I can do it," I tell her.
"And if it's Delvin? Or Isla? Or Jarrett? Then what makes us deserve to live over them?"
"Whoever clings to life the tightest wins. Whoever can persuade themselves of the most unshakable reason to survive will find that last strength when they need it."
"And you think you have that," she says.
"I have that more than anyone here. Because I still have hope. I know that I can save us. And I'm not afraid of dying for that." I can convince myself if I commit it to words.
"Everybody is already dead," she says. She bows her head. "My sister. The whole rest of your fireteam. And Gods know if the others are alive. What's left for any of us when everything is gone?"
"Whatever we can scrape from what remains."

We toe the line when the next pair leaves, realizing it's impossible to see the other side of the arena, besides the great wall marking its border two hundred yards out. Above us is another grand window to the sky, where continuous dawn radiates the rugged terrain in a thin orange haze, casting just enough light to shimmer the instruments of war strewn about the field.
My mind already spins the workings of a plan.
"Divide and conquer," I say. "We outmatch all of the cadets here. We have a solid shot here, Val, just don't lose your—"
"Val?" She asks.
"Vera. Sorry. Just don't lose that edge," I say.
From between the rocks, a single cadet emerges triumphant, grimaced with an expression of emotional exhaustion.

"Four went out, and one returns," says the guard tending the gates. The survivor has bruises all up their neck, eyes bloodshot, hands trembling as they shamble past the gate. "Whatever you can find is a tool to get the upper hand. This is not about just having the courage to kill anymore. It's about plotting and following through."

We step in front of our usher, waiting for the moment of deliverance to come. He raises his arm and fires a flare into the air. The surge of anxious energy is electric, riding the nerves from my core into every extremity, charged with such energy it's unbearable to keep it inside.

The furthest flare blasts. Motion fires all my frail limbs at once, so starved from sedentary stillness that my feet tear the thin grass in tufts of dormant tan. I scan the ground for anything that can aid me: I was trained in everything they'd teach me, far more than all these other frail firebrands.

I don't let the anticipation of the cadets on the other side to shake me from my focus. So many bloodied rocks are scattered with a signature stain on each of them, and in the shale sand, several broken blades of the cheapest metal crumple to age and wear.

All the good weapons are surely in the center, brought by every poor bastard that failed to use them well. I split right as Vera hangs left, hoping to find anything as I scrounge between the rocks. There's a pole-axe splintered in half, too top-heavy to drive it at anything and not lose it, but I grab it anyway, because if I can have any weapon whose iron isn't the quotient of spilt blood, it puts me high above fisticuffs and rocks.

It hangs uncomfortably in my white-knuckle grasp, holding an arm's-length of shaft at its jagged end. The eye of the metallic head wobbles at its shoulder, enough for no more than a single swing, but I'm more afraid of that moral anxiety that made me hesitate in the train car, and as I approach the center of the long-abandoned growing chamber, I grow leery in the absence of conflict.

I spend a moment longer nestled in a burrow of rocks, holding my breath as I take in the faintest whispers in the air, but all I hear is the distant clatter of tools. Anticipation is half the mental battle, but too much of it leads to sloth, and the longer I wait for the signal of anything, the greater that voice of conspiracy rises.

Unable to wait any longer, I shamble to the top of the outcropping to take a higher view. Guns would be too quick a weapon for what they're trying to test here, and take too much maintenance to last any relative year. Bows would run out of arrows in an instant—Gods know how long Sylvia spent fletching for perfection only to use it for practice.

From the top I see both ends of the arena, but all I can see is entirely vacant. The next two pairs of cadets look on in fervent anticipation. I squint to follow their eyes, and they glare to that passage that Vera went down.
Alone they'd be no match for one of us, but together, with the right strategy, they could wipe either one of us out.

I steady both hands on the unpolished metal axe as I approach the space where they wait, knowing this is now a battle of who dares the most, and if they've already dared to split her skull before she could shout my name, they'll stop at nothing to send me to the Reservoir.
In a moment of distraction, my right foot slips on a bundle of rocks. It's too late to react, and before I can regain my footing I slide with them.
"Got you, fucker!"
My hands raise the axe before I can react. It's not a voice I recognize: the bastards have been hiding out here the whole time.

Vera's body is unceremoniously sprawled right in the center, and I'm sure they left it there to dishearten me. They bludgeoned her head in before she could shout for help, crumpled on the ground like her sister as nothing but a bloody mess. Dragon Class or not, she stood no chance.
The rockslide makes the ground fluid like slipping on oil.

"You stupid vagrant, you should have frozen with the rest of your kind in the outer walls," he says, before taking a swing at my head. I manage to lift the axe head, but as soon as the shoddy sword sparks against the steel, I lose my grasp and the face of it clocks me in the head.
Disoriented but finally free, I stumble to my feet.
"Where's your damn friend?" I ask.

"Above," he says, and once he points up, a full-size boulder crashes at my feet. It clips my toes. I screech with pain as it binds me to the center, crunching the bones of my feet as I stumble with my last good leg. All I have is the head of the axe, and I hold it awkwardly by the eye without the wooden neck.
"Just give up," they say.

"Not a chance." Trapped by the rock, the loose cartilage of my foot crunches like red-hot sand as I find my balance, but my adrenaline is too high to feel it: that's a debt of pain I take from my future self if I ever make it through this.
The first one makes a predictable high swing as the other scans for another rock: pinned like a dissected frog I have nowhere to go but face the lone firebrand head-on.

I dodge the blade of the rusted sword. He falters after expecting it to fully connect, and in his moment of vulnerability I feel myself hesitate when I remember all the bodies of the First Red; the chaos I created; the scope of devastation I never had the chance to assess.
The opportunity passes. Before I can retaliate another earthen mass crunches my skull, and I lay there helpless as my adversaries relish in their victory.

Dazed and furious, sprawled alongside Vera, I watch as they spare no mercy on us. "If you weren't so goddamn green, you'd have a chance," he says, before spitting down on me. He raises his boot, and I'm dragged backwards once more before he can stomp my head in.

This time I can feel how saturated my circuits are with Essence, and before that tensile force can drag me any further into the countless hours I spent alone in my cell, I reach out with all the spiteful anger and regret I have, grappling for that limbic connection to return to the moments before I gave in to that pathetic sense of restraint.

My mind pulses when the splintered pole-axe slips from my hands. The tendrils of my conscious mind from moments later reach deep in this frail vessel as they puppeteer another lace of thread, and as my awareness overwrites every cell of my past failure, faster than the brain sends signals to the muscles, I dash directly for that outcropping, praying to whatever God or Goddess that grants me this thread that I'm not too late.

My bare feet and hands scrape, stub, and slice on every sharp edge that can pull me there closer, and I no longer care about all the sound I make. In my future memory they laugh at me in my dying moments. Every breath wasted running is another chance for them to ambush her. I don't want to care about her, but there's this primal rage of humiliation and defeat that exhausts every ounce of life from my shambling corpse, and I can feel my circuits light with that otherworldly energy providing power where there is none.

There's a sound of scraping rock for a moment like chalk dragged on its edge, and I realize I've found the first one. I glance from higher and see all three of them, right as Vera spots the lower cadet, mistaken that he's acting alone and defenseless. She could eviscerate them in swordplay, as I've learned from years of facing their fireteam—but there are no tactics to stop a chunk of stone that plummets from the sky.
The actor draws back in fear towards the ambush. These firebrands are so used to weakness  at the bottom of their ranks that his expression is flawless, and Lyra wholly buys it.
She raises a dagger she found nestled somewhere in the rocks. "This is nothing personal," she says.

The cadet with the stone is dumbfounded at the success of their plan, and struggles as he raises it to the ledge. It will be the last thought he has as I rush at him: with his hands full, he has no chance to react.

My whole body is just a vehicle for that white-hot fury to act on its own. I don't just want them to die, but I want them to suffer, and so when I drive the mass from the cadet's hands, I body him into the pit with my shoulder. He falls flat on the same surface Lyra's thoughts were splattered on, concussed from the shock of his head crashing against the asymmetries of the rock. It's the perfect crushing face.
Though my arms have withered to little more than emaciated lean muscle, I'm able to lift the same stone with ease.
Vera draws back when she recognizes the cadets' crafty ploy. Before she reaps retribution, I cast the stone from atop the ledge, ensuring I don't make the same mistake that they did.

The loud crunch is satisfying in that brief moment. Sprawled in his back, the cadet panics when he realizes he can no longer move his legs, and both the adversaries below watch in disbelief. Lungs crushed, he has no breath to scream, only a mind to process the useless pain he can no longer resist.

My anger is as blind as that endless injustice I suffered, and with their lives, I will paint my surroundings with their entrails until every debt has been repaid. I heave another rock, and another, until every hard part of the flesh puppet below is liquefied from the trauma, and when the unspeakable horror moves the two cadets below so far that they tremble, I join them.

The other cadet brandishes a feeble knife that couldn't cut spiderwebs, and when he lunges, all that persists in my mind is that last sight of him smiling, triumphant, calling me weak as he spits on me.

He tries another jab, but he's too slow. I've been trained as a killer and I no longer hesitate. Grasping his arm, I twist and punch beneath his shoulder in a space that shatters his ribcage. He still manages to hold the knife in a death grip, and slices again off-balance, managing to connect with my arm.
I bash again at his ribs. I tension my fingers in his hair though he still refuses to let go.
"Die, fucker!" He manages, and right as he tries to strike me again, another dagger digs deep into his neck.

Vera stands beside me, her eyes wet, gasping for breath as she wipes the residue of the last cadet off her uniform. But as the loser chortles away on the last wet breaths of life, I refuse to waste it.

I can tell he's dead when his weak trail of Essence flows in to me, but that doesn't matter. He goes limp when I bash his head against the jagged wall, again and again and again, until none of his pathetic shit-eating grin is left to taunt me, just a gaping hole.
I take the knife from the ground because there's still more canvas to paint.
"Titus, stop this! It's over," Vera pleads.

But my hands are moving on their own, carving this cadaver whose soul departed moments ago. Stabbing, and stabbing, and stabbing, until there's no blood left to drain, until I'm blue in the face and feel so much worse than when I started.

I fall to my knees though my eyes refuse me tears. I can feel the pulse of the life still in my veins. Vera extends a wet hand to lift me, and so I let her, limping across the battlefield as the Afterlife come to collect their mulch for the lower gardens.

We don't speak another word as she drags me, tugging at the arm I've extended around her shoulders. My hands tremble from shock, and when the adrenaline fades, all I'm left with is the price that all those acts of violence cost.
