She drops me at the entrance, too disgusted to turn around and watch.  They drag me off to my cell where another meal waits, another place card of congratulations telling me I'm one step closer to the end.
I refuse to eat that night.

The Afterlife heals my wounds with a small transfer of Essence to the parted flesh. I've proved myself as a valuable asset with a chance. I've done everything I had to in order to survive, and now that I've crossed this line, nothing can hold me back from returning to claim my perfect end.
I had no choice.
They would kill me if I didn't kill them first.
I had to send a message.
I had to prove that I was valuable, and if Vera couldn't do it, I had to step in and do it myself.
They'd crush and humiliate me the same way.
Or it was an accident that I ended up here in the first place.
I was forced into this.
I never meant to kill, what else could I do? Would I rather be dead with the rest of them, or have a chance to live?

It was only a day between the first and second trial, but now around two sleepless days have passed since they returned me here. All I have left is just my imagination to fill the spaces between these dreamless hours. I'm unable to obey the cycle my biology demands when the sky still glows with that same color of dawn.

Do you really want this anymore? I ask myself. Is it worth it? Because ever since the second meal passed beneath the door uneaten, my dreamless fantasies have spilled over into the waking world. My past self would shun the miscreant that shutters reality, basking in their own internal paradise, but for once I've earned this. Maybe Sylvia was right to tell me there was nothing else out there, because it was blank and unfulfilling, just a myth I told myself to suffer on.

There's only so much a person can take, I thought at some point down the line. And I was right. Because now when I stare at the ceiling, I see the same shapes I found in the cracks at my Academy loft, and I'm home.

Somewhere beyond the Academy towers, the midday Sun melts all the snow from the ground. My room is furnished: Clint and Moira helped me decorate it when I first arrived here, and loving scribbles from my younger sister decorate the walls in place of paintings.
I was never alone. Because there's been someone alongside me this whole way.

"I want you to know that I'm always watching you, ever since the orphanage, ever since you saved me from it," she says. "And I forgive you for what you've done, Titus. Shouldn't effort always equate to love? Shouldn't you only ever be expected to try, just to participate, to accept the end whether or not you succeed?"
"I guess," I tell her. If I really want it, I can see her there, and I want it. She glows with the same colors of the Goddess I witnessed moments before I lost her.
"You're safe here, Titus," she says. "You can let go now. You tried, and that's all that should matter."

I rest my head on her shoulder and she brushes my hair with her fingers. I can feel her. She's really there, sitting next to me, the refuge I've sought since the beginning though I hadn't the words to ask.
"It's you. It's you and it's always been," I repeat. It keeps her here. I tremble at the thought that it's my own fingers pulling the surly tangles from my hair.
"That's right."
"But I left you! I gave up on everything we could have had," I tell her.
She doesn't answer.

My arms tension further around my scrawny, naked body, unable to wear the bloodstained trousers without rolling the edges up or else they won't fit. My hunger makes it so hard to hold on. Nothing stays in my stomach. And when my head dips in my lap, after I make myself small in the corner of the room, I hear the door open.

Someone enters wearing thick boots, but I refuse to acknowledge another guard telling me to eat. It's just my imagination. The pangs of hunger are preferable to all the other thoughts fighting for the forefront of my mind, giving me the pained solace of one-pointedness, keeping me on the edge of a pit that has no bottom.

I won't let myself feel the guilt of giving up. I'm in the loft again, and if I close my eyes I can feel the contours of this space. The smoke is gone. Firebrands laugh somewhere in the lower rooms. There's a party for Romin. I'm gathering my things before I spend the night in the Compound, drinking  the night away in the same spaces we all played as children. Even Valentina will be there, and she never goes to the Compound.
The voice is light and soft, a mistaken Cadet in the wrong room after a drunken night out.
"It's really you," she says. I feel her shadow looming directly over me.
"You're in my room. This is private," I tell her.
"You're really here," she says.
"Of course I am," I say. "I live here."
"Do you not recognize me? Hey—why won't you look at me?" She asks.
"Get out," I demand, and I'm furious again when I feel this grasp on freedom slipping away.
"You need to listen to me. There's hardly ever a moment they're not watching. You just have to hang on—"
"Get out!"
"Quiet, Tie! Please, just listen—"
"Get out! Get out of here!" I yell, and it frightens her enough to cast her out. "I hate you! I'll kill you, I swear to the Gods, I'll fucking destroy you! Leave me alone!"

I bash my fists against the walls until they bleed. She quickly latches the door behind her when she retreats, and I'm back again, spending all the energy I don't waste to hunger painting this fragile picture before it can be shattered again.

The air is warm. The windows are open. Valentina invited us to celebrate downtown. I'm taking the gondola with Sylvia later, and she's getting ready, actually trying this time, instead of letting her damp hair hang unbrushed like she did almost every morning. I can smell the perfume Valentina gave to her that holiday. She wears the dress I picked for her. And tomorrow I'm spending the day with Clint and Moira, taking Ellie to the park where I'll teach her everything I know about the Academy because she graduates from Seminary in three days.
"Nothing can ever hurt you again," Sylvia says. I can feel her there if I want to, and I do.
"I wish I could touch you," I say.
"I know," she says. "But at this rate, you never will."

I give up on that dream for now. My shame is hard enough to resist. I shiver though my arms wrap around me, bringing neither warmth of the body or heart, knowing that without death, there is no other option.
There can only be one left at the end of this path.

"You were first evaluated for your ability to kill, Firebrands. Then for the strength of your self-preservation. Then you proved your ability to outwit the others. And now, in the final test before your truest worth is measured, just as tens of thousands have gone before you, you will prove your ability to survive as a team."

The warden pauses as she consults with her faculty. Her voice echoes so far and wide it feels ever-present. We stand at the center of another growing chamber, verdant trees and grass contrasting this one from the sparse desert of the other. People look even scrawnier when their soul is drained from them, because when I look around at the survivors on this Victory Row, I know three days couldn't wither them away this much.
I hear Isla behind me. "What happened to Jarrett, Vera? Where is he?"
"I don't know, I haven't seen him," she says.
"He was before me," says Delvin. "I caught a glimpse of him, but only his partner returned."
"We all knew the four of us wouldn't make it," Delvin says. "But I'm sure the three of us can still pull through, right?"

This arena has a makeshift sitting area from the tiered steps of growing spaces, and I'm taken aback by the number of Royal Guardsmen in the stands. It's obvious they're the officers of the Afterlife, and from the pads of paper they scribble on, I'm sure that they're recruiting.

Halfway between the entrances, along the wall of stone bleachers, is the warden of this timeless garden. To her left are the functionaries watching each floor, and to her right is the massive Chymaeran known as the Heiress of Purgatory.

"Attention, Firebrands!" Her voice fills the chamber as she raises her hands toward the fading colors of dawn. "The death of night marked the beginning of this great contest of champions. So far you've proved yourselves as something better than all the shitbloods that raised you, and just as morning fades from early colors to bright day, so too does your life have a chance to begin again."
She draws a pause as if expecting applause from her prisoners, but the only chorus of cheers comes from the spectators that have no part in this bloodshed. Every word is just formality.

"In the beginning, the lowest cadets in the Academy were nothing but living mulch, tending the gardens they would feed with their own bodies. But with the succession of Ullrich as the Grandmaster General, we reshaped the ancient growing grounds into the greatest combat powerhouse the world has ever seen."
She points to all of us.

"You are the best of the brave. The chance was offered once your proved yourself upon arrival here. And instead of being ground down for every ounce of energy you can provide—like the weak that harvest far below these levels for the rest of their lives—you have a chance to be even greater than the classes of cadets that were once better than you."
The Royal Guard surround the arena in an evenly spaced-circle.

"What began with 256 cadets, in this class, has dwindled to a mere 60. You will be building your own fireteams now for our last exam. Separate into groups of four. You have one minute to decide," she says.

Commotion rises between the survivors, and soon, the whole space is a cacophony of noise. I feel hands on my shoulder, pulling me every which way, my peers evaluating me for height and muscle though I'm average height and look even more like a vagrant.
"Get him. Titus!" Isla says. She pulls me their way, but Vera resists.
"He's a ruthless murderer," she says.
"So what? He spared my bloody-damn life," Delvin says. "Look around. Those are the only people left. Even me."
I'm apathetic to the choice, because either way I'll be forced out the end as the lone survivor.
"We're the only ones here that recognize him for his skill," Isla says, "it would be a waste."
"Now step apart and space yourselves evenly," the Warden orders.
A Royal Guardsmen approaches each circle with four different marks bunched in his hands. Isla's as quick on the uptake as I am, but the others don't get it yet.

The Warden continues. "Should you be chosen to fight in our ranks, there are many friends that will become enemies. The ones you cared for the most will remain shitbloods. They are the weak, the fodder for the cause raised like cattle, and if you refuse to see it that way, then you are useless."
The Royal Guardsmen hands me a green-colored mark. Isla gets blue. Vera gets red, and Delvin gets yellow.
"Wait, we're not together for this?" Isla panics, and Vera wears the same expression. "I can't do this. Not a chance."
Delvin says, "This is what all of this has been about. The courage to betray and the strength to separate, just like the Afterlife that betray their own race."
"You can't tell me you're buying into this?" Isla asks. "Are all of you mad?"
The Warden continues. "This game will only end when all the cadets still standing wear the same color."

Four banners drape from four equally-spaced sides, and against our collective will we're divided. I'm surrounded by strangers with green marks hanging behind them, nor a single one I recognize, and I watch every cadet eyeing another surviving friend of a different color.

There's a small room beneath each banner that once held supplies to tend the gardens, but the racks of rakes and spades have been replaced with the same shoddy weaponry from the last arena. Two-hundred-something extra marks are bunched in the back.

My teammates first fight over shields, then swords, until all that's left is just bows and arrows and daggers. I manage to grab a sword that fell behind the racks. It's in a better condition than all the rest, and when I step outside, I test its weight in a couple practice slashes.
A hand grabs my shoulder, and when I turn around, it's a taller cadet that studies my face.
"Why do you look so familiar? You're not some vagrant, you're a Firebrand, aren't you?"
It takes a moment for the realization to register: to all of us it's been more than four months since we saw the outside.

"You were the valedictorian of our class," he says. Others turn at the utterance of the word. "I'm Zane, I remember seeing you in the Compound with Romin. You were, uh . . . Tiras. No. Titus, right? Titus Berguard? How in the Gods' name did you end up here?"
The fifteen green firebrands circle around us. Zane raises his voice to the others. "It's the valedictorian, everyone! Class Four. Titus," He says.
Their faces light with some thought of salvation or relief, falling to the same desire for order those cadets at the inner walls did.
"You can lead us," he insists. "Tell us how to win."
"I'm no better than any of you are," I say.
"No, bullshit. You have to," another says. "Someone has to organize a strategy, or else we're all going to die alone."

Our makeshift squadron stands in silence. They wait for my reply, begging for some assurance of order. I peek between them at the other parties, already beginning to organize into groups. A hundred-or-so feet away to the right, Delvin stands at the center of Yellow. To the left, Vera's recognized from her secondhand fame as a commander of Red. And somewhere through the dense patch of forest, Isla reconvenes with her blue team, though I'm unsure whether all of them are leaders.
"What do we do?" Zane asks.

"There's no terrain here like the last arena. It's all flat. This isn't a battle of cunning or strategy, all they intend for this to be is just a battle of bloodshed and attrition with few survivors," I say. "They don't want us to organize. They expect that if we hold to our old alliances, we'll refuse to join the new team."
"It makes sense," says Zane.
"The only victor can ever be the one that will do whatever it takes, no matter how dirty their hands get. You will all kill without hesitation or else you are worthless," I say.
They still scan the distant colors for the faces of surviving friends, and I know it will be our downfall.

"To me, everyone I care about is already dead. But it's made me realize a truth that I knew all along, that when you strip away all the petty distractions of love and passion, we are only tools, only ever be measured by how useful we are, deserving nothing more and nothing less. We deserve nothing in this life. All we get is what we're given. Love is a hollow word for something that can never persist in such a cold place, because all we were ever made for is just to fight!"
I hope I can change their minds even if just for a second. I won't make an effort to learn their names because I'm leading them to die.
"Every man and woman is born into this world alone and dies alone. So what is commitment but an illusion if it doesn't hold at either end?"
They're beginning to accept it, just enough.

"We are alone together in this moment and we'll stop at nothing to preserve that. There is no salvation, no bright future or end for any of us but the cold peace of death that we'll reach either way. Let us be born again to the Reservoir whenever our last breath comes, but today, we'll fight with everything we have!"
A blinding flare launches towards the top of the chamber as I finish those last words, snaring in that timeless space somewhere above us like a fixed star.
"Kill them all!"
The words are mine. I've earned them.

I run behind the first cadets I goaded to the front; it wasn't hard finding the stupidly-courageous ones with tombstone courage. I learned from the best, because if Romin can lead a third of our bravest cadets to die for nothing, then I can scrape the shit from the bottom of this barrel.

I know the upper two-thirds of Academy Cadets are the leaders of battle. All they're raising here are the mindless grunts to soil their own hands. These people would all die anyways. I feel nothing when I steady the steel blade to drive into my first victim's chest. Arrows whiz overhead. The cowardly rangers have already begun their barrage, though they no nothing of how to properly aim and fire a bow and arrow.
"Keep going, all of you," I insist. "Don't hesitate, not for a moment, or else you kill all of us. Feast on their reluctance!"
For a moment all we hear is the clatter of footsteps from smudges of color between the trees. But as soon as clashing metal breaks the air, the screams of war are all that follow.

We are all instigators of coerced savagery. All that divides us now is whether we see ourselves as victims or champions. I can see it in every brutal attack and hapless defense, that difference of predator and prey only split by a thin mental line. Vicious green carves and slashes at everything because they've taken my hollow gospel to heart. It becomes so easy after the first, as if I've unlocked the full extent of all my training I received for the first time. Any skirmish on the training field stopped at first injury, but here, there is no end.

All I remember is the adrenaline-fueled blur of mindless savagery. There is no line between the reality I deserve and the penance I refuse, so I bash, slash, carve, and slice at everything that holds a pulse and stands to destroy me, regardless of death or life or the accumulating threads on my wrist, because all I persist as is just a vessel for the purpose of which I was instilled, a force of nature as definite as snow and ice with no means but a long-decided end that forever will be path-independent, as merciless as all of nature and the—
Her hands tremble when they grasp the blade. She's so small that I didn't see her when she approached behind me to put her hands on my shoulder, defenseless, not even holding a weapon.
She was never meant for combat, but she was so bright and brilliant, and I never accepted how she fell for me.
"Titus . . ." She moans, spitting blood from her lips. "What . . . have you . . ."

I look down at my steady hands that still hold the hilt, unable to believe that they're attached to me. I almost lose it, that edge, and I'm so Gods-damn close but I hold on to it, just a little bit longer.
This body was made to work, not to live. The fruitless labor of all my sacrifice has led to nothing, so I will become the sacrifice.
I meet her eyes and twist and pull, tearing her soul from her body in the same motion with all her Essence.
"You fucking bastard, Titus!" Delvin yells.
"Is this not 'what all this has been about?' Are you too weak for your words?" I ask him, because his anger makes it easier.
"All the extra marks in each room. She was trying to tell you — that there's enough marks of one color for all of us!"
"They will never let that pass. The only color we'll wear is red," I say, and in the center of the field I slash at him. "You pathetic twig, you'll never be good enough!"
"I'm everything you wish you could be," he says. Our words find air where all our training reduces everything to muscle memory.
"And what is that?"
Every opening I find he counters.
"You're brilliant but hollow, strong but so emotionally weak, and that's why you've always been holding her back."
I parry. He blocks.
He says, "Because you don't love yourself enough to give her anything, but I can."
"I watched her die," I say.
It catches him off-guard. I move for that perfect lunge, but something else stops me, something warm in my side, and I realize that someone else returned Isla's favor.
"Then I hope you never see her again, not in any afterlife," Vera says.

The steel is sharp, but my will is stronger than all of theirs together. I drive my sword behind me before my hands can give out, and with the momentum of hard contact, I spring directly for Delvin, forcing Lyra's sword between his ribs to empty him of all that disgusting self-love.
We all fall together in the center. So few cadets remain in this ring, but when I see Green approach and end the last of their fireteam's suffering with short stabs to the neck, I know we've won.

The mission is the highest form of love. This mission is sacrifice, the greatest crowning gift any living being can ever bestow. And when I meditate on all I've lost to make it this far, it's the only reason I live long enough to save this thread until the Royal Guard tend my wounds with Essence.

Among the surviving members of the Green, the Royal Guard call me the champion of Victory Row; the most vicious; their ideal candidate to fight as a grunt on the front lines. Immediately after the last challenge, the Warden demands my presence. And when I step into her office—adorned with the priceless trinkets and artifacts all her prisoners relinquished—she praises me for my ruthlessness, on a level like like "none of the other failures in this Gods-forsaken pit."

She paints me the vision of a future I've already witnessed, expecting the truth to captivate me."You're part of the last batch of Cadets being processed here, the last graduation now and forevermore," she starts. "You've proven you understand the sacrifice of self-preservation and the courage it takes: the force that keeps true Humans alive. And because of that, you are one of the few that might deserve to walk among us."

I bow my head in compliance knowing this pact is ephemeral. I can predicate her words before she speaks. All I can think of is the last step in this plan, and hope the Essence is enough to pull me all the way back. Because as sure as water finds its way to the lowest point, I will slay this abomination in any number of lives, then end myself.
"The Heiress of Purgatory is the one that will decide your worth. You know how we feel as the overseers of this program, but she has the power to  decide where you fit."
"I am honored by your consideration," I tell her.

"She will test you now," she says, gesturing to the guards to lead me down the hall. "She feeds on the Essence of all the weak and broken failures here. You will give your best or else you will join them."
"Understood," I say. "I will not disappoint you, or anyone, that trusts in my skill."

They guide me through the corridors. We pass a cart of the dead cadets being taken away to their final use. I see the unstaring eyes of Vera somewhere beneath them, but I refuse to allow my stomach to twist at the sight. This world, after all, is just the sawdust of that perfect reality, to be blown away on the winds of change.

Half a year of my life has passed, and for the first time in ages, we approach the stairs. I expect us to head up and into the stale sunlight of eternal day, but we head further down into the depths. The nausea of relativity sickens me, but I've learned to hold my breath to retain the meager scraps in my stomach. I'm half the weight I was when I walked the same set of stairs, but there's still a spark of strength in my muscles I've maintained through all of this.
"You know, Ullrich's order to switch this place to a combat zone came through only two days ago," one guard says to the other. "How long has it been for us?"
"A bloody damn eternity," the other replies.
"And only a day to process half the Cadets remaining on the lower floors. There were a hundred thousand of them, can you believe it?"
"If only they'd tell us what's coming."
The end, I think. The end of you, and the end of everything. But I keep it to myself. They know nothing of what I witnessed at the rightful fall of the First Red.

We descend from the second floor to the fourth, the deepest I've ever been. Every transition feels like sinking in molasses, as if the air were thicker, like diving deeper and deeper into a bottomless lake. Only five days of waking time have passed since I was last down here, but I'm certain it's not relativity that makes it feel longer. I can't tell a single face from the masses I spent half a year with, and when I go even deeper, the smell and sight of age and destitution only grows stronger.
"Level four, so. . . two days, times seven, times seven, times seven again . . . times ten . . . is how long?" the first guard says.
The number clicks in an instant.
"An awful long time," the other says. "Look how old these shitbloods are. We got more up top to replace 'em, right?"
Sixty nine hundred days, I think. Almost nineteen years down here, in the time the moon touches the horizon twice.
"They say it's all Ahkvasan tech from ages ago," one says.

Black cloaks drag across the sultry ground as pale phantoms tend the plants and heavily inbred livestock. Cadets in their fifties, sixties, seventies and older don't even turn to look at the relative vigor of my skin-and-bones. The concentric wheels atop the dome are so distant, but now I can see the centermost circles when they spin.

There's a blocked-off, private circle of almost two acres in the center of this edgeless floor, in the dead center of the three vacant pillars of light, right below where the last arena would be two floors above. The walls are smooth unlike the jagged, cavernous surfaces of the rest of this labyrinth.

When I enter, I feel the artificial glow of an ever-burning Essenced flame lighting the top of this space as a false sun. My eyes struggle to adjust to the ambient light, but sure enough, I know what awaits me without a second glance. At the center of it all is the harbinger of the end, and around her, the Human-and-Chymaeran  colonists from the Afterlife watching over her. Her height in full Chymaeran form now reaches the first-story eaves of the buildings. This false mortal goddess is so much stronger than I remember—flooded with such Essence that from twenty yards away, my circuits raise gooseflesh on my arms.

Her voice is ever-present and commanding."Leave us. This one is mine," I hear, and I'd be petrified looking up if my anger were any lesser. The others scatter, and I find myself ten paces away from the Heiress. Fighting her in this state would be like fighting Ryder's statue if it sprung to action and tried to wipe out a whole city block.
"All the champions of Victory Row have come and passed. Some have lived and will fight alongside me. Others have lost it all."

The half-blood Chymaeran begins to transition. Slender limbs of obsidian re-morph into the texture of flesh—and who knows if this isn't just the guise of another one of her victims. The crux of everything I loathe stands before me as a Human woman. And when the tar dissolves from her body, into garments and hair brighter than my half-year's first dawn, she stands no taller than I am.
"A thousand cycles, and you stand before me as the only one I've truly waited for all this time."
"You should have killed me when you had the chance," I tell her. "Why did you resist? Why did you purge the Chymaeran Curse?"

"Because I'm the reason you got it in the first place," she says, and I remember the last moments I witnessed. It was a smudge of black when i threw open the door to find the window ajar, the curtains dancing on frostbitten winds, and the first syllable of my sister's name before all my senses were robbed from me.
"You took her." I can't say the words without shuddering. "This whole time, having me believe the only soul I've ever cared for in this life is dead! Tell me, is she still alive?"

"You'll be meeting her soon, no matter how this ends. That Thread can only lead you to one place: you probably think you're tethered from some distant beginning. But did you ever stop to think you're being dragged towards an unavoidable end?"
"I can change everything," I say. "I'm more a God than you will ever be, Mask. Because the only future I'm tied to is draining all the Essence from your lifeless corpse!"
The stewards part before this crucible can burn any hotter, and even the guards leave us.
"You were too pathetic to save your friends — so pathetic you let them die," she says.
"Shut up."
"You betrayed them, then killed them, all for nothing, Tie."
"Shut the hell up!" My nails bite the flesh of my pallid palms as the hate magnetizes me to her, fists drawn.

She says, "And your sister? She deserved everything she got, along with that bastard father of hers. Both their deaths were long and painful." My feet scuttle faster than my muscles can handle. "But you, Titus, I'll make sure yours is—"

I feel my knuckles crack when they drive square into her chest. The shock travels up my frail bones while she hardly moves a step, and whether it's thick Chymaeran scaling or solid muscle, my hands won't tell until it's over. But she doesn't smile with a sadistic smugness. She's still watching all her handlers as if our final skirmish is just a performance.
"You fucking bitch!" I try the same hand again and coerce the answer, only to find if when the searing agony alarms all the nerves in my splintered arm.

I yelp when I withdraw, and I think she's found her chance to strike when she lunges for me, playing with her food, but there's still that same sense of hesitation from when we fought beyond the train car.

She stopped herself from reaching for me. I can see a crack in this abomination's armor: something that makes me different from all the others she's ruthlessly killed, but I just don't get it. No. She gets off on the torment, watching me suffer somehow knowing the thread will just bring me back here again.
But everyone boils over at some point. Though my muscles are gone, my mouth still waters, and I spit on her when she draws close again.
"Fight me, you whore!"

I try to hide my wincing when I'm left with my weakest arm. That's when she takes her first swing: a slow left hook, telegraphing it all the way to my face though I'm still too slow and spent to dodge it.
It still spills me across the floor, and when I land on my right arm I shriek in agony: out of all the places to land, and my arm is fractured further over a small rusted garden trowel.
I still raise myself to my knees, then my feet, taking the dulled divot tool in my non-dominant hand.
"You're going to kill me with that?" She asks.
"Not this time," I say, and I flip it around in the palm of my hand.

I catch her in a moment of confusion before she can pummel the rest of me. I find that same space I drove the sword into Delvin, and without that stupid self-love he died on, I doubt anything will leak from me when it parts the soft meat between my ribs.

But she's quicker than me. Afraid, even, and she shouts while she ejects the spade from my grasp. It still manages to slice me like paper when it's driven a thumb's-length in, and I feel an amethyst pain when her hands crumple my wrists and we fall backwards together.

"You'll win again, and again, a thousand times—no—a million times, even more, and just one time, you'll make a mistake. Kill me now. I'll meet you again real soon, just do it. Do it!" I plead her, but she's just bent over me with her hands pinning my biceps, as if she's too afraid to make the next move. "Do it! Just let me go. All I've ever loved is gone."
I feel a wetness on my face as the amethyst floods my veins. My eyes are too dry to cry, even when the end of this long cycle is just moments away.
"Just hang on," she says.
"Huh?" I manage.

"Just hang on for me," she says, as the tears fall from her eyes, but before I can answer, the same pitch black oblivion overtakes me, and I can feel my soul still hanging here, barely, on the next thread just waiting to burrow through my flesh. I feel dragging, then heat, then stretching time, then bitter cold, until every sensation eludes me and all I'm left with is the slow beating of my heart.
My senses awaken to the feeling of inertia. Though vision struggles on faltering eyes, I hear wind whistle in my ears and feel sun kiss my bone-dry lips.

Sprawled skyward, sharp smudges of sage slide past my sight at such a swift speed I struggle to discern them—until the smell of cedar sifts into my nostrils, and I realize I'm outside for the first time in forever. Snowflakes slide past at blistering speed though they never touch my clothes or skin. The scalding heat evaporates anything before it can touch me.

Something supports my back and legs. And when I blink my eyes and turn my head to try and reason the sickly figure, just beyond my vision, I feel the texture of obsidian scales abrade my bare neck. They take extra care in carrying me as softly as they can, dampening out the ruggedness of the open road I realize is the railroad tracks.

I expect the pain to return once my awareness peaks, from my broken arm, the Chymaeran curse, and all the wounds I've suffered in this worldline everywhere in-between, but it never comes. I dare to hinge my right arm and flex my fingers, and I'm surprised when I feel them fully respond.

My voice won't vibrate my vocal cords any louder than the blistering winds. I have no power to shout or yell. I trust nothing, and when I realize the breadth of unaccounted time I've lost, I struggle my body in the Chymaeran's arms. We move so fast the fall would kill me in an instant. It's all I can count on to get back there. She knew I'd win through persistence. She's taking me out here to abandon me in the middle of nowhere so that the thread's horizon eclipses our last confrontation!
She took the trowel before I could disembowel myself, and she pinned me to the ground, inflicting me with the curse so that my conscious soul was imprisoned in my body.
I try to struggle, but her grasp is so strong, refusing any motion of my shoulders and legs, and for the first time in all of this I feel absolutely hopeless.

I'll beg and plead to this unfeeling, genocidal monster if it offers me the sliver of a chance. That purpose, that unlikely vision I held to that pulled me through everything is just smoke, and I was damned from the start, throwing away everything I could have had for a sunken cost. And I regret everything I've ever done. I loathe myself for that persistence. I'll kill myself a thousand times just for spite, just to suffer the pain I deserve for failing everyone I love, leaving them in that frame forever.
All I give will ever return nothing. I can never be enough.
"Please," I grumble as loud as I can, but it's like talking with a mouthful of water. "Please, just leave me to die, Mask, I beg you, please!"

I shed the same pathetic tears I've held since I razed my childhood home. I don't deserve to feel their catharsis though I know I've failed, and the more my heart breaks over all the terrible things I've done, the more I resign myself to whatever eternal struggle awaits.

"Please," I still say, no longer struggling against this immovable force of artificial nature I was stupid enough to challenge. "Please, just do one thing, if anything. Take me back to the First Red where I can spend my last eternity paying my respects."

The Mask doesn't respond, but acknowledges my final wish. I'll leave myself the endless cycle of living and dying, in a place where I can forever reflect on the weight of my betrayals—and that meaningless 'edge' I valued more than anything. There is nothing left in Blackwater anyways, and I made sure of it in my last moments in the Backwoods.

Only meager days span the time between when I left and when I returned, but I recognize nothing. Sheets of ice cover every trail and tuft of grasses, returning this impossible bubble into the barren wastes of eternal winter.

The Mask sets me down on the stage of the empty amphitheater. Wherever she walks turns planes of ice into bare patches of grass in an instant, and as her influence expands, the bodies of dead Carmine emerge from cocoons of snow, still perfectly preserved.

"There's nothing for you in Blackwater. I destroyed it. Your handler Ullrich is dead, along with everyone: all the citizens, and the Afterlife, and the Cadets, and the Carmine, and the Merlot, and all my friends and family," I say, trying for a last appeal.  "It's all Dead Essence!"
She just stands there, motionless like a black wax idol, and I bow my head as I sit on the edge of the stage.

"You've ruined everything! I can go back, and I can fix all of it. I'm Gods-damn worthless without the chance. You stupid brute, you ruined all of it, everything our people could have had, that I would have brought them. You just like to watch me suffer, huh? Is that what it is, you bitch? Is this amusing to you? Then why didn't you just—"

I feel the softness of the human parts of her when she embraces me. I'm surprised when I feel her breath pulse from her lungs in deep, rasping breaths, and finally, I'm awestruck when her weary, heartbreaking wail reverberates across the amphitheater walls. I still refuse my arms around her though I cry harder. I have no empathy for those that try to massacre their own kind in thoughtless violence, but when that first name leaves her lips, I realize the persistence of something I'd missed the whole time.
"Tie," she says.
The awe fills every space I left for tears. I stand to hug her, reaching my scrawny arms to wrap her in the tightest squeeze I can.

I clutch the back of her head softly and bury my face in her shoulder, and when the shock leaves I feel the sadness return again, allowing it all to flow through me until every ounce I can spend is gone.
"Three nights. But for me it was nineteen years. As soon as they took me I was flooded with Pure Essence, and ever since, all I could feel was this hunger, ever-present, never leaving."
"You cured me then, outside the train car," I say.

"I knew you would save me, that you'd never give up on me. I held to this moment, wishing so strongly it would come. I planned for ages, acting the roles, telling myself it would arrive, and that wish came true," she says, grasping me tighter, pulling me in so strongly that it almost hurts.
But all my self-loathing anger has been traded for sorrowful guilt.
"I should have never taken my eyes off of you. I don't deserve this. Not when I allowed you to be taken so foolishly, to have you suffer like that. You should hate me more than ever!"
"How could I hate you?"

"Because I ruined everything you could have had," I tell her. "I should have let you go, but I was selfish, Gods damn-it, how much I wanted to love you for everything I never had, to give you the world. But all I ever did was make you suffer."
She pushes me away, grasping me by my shoulders. She meets my eyes at arms' length with her amethyst glare.
"I was wrong, Tie. I was a nave child that understood nothing of all the hurt you saved me from. You gave more than everything you had to me."
"It wasn't everything if it wasn't enough."

"Are you that blind to yourself and everything you've done?" She asks. "Do you know how amazing you are? Because of all those years I spent in education and training—in every moment I wasn't groomed to lead the armies of the Afterlife, every quiet moment—all I could think of was all the goodness you shared with me. How you absorbed every punch of my small fists and hurtful words. How you turned all of that into kindness, no matter how hurt, and lonely, and sad, it must have made you feel."
I bow my head, but I just can't grasp it. "There's still so much I have to do before I can ever rest," I tell her. "And somehow you've found out exactly what that is. I still have to—"

"Just rest, Tie." I feel the Amethyst flow from her fingertips, but it's not the curse. I feel all the muscles in my body relax when I crumple in to her. "You must be so exhausted. By the Gods, Tie, all you need is to rest."
"But I'm losing time, Ellie. Every second that passes pulls me further away from . . . from . . ."

"I know," she says. My tongue feels so heavy in my mouth. "And I have a plan. I love you more than life itself, more than anything," she says. "You're not going back until you've prepared, and I swear I'll fiercely defend you until that day comes."
"I'm your older brother," I slur. "You're my treasure to protect."
"Not anymore," she says, as she lifts me on her shoulders. "My younger brother's given enough for a thousand lifetimes. You're a hero, Tie. Now, please — let someone else cherish you."

When fear is stronger than hunger, you often forget to have an appetite. For more than half a year I ate so little, focused on each passing moment, attentive to any chance that might arise to return home to the past.

Ellie's glad I'm hungry. She found the hunters' meat still frozen in the icebox while I sprawled on one of the cots in the hunters' lodge. If it weren't for the leverage of her Chymaeran Curse I would have helped her, but she refuses, forcing me to hang there without a muscle to move.
"And you're gonna stay there until you give in and let me care for you," she says.
"This is an equal relationship," I offer.

"No. It's not. Dad's not around, and I'm the oldest," she says. I try to fight it, but my struggle is useless, helplessly watching as she grills a whole spit roast without even lifting a finger. The succulent smell waters my dry mouth when I imagine the taste of meat, and my stomach rumbles, so starved of real food I can't even remember what it tastes like.
"Let me do something," I insist.
"Sure. How about you lay there, and wait a little while longer until I'm done? Remember what I said? Relax. You're not doing or thinking about anything for a while."
"The Afterlife—"
"—Can't do anything, Titus. Do you even understand the extent of my power?"

"They're probably watching us right now," I say, and that memory is creeping back into me. I held it all off for so long by running forward. I forgot that everything would consume me alive if I ever stopped to rest.

The smoke. Just like the smoke of Blackwater at the end of everything; of burning flesh in the storehouse; of the scalding heat of the bootlegger's hatch beneath a room just like this waiting for ambush, and people just standing there like idiots, like she is, so completely unaware of—
"Hey! Hey, look at me," she says, sitting right in front of me on her knees. "Please."

My eyes are restless. I sweat and choke. My face runs with tears and I'm breathing hard, clutching my chest, sure my heart will explode like Valentina's skull, my lungs will crush like her body under all the—
"They're out there, Ellie. They're watching everything!"
"Titus." She cries every time I lose it.
"They're going to kill us all over again, don't you get it?"
"Titus, please, look at me!" She begs, hugging me now, tighter and tighter, as if it could ever banish the curse of memory.
"I can't lose you again. I'm so scared, it's so dark out there, and I can't see anything!" I cry.

"I know, Tie, I know," she says. She puts her head to my chest, listening to how fast my heart beats. "You're healing. You're facing everything you've buried all at once, but you have to hang in there."
"I love you, Ellie," I cry. "I love you so gods-damn much, that's why I'm so scared."
"I love you too, but please, just eat something, okay? I'll watch outside the whole time."
"Let me by the window," I say. "Let me see what's out there."
"You can sit there when you eat," she says.
"I'm not letting this happen again. Gods . . .  Romin, Valentina, the fucking smell, like..."
"I know, I know. I'll cook outside from now on. I'm sorry," she says.
"It's alright. I'm sorry, you're doing so much for me, and I'm just—"
"You will. And in fact, I'll prove my power to you. Like you always taught me, I'll put actions to my words. Then you'll believe me, and maybe then we can make it through a whole night."
"Of course," I say.
"Now just breathe," she says, and her amethyst touch relaxes me even further.
I close my eyes and draw shivering, deep breaths, gasping between sobs as I bury my face in my hands, running out of tears to cry when I've drank so little since we got here.
"That's it. You're doing great. Now are you ready to eat?"
"I think so. I'm getting better. I just need time," I say, just to persuade myself, but she nods her head, a smile parting her lips as she helps me get up.
She releases the restful curse, and the full motion of my body returns.
I walk to the table instead of the window.
"Are you sure?"

"I won't get better unless I can deal with it," I say. I scarf the plate down in seconds, nearly choking before I guzzle water. She fills my plate again, and I eat slower this time, savoring the fine cuts that Ellie smoked to perfection.
She sits next to me, indulging in the tastes of her own cooking. "It's not as good as you ever made it, but I hope it's close," she says.

"The Essence adds flavor," I joke, and her face lights up when I'm back again. "Don't drown it on mulling spices like Mom did. Or douse it in steak sauce like Clint, saying it's 'too damn tough to eat.' But really. This is wonderful."
"I'm glad you like it," she says. "Do you want another?"
"No, I'll choke."
We share a laugh.
I return to the cot after supper, and we spend two hours reminiscing on our earliest childhood. I'm not the only one that needs to heal—right now she's just slightly less wounded than I am.

Ellie won't tell me what the plan is, but I want to trust her. And I want to get stronger so I can care for her again, spoiling her with my cooking she missed for so long, filling her with all the compassion I couldn't give in the unimaginable breadth of time we were apart. There's still the darkness I find in her eyes when she thinks I'm not watching: losing herself in some unrecognizable cycle of thought and action.

I find light sleep in the cot, tossing and turning, still convinced I sleep on Victory Row, that this day is unlike any of the others. But the air is warm, unlike the unfeeling grey cobblestone walls that absorbed all the heat of the toil below — and at some point, I find a solace, drifting away into memories of a distant past before any of this, as if the innocence before graduation that we shared could last forever.
I awake to softness on my cheek, no longer swinging in a hammock of twisted fibers. My face is wet. In all my exhaustion, I passed out entirely, drooling on the soft silken surface I slept on.
"You passed out so easily once I moved you," she says. Her hand is on my back, and she sits on a padded L-shape of rucksack cloth, supported by the wall, resting my head in her lap.
"Do you sleep at all?" I ask her.
"No. I was too busy watching you—Gods know how many more times I'll get this chance again. I think I understand how you felt all those nights you stayed."
"You have to sleep, Ellie," I tell her, raising my head as I wipe a string of snot before she notices. "Just try, please."
"I know," she insists.
"And when you wake, I'll have a meal ready for you. Just like before."
"I would love that," she says.
"Then it's settled."

I sit next to her, and soon I realize if it wasn't for her words, I couldn't recognize anything about her. She's an adult like me now, but it's more than that—the empty stare she settles on by default when staring out the window and using a knife in the kitchen, cold and unfeeling, only to turn around with a warm smile when she finds I'm watching. I wonder what really kept her going: I know I'm not important enough to bring anyone, let alone my sister, to endure nineteen years of brutal programming.

But it's been nice, at least. Moments earlier I have given up everything. I can almost feel myself begin to relax when I approach the kitchen, considering what I can make her. Several vegetables are scattered about the icebox, ripe from rapid growth in Essenced harvest.
I can't remember the last time I had a chance to cook with these. It was always a treat. I withdraw several potatoes and carrots as I plot out some side dish to go with the leftovers.

I turn around to find Ellie either sleeping, or pretending to sleep, on the rucksack ottoman, her silver flaxen hair tangled in the coarse fibers. I feel something lighten in me from the last time I witnessed this. Is this what happens when a caregiver realizes their child is strong enough to stand on their own? Or—

The kitchen glass shatters. Something explodes the ceramic pot on the far shelf before burying itself in the trunk of the log wall. My cheek runs warm when the window glass splinters in the air, and all that fear returns to me, melting every trace of peace and trust.

I turn my head before the fractals can blind me. My knees hit the ground before the glass can scratch them. Beneath the table, I see the Ellie I can't recognize wake in an instant, dissolving from human flesh into Chymaeran form, surpassing the height of the tallest cross-beams before breaking out of the log wall.

I can't leave her alone out there when I can only imagine the entire force of the Afterlife waits to reclaim their corrupted asset. I remember all the ones I allowed to sacrifice themselves, and I refuse to let the one I cherish to waste herself on me.

The cold air siphons through the vacant hole. That fear of death churns my stomach as I grab a shotgun from the wall, but I'll hold it down for her. She can't do anything without me. I am her strength, and I need to prove my self worth as her brother: or else she'll supersede me and forget.

I put on a First Red cloak and boots as gunshots ring out from all sides. They've been surrounding us the whole time, waiting for a vulnerable moment, and I was right. I'm sure it's all of them, every single one that survived, just waiting for that perfect chance to kill the reason she left.

Swaths of amethyst flames flicker the log walls with brilliant light, and I can hear explosions crackle in the night air. I kick open the door to face the enemy, ready to die for her again as many times as it takes.
But I'm halted when I exit: there's a membrane of pearlescent energy cloaking the cabin, casting everything beyond it in a haze like looking through marbled glass.

The adversaries of the Afterlife target me with their repeating rifles, but all their bullets dissolve to dust when they slam against the barrier, coughing smoke and sparks of steel into my face. I turn left to find Ellie standing there in her full Chymaeran form. She's been waiting so that she could fulfill her promise in proving herself to me, and I realize the only chance the Afterlife ever had was a surprise attack.

All she needed was for me to watch her. And as I stand there, dropping the weapon from my hands, the two-story terror casts white-hot flames across the landscape, burning all the First Red cabins to ash in a single sweep.
They try to retreat, but they're too late. To Ellie, it's personal now, and within her range of influence, she clenches her fist and they crumble to Endogenous tar.

The air is silent. Fresh Essence floats in the air when the clumps of Endogeny dry over and crackle, and Ellie diverts it into me, flooding my circuits with unimaginable energy. I feel the slice on my face soften over, and I realize that this is the true power of Essence the Afterlife would raze their own kind for.
Two minutes was all it took. And when the barrier dissolves, I can finally survey the landscape.

Heading east towards the Chieftains' Lodge, I count at least forty full-Essenced Royal Guardsmen reduced to ash. She follows somewhere behind me, standing watch as a roving tower. Every moment, I expect a survivor to emerge from the rubble, but once I truly witness the scale of tremendous destruction, I realize how powerless I am compared to her.

The moonlight eclipses when she stands above me. It was only two minutes. I can't even imagine the full extent of her power as the Mask if she was forced to try. I look up to find her slender, Obsidian limbs blending ceaselessly with the dark sky, so far removed from the smoke and light of civilization that both moons and all the stars are fully visible, including the blue spec Oceanus and its satellite.

I feel a strange warmth in this helplessness, and when she decides our small encampment is safe, she returns to human form. The smell of ozone and burning rubber saturates the air as her great form erodes away, leaving the flaxen-haired girl of silken cloth standing right behind me.
"I believe you now," I admit. "Gods—I thought you needed me. But you could take on the whole world like that."
"I do need you. You're my purpose. You're the treasure I have to protect and cherish, until our time here is up," she says.

"But why? What am I worth if I can't give anything to protect or help you? It's so uncomfortable, this . . . helplessness," I say. It's an unfamiliar feeling: that despite the thread and all my potential, there is a wall.

"You don't have to do anything right now. All you need to do is accept my protection, and trust me when I say you are completely safe under my care," Ellie says. She embraces me as I watch the sky. "You've spent your entire life giving all without expecting anything in return. So cherish this moment. Recover as you prepare for the final battle that lies ahead. That relentlessness is the most important thing you have to give: both to me, and to all those people you miss in another lifetime. From this frayed end of reality, I will give you all the strength you need to return. It is not your hardness, but your vulnerability, that will lead you to victory."

I have my limits, but that does not make me weak. I am as small as a speck of sand on the shores of Blackwater lake, but I still remain the furthest from nothing. I cannot change the world in it's entirety. My reach is small, and my influence in the affairs of this world is limited.
So I choose my focus wisely when I prepare to return to that future past.

Ellie slept next to me for the first two weeks until the nightmares subsided and I stopped trembling. She still insists on it every night, from how many countless years she spent dreaming of this moment.

I ate well, and even better when I built the strength to start hunting, using the sharp obsidian arrows she synthesizes from Chymaeran scales. Every day I get one percent stronger, smarter, and more vulnerable to her kindness. She tells me I need to practice, and so she trains me, spending entire days practicing everything she can remember.

I still stay away from the Chieftains' Lodge. I can't bring the courage to return there yet — knowing she lays there with all the people who ever trusted me before that fated end. We quarter ourselves in the barracks on the edge of the Backwoods, living on little, because there is nothing I can take back beyond a plan and a lighter soul.

She instructs me to drop the sword and rifle and take up my fists. She transfers her boundless Essence in short episodes. In two weeks, I can hardly sustain a steady flame in the palm of my hand, but she's so excited, praising me at every advancement, reminding me of how much they made her suffer just to learn that.
But she still refuses to tell me the plan. At first she would just change the subject, but as my curiosity runs deeper and deeper, she says I need to be stronger to accept what I have to do.
"All I can tell you is that your target is in the Afterlife, and it's a significant task you can't hope to ever do alone," she finally says, refusing to tell me until the last moments we share.
I'm building muscle. I'm not as strong as I was, but when I practice in combat, I've almost been able to take her down.

I write everything I can remember until I feel I've planned every contingency, every detail, and when she describes all she knows of the city above the smoke, I can visualize the last moments I'll spend there.
It's been at least a month-and-a-half since I discovered her in the amphitheater.
"I think I'm ready," I tell her.
"Are you sure you want to do this?"
"Without a doubt. I'm ready to talk to her."
She embraces me tenderly. My sister has protected me all this time, giving me everything I could ever ask for, teaching me the lessons I needed to grow just a little more.

We walk out the door together, and the weather is just as warm as when the First Red called it home. The bodies of the dead no longer taint the air, and it's been so long since Ellie dissolved them to endogenous ash that they returned to the earth. If the ground accepts them — and nature can cycle on without hesitation — I know I can come to terms with this. It's a patch of frozen ice just like I left it. We've been staying away from it this whole time, and now that Ellie and I approach the Lodge, the evidence of that past reveals itself.

I will grieve and mourn. There are sacrifices I will have to make, and terrible dilemmas whose outcomes I will have to accept. I will lose the ones closest to me — and if I can't accept that — I will forever be trapped in this endless cycle.
I return to the porch of the Chieftains' Lodge to dwell in that last glimpse, and as the bodies of that cataclysmic reckoning emerge from the thawed ice, I remember everything.

I close my eyes and I can hear the voice that woke the whole village. In my hand, I can still feel that celestial pebble of divine power resonating my circuits, waiting for the contact of blood to reap their comeuppance.

All the evidence of that last struggle exists before me, halted in time — and though more than half a year has passed for me, for them, it's only been a mere month — or even less, from how perfectly the frost preserved them. When the deed was done, they dragged me off to the only windowless room in the village before I could bear witness to the Afterlife's carnage, before I could reap the collateral Essence. They locked me in the nearest shed, tying me up with rope and gagging me with my own mark, leaving me for hours until I heard the sounds of combat and then absolute silence.
I never got to see any of the ones I left to die. By the time the Royal Guard bludgeoned the lock and dragged me by my legs, the first flakes had already begun to fall.

I stand on that porch, and when I close my eyes, I can hear her shout as loud as she can, her voice still tinged with that wavering cowardice that followed her for her whole life: afraid to lose everything; bound by blood and allegiance to nothing; drowning in the same self-hatred I held for so long.

Her incessant shouting infuriates me. After everything I've given, I'm insulted that she could think I was throwing it all away; that in any way this could matter; that the entire population wasn't damned from that moment the Afterlife got their means to our end.

And when I close my eyes, I can still feel it, that biting loneliness and sadness that liquefies to incendiary anger under the right pressure. The breaking of that dam — or the fall from that ledge — the last sense of humanity withheld before the sanctity of the mission. I knew how the Gods felt when they watched the pettiness of mortal affairs, because in that moment, I had no room left for the pruned ghosts of this dying timeline.

She told me she loved me right before I did it. But I denied her. I said the only thing she really loved of me was just the image of what I could give her and nothing more, but I didn't know I could ever feel the way I do now.
That doesn't matter, though. I know her love would have changed nothing. It was my own love for this world and the desire to save everything that drove me there, after all.

And so the Pure Essence flooded my veins for the second time. The beacon erupted in a bright flash of pearlescent light, stretching all the way from the divine realm to the mortal world. I understood the reason for that column of light now: with no Mask to flood Essence into, rejected by my thread, the celestial pebble jettisoned all its potential energy into the atmosphere.

I saw flashes of another life when my soul tried to bind to that divine realm, but the thread obscured so much of it. All I could see was the vision of a young girl threading that first line to tether herself to me, dragging me at the wrist in a rush to jump before anything could stop us.

The First Red panicked at how I overturned their vote, but still refused to come near me. The fight was coming to them, and suddenly that fear of the darkness — nestled in trees and settled behind snowbanks — overwhelmed them as they hastily prepared their defenses.
At some point Sylvia tried to separate me. She leveraged her height to pull me from the flux of that column, and when I hardly gave, she fought instead to wrestle the Pure Essence from my hands.

She had no idea of what was begging to be released from inside of her. I fought even harder to resist when I considered the Goddess stranding me here with nothing. I lusted for the life of every breathing thing around me as much as she longed for any kind of life that I was with her.
She resorted to pleading when her brawn was no match.
"Just let go, Titus, yield!"
"I can't let you ruin this," I told her. My grip tightened further. I couldn't let her touch any part of it or else that celestial side would come out and turn everything to lava and ash.
"You're killing everyone! When will you ever be satisfied? When will this ever end?"
"When I fix everything, Sylvia, this is all I live for. I can fix everything. I can fix you!"

I felt  her grip loosen and I thought I'd won. But then Raine shoulder-charged me, and I flew backwards, releasing the remnants of the Pure Essence across the stage as our combined weight crunched the planks of the porch.
"I'm not broken. I was never broken, Titus. I own every single part of me, because it's brought me to who I am."
She reaches for it.
"Stop, Sylvia!"
"And if you can't accept yourself for what's made you, then, then . . ."

All she did was raise her hand. She didn't even have to touch it. When the pebble of divine Essence made contact with her skin, the shockwave knocked all the bustling First Red to their knees, blasting trees to bend like blades of grass in a windstorm.

That earlier reaction to Raine's Essence was only the slightest preview of what it could do to her. Saturated with radiant celestial light, I watched as every shred of Sylvia dissolved away. She floated into the air, above Raine and I as we reclined in the recess between cross-beams. Her hair became silver like Ellie's, skin patterned with runes and symbols of a long-forgotten age, her tattered clothes replaced with billowing garments that could only be synthesized by divine tailors.

I found Lyra in the crowd, on her knees along with all the others, either too dumbfounded to move or forced to prostration. They all looked upon the face of divinity with reverence while all of Blackwater worshipped false idols, so they were overwhelmingly aware of their sins of fear and avarice, like children brought before the source of their shame.

The daughter of the Goddess' voice boomed with thunder. "I needn't explain to you the shame behind your fear, because the thread-barer has brought before you the judgment you so clearly deserve. Removed from your homeland to toil here, under the pretense of courage and emancipation, you soil the name and purpose of your Carmine, and leave your own brothers and sisters to die alone! You will — ugh..."
The Goddess grasped her head.
"Enough, you've taken over for years! Saying that you're the real one? Weak and pathetic as —"

The First Red watched in confusion, unsure whether to grovel and beg for their worthless lives as the Goddess toiled with the other side of her. This wasn't anything like the Afterlife. That side was weaker now, I could tell in an instant she knew how little time she had in that form.
She descended to the ground. The dark locks of Sylvia's hair pulsed back in color.
"I refuse," she said. "We're not doing that. Not now, not ever!"
But she turns again. "You pathetic bitch, has this taste of mortality made you this soft?"
The First Red looked on in horror as the Goddess turned to me. She tensioned her fingers around my collar and lifted me into the air.
"You were the one that brought me here. You swindled me. I longed for freedom from the divine realm so much, you used me to come back from the dead!"
"I don't remember anything," I told her.

"You were trying to save your sister. Just like your father, you told yourself you'd do whatever it took to go back there, all the way, even if it meant you'd die forever. You told me. The house, the little girl, and the Snowdrifters that ravaged everything. You made a pact with me. I would bring you back, and you'd bring me with you. You promised a beautiful world, but all I found was —"
She faltered again, dropping me to the ground.

"Suffering. I found suffering, and that's all you thought it was," Sylvia says. "I remember all of it! What did we long for? We longed for the joy of a full experience, the one thing mortals could find that made the Gods jealous. The bounds of time create purpose. And when we longed for a taste of that, did you really think all we'd find was joy and peace?"
She paused for a moment to receive the internal monologue. I found myself next to Lyra who already connected the pieces, unsure of how to react as I struggled myself to accept this revelation.

"You bound yourself with the threads to create me. You made sure you'd forget so you'd feel the thrills of mortality," Sylvia says. "We were the ones that used him, knowing he might never return there. It was a chance for us as much as it was a mission for him."
She turned again.

"We were supposed to fix the failure of Khiras and her experiment. The end was meant to be different, and if you can't see that — I'll make sure that no mortal will ever suffer the end of this timeline!"
The Goddess rose into the air, still fighting herself, a young spirit and an exhausted immortal forever unwilling to coalesce.
"You fail again, thread-barer. This is the end of another—"
Sylvia resists. The winds pick up all around us as the ground shakes; distant tremblings of a familiar end I remember from a past life. I couldn't let the Goddess unwittingly trap me here.
"You have to resist, Sylvia, please!" I shouted. "I have to go back. I have to save all of us, to make things right. The mission. Whatever that was. I have to finish the fight!"
Just then, a distant flash lit the sky that only I could ever recognize.
"I'm sorry, Titus. I'm sorry I dragged you into all of this. I've only ever been sincere to you, in all that time we were blind to that truth of where we came from. But my love for you is —"
"I know," I told her.
"We loved each other in the Reservoir, and yet . . . even with our memories lost, we still found that lost piece."
"I just wish I could remember. Anything."

She descended in her heavenly raiments on the last pulse of Pure Essence, dissolving, reaching for one last kiss before she was withdrawn from the mortal plane. I turned my head up to her as she approached, but when three minutes passed since the flash lit the sky, the wall of pressure disintegrated her body to shimmering dust.
I fell to my knees. The First Red remobilized when they remembered the closeness of their last trial, as if nothing had ever happened.

"You were him all along," Lyra said. "You don't remember anything. The house. Father. The passing of the Mask to you. I knew it as soon as I saw that column of light. You're . . . Fletcher . . ." She looked halfway torn between embracing me and outright killing me, but before she could react, Raine brandished me across the face with his fist.
"You Gods-damn bastard!" He shouted.
"Raine, stop it!" Lyra pleaded.
"He's getting thrown the only place he deserves to rot. Away from everything, and away from the Essence he longs to pilfer from our corpses."
"Stop it, just give us a moment!" Lyra says, but like his son, his mind is immovable. Two more Carmine join to drag me off the streets towards the windowless shed as Lyra falls behind.

And now, I stand here on this porch, opening my eyes to recall every minute of the events as they unfolded. I finally see the aftermath I missed when the Royal Guard dragged me from that shed. Lyra died five steps away from the crater in the floorboards. Raine died just past the shed. And when I notice Lyra's hand missing the ring finger, I draw a long, shallow breath before I anticipate her to speak to me again through death.
Her hand falls on my shoulder, and I shiver at her cold touch.

"It's something you think about when you're surrounded by Chymaerans all the time. It's the soul that's the question. Do we identify with the body as our identity? Or is the body just a vehicle for the soul?"
We look at her body as we sit on the steps of the porch, but she isn't dismayed or terrified. Instead, she's almost curious.

"It's funny. You think I'd be a lot more worked up about this, confronted with my own death. I remember it so clearly when the Royal Guard overwhelmed us, that last moment when my defenses slipped and I gave in. But in the end, I guess I got what I wanted."
"Did it hurt?" I ask her.

"I don't remember, there was so much adrenaline. Just a long tunnel of light, then oblivion, and the next moment I'm here."  She turns to me with Ellie's amethyst eyes. "Reminds me of a joke I heard. 'I don't mind dying. I just don't want to be around when it happens,'" Lyra says.
"What do you remember? I saw nothing. I only heard the horrors of what was happening until everything went silent."

"In those last moments I thought of everything I still wanted to say to you. It's been a checklist in my mind forever — and even more so since that first column of light proved he was alive. But I realized there wasn't much else I really had to do. I was with you: for as short as it was, as close as I got to killing you at times, it all still felt like more than I could ask for."
"And I'm going to make it better next time," I tell her. "I promise you. Everything you've ever dreamed of. Say—what is it that you wanted to hear the most from Fletcher? From . . . me?"
"That you're proud," she says, without hesitation. "Telling me that I lived up to everything you left behind, that I squandered none of that potential you wast— er, 'spent,' on saving me."

"You lived a wonderful life of service," I tell her. "You gave yourself to a cause, and you were faithful to the end. I took that chance at life from you before you could see the fruits of that dedication. I was selfish because I had a different mission. I knew that all of Blackwater and everyone around it would be swallowed into the earth, met with a violent, sudden fate, and because of that, I had to do whatever it took to go back there. And regardless of that, I'm sorry I betrayed you and everyone you care for. I hope that you can forgive me, even in death."

"I do, Fletcher — if I can call you that. I fully understand your reason. It wasn't you. You were as married to your purpose as I was to my own, and it was even grander than mine, so believe me when I say it's only the First Red that need to redeem themselves. You gave them a chance to react to this and put your faith in them."
"Everything will change next time," I insist. I have the workings of my plan that I've pieced together for the past month, filling all the imaginary holes and threading all the pieces.
But a question still lingers.
"Say. How is it that you remember so much as a guise?"
"A . . . guise? What do you — you mean I'm. . ."
Her hands feel for every contour of her body. I'm frightened for a moment as I watch her panic, then I remember what we've been staring at this whole time.
I laugh.
"Very funny. But really."

"It all depends on the connection," she says. "Your friends Romin and Valentina died horrible, gruesome deaths, and I bet that made them far less-willing to surrender themselves to complete strangers. You feel that other consciousness intrude on your existence, and at first it's terrifying, threatening everything that makes you who you were. Ellie tells me that's why sometimes it takes years, while others can be instant. What it comes down to is compatibility and trust."

It reminds me of the exact same feeling when I enter my past self. But every time it's a hostile takeover, like killing a past fragment of myself in their sleep with just own hands: too slow that they soon awake to what's happening; forced to accept it as their own existence is haplessly erased.
"You said you were so afraid. So what was it that made you surrender yourself?"

"I gave myself up because I could feel the warmth of it it — the biggest commonality between both of us: how much we love and cherish that brother that brings himself to suffer and toil for our own well-being, expecting nothing in return. We want you to thrive, even if we know that one day soon you'll be leaving us both behind here."

"You will never be dead to me," I tell them. "I swear it, I'll carry on every piece of you and wear my pride on my sleeve. I'll know you still persist here. I'll dream of us as if sleep can bridge our lifelines. And at the end of it all, I'll think of you every day from morning until night, until it's the last thought I ever have, I swear it!"
Lyra's eyes run wet as the hope in my words grows. Ellie slips out from Lyra's guise, and the conviction of my words draw a deep, lonely sorrow through her eyes.
"What happened? I'm sorry. Did I say something wrong?"
She makes herself small, curling up just like she used to when I came home late and found her feeling so alone. Because I know I will be leaving her here.
"I can't tell you yet, not until the end of this . . . but I've just been dreading it so much," Ellie says.
"Then I will listen, whenever you are ready," I say.

She stretches her slender legs down the steps. "I just wish you could stay here forever, Titus, and regardless of how important I know that mission is to the both of us, it just makes me so sad. I got what I could only dream of for years, and all I can think is what it will feel like when it's gone!"

She bashes her fists into the planks, and one of them snaps. I reach to comfort her, just like I've always done. I remove the arm of my coat and wrap her in the warmth of it, allowing her to bury her head into my shoulder and sob as I extend my arm around her.

"I wish I could give you everything for all you've suffered, and all I've missed. The reason why it's so easy to give to you? You give me so much in return and you don't even realize it," I say. "I've spent my whole life thinking I'm a burden paying off an ever-increasing debt against all the people I care for. That they keep me around just to collect what I can give. Gods forbid, I was the Valedictorian of the Academy and I still felt lower than dirt — so entrenched in the mentality I learned in the Orphanage before I was adopted, deserving love. At that young age it might have been hard for you to show it, when I was just another adult telling you how to live."
"I shouldn't have been such a jerk," she sobs.

"You were a child — but through it all, you accepted and cherished that kindness. And that alone was what was enough to fill my heart and keep me going. And even now, you teach me that lesson through your boundless love." I begin to cry, but I let it flow out of me, not judging it, letting all the inward pain I collected to harden myself with to melt away. I can feel her now. And as I opened up this past month, I noticed things I had never taken the time to care about before.

"When I was broken down to the lowest point, fully vulnerable for the first time, you were there to protect me — or else I thought I'd break entirely. You made me feel all the things I'd run from, not allowing me to erect walls and hide. I felt all of it. And because of that, you taught me the greatest lesson of my life: that there is pain that heals."

"I'm not ready to let you go," she says. I feel her arms tension around me, unaware of how strong she is. "Lyra tested you, and you're ready, but . . . I just can't let you go. Stay, just a little bit longer, please, Titus. I'm not better yet," she says, lapsing into her younger self for a moment.
"Neither one of us is fully healed. We've only begun to reverse that momentum."
"So stay, just a little while longer," she says.
"I will. And when I return, I'm going to save you. I won't let you ever suffer again what you endured here."
"And that's what I'm afraid of," she says. "I'm not telling you until the moment you leave me. Or else you'll never go."

"I will listen when it's time. A brother always listens." She looks up at me with teary eyes to find my face just as wet. "There are so many sacrifices I'll have to accept. People will die, and so many will suffer. I'm only giving myself one shot in this last loop. But for now, in this short breadth of peace, let's get stronger together. Spirit is the only thing I can carry."

An uncountable span of solace graces the two of us. Days fade together seamlessly in this severed timeline. She continues to teach me everything she can, and I listen to every word, because I've never stopped to really hear her like this before. And maybe I've never stopped to hear anyone.
We don't have to call out the day when it arrives. We can both feel it. The only arguments we've had were about how I was going to do it, and even now, we continue to reach an impasse.
"It will be quick either way. But there's no way I can ask you to do that," I tell her.
"Aren't you afraid to die? And to do it to yourself, Titus . . . Gods above, how long has it been?"
"It's been a long time. And yeah, I guess I am afraid. I haven't slept easy the last couple nights—" though the sleep I did get was a hundred times better than when I first got here.
"Then let me do it. Please, it will be merciful, and you won't have to worry. You won't feel a thing."

"I can't put that on you. You have to live on here, Ellie, and I refuse to let you carry that weight — I love you too much to know that you'll suffer. And we won't be able to forgive ourselves on either side of it."
"But can you really do it?" She asks.

"I'll get over it," I say. I know she senses that hesitation in my voice, as if I'm asking for her to convince me otherwise, but I just can't let that come through. "My head hits and I'm done for. Just let me do it alone, I don't want you to witness this, no matter what horrible things you've been through . . ."
"I refuse," she says. "I still need to tell you that secret — what you have to do when you're up there in the Afterlife."
"You can tell me now, right?"
"You'll refuse to leave if I tell you. I have to make sure you go back, don't you remember? You made me swear I'd never let you get too comfortable or refuse your mission."
"That was so long ago," I say. "Unbelievable how long we've been here. It only feels like yesterday."
"And you've prepared yourself in every possible way you can. I know you're ready. You know you're ready."
Our words are just idle chatter. This is the first time here it's ever felt like a waste. I think about all she's done for me, and all I've been able to do for her.
"We'll turn to stone if we hesitate." Just a little longer, I want to say. I can see she feels the same, and so in that pulse of raw emotion, I concede.
I approach her, pulling her in for the last hug, the last time I'll feel her grown strength before she's just a child again, forgetting all of this except the love she's felt all this time.
"I'll let you do it," I tell her.

She begins to weep, and I feel her wet tears fall on my shoulders. I put my hand behind her head and tuck her in tighter, as if all the heat of my body in this moment could keep her warm for the rest of her life here.
"Thank you," she says. "It's the last act of love I can give to you."
It's the first time I've ever thought about what I'm leaving behind. "Where will you bury me? At the old house? Here in the Backwoods?"
"You'll be ash," she says. "You might blow away on the winds, too fine to capture a handful, but what's left is how you touched my soul, and that is forever."
