"Will I see you in the end? When I free myself from this thread — will we meet again? In the reservoir? Will it join all these realities?"
"Let's make a promise to wait until we find each other," she says. "We'll jump together. We'll be born again!"
"I promise," I tell her.
Our time is short. I can feel how much I'm overstaying my welcome when purpose lies on the other side of this thread.
"What is your mission?" She asks.
"To get to the Afterlife," I say.
The amethyst begins to surge.
"How will you get there?"
"By rallying my closest allies."
"What will you pay?" Ellie asks, as I feel myself disintegrate.
"Whatever cost within free will," I say, as a comfortable warmth fills my body. "Of myself and all the others."
She sobs. "And to what end will you go?"
"One continuous push," I say. "Not to die by intention, but only by circumstance!"

"You're ready, Titus." The painless dissolution of my body decays my fingers to ash as I try to reach for her one last time. "You have one mission above all: one final act of love and mercy." Every part of me that remains is lighter than air, floating away as timeless firebrands, off to spark change in another life she'll never witness.
With all my lingering consciousness focused on the last surviving sense of sight, I read her lips as she speaks: a single demand of two words.

"At the end of the day, and at the end of all of this, friends, we are all just watchmen of the night, taking our shift until we're relieved of service and get to go home and rest. We might tire as the shift grows long, and at times, it might feel if we've done nothing at all but just watch."
This Titus draws a breath. Surrounded by thousands of faces, celebrated for his relentlessness with the honor to speak encouraging words, he has never felt more alone in his life.

He thinks this is the worst it can get. But he knows nothing of where this current path will take him if he's undisturbed. His eyes flicker to that space of vacant seats he reserved until the disappointment feels like it will burn his stomach. That friendly shopkeep from Clint's is the only one that showed up — he must have sent her here as an errand. He purses his lips and continues on after pausing for effect.

"But we haven't just watched. We've experienced a full and beautiful life," he says, and he almost loses himself in the irony, but pushes it down just like he does with everything else. "We never asked for this job. None of us asked for this job of living, but we were born into it. We all understand the value of sacrifice, the beauty of watching our influence carry for generations, and the question we all have here is the same."

He pauses again. This Titus acts resolute though the question still devastates him. They sit at the edge of their seats, knowing what question awaits, the single burning thought that's worn into the grooves of their minds since they first heard the phrase Suicide Scholar.
"How, friends, do we live to fight, knowing that most of us are going to die out there?"

The auditorium is silent. Ninety percent of the parents and supporters' children will be sent beyond the walls; only a mere ten percent were good enough to stay. The cadets no longer chatter. It's so silent that the sound of nature in the Foothills re-emerges as if Endogeny had already extingusished them, so quiet that Titus hears the Grandmaster General Ullrich cough behind him at the podium.

This Titus rides this feeling of anticipation because he loves the satisfaction of absolute control. He can see the desperation resurface in Cadets and supporters alike, but he wants to provide them reassuring words, even if they're not his.
He opens his mouth to speak, but then the sudden migraine overtakes him.

He grasps his head. He feels such anguish that it almost casts him all the way to the floor. He drops down on one knee, but it feels like another voice is calling to him. The scar on his right arm beneath the ceremonial armor and mark feels like that hard scar tissue is replaced with molten steel, and he feels a lattice of cuts cascade up his arm.
The crowd rises with commotion. Ullrich reaches behind him to grab his shoulder. "Are you alright, son? You were doing so great."

This Titus groans with pain, but just like they always do, he concedes once he hears my voice is his own, once he sees a glimpse of that inevitable premonition and the whole path he's destined to suffer to get there.

Just help me. I never, ever, want to witness or feel that horrible future, he pleads me, and I'm merciful when I take over. I can feel all of future Ellie's Essence funnel into me though that threaded tether
like talking wires, and I know this time I have so much Essence that failure is impossible.
"Titus? Are you alright?" Ullrich asks. "What happened this time?"

If only these people knew what he was responsible for, how much suffering he accustomed them to, generation after generation, goading their habits towards unquestioning acceptance of indentured servitude.
I should strike him down right here, but I can't.
"I'm fine, sir," I say.

I grab the podium again with fresh eyes, looking upon the faces of the dead I've seen dissolve to ash so many times before — lives I'll save that I've never met; cadets I've killed that know nothing of what lies ahead.
"Why do we fight the inevitable?"

That Titus' answer to his own question is the last remaining piece of him, but it's not good enough for me anymore. It doesn't encapsulate the lessons of that unwritten chapter, and when my eyes cross the audience, I find familiar faces that won't ever know me like I knew them. In the front is that poor Cadet destined to die when he fights me in the train car, calling me a vagrant, and sitting beside him is Zane, the cadet that confided in me at the end of our trials on Victory Row.

To the left are the forty-some cadets that Romin convinced to fight with him beyond the gates. Three of them had their torsos bisected under the weight of the wrought iron. Twelve or more of them were too late. The rest were the ones I saved that gave their lives to protect me, yet they don't even know what might await them. Towards the back are the two cadets that killed Lyra and I in Victory Row. I remember obliterating the first one's skull with a rock until his features were indiscernible, and the second one, I stabbed in the chest until I ran out of breath, finding no satiation for that unfathomable rage. But here they sit before me, goofing off and hitting each other with one of the graduation fliers.

And finally, I see the top one percent sitting there before me: the three friends tied to me; our bond stronger than blood; the ones I've learned will fight alongside me through death; the three flawed, despairing, lovable, cherished cadets that I'll give my everything for.

"We live to fight because we were made for higher dreams," I tell them. "The passion of the fight is what makes the act of living worth anything at all. The capacity to feel; to be hurt; to feel the fury of a thousand suns and the solace of the softest sleep; the experience of the act of life is what we live for."

The peace of that uncountable breadth of time with my sister washes upon me, and I can feel it again, that feeling I never thought I'd feel, that feeling mythologized by my own obsessive lust for suffering and seclusion.

"So ask yourselves not what the meaning of anything is in times of despair, because you will never get a whole answer. We are not machines like those generators casting that thick, residual haze into the air. Above all of this, somewhere, is a blue sky. The meaning is the experience: not the eventuality of waiting for an unpromised future, but feeling through this moment we live in right now," I say, and when I see the three sitting in front of me jarred by my shift in demeanor, I thank whatever Gods may be that I get whatever time I have left with them. "This exact moment doesn't care about the future or the past, so live here with me, friends, and you'll endure the greatest of life's challenges. Feel through it, because all that persists from generation to generation is memory, and nothing more."

I'm surprised when my hands are untensioned against the podium. I feel a wetness reside in my eyes, a newfound feeling, and I wipe it before they notice. It's not the fear that leads me to tears. It's the beauty of this moment I once lost when I decided it was a chore, and the joy of that blessing to have finally returned.
The crowd applauds as I turn to descend the stairs, but Ullrich extends his right hand first. I clasp it and he pulls me in to whisper something in my ear, twisting my right wrist.
"That was a wonderful speech, son," he says. "A lot different than I remember."
"Huh?" I mutter.
He tries to twist further, but I resist him.
"Nothing. You wouldn't get it," he says, releasing my hand, and we turn away in smiles, waving to the audience.

The auditorium clears out shortly after that. The cadets are either too excited for their families' parties, too drunk, or too hungover after three hours of sitting, all eager from the restlessness of hearing so many names.

Like all of them, I'm happy and afraid, but I'm more of both than they'll ever be. Overjoyed for this brief stillness like rising to the surface of a lake after being bound in briny, dark depths. Catching that first breath of air is an elixir, for the exhaustion this unweathered body feels as phantom pains of an agonizing past.

And so I'm more afraid than they could ever be, too, because I've seen every outcome of this lie. What is survivor's guilt called when you hold it for a future passed? Can I live with myself when this is over?
You can, that Ellie says. She's still there in another life. The thought is useless. This present was never yours to hold on to in the first place.

And so I can relish this day, drinking to the joy of the unconscious as if my eyes were fresh; as if that past Titus were still within me; holding to that brilliant sense of purpose that stirs me to fight for all I've ever loved.
I can't have it all. But just enough just might be enough.

Somewhere behind me, the mass exodus swarms the last-lettered seats. Berguard is up front. Zebal and Vermillion are far behind, along with nameless Sylvia, and after such a flood of bodies crowds the aisle, I know there's no chance I can get back to them.
Something grabs below my eyes from behind, startling me. They're fingers.
"Guess who?"
"Someone that isn't tall enough to blind me and do it right," I say, but my stomach twists for a second, afraid I might see her just like the way I left her.
"Guess," she says.
I still find myself frozen there.
"Hey, it's a joke . . . are you going to turn around?" She asks.

"I'm sorry," I say, sheepishly. That phantom shame makes me feel as if I don't deserve to see her at all, remembering that look of betrayal on her face when the cold steel was inside her — but she sneaks around me.
"Last name is the only thing I could ever come before you in, I guess," she says.
Isla Assal.
Her blue eyes are so bright when she looks up at me. So little she knows of anything I did to her.
"So you're going into intelligence. Just like your father did," I say.
"That's right! How did you know that?"
"You told me. A couple days from now, actually."

"You're pretty strange, you know that?" Isla laughs. She looks past me, and finds her Fireteam-mates gesturing for her to come, in some kind of a rush. "Say . . . Vera's celebrating our fireteam at the Vermillion Estate, in the main house."
"Sounds like a grand time," I tell her. "Have fun. I bet Valentina's excited, too."
"To visit, you mean?"
"Huh?"
"Valentina told us she was only coming to visit. That she was celebrating with you, instead," she says.

"Oh, yeah," I say. "Shows how well I remember things." But she never asked for us to go out. Despite all the anticipation of planning something, nothing ever came to be because we kept putting it off, and that's why I went on that trip beyond the walls in the first place. And I know exactly where I'll find her: the first one I'll convince of this plan.
"It's a pretty tight list, you know how Vermillion functions are. Maybe you could be my guest of honor?"

I'm fortunate this Titus was already in formal clothes when I took over. There were so many people flooding the event hall that I never caught a glimpse of Sylvia, Romin, or Valentina, despite how hard they might have looked for me. But that's alright, because by the end of the day, I'm coming for each of them.

The touring cars were already pulled to the front of the lot: drivers in Merlotan royal gear mimicking that of the Afterlife, doused in gold and bluish-red like all the Royal Guard's whites were drowned in barrels of wine. The whole way there, they mocked Isla for our connection, inferring there was something else behind it, but I could feel that joy inside her that I was with her.
My eyes catch the ground-level windows of the cellar. Still pitch black. Either she sulks inside, or these monsters didn't even send a car for her.

The inner hall of the Vermillion Estate was even more immaculate than I last remembered it. I might have been the only person here past the Vermillions that treaded in the Afterlife, and somehow, after seeing the perfect marble walls and polished floors of every building in that land above the clouds, this all feels like a convincing imitation.

Isla tucked her hand around my arm and introduced me to everyone that would listen. She blushed every time they called me her "brilliant man." I felt worse when I remembered I was using her for a pass on to the grounds of the estate, but better when I knew my presence made her day all the better.

I excused myself to the restroom. It took half an hour to navigate the labyrinth of corridors full of servants and guests, punctuating the red-and-gold hallways with black and white, and when I finally made it to the entryway where the morning sun shimmered through thinner smog, I noticed the lights were still off in the stone-walled shed.

The greenskeepers were asked to trim the already immaculately-shaped bushes, but only the front, so the guests would have another reason not to doubt the prowess of the Vermillion name. The side of the house was bare, and riding on the excuse that I'm either drunk or lost, I headed for the shed.
I pressed my ear to the thick wooden door, hearing nothing at all, so I tried the handle. The door was locked . . . but from the outside.
With the key still in it.

I slipped inside before anyone could notice. The room was just like I left it that night: the posh, gold-plated bed made with fine silken covers sitting against the cold stone wall, the entire space submersed beneath the ground, lit only by candles or the faint trickle of light from the grated windows, with so much dust that I coughed and sneezed.
I've been waiting for several minutes now. I hear a commotion, but it's not from outside. It's an echo, and once I realize I'm standing over that grate that allowed us to escape, I jump onto her bed.

Footsteps slosh through the drainage pipe leading out towards the foothills, growing louder until I hear her mutter to herself. Maybe she walked all this way. Or maybe her mother sent a car late, just to spite her and make her wait.

I hear the thick metal grate lift off the recession in the floor like a manhole cover, just a crack, and somewhere beneath, her solid heels clatter against the steel rungs of the escape ladder. The grate drags against the uneven cobblestone as nails on a chalkboard, and from the ground, she emerges wearing her finely-woven garments, facing the other way, hair still perfect, hat and clothes spotless and clean without a single drop of mud caked on them.
She raises from the drainage tunnel like a water lily blossoming in mere moments from a murky lake, and it amazes me how such a colorful form can persist in the doldrums of this hopeless chamber.
"Gods be damned," she mutters to herself, removing her hat, exposing the ears that twitch to her surroundings, and when the bed creaks beneath me, she wheels around to find me sitting there.
She's speechless. But I'm short on time, and this is the only way I can prove it to her. All I needed was the means, because I've rehearsed the words enough times.

"I'm here because I need you to believe me when I say the next unthinkable string of words." She still refuses to speak, covering her head with her hat, paralyzed with too much humiliation to be angry. "In another life I was here in this cellar, where you told me everything. I'm aware of it all. Your spiteful mother. Your bastard father. The ears on top of your head that prove there's a whole other world far beyond there, with so much we couldn't possibly imagine."
She sits down on a crate.
"But that's roughly six days from now. Some time after we go to the Vermillion club. You're worried that one of the bouncers like Marcel won't let you in."
"Why are you saying these things . . . what are you? Are you doing this to threaten me?" Valentina asks as she trembles.

"I would never hurt you. But there's a fate far worse that awaits all of us, and I've lived that future, over and over again, where . . . Gods, how many times has it been now that I've explained this to you?"
"What do you mean?"
"Every time I die, I go back. I've been living this same loop for ages, and over and over, I've lost everyone I care about. All of Blackwater is going to be destroyed, and only I can prevent this."
"You . . . you're saying—"

"But I can't stop this. I can't do it alone. For so long I thought others were just an obstacle to perfection, that asking for help was an act of charity, but I was Gods-damn wrong, Valentina, and I need your help. You have some dreadful people in your family, but you are loved beyond compare by me, Sylvia, and Romin, regardless of that perfect act you've honed into a career." I lean forward, looking into her emerald eyes with the slightest crescents I hadn't noticed before.
"Please, Valentina, I beg of you. Will you help me? And most of all — can you believe me?"
She nervously traces her manicured thumbs around each other. For putting her through so many different emotions at once, she looks like she'll cry, but she persists.

"On the stage, there, that massive headache that cast you down," she says. "The change in tone. Those words you said. It was different than anything I'd ever heard come out of your mouth, and you believed it. You made me believe it."
"That's when I came back," I say, unbuttoning the cuff on my ceremonial clothes, folding back the sleeve until the slashes of the thread are exposed. "You remember this scar from when I was a kid?"
"Gods above, Titus!" She says. "What happened? What did you do to it?" The flesh is so latticed by glowing cuts that my entire arm looks mangled.
"Each of those is a death. And this—this is the earliest I've been able to return to. I'm not sure I have it in me to go again. And I think I've decided this is my last chance."
"What do you need?" She asks.
"What I mean is that I've died, over and — wait, did I hear that right?"
"What do you need from me?" She asks.

"I'm here to tell you I was wrong in not asking you to come with me beyond the walls. I need you to travel with me, because there's only so much I can do alone, and I've got something to show you that will change your life forever."
"You have my help, though I'm not sure what I can do," Valentina says.
"Then meet me tomorrow morning at Clint's trade building, before the sun rise and right after the Seminary bell."
"What should I bring?"
"I've got all the Snowdrifting gear. Just dress as inexpensively warm as you can."
The feeling of fear is new to me when I stand outside her door. I don't wait here because I'm afraid of the other side of her. I'm scared of something else.

Maybe that inching anxiety came back to me since I left my peace with Ellie in another time. Old habits of thought and feeling persist as wine soaks its flavors into the wood of a barrel, coloring every future batch with the memory, and so in only a matter of hours, the walls have already begun to erect themselves.
I have to act now while they're only chest-high.

The door is cracked. Inside, I hear the scratchings of charcoal against paper, and when I open the door further, the faint smell of her perfume wafts into the hall. I wonder if this is how she feels: at a loss for words, waiting for the right moment to speak and break the stillness.
"Sylvia?" I venture.
She turns her head, astonished. "Oh, hey Titus. Is something wrong?"
"Of course not. Why do you ask?"
"Oh . . . I've never seen you come up here unless you needed something," she says.
"No. I'm here for you," I say.

She drops the chalk at the base of the inclined easel, looking as if she's been struck by something, and turns to face me. Her hair is disheveled, her fingertips are covered in black, and her crimson eyes shine bright — looking like either a tortured artist or the Chymaeran caricature on the page — yet she's still beautiful as ever, with the tender glance she reserves for me.

She wears nightgown shorts that fit tight around her thick legs, cuffing the flesh of her pale white skin streaked lightly with charcoal. Her top is thin and smeared the same way, used for little more than utility to keep the art separate from her body. I feel my heart jump when I realize she's wearing nothing under it, and that same recurring fear discomforts me, but this time I won't let those anxieties tangle with the warm, electric feeling as it floods my nerves.

My mind fills with the fantasy of any way I've dreamt to have her. I recall every time I felt her relax in the presence of my strength, protecting her, living vicariously through imagining what it felt like for her to melt, but this is no longer a stroke of my ego. It's something more than that. It has to be: not just a mission to be completed, but something everlasting to be beheld.
And then it breaks: whatever last unlikely brace that held my composure, the same one Ellie disarmed though months of caring for me as I pulled my soul together again. The tears stream down my face.

I can feel her pull me in to the warmth of her body as my sobs are snuffed out. She reaches her arms over my shoulders to hold me right, tracing her nails on my back with such gentle intention, until I can muster the strength to say anything, and then I feel the need to explain myself, to preserve my pride.
"I just . . . I . . ."
"It's okay," she says. She sits me down on her bed and lets me cry until her shoulder as she tells me I have no reason to explain myself. "It must have been so hard."

"I did everything. All I ever wanted was just to save everyone! And they died, over and over again, and all the horrible things I had to do, just to—" I let out a squeaking gasp that startles me as my throat jumps, but she only tightens her grasp. She kisses me lightly on the forehead, and even in the deepest throes of sorrow and tragedy I can really, truly feel how much I love her.
I'm not afraid anymore.

I wipe my eyes and turn to face her, our lips so close though I'm a sniveling mess, only to find that she nearly cries for me, too. All that separates us is just the catalyzing energy it takes to get over that wall, and we can both feel our stomachs rise with blissful static. We draw closer and closer, until soon enough I'm surprised when our lips are already touching, and my hand caresses behind her ear, drawing her closer because now I won't ever get enough of her.

I'm surprised again when she twists me down against the bed, but the static rises further as I pull off her thin shirt smeared with stains of soot, exposing her full breasts that compress as she sits on my waist and tightens her chest against me. Her tongue flickers inside my mouth as I hold her tightly in all the places I've only ever undressed with my eyes, fighting to turn her over so I can tear off my own shirt, and when I do, we press ourselves together to share the warmth of our bare skin.

Neither of us venture past removing another garment, too engrossed with the voiceless passion of our lips we've been mute to for so long. I hear her moan softly as I plant wet kisses upon her neck, grabbing all the soft places I've only touched in daydreams as she squirms under me.
I look into her eyes after another kiss and she cracks a smile: not just of joy, but of good humor. And then she can't stop laughing.
"What? What's so funny?" I ask, self-aware now of anything stupid I might have done. She sucks on her unblackened forefinger and drags it across my nose, returning a full stripe of charcoal.
"I got myself all over you," she says.
"I don't mind being your canvas," I tell her. I reach down inside her shorts to try and pleasure her further, but she stops me, grabbing my hand.
"Is it alright if we . . . stop here?" Sylvia asks.
"Oh. Yeah, of course," I say, retracting my fingers. "I'm sorry."
"No, no, it's alright. I just want to savor . . . us," she says, and when I lay beside her, I wrap my arms around her waist. "It both took us such courage to get here after all."
I might cry again from how safe I feel here, and she knows that from how I tremble, remembering the feeling of death my mind has tried so hard to suppress.
"Sometimes you just have to let go, Titus," Sylvia says. "no matter how painful it is—"
"—You have to succumb to it and feel it through." I use her words before she can speak them.

"You took the words from my mouth," she says, caressing the side of my face as we lay next to each other. "I just want you to know that I'm always watching you: ever since the orphanage, ever since you saved me from that darkness, ever since you showed me that kindness, you know, because . . ."
"Because you love me."
"I do," she says.
"And because I love you too, Sylvia."

She nestles her head into my neck, and I can feel her chest rise and fall as she breathes deeply. The same timeless feeling of relaxation washes over me that I felt when I was with Ellie, and I know this moment will forever live in my mind, no matter how long I live in this last cycle.
"I came with one question to ask, but now I have two," I tell her.
"What are they?" She asks, tracing her fingers against my chest.
"I was wrong to tell you that I didn't need you on this trip beyond the walls. I need to do better at letting people help me, and I need your help out there."
She laughs. "You're so damn cute."
"No. Really, though."
"Of course I'll come with you," she says.
"Can you meet me in the morning at Clint's?"
"What are you talking about?" She asks. "You know you're staying the night here."
"Oh . . . uh, yeah, of course," I say, with a stupid grin on my face.
"I hope that wasn't your last question," she says, pulling me closer.
It wasn't. Though I'm sure I know the answer.

Sylvia and I show up at my house an hour before meeting. The lights are off, which isn't uncommon — often times the caretaker leaves them off so my sister can sleep, keeping on a couple to make her feel safe.

There's only two modes I find Ellie in. Either she's riled up to get to school, so excited about meeting a friend or show-and-tell that I have to force her to eat, and other times, she's still sleeping, and I have to feed her and nearly drag her out the door. Unlike other kids in families with full-time parents, the house isn't filled with enough fun activities to keep her up late, so she often sleeps sooner than I do.
My keys jangle in the door as Sylvia shivers behind me, burying her nose in a crimson scarf. I expect a voice, anything — but all I'm met with is an eerie silence.

"This can't be right. She was here last time!" I say, and I rack my brain over happenings more than a year ago. Dad slept at the shop like he always does. Ellie tugged at my shirt, pulling me towards that commemorative wall to ask me about the names in the stones.
I sniff the air. It smells like early breakfast, so I know the caretakers made something for her, and when I cross the dark foyer to check the kitchen, I found she already ate.
I call her name again and again, voice wavering, my fingers caressing the handle of the switchblade in my pocket as I ascend the stairs, remembering the despair of what she last told me.
"The door was locked, Titus. You say she's good about locking the front door, right?" Sylvia calls up to me.

"Yeah. Usually," I say. I open the door to her room and it's freezing. My first thought is to check the window, but as soon as I notice the curtains don't dance, I know the window is shut. My fingers trace the top of the window. Locked. And when I scour around her room, her school bag is missing from the spot it usually sits.
"I'm sure she left. That little girl is better at waking up than I am most mornings," Sylvia says.

"You're probably right," I say, but I could have sworn I walked with her. The memory is hazy. All I can remember is remembering the way I remembered it. Maybe last time I showed up earlier — and this time, she got tired of waiting. Or maybe I've changed enough already in this worldline to affect her.
"She's probably fine," Sylvia says, standing in Ellie's doorway as I turn to leave. Deep down I'm relieved I don't see her, and maybe that pushes my convictions over the edge.
I descend the stairs to leave, but Sylvia goes deeper into the hallway. Something catches her attention, and when she opens the door to my old room:
"Dear Gods, what happened here?"
My heart skips. I rush down the dark hallway and poke my head in the room in mere seconds. Sylvia sits in the middle of the floor.
"Why is everything gone?"
"Oh. You scared me," I tell her, catching my breath. "I sold it all a long time ago."
"But why?" Sylvia asks. "Your bed. That bright red dresser. The toys, and the books, what happened to it all? Did . . . did Clint make you sell it, in his store?"

"No," I tell her. "I just couldn't stand looking at it. It reminded me too much of something I could never have again, and letting those things go—" I say, tensioning my fingers around the necklace that's persisted around my neck through almost everything. "I kept the little that mattered. Just enough."
"But that's so sad," she says.
"The profits helped Ellie live here longer in her childhood home." Though she deserved so much more than this house that's way too big for one-and-a-half people, I think.
"You remember the first time we kissed?"
The question catches me off guard.
"You mean . . . last night? Of course I do."

"No, you idiot," she laughs. "You seriously forgot? Your grandfather Everett read us Seminary tales. There was the one about the poisoned princess that could only be saved with a single kiss. And we were in this room together after he left, playing pretend before your mom would take me back to the orphanage, and I laid down on your bed, playing dead, and..."
"Nope. Doesn't ring a bell. Maybe it was too traumatic," I tell her, and she glares at me with her crimson eyes until I apologize.
"It wasn't just a kiss, though. Gods damn, you must have snuck in your parents' room the night before when—"
"Enough."
"—they were getting a little intense and got some ideas, or maybe—"
"Stop it."
"—you thought my face was a slice of pie, hah, the way you dragged your tongue—"
"Enough!" I shout, crumpled on the floor with my head in my hands. "Yeah, I remember. I never wanted to again, though! Please, Khiras, dear Gods above..."
"I never said it was bad, though. You know how many times I've thought of that late at night?"
"That's your business," I tell her.
She crawls up to me.

"Well, I hope you're ready for a whole lot more," she says, but in her attempt at being sexy, I catch her off-guard. I throw my hands aside and lick her all the way across the face, pinning her to the ground.
She screams.

"You can have as much of this as you like!" I shout, tickling her as I wag my tongue above her face. She screams and jolts in laughter every time I poke her sides, though I only hold her down harder, making her laugh even more.
She headbutts me when I tickle beneath her armpit, and I fall back, stunned.
"Oh, Gods, I am so sorry," she says, drawing deep breaths after losing them all to fits of convulsive howling. "Are you alright?"
"I'm fine," I say, holding my hand into the bright rays of Lighttime that filter through the window: dragging my hand against my nose a couple times, only to find there's no red.
"No, no, no, I'm not losing you!" Sylvia says, pressing her hands against my sternum with firm compressions before I sweep her legs and she crashes to my chest.
"You need to take some acting lessons from Valentina," I say.
"Oh, hush."
And then I pull her head in for another attempt to correct my past. I make the most of it, and some time later, we rush out the door when we realize we're going to be late.
Sylvia and I hold hands as we approach Valentina and Romin at the shop.
"When the fuck did that happen?" Romin asks.

We make it to the first safe-house by sundown, and Valentina and Sylvia hold up surprisingly well, despite my father's sentiments that they were too wimpy and frail, insisting they stay back or else they'd get frostbite. It's been the dynamic of our group that keeps us the warmest. We only poured through a hundredth of our shared memories. The time and toil passed so quickly that we were surprised when it was up.

They're still nave to the future that awaits us. I can still feel the long shadow of the Afterlife's avarice hang over the whole city, but I'm the only one aware that the exalted gods above us bleed all the same.
Part of me still doesn't want to tell them how it ends, but I know better. I need to trust they're strong enough to handle that truth, no matter how bitter and horrifying it is.

I just struggle to find a way to start. They keep me distracted with questions about Chymaerans and Snowdrifting, and any time Sylvia or Valentina edge into an emotional topic, Romin lambastes them with his witless humor, quickly changing the subject. All that persists is just that feeling of being watched. The wind howls, though there are so few animals beyond the walls that can muster such a call. And as much as Romin comes to accept that the First Red might be a fairytale, I know they're real, hiding in every snowbank to act on anything that comes too close. They scare me more than the Chymaera.

After Romin unloads his limited rations of Dead Essence in the old fireplace, the dull orange light brightens with crimson, fighting off the cool, pale moonlight trapped in the tattered curtains. Romin and Valentina sleep close—just far enough so they don't think we think they're that close—only coming together when they think Sylvia and I are fast asleep.

I wake up and they're on opposite sides of the room. Romin thumbs through the picture book he read last time like an oversized toddler, and Valentina straightens her hair in a reflective surface, until she realizes nobody's going to see it.
"Did you guys hear that last night?" Sylvia asks, wiping the dust-covered plates with snow-dampened cloth before she prepares us some of the rations.
"The wind was loud. A couple animals, and that was about it," I mutter, realizing I slept soundly for the first time in ages.
"What about you, Valentina? Romin?"
They shake their heads.
Sylvia says, "There were footfalls, in the snow. I looked outside, but it was so dark, and with all the trees, I couldn't see anything."
"A pack of wolves, maybe?" Romin says.
"No. I could have sworn I saw light," Sylvia says.
"Another Snowdrifter, maybe," says Valentina.

"Not a chance," I say. "The odds of that are slim. And if it's that late — and you're on the edge of freezing to death — you'd be pounding on the door of this cabin. You wouldn't just keep going: you'd need far too much Essence just to stay warm!"

If it wasn't a penniless Snowdrifter, it'd have to be someone with such a high level of Essence that the weather wouldn't phase them. The Afterlife has no reason to come out here. Plus, I think we're still too far from the First Red.
"Doesn't matter," I say. "Let's finish up breakfast and keep moving." There isn't just one stop that awaits us today. I want to go all the way to the end.
Romin and I pull a sled while the girls walk beside us. The path I took last time comes back to me, so I find I never need to use the map.

A blistering snowstorm blasts between us, casting us each in our own little white room unless we stand closely together, the wind erasing our deep footprints as soon as our boots leave the ground. The snow feels shallower and crunchier than I last remember, and all I can think of are Sylvia's words.

I marvel at how well the plan has worked so far, but even more than that, it surprises me how little anxiety I carry. I've done everything to prepare, and I've done everything I can, and the dream doesn't seem so insurmountable anymore.

This worldline will change everything. For once I can finally reach that celestial pebble of Pure Essence and vest myself as a Mask of the Gods: my true birthright. My stomach fills with the static of excitement when I feel that dream spill over into a tangible reality.

I can barely contain myself when the cabin's dilapidated roof emerges from the top of the snowdrifts. I'm running now despite my exhaustion—and although my friends laugh as I trundle through tall pockets of powder, I can feel it call to me. I've earned an easy end to all this suffering. I can feel how badly I lust for that beautiful dream when I bash the door open at its hinges, only to find that snowflakes have already siphoned in.
The barricaded door to the study hangs by a single hinge, and then that feeling of powerless anguish returns to me, cursing the hubris I allowed to overtake my sense of reality.

My heaving breaths of exhaustion don't stop when I'm no longer running. My friends prod at my eagerness in good humor, but I can no longer hear them as they enter. I scramble on my hands and knees to tear back the carpet in that same corner. Touch confirms my fears when I find no cool metal box beneath the floor.

I thought that I held so much of that poisonous fear, churning in my stomach, that I became immune to the highs and lows of peace and desperation, but here I am, heaving in shallow breaths on the floor of the office, fighting the urge to vomit, gasping for cold air, almost just as lost as all the times before when I navigated this world alone.

But this time is different. Romin lifts me to my feet as Sylvia instructs me to breathe. I feel so pathetic, but in their concern I realize they genuinely care about me: not because of some favor I asked them, hinging on debts overdue.
Valentina reassures me. "It's okay, Titus. We're still going to make it through this. All of us," she says.
"Who cares about a stupid necklace? I'll find you something far better," Romin says. "Most days I work repossessions with Carmine business. Nobody hides anything from us."

"Just stay strong, for all of us," Sylvia says, and with all my friends smiling back at me, the gravity of this horrendous outcome becomes just a little bit more tenable. "We're here for you all the way until the end."
I mutter incoherently. "The whole plan. It was all around that piece of Pure Essence. And it's missing. But I'm the only one who could have known . . ."
"All we can do is move on," Romin says.
"He's right," says Valentina, "and you still have that surprise for us, right? So don't give in now!"
I made a promise to Ellie. I swore on our reunion in the Reservoir that I would never return again by my own hands, and I refuse to break that.
I'm not going back. I will never go back again, and with that decision consciously made, I have the courage to look ahead once more.
"Change of plans, then. We're going to keep going," I tell them.
"But what about the loot? The sleds?" Sylvia asks.

"That's not our priority anymore. That's not what this trip was about, after all," I say, as I pick up the framed picture of me, Lyra, my birth mother, and Ullrich, pulling the worn photograph from the shattered glass as proof for what I plan to do next. I turn to Romin.
"You deserve to be rewarded for your loyalty and hard work to the Carmine. This is your chance to turn the tides of the upcoming war, and convince our greatest allies that it's time to return."
His eyes grow wide. "You don't mean..."

We trudge on for another three hours, until the fear of the darkness begins to embed itself in my friends. They believe in our shared mission and every word I tell them. I explain just enough for them to understand, but not too much. I anticipate their genuine reactions.
The weather climbs, faintly, a few degrees at a time. Grasses can be made out through slush, instead of plated sheets of ice scraping the near infinite landscape.
"Can you feel that?" I ask them. "The temperature, yeah, it's rising," Valentina says. "I thought it was coincidence."
"We're almost there," I say.
And then a sudden sense of unease, the feeling of being watched.

We're getting closer and closer to the territory of the group that will kill to hide their presence. The crunch of icy footfalls catch Romin's attention first. Six forms, concealed in transparent Chymaeran scales, steady their firearms. Last time it was because Lyra was with me. And I know the only reason they don't pull the trigger this time is because of Romin's Carmine mark.
"State your business or be executed where you stand," one calls out. "There is no return from here."
"We bring a message for the Elders of the First Red. The message you've all been waiting for," I insist.

"There is no story of Blackwater our finest messengers can't deliver. We are surprised my nothing, so what is your business here,  Snowdrifter? How did you find us, and how do you know who we are?" A familiar voice asks, wrapped in a white scarf that masks his dark face.
"The end is near," I say. "The Afterlife are preparing their last strike to reap what they have sown."
"Said every false prophet for the last two-hundred years," Raine says. "Your lies don't interest me. I'm interested in what the Carmine Brother has to say."
Which is exactly what I've planned on.
"Brother Romin. Second Blood. Son of the District Fourteen Carmine," he says.
I see Raine's eyes light up on a realization he hasn't quite grasped yet.

"The Fourteenth District," Raine says, lowering his gun, though the other five aren't so easily disarmed. He's light with his words because he's not the one being threatened. "My sons used to live there. I know it's a common name in the Carmine, after our founder, but one of them even had your name."
"I lost my mother and father long ago, at the same time," Romin says. "It was a freak accident. Closed casket funeral, and I was forced to pick up the slack."
"Huh," Raine says, uncomfortably scratching his brow while both sides come to the realization faster than these two brainlets can. "Just know that this is not a personal act—"
"Dear Gods above, you're both as big as you are stupid," Valentina says. "Really? Do you not see what this is?"
"Now, Val, really?" Romin asks, annoyed. "I'm trying to keep them from executing us on the spot!"
She groans. "Last name. What's your last name, Romin?" "Zebal. But why? These outwallers aren't going to know me—the fabled First Red's been out here for decades!"

The six Carmine drop their rifles. The name is familiar to all of them. They've only heard the stories of this child for nearly two decades, told over and over by the father just to keep that memory alive.
"That means . . . you're my . . ." Raine mutters, stepping closer to Romin as we drop our hands, as if we're a vision more transparent than they are. "Oh Gods, how many years have I been gone?"

I turn to Romin. For once I think the dumb brute doesn't get it, but it's because he's not elated by this discovery. He's mad. Furious, even, and he pushes his father away, casting him backwards onto his back while the five others raise their guns again.
"No! Put your guns down," Romin's father demands, before raising his head. "But why, son? Why would you do that when we've been dreaming of this moment for years?"

"No, you dreamed of this!" Romin shouts. "I had to live! I had to pick up the slack of my dead brother and fill your shoes because I never had a father to raise me. Ryder died thinking you were gone. And me, Gods be damned, I lived on in your name, only to find you're hiding out here the whole time? And after all this time..." He pauses, trying to channel his spiteful rage into a string of words. "After all this time, you and the First Red left us there to protect nothing? I spent my whole life trying to keep the Carmine going . . . to keep them strong, when we were all just a fake for true leadership," he said, heaving from the exhaustion of a single breath.
"Romin. Romin, it's not like that," Commander Zebal said. "Just let me explain!"

"Then why didn't you tell me? Why did you leave me with nothing besides a vault door I couldn't open? It's . . . It's as worse as lying," Dad, the word balanced on his tongue, but he wasn't sure if he was ready to say it.

"But you know the value of that secret," Zebal said. "The First Blood are alive and well, but it wasn't without sacrifice. There were too many moles in the main temple. And when the calling of our mission came — nobody could know that your mother and I went somewhere else."
Romin doesn't reply. He knows his father was right. He's amazed by his dedication—but feelings don't require logic to feel legitimate.
Zebal continues: "Rose and I had to leave. We had to. I know it wasn't fair to our boys. It wasn't fair to Ryder, or you, but we had to.
She and I. Your...your mother and I . . . e e had to." His mouth and tongue contorted on the letter 'S' but quickly changed back. "Romin, we had to. If they knew, the truth would destroy us."

"Then what has the Carmine been doing this whole time?" Romin said. "Pissing in circles? Are we just a club full of blind idiots? Are we just a distraction for you? What's the purpose of it, what's the purpose of doing anything?"
"Son." Commander Zebal purses his lips as he approaches his youngest. "Son, you've done a service to the future of Humanity," he says. "The Carmine of Blackwater are the reason we could get this far.
The value of your work saves the lives of good people."

"But..." Romin says. "Ever since Ryder passed, we haven't been close to what it used to be." He's petrified in the same metal casting that immortalizes his brother, his face sullen with a certain weakness that wears against his laugh lines in a grimace. "I've never lived up to his image. I look at the statue that immortalizes him, and every morning I stand in its shadow. It feels like it's never enough." His voice now trembles. It's seeing the mannerisms of someone he thought he had forgotten so long ago that grips him with such an inescapable weakness, where his brawn is no match.
"You've done enough, son. The Carmine has done enough. And it's done everything it's had to," he replied.

He embraces his last living son. He weeps for the death of Ryder— a sense of guilt nagging him in his utter yet forced lack of awareness. "I want you to never forget that I'm proud of you," he says, "and I always will be. The chance to see my son again is a beautiful gift."
The corners of Romin's mouth stretch across his face, and a certain glow emanates from his chest, thawing the stillness of his joints. "Thanks," he says.
"I still need to know what brings you here. Nobody else would have this chance, but the best gift I can give my son and his closest friends is the benefit of the doubt."
"A message. The city is in danger, and only the Carmine have the capacity to give Blackwater a fighting chance against the Carmine. It's time to go home," Romin says.

The weather is temperate. The grass is verdant. And as Romin parts with his father to catch up on decades of lost time, Valentina and Sylvia find no words to hold their amazement when they see the Backwoods for the first time.

What amazes them most is the surplus of Essence and how it's used so openly: farmhands tending crops in once inhospitable climates, cultivating them with a turnaround of mere weeks, with the same technique of that chamber beyond time.

Young cadets of the true First Blood train along the walls, learning how to harness generational Essence to protect themselves and the village. The buildings germinate from the sides of dirt trails with stripped birch pillars, as if the city had grown from its surroundings.
When the distraction and awe diminish enough, they realize we're not just wandering aimlessly, that I'm taking them somewhere.
"Where are we going, Titus?" Sylvia asks.
"I've got something to show Valentina,"I tell her.
"What is it?" Val asks.
"We're going to the west walls. A village this size couldn't survive without help."
"Not help from Blackwater, of course," she says. "But who, then?"
"The ones who share your blood," I say. "They should be here today.
They've been supporting the Humans for a long time, and I think they'd be just as amazed if they met you."
Her eyes light brighter than any expression she acted out for her moving pictures. "You can't be serious. That's impossible. I never..."
"We need to hurry! Come on — they won't be here for long."
She tugs with a reluctance, but not enough to show she truly doesn't want it. "O...okay," Valentina replies, with a stage fright as if she were giving her first performance.
"You're gonna be great," I say.

Her mannerisms remind me of Ellie when we approach them: a childlike mix of disbelief and wonder. I had only seen them in passing when I last arrived here. Their tongues rattled off Ahkvasan in quick, accented words. An orange-striped Ahkvasan commands all the others, ushering them to move boxes of supplies into the barracks.
Valentina approaches awkwardly. She looks back at me.
No. No, go ahead, I gesture, they don't bite. They're not animals.
"N—Nord," she said. She startles the orange-stripe, and he jumps back a near foot.
"Ahk'na!" He shouts. The others snigger at the easy fright of their leader.
"Sorry, heh. Nord. Do you speak Nord?"
"Yes. Yes, you scare me," he says. "How can I be service?"
Valentina pauses. She forgets the lines. I know this moment has played in her imagination ever since she learned she was different. She grasps for the words to introduce herself.
"I'm Valentina. I'm like you."
Orange-stripe snorted: "Hah. Like us? What do you mean?" he says, intrigued as Valentina's fingers reached for her hat.

I see her hesitate for a few moments. She glances back at me, reflexively, before withdrawing the hat from her head. The foreigners' expressions change from jeering grins to amazement, before cries of disbelief escape from their mouths.

Valentina recoils in fear of mockery, bowing her head, eyes stuck on a patch of dirt she traces with the toe of her boot. She expects them to treat her no different. But she feels their sharp claws lightly trace around her ears and she lets out a squeak. Her ears flutter in response.
"Incredible!" Orange-stripe says. "But the Essence, the Essence . . . with half blood between us and the Humans, do you know if . . ."

Valentina's eyes meet his with a novel sense of clarity, as if the peace of acceptance has begun to revitalize that half of her. "Raise your hand," he instructs, and Valentina touches her palm to his.

Mere moments pass before I realized what is happening: the impossible speed of their mannerisms, their speech, lips moving so fast I couldn't even discern their words, and in awe I realize that it wasn't the two of them moving fast, but the world around them slowing down. It really is real, the true power of the Ahkvasans, to slow the speed of time — and I realize I'd seen it once before, in that selfless moment that Valentina saved us from the falling debris.

She draws that same power from within herself. She is truly one of them: her abilities born from two different races, and as they trade words, I see her straighten with a beautiful confidence I've never seen before. Not what she acted in the theatre, or the Academy programs, or even when I talked with her.
It's only a minute that passes. To her, maybe it's been hours, but either way, I know the eternity of that moment will live with her — for as long as we all survive.
Sylvia and I leave Valentina there, and Sylvia's eyes glow as I bring her towards the next destination. "You have something to show me, too, don't you?" She asks.

It's the thing I fear the most about all of this, but it's what can prove, beyond any shadow of a doubt, that this is the right time to act. "I do. Just know that we can always ask forgiveness after the evidence is undeniable," I tell her. "All you have to do is trust me."
"I always will," she tells me.

Impossible truths are easier to swallow when they're told by the ones you cherish, when they're an emotional investment. It's why Ellie was disappointed every time I came home late to her, because despite my good intentions—and all the demands that weighed on me in those years of the Academy, between family, school, and no personal life—a part of her clung to a persuasive hope every time I said that I would come home to her.

Romin, Sylvia, and Valentina were convinced before all of this by the heaviness of my words, impossible coincidences, and the trust I've built within each of them, but when it comes to the intimate strangers that remember nothing of our shared suffering, the persuasion requires far more. Only dramatic acts can cover where the conviction of closeness can't.
"I know there's a voice inside you that's spoken for years, trying to get out," I tell Sylvia. "You told me in another life."
"No. It's just hysteria. Pleading, begging for me to accept that I'm something else, that this is all just a faade,"she insists.

"What if I told you there was a chance to stare it down once and for all?" I ask. It gives her pause. Maybe she can feel herself compelled towards that inner truth that terrifies her. "For so long you've told me how unexceptional you think you are, but you're far more than that. You say you're dragged at my heels towards greatness. That you only thrive in the shadow cast by the three of us, but you are more important, and more powerful than you could ever imagine."
"I'm just scared," she says, though she doesn't even know where I lead her.
"I will be with you through it all, from the beginning to the end, and every moment after," I tell her. "You are the final and most essential piece to this plan. I can't do this without you."
"Then I promise you I will try," she says.

Despite everything that's worked so far, I can feel my stomach twist on itself. I might be more afraid than she is, because I know exactly what's going to happen. It's a huge gamble. It's inconceivable to think someone so small in size could hold such tremendous power, and I hold myself from remembering the terror of our first encounter.

We reach the steps of the Chieftains' lodge, completely unguarded. The whole village is in an uproar since the prodigal son returned: the one fictionalized by all of Raine's stories, absorbing all the attention. I'm just lucky how much Romin likes to talk about himself.
It's just the smallest pebble of Pure Essence, but I can already see how it makes her twitch when we enter. My own sensitivity heightens with the Essence in my circuits from another life.
"Are you sure about this? I just . . ."
"I would do it myself. But my blood refuses it. I'm cursed by a decision I made a long time ago," I tell her.
"I can hear it again, Gods above," she cries, holding her head as a splitting migraine brews in her head. "The voice! The voice of the Gods, and it screams to be let out..."
My guilt overtakes me. "It's okay, Sylvia. There's time. We can do this again after—"
She grabs my hand, tensioning her fingers between the spaces of mine, to fill-in the words she can't speak, and I tighten my hand to share with her my strength.
She hardly has to raise her other hand. The pebble magnetizes to the side of the glass, trembling as it begs to be released, rocking with the slightest motion of her hand as the glass splinters.
"I'm scared, Titus! Oh, Gods, it's—"

The protective shield hardly shatters when the stone launches through the jagged hole. It's only after it makes contact with her hand, absorbing into her circuits entirely, that the pulse of turbulent winds deafen our ears, shattering every window as I feel her embrace me tighter and tighter.

"I've got you, I'm never letting go," I say, though her newfound strength begins to hurt. The smell of ozone floods the small lobby, and though the thousand cuts of glass writhe my flesh as turbulent winds circle around us, a strange heat binds and heals them.

I can feel the resonance of celestial power in my threads, the way my right arm emblazons in a flash of heat, and when silver strands of her hair touch my cheek like ribbons of pure moonlight, I know that this time is different.
"For the first time, you've awoken me with real purpose, human," the Daughter of Khiras says. "You've come such a long way. And you really believe this will be the last time?"
"I'm certain of it."
"What makes you so sure?"
"Because I know I can live with whatever comes next. I've prepared with everything I have, I'm unwilling to bow to anything, unless it truly forces me down," I say.

"Oh, is that so? Then for what reason do you summon me?" She grasps my shoulders, staring directly down at me as I try to meet her gaze, though glancing her eyes feels like staring into the street lamps of Lighttime, leaving a fluorescent glow when my eyelids hinge in protest. "If you're so certain on your own, then why do you need the help of a Celestial?"

"I don't ask you to crumble their glistening peaks with the strength of your hands. This is our fight: wrought by humans, so it must be solved by us alone. It can't be won without the costs of loss and casualty. All I ask for is the persuasion of your presence."

"Then you'll prove it to me," she says. Her strength bends to nothing when she takes my right arm in her hand, tracing the mangled, threaded scars with her fingers. "As long as this boon softens the blows of true, one-pointed destiny, you will always be too weak."
I can feel the anxiety of real death still there, deep inside me. She chides me with a mocking smile. I hear the footfalls of the furious First Red approaching.

"The world is so much greater than this small, forgotten scab of frostbitten dirt. Your whole world is less than a speck on the shores of eternity. Tell me, then, human: when all this is over, if you die before you see the fated end, then what will you have left?"
"Then I'll have both the ones I love waiting for me on the other side."
I can swear I see her face flush as a heat flash rises. "But you erased her. You've abandoned everyone in those old lives, don't you understand? What do you have left when no one will remember you?"
"With absolutely nothing? Then all I'll have is the honor." I extend my mangled arm to her. If this clears the barrier preventing me from using my birthright, then it's a wager I have to make.

"You've proven yourself worthy, then," she says, projecting pure energy across my circuits. The tangle of latticed lashes beneath my flesh dances as if worms wriggle beneath my skin. The mangled mess is untangling itself, and before long, a single thread remains.
"But . . . I thought you were taking it away?"

"The Gods of Purgatory have seen far too many of your kind come and pass; demigods absorbed by their selfish visions; promising the world to those who listen when they're less than dust. I can feel how much you've changed this divergent piece of myself called Sylvia. Don't you remember that you gave her that name?"
The memory is dim, but I know it's there.

"So I'll give you a chance, human, because she tells me to believe. You have control of this cursed boon, whether to erase it, or to let it consume you. Sever the thread when the time is right, and with enough Essenced power, you will imbue yourself with the powers of the Mask."
My hands reach for the thread. "If I've decided this is my last chance, then why wouldn't I do it now?"
"Because the fate you forestalled still has to collect. It is the law of nature. So do you really have what it takes to let go of what you never deserved?"
My stomach twists on all the things I've come to possess that I never had before: experiences I've stolen.

"In the grand scale of the universe, the breadth of your lifetime is a single breath in the lungs of the Divine. I will grant this small piece of me this life. Just promise me one thing," the Goddess says, wearing a familiar expression I recognize from the one I love the most.
"Anything."

"Cherish me in the time you have," she says, taking my hand as she guides me out the double doors. I can feel the Goddess' rigid grasp taper off as Sylvia regains her heading, the two coalesced as one in divine spirit.
"Your love is burned in my soul, and I will cherish you in every life I'm given, no matter how memory fades with age and rebirth," I promise her.
The villagers congregate outside the hut, trading their anger for awe as they prostrate in zealous worship.

"Brothers and Sisters of the Carmine: I stand before you today with the prophecy of a certain future. Fletcher has seen every end, and I've been the passenger to every outcome. You have a chance, when all the failed realities before you have folded inwards on the avarice of the Afterlife, reaping the souls they've sown for Essence by the great Chymaeran weapon Endogeny."
She floats in the air as her worshippers drink to her celestial presence. Lyra's eyes are the only ones that focus on me, dumbfounded by the name she's waited decades to hear again.

"It is time to return. This is your fight to finish, and you carry my will and blessing to stop the Afterlife, before they extinguish the family you hold dear. Hesitate for nothing. Give your lives for the freedom of your people: the true humans whose souls are uncorrupted by golden dreams."
I can see her celestial charisma fade as Sylvia returns to me, her silver hair darkened as she descends to the ground and into my arms.
"I remembered it," she tells me. "I could have dissolved away to that other realm. But I want to experience this life here, with you."
"And I'll have you for as long as you'll stay," I say. "Just please — hey, what's wrong?"

"I told you that I remember. It was all so awful!" She says, and her eyes fill with tears as she buries herself in my tattered jacket. "If only I knew how much you suffered just to get here. I wish I could have done more, when you were so alone, just..."
"It's alright," I say, as I return Sylvia to her feet. "All that matters is that I'm here now. And—"
"Fletcher," Lyra says, standing at the bottom of the steps as she extends her arms. "They thought I was crazy. I was even beginning to lose faith, but..."
"Go spend time with your sister," Sylvia says. "It's time you get to know her all over again."
The First Red spent forty-seven years beyond the walls in the Backwoods, prepared every day to leave at a moment's notice.
And today was no different.

I steeled myself to persuade them in the vote, siding with Lyra, hoping to use Romin for leverage on Raine, but now they leave in a mass exodus, carrying their lives on their back as we march to the city.

They're too afraid to talk to Sylvia, but Valentina walks beside her, unaware she left her hat behind. Behind them, Romin laughs with his father, reminiscing on distant memories of his mother Rose: the last thing they did was pay respects to her grave. And I walk beside Lyra, listening as she tells me stories of a past life I can't remember.

I tell her of the trials we faced together in another life. She laughs at the times she almost killed me. I feel like I've robbed her of these sublime experiences through resetting, though she reassures me that my return to her is all that matters.

The group divides by province at midday, yet an uncountable number of Carmine still trudge towards District Fourteen. The evening settles in the sky though no one is nervous: their Essence potential so great that our pocket of nomadic land becomes bearably cold. When we settle for the night, no fires light the sky. All is pitch black, or else smoke might give away the mass approach.

I rest beside Sylvia, back-to-back with her so neither one of us has to sleep on the ground. By the time the brief lapse of sleep comes to me, the snow has thawed down to dirt, the climate so strangely temperate while snowflakes still sink in the distance. The disappearance of the Amulet still torments me, and the longer I try to reason what changes I sewed intro the fabric of this final effort, the less I feel I know.

"This is the best I can do," I mutter to myself, long after Sylvia falls asleep on my shoulder. I try to stay awake just to support her—so that neither of us wake on the cold, hard ground—but my exhaustion finally comes to nest, sometime after twin moons rise above the silhouetted trees.

I awake to softness on my cheek, and for a minute, I think I'm home. She smiles as my head rests in her lap, brushing the coarse tufts of my jet-black hair so I can see her. She tries to bend down to kiss
me, though something else gets in the way. My face flushes. And just from waking up, I notice there's a new sapling in the forest.
"Was that my fault?" She asks.

I survey the camp. The sky is still dark, and the early-risers are just waking up. Romin and Valentina are sprawled against a tree, and near them, Raine waits impatiently for his son to wake so they can talk again. The Carmine keep the fires small as daylight crests, just enough  to set a carnivorous odor in the air as they satisfy their hunger, waking the lazy ones to the smell of freshly-grilled meat.

That afternoon, we arrive at an unfamiliar burrow: an abandoned mineshaft whose entrance is no taller than my head, so low that Sylvia and Romin have to duck to fit inside. The single-file path runs hot with sweat for the first hundred yards, until the branch opens to a main tunnel, lit by plumes of fire conjured between the well-trained travelers' palms.

The path runs straight into the city, and just as hunger begins to overtake us, bright blue light marks the opening of a long-forgotten quarry, years etched in the stone that are older than the city by centuries. I'm sure the search of subterranean treasure halted when the Humans found a far greater resource: themselves.
Raine instructs us to disperse as we approach the Compound, and since I've acquainted myself with Lyra better than she knew me in past lives, she accompanies our Fireteam to the Compound.

"This is the best I can do," I mutter to myself again when my allies can't listen; when I feel the weariness of my body reflect in my weathered soul. I wonder what my mother would say to me in moments like these, and when I remove my mother's necklace to polish the cold obsidian, I try to imagine what secrets died with her.

We reconvene at the compound around midnight, and the streets are so silent I wonder if Endogeny already cleared them. Hundreds gather in the belly of the Carmine Stronghold, awaiting the moment they spent five decades waiting for. I manage a glance between two Brothers when it opens, and when it does, the thunderous cheers of Carmine tremble the throated hallways like the deep growl of a beast.

I let Romin relish in his moment. Hours later, they'll be planning their advances, and in less than two days, the assault on the upper lands will begin. To quote Romin, "There's no chance someone won't notice all these sweat-soaked, piss-smelling Outwallers."

I move upstairs to catch an air of silence, and I find Valentina and Sylvia leaning over the balcony of the second floor. Below, the commotion rises as the Carmine prepare themselves for war, trading their cries of jubilee for barks of disciplined order.
The overlook captures the full expanse of the Foothills, casting the three of us in the point of its shadow.
"Titus. Titus," A familiar voice calls. "You're here, praise the Gods...."
I turn to find my father's lone shopkeeper. At her old age, I'm surprised to find her dressed in the robes of the Carmine.
She takes me away from my two friends.
"Maude. What is it?"
She pants for breath after climbing the stairs, barely able to manage the words.
"Your father's been waiting for you to return," Maude says. The itching fear I've had since leaving returns to me, and I know her next words before she speaks them.
"It's Ellie. She's missing," she says.
"You're in the Carmine. How didn't I know you were a Sister?" I ask. "I should have seen you at the Compound, at least once, on those days I visited Romin."

"Because I'm nobody at all. A ghost, Titus, spread so thin between fragments of personality that I forgot who I was to start." At first I thought it was the sound of keys in her pocket clattering against a ring, but when the dark obsidian in my necklace matches the charms hanging from the metal loop, I know what she's been this whole time.

"City folk have no idea of what lurks in the shadows. How many of us there really are. And we play our parts with so much conviction because most can't separate themselves from the lives they overtake.
We're—"
"Chymaerans. Half-blood informants, you must be," I say.
She's surprised at my quick answer. "But . . . how did you know that? Gods above, did you know the whole time?"
"I only came to know recently. Very recently. I had the chance to meet a few of you," I say.
"They'll never tell you. What gave it away?"

"Nothing. They were sent to protect us. Gave us clothes to conceal our identities, so convincing I'd never guess their guises were dead for years." I play with the pendant between my fingers. "They told me something. They said there was an informant here that might be interested in this."
She doesn't have to turn to know what it is. "A guise token. But where did you get it from?"
"From my mother. The First Red Chymaerans were overjoyed when they found it. They insisted it belonged to someone in the city."

"Well, good luck, kid," she laughs. For every hundred people, you can bet at least one of them is a Chymaeran. You see all these?" She holds up the ring of charms. "This is a tenth of what I've had. I've lived and burned hundreds of these guises, given no longer than months for each of them."
"Then what would cause someone to stay in one guise?" I ask.

She pauses for a moment. "It would take conviction. It would take a feeling of guilt, probably. And after all of it . . . Gods, I remember the faces I wore for months . . . you can still feel fragments of those mannerisms, those personalities, lingering there, long after you burn those connections. The code is 'no longer than a month,' or else you're made."

I glimpse at the face of every civilian we pass to find their tell, as if I could see their truths so easily. When I give up, I withdraw the clasp from around my neck, pooling the last surviving artifact of the past in my palm.
"My mother cherished this. Maybe you can find its owner," I tell her. I have no use for it anymore.
"But you value that, son," she says. "It's more useful to you than any Chymaeran on the street."

"It's time I let go of the past," I say. And as we approach Clint's trade building, she sits outside on the three-legged bench, taking the necklace in her hands, trying to discern anything from the energy within.

"Titus, you jackass, why didn't you come any sooner? Dear Gods above, son! How could you not know?" He shouts. His face is redder than mine after braving the cold. There are spaces on the shelves where antiques are missing. I see small gears, springs, and scraps of wooden debris scattered across the floor.
"I was beyond the walls, Clint! Calm down."

"You didn't even see her before you left! She never made it to Seminary. How could you not know something was wrong?" He strains his fingers against the fabric of my shirt, because I'm too big now for him to do anything else.
"Her bag was gone, Dad. She ate breakfast. Her window was closed. I thought she left early!"
"You bastard. Your laziness jeopardizes everything, can't you see that? If you'd just try—"

Like you do? I almost say, but realize it's not worth it. His hand trembles as he waits for a response. His greyed hair is disheveled, and I can tell he hasn't showered since he realized she was missing.
"When did you find this out?" I say, trying to level my voice.
"It was . . . two days ago. And I've tried everything," Clint says.
"The day after I left?"

"Yeah," he says. "And I would have known earlier if you didn't take so damn long! I didn't realize until the nanny you hired couldn't find her. Gods, and that was two days after it happened. She must have run  away, Titus. I know she's sick of our feuding. So lonely, even."
But he can't handle his part of the blame.
"If only you signed that damn form, son, she'd've had a chance at a better life!"
"You're right," I say.
"No, I know I'm right. If you just..." He pauses. "Wait. What did you say?"
"You're right. There's so much more she deserves than what we could both give her. We were too distracted: so busy with our grief and our obsessions that we never really listened."

"And now she's gone, Titus! The City Guard report nothing, I've checked over and over, and she's probably frozen somewhere. Dear Gods, Titus, if your mother were still here, things would be so different. I wouldn't give you so many reasons to hate me," he says.
"I don't hate you. You're my father. You taught me how to swing a sword, and though we disagree, that doesn't detract from the reasons I'm thankful."

"Don't spite me, son. I don't deserve your thanks. This stupid shop. And Moira! I see that picture, and every time I hate myself more, knowing what I leave behind. when I know how long it's been that I've waddled in this addiction."
"And I'm my father's son," I say. "We're going to find her. Because if she has even a tenth of our resilient spirit, she'll survive anything."
"Yeah," he musters. "Yeah. We can't give up." He picks up an ancient metal tea set, brushing it off before he notices the large dent in the other side. I stoop down to help him.

I leave ten minutes later. Maude is gone by the time I return to the Compound, along with the necklace, and all I can think of is the final promise I made to Ellie: how reassured I feel that I don't have to handle the unforgivable — or at least not until I see her again.
"Dear Gods, and our kids have no idea what's going to happen," Romin says, crouching beside me as we watch from a pile of rubble behind the warehouse.
"And under what pretense do they force themselves in?" Lyra asks.

"That the kids are out past curfew. They knock on the door, because all kids see is just authority, not politics or ulterior motives, and then..." I remember that horrific sight from the time I didn't know.
Romin says, "I'm hinging this whole operation on your hunch, so you better be gods-damn sure you're right. This is my chance."
"It's going to happen," I say. But after all that's changed, the words almost hang in a question, and when Romin looks back at me, I make sure my face is resolute.

Whatever force of fate that fights me can't possibly know that I've everything right, and the Gods are on my side, so it has to be! I look down at the lone scar on my arm until I can hone my feelings of righteousness into surrogate truth.
"You're sure? You're absolutely sure, Titus?" Romin asks.
And then he gets his answer.
When he looks back, a First Red Sister conjures two faint flares of fire while she leans against the side of the building.
"Something's going on," Romin says. "She's not sure yet."
"It's about that time," I say. But the first time I wasn't there, and the second I was so far underground that light couldn't tell me the hour. I can still feel it's going to happen.
Two more faint pops of light.

"Still not sure. But they're approaching." He motions for Lyra and I to move up. Ahead, my eyes can barely pick up on several of the First Red in their transparent, Chymaeran-scaled cloaks, steadied with axerifles, ready to blast a hole in anything that gets too close. And then the scouting Sister retreats.
"Yeah. Whoever it is, they're definitely heading for the door. Lyra. Signal the Guise," Romin says, unable to conjure anything from empty circuits.

Lyra swipes her hands across the air. A line burns my retinas, and once I see through it, the two half-blood Chymaerans that guised my friends in a future past take the form of Merlotan city guardsmen.
"I wouldn't have gone for this. Those bastards deserve to die, but if you can make me eat my words-" Romin says.
They emerge from the right side of the property. One smokes a  false cigar conjured from whatever fabric their guises take on, and when the Merlotan impostors come into view, they hail them.
We get closer when they're distracted. I can hear the kids now, inside, dragging boxes and laughing at an innocent joke. And when I slide across the wall, I can barely make out their conversation.
"Disturbance call. Made by the fella across the street." He points at Clint in his shop.
"Please. Disturbing what? The position of some poor crates?" our Guise says.
"You know how this works. Just so we can write it off on the paperwork," the Merlotan says. "Three's enough but five's a crowd, so piss off somewhere else, will ya?"
"There's been a heavy hand on Carmine children for ages. We're not leaving. So do your business and get it done," the Guise says.

I find that same primal look of resigned panic in the guards' faces, the one those fake social workers had when they were on edge. Romin notices it too. But when his hand unbuttons the holsters, I halt him.
"I know your trigger finger itches for action, but this will work out. Trust me. Just watch: they're just beginning to realize they can't do anything."
"Well, I remember something about caged animals," Romin says.
"No witnesses, Romin. This has to happen inside the building. They can't have any reason to think anything happened to them when they came here."
I can feel the disdain in challenging his authority. But he can live with it. I'm swayed stronger by my vow to see this life through on a single chance.

The door hinges shut, and as we hold our baited breaths in silence, we listen, as an eternity drags on far too long, longer and longer, waiting for a voice, a sound, anything to give us a hint of what's going on inside while the rest of the Carmine stir uncomfortably around us, the basement team somewhere beneath the ground, waiting behind the same door I hesitated at, waiting for the signal, while Romin twitches in bitter anxiety, hoping something will just happen so he can get it over with, and as soon find I feel the same way, though I have the courage to weather the storm.
"You don't run this," he suddenly says. "I run this." His hand gravitates towards the axe-rifle, but he still finds that sense of hesitation.
It's only when we hear a loud crash that Romin lurches to action. I can hardly stop him when the shrill whistle rises in his throat. The sound halts when I squeeze his shoulder.
"Trust me, Romin. Not yet!"
"No, Titus! They follow my orders, not yours."
"I know. But trust your crew. We need those faces in there. They're gonna save those kids."

He groans hoarsely, only allowing an anguished whisper. He looks down into my eyes to see if I withhold my conviction, but I refuse. I can see that strain for power so close he can almost grasp it, because I saw it on the hill when he led those innocent young cadets to die.
"You've always been strong, Romin. You have nothing more to prove."
