I can see his nails bite into his fists. It takes a moment before he lets his itching pulse of energy off with a shiver.
Lyra joins me. "The Carmine are now stronger than they ever were before. None of them can anticipate our allied Chymaerans. Don't doubt our power."

Romin's hand raises in the air, and he clenches it in a fist. I can see his fingers almost hinge out with the signal to move before he gives in. "Fine, then. We'll wait a little longer, but I swear . . ." I can see how badly he itches for action, to be the one that got them, to bring it all home to his father.

I rest my hand on his shoulder. We lean further against the wall, and I peek into the windows of the cellar. Somewhere, I can overhear the faint commotion, and then a door opens in the basement, followed by light footsteps.
I can see the door crack open as the children descend the stairs.

Romin realizes what holds my focus and he watches with me, and a sigh of relief overtakes him. Between the kids, six figures stand past the doorframe in disguise. The only difference is, four don't know that the other two are playing the part better than they are.

It's when the last cadet crosses the doorframe that the Merlotan grabs him, pulling him backwards and slamming the door. The children cry out in panic, and it's then that Romin bashes himself through the window, the glass tinkling across the hard concrete of the unfinished basement as his feet plant on the floor.

Lyra and I follow right after him, and we realize we can't catch up. I can see the anger rise inside of him as he passes the survivors, taking three stairs at a time until his hand crumpled the brass doorknob,

tearing it off the wood as he throws the door open. He halts there, absorbing all the light of the main room, and when we get to the top of the stairs to look around him, we find the child lying there in a small pool of blood.
"We were too late," Lyra says. "We saved as many as we could, but —"
Romin bends his knees to reach down and lift the young cadet, still breathing though they cry in anguish.

"You're going to be okay," he says. I think he's just comforting the doomed until I realize he's telling the truth. The child has hardly a slice on his arm, just startled of the sight that I'm finally able to process.

The blood is from those bastards of the Afterlife. They never expected expertly-trained half-bloods to carve them up, and they sprawl across the floor as their dark blood pools together across the wood.
"It's Jeremy, right," Romin says, and the kid nods. "That was really scary, I know—but you were real tough, buddy," he says, and the child smiles.
"I'm tough," the child repeats, though they still tremble, snot and tears caked on their face as Romin wipes it off with his fresh cloak.
"One day, sir, I'll be strong just like you!"
"You will be," Romin says. "I'm proud of you."
He turns his back to the sight of the massacre as the Chymaerans dig out bones to make fresh Markers. They'll have to be quick to make this exchange convincing.

Less than five minutes later, we watch from the darkness as the first flames crackle the aged wood like an orange hand reaching out from inside the building, cramping its fingers on every window until it squeezes enough to bring the whole building down.
Sylvia shivers on the porch alone as I climb the steps.

"You didn't have to wait out here, you know," I tell her. "You should know by now where I keep the spare key. It's the same place Moira hid it for years." But when I reach for the porch's cross beam, barely able to drag my fingers across the splintered surface, Sylvia dangles it from between her fingers.

"I just didn't want to scare you, or give you some kind of false hope that your sister was back." She leans into me. Her cold skin sucks the warmth from me as I fumble the key into the lock, and when I twist the knob, a wall of warm air buffets us.

The door's shut before we can strip our jackets, and our boots condensate the warped wood floor, worn from years of neglect. The house is far too big for the two of us, especially at night, the way it creaks from the cold just to break the silence; how the dust highlights all the unused spaces a fuller family might have used; and it's no wonder Ellie slept every night with her door shut to ward off that overwhelming feeling, or else it might leak through.

My bare feet crunch into the stiff carpet, and with a layer less, I can feel how cold this space still is. I feed a couple logs into the fireplace, crumpling ages-old newspapers from the Merlotan Bulletin to ignite with Clint's old lighter resting on the mantle. Sylvia grabs the blanket Moira wove with Ellie, and my sister's unfinished strands tangle on Sylvia's bracelet when she tries to wrap it around her.
The smell of lavender is absent when my nose adjusts, though after all this time I still find that I expect it.

Sylvia's eyes feather shut on exhaustion until I speak. "I guess I could never make it like it was, no matter how hard I tried. For her. Just to make it a fraction as close as it used to be. I hired a maid for a while, then a caretaker. I gave them my mother's cookbook. I got the same scents she used to light. Once I even smoked on the porch, just to waft in the stink of Clint's tobacco, but no matter how hard so tried, it never broke that sense of disbelief."

"It's just a feeling you know without thinking. A habit, maybe. When it's dark in my room, the blinds are drawn, and the window is open, sometimes I awake still thinking I'm in that small bed at the orphanage."

"We played on this carpet as kids. A decade and a half away, and no more than an arm's reach from where the toy box was," I tell her. "I used to think it was just time that separates us. But the further I get from home, and the less time I have, the more it feels like it's something greater than that."

The polished tables are the only preserved piece in all the house. The drapes are faded from cycles of lighttime. So much furniture was gouged from this house at the estate sale, and I had to fight just to keep the tattered red couch I slept on while Clint read the news.

The same words he read back then float from the printed pages of kindling on glowing embers, cracking and popping like punctuation as strings of sentences dissociate to thoughtless smoke, never to be arranged in the same order again by either accident or intention.

"I wish I could hold on to this moment," I tell her. But she's already asleep: cuddled up to my arm the same way she did when we were kids, and silently, I wonder how many days it will take until this house is leveled like all the others, and without a reason to keep this roof above anyone's head, I find the attachment is no longer there. Maybe through all these lives, home has become something else — because I can still feel the heat while I fall asleep, without a corner of Sylvia's blanket.

I expect we'll sleep the whole morning away in the empty house, but the faint hum of something mechanical wakes me from beyond the window, chattering the glass. A lone girl stands on the porch, dressed in the fine garments of Merlotan prestige, and at first I don't recognize her without the hat.
"Valentina?" I ask, using the doorframe in lieu of a shirt. "What's going on?"
I see familiar garments in her hands: ones worn by the impostors the night before, still saturated in dried blood. "So Romin had an idea, and he told me to find people I can trust."
"You came to the right place. Maybe the timing was a little . . ." a yawn punctuates my sentence for me.
"Come with me, please," she asks. "I don't have the strength to go it alone."

"Of course. But I don't have any clothes here — Gods forbid the only formal thing I have left in a box somewhere is my seminary uniform. And Sylvia," I look to her still sleeping on the arm of the couch, "well . . . she's got all the dresses you gave her at the Academy loft."
She reaches behind her to unfold a triple-folded leather bag. "I came prepared because I knew your answer."
I laugh."No way. Is that . . . really?"

"Yeah. Unworn, too. Five years ago, Romin and I were going to a big Merlot event. Well, you went to that party yesterday, and we don't even call that formal," she says. "I got this made for him so he wouldn't stand out too much, but he hated it: went in his Carmine Reds, and I couldn't distance myself enough from him after he drank a barrel dry."
"I guess I'll wear it then," I say.
"Always the center of attention, Romin is, like he's trying to prove something. But this time is different."
"He's changed, just a little bit," I tell her.
"I guess so," she says. "Anyways. You two get dressed now, we need to head up there."
I look past her, squinting at the blood-red color of the touring car, far louder than the reserved, muted color of wine I expected.
"And we're going there in that?"
"I don't mind," she says, "plus — this is a rare time we should take after Romin. 'Loud' is exactly what we need."
Somewhere a quarter mile past us, the guards make out a cherry-red blip in the distance, squinting to try and tell whether the bright red is just an illusion in the muted fog of lighttime.

It should be dull and reserved like the banter at their parties: far from interesting, yet dressed in gold and far over-the-top. It's isn't until a hundred feet and closing that they raise their rifles to the hard-topped motorcar embellished with the crest of the Carmine.
"In the name of the Upper Gods, stop your carriage!" They yell. But Valentina keeps the speed of the motorcar steady. "Are you sure about this?" Sylvia asks, sitting next to me in the back.
"We should slow down," I add, grasping the seat in front of me to brace myself.
"By Gods above, loud I said. I meant it!" Valentina orders."This is a message. They won't get out of the house for me through diplomacy. Trust me — I've tried it so many times."
"Then what about the plan? Why are we dressed up?" I ask her.
"Change of plans. Now get ready."

I brace myself on the leather-bound seat in front of me, reaching my arm out to protect Sylvia. A loud crack erupts in the distance, and once the second one snaps the air, I realize they're taking potshots at us.
"Keep driving," Valentina insists. "Pedal to the floor!"

We're a stone's throw away when the third gunshot shatters through the window, through the front window glass, the front headrest, back headrest, and rear linoleum cover. We're so close I can hear the chamber load as two of them jump to the side, just as a third round blasts the tire, letting off a loud pop, chattering the car along on its axle like a train on overheated rails.

My trimmed nails try to dig into the headrest. My toes curl in my boots, and all my muscles tighten, though I can't decide whether or not I should go limp. The gate is grand and expensive, and after the last of the four desperate Merlotan guards dive out of the way, I scream with everything I have in me, maybe even louder than Sylvia.

The motorcar bludgeons the expensive golden gate open, bending the latticed, floral curvatures until they snap. The violent impact lays Valentina's chest into the horn, bashing it in so far it sounds even when she withdraws. Without power, the motorcar chatters along the muddy ground a bit longer, swerving on the missing front right tire until the spoke wheel sinks into the ground. We feel the center-of-mass shift to the missing tire, and with the speed so suddenly brought to a halt by a boulder, the car flips about its front until the hard-top becomes a softtop.
I'm dazed and disoriented, but we're fortunate that we find no blood.
"They're going to kill us now, Valentina!" Sylvia tells her, as she sprawls across the jagged roof-now-floor.

But she's laughing. "Ever since three years ago, they never let me through that Gods-damn gate, and I had to crawl through the drainage pipe to get to that cellar. Do you know how long I've dreamt of this?"
I unbuckle the seat belt and lower myself to the crumpled steel roof, careful not to cut myself on the frayed edges.
"Romin's not going to be happy," I say, as I orient my legs to kick out the glass.
"Love, he's totaled two of mine already. So I think he owes me," she says.

I ramble something about rich people when the heel of my boot strikes the glass. It's a miracle this vehicle kept itself together enough: any faster and it's own weight would have flattened us. There are at least twelve pairs of boots past the window by the time we try to escape, some the fatigues of the Merlotan guards, though most of them are startled groundskeepers, green stained on the knees of their trousers and work-gloves.

"Get out and put your hands up! No, behind your back!" a young guard shouts. His voice cracks. "Stand up slowly. On your knees. Legs crossed." I emerge first, with Romin's fresh formal wear stained with dirt and oil as I sprawl on the ground, their rifles aimed at my head, one gardener poised to attack with a set of hedge clippers as if he'll cut my head off. They gasp when Valentina comes out next, perfect hair disheveled, her secret features twitching with the commotion all around her.

"No excuses. No telling me I'm an unwelcome guest in my own home. No offers to drive me back to the Academy or shepherd me to the cellar or any of that disgusting neglect you're all passive to. You have no choice. Now you have to bring us to them," she says.

The staff are too uncomfortable to raise their weapons at a Vermillion, let alone her associates. All they can do is prevent us from leaving, which we don't intend to do anyway, and so we walk together towards the main house.
A tall woman approaches, holding a child as she stumbles through the grass in heels, careful to not let her insular, white fur coat touch the dirt.
"Gods above us, what is this vociferous racket?" She locks eyes with Valentina. "You Gods-damn weasel! What are you doing here?
What did you do to my gate?"
"I had to get your attention, Victoria," she says. "You wouldn't let me in otherwise. And all Vincent can ever do is be complacent."

"Nothing you do could ever be worth my time," she says, stroking little Vanna's hair from her eyes as Vanna sucks her thumb. "You have your damn audience, only because you're going to be fixing that yourself with your own sweat and blood."
"I only had to break the gate because you never let me in!"
Victoria strikes Valentina's face with her free hand, enough to stagger her, and I catch her before she has a chance to fall.

"You're only a lowly leech, child," she says, refusing to even look at her, and Valentina cowers, struggling to meet her stepmother's eyes as she rubs her cheek. "You're not a Vermillion. Nor will you ever fully be with your tainted blood, so don't think you're entitled." Her tone is muted, stating her truth as if fact.
Vanna begins to cry, and when Victoria consoles her, I clench Valentina's arm to goad her to continue. But she's silent, trying to fight back tears though they well in her eyes.
"Oh, I'm sorry, baby. Mother has unwanted guests. They'll be leaving," Victoria says. But Vanna reaches out her arms, reacting to her half-sister's change in emotion.
"Ally! Ally," she says, and though Victoria tries to reconcile any other reason she weeps, she has no choice. After a minute, she allows Vanna to slip into Valentina's arms.
Victoria sighs. She covers Valentina's disgraceful abomination with her hat. "Follow."

Sylvia takes Valentina's hand and I follow right behind them, ushered by guards that, even with weapons, have nowhere near that icy ferocity. Victoria stumbles several times before cutting onto the well-manicured sidewalk snaking up to the mansion, and we follow her, as Valentina copes with her crippling anxiety and tries to piece together the words before it's too late.

I give the bloodstained Merlotan garments to Valentina, the evidence still far more sullied than our formal wear. "Remember what we're here for. You're not alone," I tell her, and as we approach the main house, several flaxen-blonde-haired figures watch from the third story window.

"Dote on your sister while you still can, because it will be the last time you'll see her after Vincent is done with you," Victoria says. The grand doors open and we step inside, and even with all its servants, the house feels so empty without a cause for celebration. Valentina puts down Vanna, telling her to "go play" so she doesn't have to witness what comes next, but she grasps the edge of Valentina's skirt, and it makes me miss Ellie.
"No!" Vanna exclaims.
"You can't come with us," Valentina says, getting down on one
knee. "This might be the last time I'll ever see you. Maybe when you're older, I'll have the chance see you again, but..."

Vanna just stares at her, unaware of the meaning though she understands the feeling. She runs off into the adjoining room where her toys are strewn about, and so the guards usher us up the grand, marble foyer stairs embossed with a great, golden "V".

Dear Gods, they must have only stopped having kids because they ran out of "V" names, I think to myself, but I don't dare speak the thought aloud. Vera and Virgil accompany Valentina. I can feel how their mother's spite poisons them with secondhand squalor, their panic over the situation as if shepherding the damned to execution.

"Sissy, why are you here? What happened?" young Virgil asks, as Vera thanks the Gods she isn't in her sister's shoes. The caretakers are vacant on the upper floors; they flooded out as soon as they heard the doors and saw the cat-eared bastard child enter. Valentina's manicured nails bite the flesh on her palms though Sylvia and Vera try to console her.
"It's going to be fine, Val," Vera insists. "I'll talk to them. I'll do whatever it takes, just hang in there."
Valentina's voice wavers. "This is pretty irreversible, dear, but it's alright — because I think I learned something. For all these years, I never realized I was so much more than my name."
"No. Valentina, please don't burn this bridge. You're saying you're willing to—"
"I already bashed a gate in, love. I won't try burning anything, but a bridge isn't too much more."

His chair turns from the window when we enter, and a balding, mustached man sits behind an embossed mahogany desk. He seems so much smaller than I imagined, with such a large chair and a vacuous, high-ceiling office. Maybe it's the look of fear and confusion in his eyes when Victoria drags his daughter in.
"You know what this . . . outsider . . . and her associates did to your gate? Did you see what happened?"
He twirls the ink pen between his fingers. "No. What did they do?"
"They smashed it open. With a car! These intruders."
Vincent cringes at the word. Instead of making any effort to correct her, he crumples further in his chair, serving whatever words might appease his wife. "And what do you propose we do?"

Victoria turns so she can watch Valentina's face twist on her next words. "Virgil, Vera, this is no place for you right now, children. Run along." Virgil hides behind the doorframe though Vera lingers.
"What you say to my sister, you can say in front of all of us," Vera says. "And, Gods above, Vince, are you going to let her talk like that about your daughter?"
He opens his mouth to speak, but is cut short by Victoria.
"You dare stoop to her level?"
"She's my sister," Vera says, stepping foot into the massive study.

"She's an interloper. And she has no more future with us. We gave her sustenance to leech from us. We let her stay in the cellar with the rats, though this cockroach persisted to tarnish our property with her putrefied presence," she says, spitting every letter. "We should have the Royal Guard noose her up after we drag her from the lift!"
"Well. It's just a gate," Vince mutters.
"And she's just a bloody-damn criminal threatening our family's safety. Wouldn't you do anything to protect us?"

Mild-mannered Sylvia looks like she wants to tell them off, but I tighten my hand around her wrist. This is not our fight. Our words will only discredit Valentina's inner strength. All we can do is just be here, in this moment.
And so Valentina removes her mother's hat from her head, causing Vince to look away and Victoria's anger to rise further.

"I think you've said quite enough, Mother," she says. "So many years you've abused me. I remember standing here in this office when it was just you and me, almost ten years ago. You left a hacksaw from the tool shed on the floor, don't you remember? Without a word? And I knew what you wanted me to do, and I complied, and you relished in every moment of my suffering." She rubs the space between her back and rear. "You let me bleed until I passed out from the shock, and only then, did you let the caretakers tend to my self-inflicted wounds."
Sylvia's mouth hangs agape. And it seems that not even Vera knew the secret truth of her sister.
"Gods above, Val," I whisper, but Victoria cuts in.
"And I should have-"

"Neglected me every day I lived here, turning my life into misery, all while Vincent turns a blind eye to everything, digging deeper into the Merlot so he can see me even less and forget the daughter he used to love when he was allowed to." Her voice trembles with such rage and righteous conviction. She pauses to calmly draw the words like an archer. "So if you want to release me from your burdens, to stop me leeching from the rightful blood I share of this family, then grant me one final request, and I will change my name and never return."
"No, Val, please," Vera says. "Vince, she's your daughter! You can't let this happen . . . don't you have any love in your heart for her besides your cowardice?"
"I . . . I think—" Vince looks first to Victoria before looking at his daughter. "I think we'll hear her out."
"She should get nothing. Send her off with nothing. You know you can," Victoria says.
"I will hear her out," he says, standing up from his chair, only to find out his stature is taller than all of us.

"I know this drama exhausts you. But I have only one request." Valentina turns to me before she speaks, as if to check that I really believe in this gambit. "Don't go to the celebration at the Afterlife."
Vince, Victoria, and Vera let out an audible grunt of confusion. They expected hush money, buyout from the Academy, anything else than what she offers, so much that it leads them all to laughter.
"You don't want us to go to a . . . party? That's it? That's preposterous!"
"That's right," Valentina says.
"But why?" asks Vincent.
"Because I forgive you. And though you might not love me the way I love you, I still want you to live."
"You're not making any sense," Victoria says, "is that a threat?"
"Check beneath the lift you said you'd drag me from. The Afterlife conspires to wipe out every family of the Merlot. They never wanted you to get to the top in the first place."
"The Vermillion Merlot are a faithful conduit of both worship and stability. What you say is just obfuscating slander," Victoria says.
"Then check beneath the lift. Write me off with nothing, I don't care anymore," Valentina says, "but you'll regret it if you don't look."

Victoria calls to one of the house's stewards, and demands they assemble a team to go and look. We stand in silence for nearly thirty minutes. It's long enough that the anxiety begins to crawl into my mind, worrying about how much has changed, if after all this time my prophetic visions have left Valentina out to dry.
"How would you know this? Did you plant it there, just to save the day, to prove a point?"
"I don't have access. You lock the doors of the cellar so I can only come through the drainage tunnel. In Khiras' name, I had to smash a car through the gate just to get in!"

"Well you better hope you're right," Victoria says, as Vince and Vera approach the window. A commotion travels up the stairs, getting louder as it climbs from level to level, and somewhere beyond the window, the cooks and custodians flood out of the house onto the back lawn. The nervous cadet from earlier breaks the doorway with a steel weldment in his hands, and I recognize the etchings on the side from the debris that crushed Valentina.
"Found it."
The sight startles all of us. Victoria nearly falls over the desk to use Vincent as a blast shield.
"You imbecile, you brought that . . . thing . . . into our home?" Victoria asks.

"It's inactive," he says. "The detonator line was attached. It would have started several moments after you activated the lift, but now it's just a brick of Essence," he says, tossing the heavy container in his hands before he drops it on the floor, giving everyone a start as Vince nearly flips over the desk.
"I should have you fired, boy!" Vince says.
"I'm sorry. Very sorry," he replies, cradling the improvised explosive like a child now.
"Well, who planted it, then?" Vera asks. Vince nervously approaches, making the brick look small as he turns it over in his large hands.

"I deal with trading a lot of what this province produces. This is high-carbon steel. No witness marks. Far too nice for an improvised dirty bomb by the Carmine, yet it looks just like what they might try to make."
"And all the Essence in there, mixed with saltpeter. Do the Carmine even have that much dead Essence to throw away like this?"

Valentina withdraws her tattered bag that survived the crash. "And now that you're beginning to discover the nature of who did this . . . here's the tattered uniforms of four impostors using your name to try to kill Carmine children." She places them across the desk: the details indistinguishable from our district'a Merlotan City Guard. "They were trying to start a street war. But we stopped them first."
Vera asks, "And this 'they' is . . ."

"The Afterlife," Valentina says. "Their final mission was never about stability. It's to harvest their field of souls as crops — whether loyal or indifferent — to bring back the glory of another golden age. All they see is as is Essence."
"Pray tell, and in this theory, what would they get by destroying us?" Victoria asks.

"The instability they need to wipe us out completely, while we're too busy fighting each other." Valentina nods to me. I rehearsed these words with her before, preparing for diplomacy that didn't involve destroying property. I made the choice to believe in her, and I'm proud of her.
Vince sets down the dormant explosive, commanding one of his attendants to take it far away. "Thank you. Daughter," he says.
The words don't do much for Valentina, but she nods. Victoria is still too distraught with surprise to react.

"The Carmine are aware of this farce, too," Valentina tells them. "They hold an open table with your seats in place. Stay too much longer here — don't take that lift — and the Afterlife will wonder how you got the best of them. Take the lift without the explosive, and they'll find another way to do the job."
"So what are you saying, daughter?" Vince asks.
"I'm saying the enemy of your enemy might be the only friend you have now," Valentina says. "And they're waiting for you."

We approach in the third car of twelve in what's a sight for the ages. Frightened onlookers duck out of their windows when the muted Merlotan red reflects up at them off the hood of the motorcars, embossed with the bright letter "V" in gold on each of them, thinking war is about to unfold on the streets.

The driver crimps her white gloves on the steering wheel while the man riding shotgun stays true to its name, as if they've never delved into the middle-lower-class slums of Blackwater before. And when the entourage finally makes it to the Carmine Compound, the cars leave a single set of tracks as they circle in the frozen mud of the front lot.

Beyond the doors of the motorcar, the Brothers and Sisters look on with caution: sharing silence with the onlookers from the street, since any words might catch and flare. The doors all open at the same time, except for one, and the Merlotan Guard and Royal Guardsmen emerge, staggered green and red.

The Vermillion patriarch is the last to emerge, just as Romin and his father part the crowd of Carmine to greet their unlikely guests. Even the snow halts itself somewhere above the smog, waiting for the two estranged men to make contact.
"Vincent," Raine says, extending his hand.

Vincent wipes his hand with a handkerchief, shelving his look of disgust for the ragged landscape before clasping Raine's hand. "It's been a long time. I see Romin there. And I heard you were out in the woods for a while. How's Ruby?"
"Ruby?" Raine asks.
"Your wife," Vincent says, wiping his hand again. "And Ryder?"
"My wife was Rose. They're both dead— though it's nice to see your family's taking good care of each other."
Vincent looks up. "Ah. Well, it's a lovely statue, at least, made from Merlotan bronze and all."
"It's as new to you as it is to me. But anyways," Raine says. "You're in my compound."
"I am. It's a common enemy that aligns our interests. Us Merlot would handle this ourselves if we had a little more strength."
"Surely you could," Raine says, before Romin nudges him. "You could, of course, but we're glad we can split the same burden."

Romin stands beside Valentina as Vincent turns to address us. "It was our children that brought us together in a way we thought was impossible. We found a fake explosive beneath the lift that would have killed us. It looked like one of yours, but we trust that's not possible."
"We wouldn't do anything like that unless we were provoked," Raine says.
"I hope not. And so you've had an incident?"
"An incident." Raine chews the flavorless words. "Our incident was that attackers trying to kill innocent children in one of our storehouses, disguised as your people."
"Which we would never do either, unless..."
"Provoked?" Raine asks.
"Oh, please. You don't get provoked when you carry the big stick," Vince says.

"Then I'm curious why you think you need our help. Since you're provoked by someone else with a bigger stick." Raine's hands grasp the collar of his vest, exposing his thick, corded musculature. "Maybe we have better experience living with discomfort?"
"Providing food and utilities to a whole province is far from comfortable, Raine. Please, if you just—"

The last car door bashes open, and Victoria stomps out, having rested her legs from all the walking. "Gods above, you two, they're going to have our heads before you can decide who has the longer stick. Can we get on with this?"
"Right," Vince says.
"Come inside. We have a feast and table ready, so long as you don't mind a little dust."
Valentina whispers, "The first time the Merlot have ever set foot in a Carmine outpost."
Romin's grin spans from ear to ear. "I still can't believe you managed to pull this off," he tells her. "You're amazing. I'm so proud of you!" He embraces her until she grasps for breath.
"Careful. You're gonna knock me out with strength like that," she says.

The Merlot are escorted down the stairs, and while the leadership convene in the depths of the outpost, the Merlot and Carmine associates begin to talk. The young members, inculcated in the lowest ranks as new blood, recognize each other from the Academy and begin to socialize, ignorant to the bad blood, just elated to see kind, familiar faces, and even manage to introduce the older members.

We follow Romin. The vault door is open, and across an open space once littered with liquor bottles and kegs, the floor is stocked with munitions, boxes, and tables of trained Carmine communicating on the talking wires to other provinces.
"Don't look surprised," Romin tells me. They're all like me, buddy. They party as hard as they work."
"I'm just impressed, " I say.
The grand steel doors close behind the figureheads of each faction, with both Romin and Valentina accompanying them, and so Sylvia, the Vermillion children and I are left on the other side.

It's not long before the children of the Carmine bring their boxes of toys over to socialize. A handsome Carmine boy approaches Vera. Virgil plays 'war' with some of the commanders' sons: mixed not by faction, but by choice, and Vanna's led off to paint with the toddlers by one of the Seminary Sisters.
Sylvia and I leave as the only impartial guests — but as soon as I smell liquor, I know they're on track for fine camaraderie.
"I feel so warm right now," Sylvia says.
"I do, too. But we can't get too comfortable," I tell her.
"But that doesn't mean we can't enjoy it," she says, as takes my hand, tensioning her fingers between the spaces of mine. "I want to savor this. And I want to savor us."

"I'll cherish every second," I promise her, and I notice a naive excitement kindled within me when I walk home, as added heat against the cold. I don't allow myself think the words or else I might jinx it, that this all could actually work, and maybe this feeling is just a balancing act between two emotions at war: anxiety over the outcome, and excitement over these recent victories. The thought is a branch I know will never hold the weight of this world, but I still reach for it, enough that I joke to Sylvia:
"With all these impossible things, maybe even Clint will be home."
"Whoa there," she says. "Don't ask for too much."
But sure enough, the sight astonishes us when we turn the corner, frightening me enough that I draw my knife and slip to the side of the house as Sylvia follows closely behind.
"I locked up before we left with Val, didn't I?" I whisper. "We never left the lights on. We just slept by the fire."
"That's right," Sylvia says.
"Well, there's nothing valuable in there at least. I sold it all." We sneak along the perimeter, but I left all the curtains drawn to keep things safe.
There's a clattering.
"You hear that, right?"
"Like steel on steel. Or nails on a chalkboard."
"Yeah, and—"

We hear a laugh, and my stomach drops. I press my ear to the window as Sylvia does the same. It's at least a man and a woman in there, yet they're not bustling around — gathering things and checking boxes, scrounging for jewelry or something.

I catch the whiff of some nostalgic smell, and for a moment I'm lost before I come to my senses. The low bass reminds me of Clint's voice I could hear through the floorboards when he came home from work, his heavy footfalls, and the small, clattering footsteps of my mother.
"It might actually be him," I tell Sylvia. "Gods above, I swear, if the bastard'a showing off the house I pay for to some woman..."
I peer between the drapes and only catch a sliver of the foyer: Clint's jacket hung over the couch, and a small, crimson cloak.
"Dear Khiras, he works fast," I say.
"What are you on about?"
"The lady's in the First Red, I think," but then I notice a familiar piece of jewelry that fell from the pocket onto the floor.
"No way. No. No, no, no, Clint, what are you thinking? The old lady? Or..."
I'm at the front door before Sylvia can stop me. Maybe I can still save her from him: he's been the furthest thing from a role model on relationships ever since he became a widow.

I creak open the front door slowly, wishing I'd lubricated the hinges and kept this house a fraction as good as it used to be. The female voice is clearer now, and it's deeper— not as nasally as Maude's.

I find my mother's necklace on the floor, and the smell of lavender hits me as I return it to its place around my neck. I feel an unfamiliar energy inside it. I look around and it's as if the house is just slightly cleaner; dusted in all the places the maids forget to clean; the smell of dinner so savory I almost forget why I'm here.

I'm almost afraid to enter. It feels like when I was a child in trouble, when I'd sneak down the stairs to listen as Mom and Dad talked aloud about my misdeeds and how to punish them. But I still feel myself drawn to the dining room, knife in hand, unable to stop as I prepare to slice at whatever illusion threatens my sense of reality.

The knife clatters to the floor when I see them sitting on the same side of the table, teary-eyed, reminiscing on the forgotten years that separated them for so long. I say her name aloud and the illusion crumbles. That magnificent dream came true after all this time.
"You finally . . . came home," I say, and she rises from her chair at the words, quick to approach and comfort me, just as I know she did before to her widowed lover.
"I'll never be able to apologize enough for what I had to do. I was made. I was called back to serve the First Red as its messenger."
I should be elated like Romin was in finding his estranged father, but I find my feelings of hope and peace curdle to bitterness.
My mother senses my reluctance. "I don't expect you to forgive me for how I left you, but I had to."

"It's not that," I tell her, and when I look at the empty place-setting across the table with the pillow on the seat, I can feel that relentless anxiety hunt me down. Clint's the only one out of all of us that has no idea what's coming. Moira's the only one that can fully empathize as a member of the Carmine, unless Sylvia truly remembers what happened to us in those past lives.

"I can feel that impermanence, too. But it's better to have happened in the first place than to never have happened at all. I just wish that . . ." Her words dampen when her eyes fall to the empty place setting. "I wish the beautiful daughter of ours didn't have to suffer."
"And we're going to make them pay," I insist.
"But at what cost?" Sylvia asks.
"At the cost of whatever it takes. Or else we'll never be free," I say.
"What, you think this is some kind of conspiracy nonsense?" Clint asks. "I loathe the golden cunts of the Afterlife—" He looks to Moira. "Sorry. As much as the next guy, but this?"
"It's happening, and it's very real," I tell him. "The Afterlife took Ellie, because she has Divine Blood inside her, and is capable of becoming the Mask of the Humans and Chymaera."
"What are you talking about? I don't have divine blood," Clint says. "And Moira isn't anything special." She glares at him again. "Genetically. I mean, love, you're special in other ways."
"That's because I'm a Chymaeran," she says.
"Chymaerans don't exist in Blackwater. Maybe not even anywhere," Clint argues.
"Then watch."

Moira lifts the ring of guise tokens from her pocket, withdrawing a weathered one. I notice the pendant of my necklace is now around her ring. In an instant, her flesh grows obsidian and her mass coalesces into a shorter figure, taking on the guise of the older woman that helped in Clint's shop.

"There was a reason I was drawn to work there. Memories fade from guise to guise, and when you lose a marker, everything fades away to your conscious mind. But instinct is the proof that they still persist somewhere." She takes the token of my necklace between her fingers and changes back in mere seconds to the face I recognize, looking as if she hasn't aged a day.
"Then why didn't you say anything to me?"

"I was afraid to break the perfect life we had. If anyone knew that I was a Chymaeran, or a messenger of the First Red, it would risk everything. We were never meant to hold a guise for longer than months. And to hold it for so many years..."
"So Chymaerans' guises don't age, then," I say.
"We can only hold a snapshot," she says.
And when I realize it, the bile rises in my stomach and the meal before me becomes unpalatable. I'm afraid to ask.
"When did it happen, then," Clint says.
"Clint. Don't ruin this," Moira says.
"You-you look exactly like the picture we took after Ellie was born, and I've looked at that picture every day, committed it to memory more than the back of my hand," Clint says.
"Please," she pleads.

"So when, then? When did it happen?" She almost becomes a stranger to him when he grabs her shirt, yet he can't quite get there. "Was it before or after? You said you were infertile after we met, after we fell in love, yet..."
"She was," Moira says.
Clint says, "Then when—"

"Did you kill her?" I finish. The genetic fury floods in our veins, and only Sylvia can hold me back. The memory of recent events returns as the surprise fades. "I saw her, dead, in Everett's basement. I saw her skeleton. My foot crunched her dry ribs!"
"It wasn't like that, I promise. I did nothing!"

So why, then? Why did my real mother die?" The word real injures her, hitting so hard it glances off of Clint. "I saw Everett's basement, all those horrific instruments, memories of a time he tried to make me forget, so why? Why did he do that to me, and why did you allow it?"
"It was all to save Blackwater. All of this."
"What did he do to you, son?" asks Clint.
She says, "It was because you were the only source of divinity he could use."
"Titus, what did he do?"

"Use?" I ask. "My mother loved me for who I was. She was the only one who ever truly loved me! Never a Chymaeran who killed her to take her identity. I was gods-damn right to believe love could never be unconditional."

"But I didn't kill her. It was Everett," she finally admits, "and he went through with it before I could even decide. The self-hatred and regret consumed that man faster than the Chymaeran Curse ever could. You know why he got it? Because I gave it to him. He showed me what he had done. He told me to continue, to finish the job. So I punished him. And to pick up the consequence of his selfishness, I decided to take her identity." She doesn't cry, but she bends her neck to glance down just past my feet. "So many identities, Titus. I buried myself with so many other faces to try to forget all those years since I disappeared, thinking myself unworthy, and the guilt pains me to this day."

I don't respond. I don't tear up, either. I feel myself retreat to that same numb headspace my circumstances created for me, all those years when she was absent, when I thanklessly picked up all the slack of Clint's failures.

"But I felt all the feelings she did. I was just foolish to think I could be anything close to what she was. I was Moira for so many years that I internalized every piece of her, and I could feel it. I felt her take over. I felt her understanding. And I actually became her. I am her," she says, "I am every part a continuation of her, and I love you just as unconditionally as she ever did."
"Then why weren't you there," I say.
"Because the Pureblood Chymaerans would have caught me. And I was, Titus! I took the faces of everyone around you, of all the ones you least expected. Every chance I had, on every mission."
"Then what do you remember?"

"I remember watching you care for your sister every night that you could. Walking her to school. How hard you studied in academics and fought on the training field, and I watched as long as I could, until the list of guises since dragged on more and more, and my memory was fragmented with so many voices of the dead, unable to do anything, locked out of a relationship with the people I love..." She trails off.
"Ellie." Clint's voice wavers. "Is she even—"
"Yes. Absolutely, yes," Moira says. "She's every ounce of you as much as she is me. She's truly your daughter."
"Then what about my blood?" I ask.
"Exactly," Clint says. "What did Everett do to him?"

"Distilled for the Pure Essence. Everett knew you were Fletcher. He found you out there. He said it was as if you could sense him coming from beyond time, waiting in the Reservoir. When he returned to that site you appeared to him. Resurrected, expending your right to the Masks of Life and Death with the power of the divine, so you could come back and resist the laws of nature. You lost it in that sacrifice. So someone else had to carry the power of both sides."
"Both sides," I repeat. "Then that means..."

"You're half Chymaeran. Just like Ellie," she says. "You have the true Royal blood on both sides. The Human royalty of Ullrich mixed with the Chymaeran royalty of Eaudicroux, the escaped princess known to the Humans as Evella."
My body feels foreign to me when I look at my hands. The room spins as I gasp for breath, and I sit at the table.

"And Everett infused me with that pure Essence containing  the divinity of both sides, day after day, telling me that next guise was just another accidental casualty, until I realized that day that she was still alive, that grief-stricken Everett never planned for an accident."
I remember the records Lyra and I found in the basement: the names scrawled on them in a single letter.
"So what, then? Where does that leave us?" I ask, and it's all I can manage, staring at the uneaten meal before us.

"We still have a mission. It's what it's been this whole time, for all of us," Moira says. "We have to save Blackwater. Your actions beyond the walls bought us this last chance. And all we have to do now is to see it through."
Clint slumps in the chair on the other side of the table. Sylvia sits there in silence, still too afraid to enter our feud.

"Just know that I love you, and I'm so infinitely proud of the man you've become. Caring for Ellie and Clint since I left. Courting this beautiful woman as your girlfriend," she says, motioning to Sylvia who blushes.
"I always imagined telling you how hard it was, what you would say to me, how you might comfort me. That's what gave me the strength, imagining you'd return," I tell her.

"Let's enjoy this meal before it goes from lukewarm to cold," Moira says. Our eyes all drag to the empty place setting in the absence of words, feeling as if it absorbs all the color in the room: waiting, and maybe hoping, the small girl might lift herself from some hiding place under the table and join us for our last meal.

I hear Clint's voice drop when Sylvia and I head outside. I know he now unloads the weight of all that suffering he held for years with the only one he can ever do it with. She's no longer trapped behind glass in a memory, forcing him to remember the sound of her voice like an endless game of telephone. She's in there now, and still listening, however long it takes to ease years of her widowed husband's pain.

It terrifies me that they both agreed to join the fight. The cold is the only thing that can satiate the pit in my stomach, but it tells me I'm attached to that promise that this is the last chance. I pray the lights might just stay dark forever; that my father's relieving happiness never ends; that the sensation of Sylvia's hand warming mine might last forever, but Ellie's promise still haunts me.

My stomach curdles on little substance, enough that the acid rises, burning with each level it climbs. Our hands grasp the chipped railing worn by decades of relentless storms. We watch together as Darktime floods the streets like Endogeny, and despite her height, it looks like she struggles to reach the next string of words. I clasp my gloved hand in hers, but not because she needs comfort. It's for me. I'll get lost in these feelings of anxiety if she doesn't tether me to this moment.
"It's wonderful that you got the chance to see her again. I'm happy for you," Sylvia says.
"It was a blessing from the Gods, no matter how late it was," I tell her.
She loses her sight in the middle distance somewhere, retreating backwards on some persisting memory until I call her back.
I ask "What is it? Are you anxious for when the Carmine and Merlot call us?"
"A little. But it's not that," Sylvia says.
"Then what is it?"
"I saw her there."
"Who?" I ask
"I saw my mother."
I turn to her, excited, expecting to find the same joy I felt when Moira came back to us. I'm surprised when all I see is confusion.
"It was just a memory. The only glimpses so got were just flashes of the past before we met."
"Then how did you know it was her?"

"Because I could tell it was all a memory. It was only a flash, but I'm certain it was decades. Maybe centuries, even. I'm sure the other side of me has been around forever, but I couldn't see anything more. Like looking into the streetlights as snow falls in your eyes—" Sylvia says, as she points to the amber smudges of lighttime glowing through the flakes, "I was too afraid to see, and I blinked before so could remember. I experienced a feeling I never want to remember."
"The feeling of what?"

"Eternity,"she says. "I remembered ages in that time. Other lives, when I escaped the same way I did now, spans of hundreds of years where I witnessed nearly everything, so bored I returned to collect dust on the shelves of divinity for another infinity until boredom became tedious. And I know that I did that. Over and over, and now I see that long, dark phantom trails behind me of everything I've ever experienced, telling me I've done this all before. I mean— could you imagine living the same life over and over, forever?" She falters on the delivery of the last words once she realizes who she's talking to.
"I have an idea," I tell her.

"I was never designed to experience this world, because I was made for something different. Do you know why the world is indifferent? Because it's driven by forces of nature that lived long enough to become entirely passive."
"And you're afraid to feel that way again."

"I'm just certain it will always come to me. Only through forgetting can I ever experience life through fresh eyes, but I could see it, Titus, it was so terrifying, that emptiness, not even black or white, but clear and colorless..."
She buries herself into my shoulder.

I say, "I might never understand fully, but I know we've both experienced it on a mortal level. It was so stupid, but— ever since the orphanage, my room was dark and cold because sometimes I thought if I left my windows open, I'd freeze and die peacefully in my sleep. And I prayed for it."

"I'm glad you didn't. Or I'd tear you away from the reservoir to bring you back into my arms," she says. "I'd warm you so you'd never feel that cold emptiness again. Because I felt it. And I know it's waiting there."
"What is the meaning of life to a person who lives for others, in those idle moments when they're not needed?"
"I mean, they sit on a shelf. Just like I know I did for years in the Reservoir," she says.

"Sometimes it feels like mortal life is waiting to die with the life you never asked for, finding ways to pass the time between the moments of meaning." I exhale between my hands to warm my frosted fingers, then cup them around hers. "I don't know. So is immortal life ever different from mortal life? Or are they just fractals of the same experience?" I watch as snowflakes fall on our gloves, tessellated with a hundred microscopic prongs of ice, each different from the other. But as soon as we look, the heat dissolves them: their pattern forever lost.
"Please. If you feel even a fraction of the same way, then what is it? What keeps you going?"
I laugh. "I mean, I don't have a choice, right? Time and entropy do that for me, I sure don't have to push them along."
"But why? Even if you've seen anything. I mean, maybe I came here because I thought I could learn. Or maybe I came here to forget all over again. I don't know, but..."

I surprise her when I grab her by the shoulders, pushing her against the wall. She's caught so off-guard that she kicks the heel of her boot back, splintering in the same place my head dented when Lyra dropped me against the glass, and still, I'm too afraid to see if it shatters the same way.

Her face flushes when I pin her there. Before she can speak another word, she sinks down the wall until I'm able to meet her at her level. My lips press against hers as the snowflakes dissolve against her skin, steadily heating our bodies together, refusing to give to the enveloping sea of early-morning darkness.

It doesn't matter whether this is once or a hundred-thousand times. I think of how many cycles it took to get past the death of Valentina and Romin, thinking I had to say goodbye to them forever. I remember the endless cycle of waking and sleeping in that chamber beyond time, but yet something always persisted there. I was found by Ellie when I even lost myself, and every reset, it was memory that brought me here.
"I'd like to think the small moments of meaning are worth weathering that stillness. This is what fills eternity for Gods and mortals. Because it persists as long as memory lives."
I embrace her until her trembling stops.
She says, "I'm just so scared, Titus."
"I know," I reassure her. "We both stand at the edge of everything with no idea what comes next."
"But what if you die and I live another forever?" She asks.
"Then I'll love you as long as my forever holds. Enough to let you live until your eternity ends and we meet again."
"I'll be so alone," she says.

"I know," I find it's so hard to practice what I preach when the anxiety still eats at me. I can say the lesson, but I can't feel it. I don't even know if these hypocritical emotions will let me live it.
I cling to this last moment of her warmth like a dying bonfire in the frozen woods, uncertain whether we'll all freeze, or worse— which ones will make it back alive.
I wish I never had to let go, and I hate the recurring thought that tells me I still could.

The call came a quarter hour later in the form of a Merlotan touring car driven by Carmine brothers. We were clinging to each other the whole time, waiting until the other felt full. Yet we knew we topped each other off as soon as we came together.

I leave Clint there inside the house with my mother: a fitting, unspoken goodbye. I can't enter those doors again or else I might never leave, so I'm the one that takes Sylvia's hand, leading her towards uncertainty as the Carmine open the doors somewhere past the snowflakes.

I make the mistake of looking back when the flurries dissolve the house to a single glow. No light might ever grace the house again when Endogeny eviscerates the streets, and I can only pray to the Gods they'll all live to see my dream. Yet I'm still convinced the only Goddess that can answer is the one cuddled to my left arm, shivering in mortal flesh as I share my coat with her.

The compound is vacant when we arrive. The early morning air is dark and silent, devoid of the bustle of pleasure or business, and it sets me at unease as we descend into the depths. Valentina and Romin reflect our expressions with the same somber faces. We've all gained so much to mourn— and here we are when the bill comes due.
Vincent's voice thunders across the room of figureheads. Transcribers in the hall tap over talking wires to relay the words in dots and dashes to every Carmine stronghold that listens.

"The Vermillion Merlot were meant to die tonight. Thus bounds the timeline of our plan," he says. "We will not hesitate from sending someone in our place. The Carmine already have moles hat will do whatever it takes to stabilize this plan from above."

Raine takes the reins when Vince steps back. "Our highest mission is to extinguish the Afterlife before that Chymaeran weapon Endogeny can kill us off. Their greatest weakness is at our highest numbers. They subsist on ignorance, which is the reason they can't survive when all of us strike together. And so I speak to all of you Carmine out there in every province, ready to give your lives as the truest blood of the Humans, to know that your sacrifice will reflect on eternity, planting the seeds through death that your future lives will bask in the shade of."

Vince channels his unlikely comrade's excitement. "We are the only province of Merlot aware of the ruse that awaits us. But we can use this to our advantage— it's easier to blend in with the ignorant. We will send a small team of Merlot on the lift that was meant to explode, as emissaries of the Vermillion. This team will slip through the Afterlife to open the gates and destabilize the walls in any way they can."

Raine says, "The Carmine teams will rush the foothills of the Afterlife from every angle with every piece of equipment available. We will strike fast and hard before Endogeny can claim enough flesh to overturn the fight."
He turns to the son standing beside him with a glimmer of hope and pride. Romin straightens.
"My son Romin will be leading Province Fourteen's charge. Romin?"

"The front lines of every district will convene on the Merlotan foothills, breaking the middle walls separating the Afterlife from the lower lands. Each has received a message from our district's Merlot, telling them to check beneath their lifts. Only the Gods can tell if they will listen."

"Thanks, Brother Romin," Raine says, resting his hand on his son's shoulder. "We hope the front lines will meet little resistance, but the Afterlife will surely sense such a surge of Carmine and Merlot at their gates."

Vince says, "That's where the Carmine and Merlot demolition teams coalesce. Sorry— where they come together. With our combined dead Essence, we'll blast the walls at these key strategic points," he says, pointing at a crimson-ink Merlotan map marked with X'es. "We'll blast their walls with the very thing they try to harvest from us, and once we breach their walls, the remaining soldiers will have free game on the Afterlife and all its blissfully unconscious purveyors of absolute ignorance."
"Blind bastards, he means," Raine says.
"Yeah, that's right."

Raine says, "Your leaders will spread this message to all the Carmine that this hour calls their allegiance. They will spread it further to each province's Academy, to the City Guard, and to all the civilians that will listen, to make sure they know what awaits them, to seek the courageous ones that wish to thrive on the right side of Human history and rise to this occasion. They will know we strike in this hour that will define the persistence of true humanity for now and forevermore!"
"And we will do this together," Vincent says. "Without division, we are unstoppable."

The raucous applause echoes across every stronghold. Carmine and Merlot in ours shed their difference of colors to congregate together, having learned that all along they shared the same contemptible adversary, unified by the same unlikely purpose. My voice strains on a mix of excitement and panic as our fireteam shouts with everything we have— because to me, at least, every second of silence is cold as death.
I feel Vince grasp my shoulder, and when I turn to face him, I find Raine standing next to him.
"You guys are fast friends," I say.
"Only for the cause," Raine assures me. "I don't hate him."
"That's great," Vince says. "Let's stay focused here. You're slated to join the Merlot team being sent to the Afterlife."
"With whom?" I ask.

"With my daughters. You will be a servant with Lyra. I'd have you wear that tacky outfit you wore yesterday, but it got a little too tattered, so I've got something else for you." He hands me another set of clothes. "This was made by one of our finest seamstresses before she died, to eventually be tailored to my son Virgil once he stopped growing. But this world won't hold long enough for that tradition to stay relevant."
"I promise I'll wear it with honor," I say.
"You and Lyra know the most about the Afterlife out of anyone in our province. And Lyra has the experience with Essence."
"But she's the daughter of Ullrich. You know that, right? What if he sees her?"

"This isn't a military matter. Our father is far too busy right now to be dealing with the Merlot," Lyra says. "I can't miss a chance to strike at him when I've missed every other opportunity. I need to pay off the chance you gave me to live," she says.

Vera and Valentina stand beside their father.  Vera says, "You'll be escorting us to the grand celebration. And though we have no idea what it holds, we'll take whatever chance we can to give our friends at the walls the help they need." Vera places the hat atop her sister's head, and Valentina adjusts it.
"But what about Sylvia?"
Vince says, "There are only so many we can take on the lift within reason. I'm sorry, Titus."
"I'll be with Romin," Sylvia says. "We'll meet you once you break us through to the other side."

It takes a couple breaths before I grab the clothes in front of me. I'm still on the best path. This is the best I can do. I reach for Virgil's untailored outfit as the Merlotan seamstresses take dimensions, ready to shape me from tattered Snowdrifter into polished royalty. The stylists clip and comb my tangled mess of hair and trim my beard. When I look in the mirror, I'm twice as refined as that lonely valedictorian that gave the Academy's last speech.
The Merlotan motorcar awaits to take me to my destiny. I feel like someone else, someone better, but Id like to think it isn't from the new appearance.
Sylvia and I kiss before I take a seat next to Valentina.
"I'll see you again," she tells me.
"Wherher it's tomorrow or the other side of infinity, I will wait there."
"I love you so much," she tells me.
"I know. And I love you, too."

The vacant Merlot estate unsettled us when we arrived: so strange without groundskeepers painstakingly tending every leaf of the hedges. We walked through the outdoor maze of shrubs and gardens before we finally arrived at the lift.

Now Vera flips the handle. The power jostles the rack-and-pinion drive to motion, and so the car inches sixty degrees upwards at ever-so-small a climb. The four of us stand at the edge of the railing. It feels so surreal when my eyes fall to that same place where we emerged from the drainage tunnel, as if in new clothes and finer appearance I look down upon my older self, and I wonder whether I've grown enough.
"Where did it happen?"
The question surprises me. Valentina approaches the railing without her hat, allowing her ears to twitch with the chilled crosswinds, and it reminds me of a moment in a past life.
"At least you believed me this time," I say.
"What?"

"Nothing." I can't force my eyes to leave that spot. Somehow I still believe the woman standing beside me is buried there, the bloodied mess of her body crushed beneath the rubble of the ten-ton machine actively chugging along the rails.
"There. Is that where it happened?"
"Yeah," I say, afraid to overshadow.
"So they stranded me here," she says. "In that other life."
"They did."
"I can't believe it," Vera says. "So Mother's hatred beat Victor's love in the end, even to the grav. I just can't believe I let it happen."
"But you tried. In one future, you abandoned your family to look for Valentina. You never ended up on the lift, and so your fireteam joined you," I tell her.
"I just wish I did more. I let my sister suffer for years, and all that time, I didn't want to know the truth."

Lyra approaches the railing. "I let that same kind of regret consume me for years, and I can tell you it never added to anything." She touches me with her shoulder as she speaks. "And all I've learned is that the future is all we have to act on."

Valentina embraces her older sister. "All this time you've given me someone to look up to. You were in the higher class, after all. I envied you. Fame in moving pictures gave me nothing of what I felt I was missing."
"But you were the stronger one. My silence always reminded me how weak I was, compared to how you took your pain and shaped it into something."
"I forgive you," Valentina says.
"And so the car of estranged siblings reaches new heights," Lyra says.

There are two stops before we make our final ascent, and each time we come to a jarring stop, Vera has to press the glowing button on the wall to keep us going. It takes an hour before the train car nears the summit, climbing higher and higher until we think it'll run out of mountain, but then it rises through the clouds.

I can hardly catch a view of the tracks ahead when I crane my neck from the railing. Merlotan creations like these are only meant for looking down. Right now, the provincial leaders should be leading their districts into battle, breaking the line of the foothills so the demolition teams can sweep in from behind, depending on us for whatever we can manage.
"What should we expect?" I ask Valentina.
"I've never been up here." She nudges her sister. "Vera?"
"The districts feed in sets of threes to a common station. Then five separate train lines lead from these stations to the heart of the Afterlife."
"So we'll be meeting someone else?"
"It depends on whether they got the message," Valentina says. "And whether they believed it, most of all."

We hear the great steel door power up when we approach. Steam hisses when the latches release, and as the ten-ton car decelerates, we prepare ourselves for the sudden lurch when it crashes against the station.

All that's left is for the door to open, and it inches slowly on several huffs of steam. We peer beneath once the gap is taller than Valentina, only to find a grand entryway adorned with gold and marble.

Vera speaks in a whisper. "This is the unifying chamber for the last three provinces."The numbers THIRTEEN, FOURTEEN, and FIFTEEN are etched into each entrance. The other two lifts are open at this highest point, dark and empty, and I can only assume their travelers are ahead of us.

"Oh. Vermillion party?" A surprised voice says. "You're late. The celebration will be starting soon, we need to get you over there!" He gestures to the trolley terminal, implying it's already on the other end of the tracks.
"Father's still arguing with the Carmine over some petty compromise, Gods above,"Vera says. "He sent for us so some Merlot blood would be here to sip your wine and gossip."

"We'll fetch a ride. Come this way," the Attendant says. Our footsteps clatter against the reflective floors, echoing across the vacant chamber. A chauffeur is already parked at the front of the complex, inside a vehicle so bright and metallic it looks like it's made of light.

The countryside is even more verdant as I remember, reminding me of Everett's storybooks of imaginary lands when I was a child. Cascading vines adorn the marble structures where denizens gather in pearlescent clothes, and we whiz past on paved roads, catching only brief glimpses between the foliage.
"By Gods, how much their Essence must have grown for it to be this full of life," Lyra says. "The climate is so warm."
"So you've been up here before?" Vera asks. "My sister and I have only been up here once, and it's when we were very young."
"I lived up here, for years. Held against my will, I guess," says Lyra.
Vera says, "It's all so disgusting coming from down below. But why would you leave? If you knew nothing of the lower lands, I think I'd live here forever."

"Because of what happened after my family fell apart. My father was all I had. One day, I woke up and realized I was old enough to decide my future for myself. He stopped loving me, so focused on his obsession of the past, turning into something I couldn't recognize. I knew had a debt to pay for the chance at life I was given. And I knew for damn sure I wasn't going to waste it up there."
"Just keep the mission first," I tell her.
"Trust me. I want nothing more than to get my revenge— except for making sure he sees how it all ends."

Before I realize how time has passed us, we're parked in front of the grand hall. The trolleys are all parked outside, looking so small compared to the massive train cars carrying loads between the lower and upper lands.
The driver opens the doors. "You need to get inside," he says. "The celebration has already begun, and you're going to miss the most important part."

The doors open to the expansive, three-story atrium, yet it doesn't even feel like we're going inside. Plants cascade from the three-story ceiling above, only separated from the sky by planes of glass, and in the far distance, the orchestra plays to a space so grand it catches no echo off the walls.
But my focus is far from captivation. "Remember why we're here. This isn't about their celebration. We need to get out and help them breach the wall," I say.
"Out on the streets, you mean?" Lyra says. "They'll detain you the minute they find you're a shitblood. You wear the uniform of a servant."
"And it's not just you. Not even the Merlot are accepted. We're all just a resource to them," Vera says, and when the denizens of the Afterlife refuse our eye contact, I believe her.

We're herded into the event hall. The chaperones follow so closely behind that I feel claustrophobic despite such a massive space. The choir chants like shouts of the damned in the Reservoir, and the constant thrum of strings on a single note make the room feel like another chamber beyond time.

The Merlot will adorn their houses with anything that shows their wealth and prestige, but I find the Afterlife are on an entirely different level. There isn't even the furniture to display such worthless items, leaving only the dining tables and chairs, adorned with the name tags of each family that sit in their place. It surprises us when, for such a meticulously planned event, the name tag on our table is blank. The servers look on in confusion. And when we scan the room for all the faces turned to hear the haunting music, we find three other nameless vacancies without a soul in their seats.

The last note dies abruptly without walls to echo, and the Merlot fill the uncomfortable void with applause, until even their clapping grows stale. A server comes by to pour a dark glass of wine for each of us into a brazen goblet before we can protest or ask for water, parched from our long climb.

As chatter between families fills the vacancy of programming, we expect the titans of Merlotan industry to take the stage in celebration— meaning that long, dull speech might be our ticket to escape. I take a sip of the wine: so acidic that it burns my throat, but to my left, Vera guzzles it.
"Gods above," Valentina says. "We're not here to get drunk!"
"I'm parched, Val. Besides. Real Merlotan wine is grape juice compared to this."
Valentina takes a cautious sip, abruptly halted with a short cough. Before she can sip again, the lights dim so that only the natural sunlight filters through the distant windows.

"I'm surprised by how many guards are here, just for a celebratory event," Lyra says. "This has got to be at least a quarter of the Royal Guard." Peeking through the glass, we see swarms of them gathered outside. We thought they they at the doors to keep others from coming in, but...

"Thank you all for gathering here this evening, ladies and gentlemen of the Merlot. Tonight, we celebrate you for all your contributions to the future of Blackwater, because you are the reason we have a chance to realize humanity's next golden age."

My eyes fall to Lyra before I realize the voice. She ducks beneath the table, bumping her head on the smooth mahogany, jolting all the glasses on the table, and I reach to catch her chalice before it can tilt over the edge, spilling a couple drops before I hold it in place.
"Are you alright, Vermillion table? Such a surprise you're here to join us," Ullrich says.
"Damn it, Lyra," I whisper.

Ullrich continues. "The reason Blackwater thrived was because the Merlot were such a fine conduit between the Essenced and the weak. So I want to hold a toast to the people of Blackwater whom you've allowed to so fruitfully grow."
He raises the chalice as the guards' piercing eyes watch every Merlotan family. We all take another drink. I can hardly stomach a sip before the liquor burns my lips, so sweet yet so dry.

"Maybe I need to let the liquor settle before I get too choked up on a story," Ullrich says, and the audience laughs. "Many of you might not know me. I don't deal in the affairs of business, trade, and production as much as you do, but I deal with the affairs of the military and the Academy. My name is Ullrich Valensend, and I am the Grandmaster General of Blackwater."
"Lyra, are you going to get out of there?" I whisper. My hands reach for the strands of her hair still tethered to the table, only to find an indentation in the table's surface from the spill.
"We're dead if he sees me."

"Then we better find a way out of here." I look around for every exit. The Merlot are smitten with celebration because pride is their greatest weakness, and when we turn from the stage, the guards stare daggers back at us.

"It was when I lived beyond the walls that I learned an invaluable lesson, almost twenty-five years ago. I had a wonderful family. A son and a daughter that used to love me. A beautiful life— and even though it was only a speck in the hundred-and-fifty-nine years the Essence has kept me alive, I considered it the kindest years of my life. I lived in the time before the Fall Of Nordhaven. I was part of the last true Royal family. I served my time and earned my keep as a Mask of the Gods, working for true divinity. And after all that toil, I thought I finally got the peace I deserved."
He points at all the audience members. I squint my eyes, transfixed by a strange tattoo on his arm.
"All of you relish in that spot at the top of your provinces, your lavish parties, speaking under the guise of compassion for the lower classes, when really, all they are to you is just numbers."
Some applaud his sentiment. Some laugh uncomfortably.
"You couldn't care less about them. As long as we're happy that you keep them fed, that's all they are to you. "
Silence.
"Come on. Am I right?"
Silence, then stale applause.
"Like cattle. Those shitbloods are cattle."
The Merlot squirm at that word. I heard it a couple times during the Merlotan parties as an offhand joke. But they still clap and applaud to appease their source of income.

"I didn't believe there were two classes of Humans until the day that tore everything from me. They were taken from me by a thieving Snowdrifter they left nothing behind. And when I returned to the aftermath, I saw my dying child was suffocating on his own blood . . . and it reminded me of that same day I watched my mother and father die because they were too weak, our capitol swarmed by hordes and hordes of Chymaeran separatists. Why did my mother and father fail? And why did I fail my son?"
He pauses for effect. A couple draw nervous sips, waiting for their dinner to finally arrive though no one's taken our order.

"Because we made concessions for weakness. My mother and father said the Chymaerans could be good. And I thought Snowdrifters and lower people wouldn't resort to such desperacy to scrounge the disgusting, meager scraps it takes to power their Essenceless, emancipated shells of bodies. The only way we can grow as a race is to purge the blight of weakness, and that's why you're all gathered here today."
He raises his glass.
"Another toast to the Merlot: the last tether between the top and the bottom."

Only several can muster a drink before the fits of coughing fill the hall. One woman falls out of her chair, and her husband and children jump to her rescue. It's only when I hear the Vermillion girls pound the table beside me that Lyra jumps from her seat, a sudden realization branded on her face.
"Poison?" I ask her. "What is it?"

Ullrich continues: "...no better than your counterparts, you still wreak of weakness and disease. But, even through the death of my only rightful heir, my firstborn son, I have still found my replacement."
A familiar face approaches the stage. My heart hurts when I look upon her face again, just as I left her in the last life. She drips black bile as she comes out of her Chymaeran form.
"And you will all be the catalysts of this change. Just as you served in life, through death, you will bring glory to the next golden age!"

The panic quickly transitions from sharp screams to gargling and choking in their own liquefied flesh, and when one stumbling man rushes the stage, Ullrich kicks him, leaving a large dent in his dissolving body like kicking clay. The two Vermillion woman suffer before me, and I lament the promise I made to that Ellie from another life that stands onstage, as I'm forced to choose.

I slit the side of my wrist in the same place Raine once showed me with a dull knife, and then slash hers. It cuts like steak: I know if I waited any longer, it might slice off her whole hand like butter with a hot knife.
I press our wrists together. Her blood exits her veins in clumps of ooze as ruddy amethyst as the wine. And when our blood unifies, I feel the Essence flood from my body into hers.

"Sum . . . ver . . . Titus . . ." Valentina gurgles. If I don't hold her, I fear she might splatter on the floor. Her skin is soft, but it's getting firmer, and the pale complexion of her flesh returns.
"Save her!" Valentina cries, and when her muscles return enough to force me aside in the chair, casting me to the floor, she reaches out to grasp her sister, pushing aside Lyra.

She pushes a little too hard when she touches her and part of her shoulder scrapes off. Vera can't manage a word. Her clothes fade from their brilliant pink color and her eyes are obsidian just like the rest of her, sinking, like a black wax statue baking in a kiln.

I watch as Valentina scoops the piece from the table and presses it back onto her arm, getting as much as she can, though it's like spilling stew across the table. She tries to sculpt her sister back to life as she weeps and screams, while Lyra takes her other arm to try to transfer her Essence the same way I did.
"Gods damn it!" She screams. "Why, why did you have to drink it all?"
"It's no use," Lyra says.

"You're not giving up, do you hear me?" Val snaps. "Please, Vera. . . " She keeps trying to hold her up. She uses her whole body to try to stabilize the mess of obsidian clay as Vera gurgles her last words, wet and voiceless, like bubbles from the lightless bottom of Blackwater lake. Vera dissolves through her sister's fingers before she can amass into anything, mutilating Valentina's left cheek with one last drag of her fused stump of a wrist.

Valentina shrieks when she knows it's hopeless. She grasps a knife on the table and surprises me as I'm sprawled across the floor, watching Endogeny amass itself with the corpses of dead Merlotan families.
What's worse is that the children were too young to drink: they were the last to go.
Valentina straddles me, sobbing as she holds the knife to my neck, pleading with every breath. "Please. Please, you have to . . . go . . . back . . ."
"I can't anymore," I tell her.

"Yes, yes you can. It's still there!"She holds up my arm to show the single thread, and when I look at her face, the jawline of her left cheek scarred with swollen bumps from Vera's last touch like severe acne scars.
"I'm never going back, Valentina! The world will never be enough. Even with perfection will be loss," I say, though I hate myself for so strongly considering it.
"No. Just . . . just kill yourself, please, for me, for my family..." she pleads. "They'll be distraught. I'll do it. I'll do it for you if I have to, and it will be quick, I can..."
An arm grabs her wrist before she can act, and the knife clatters to the floor.
It's Ullrich.
"What does she mean by 'going back?'" Ullrich asks. "Going back where?"
"You bastard!" Valentina cries, lunging from the floor to stab him in the leg, but he knees her in the head and she crumples.

"I thought I heard you were going back," he says. My muscles tension to prepare for a kick to the face, but instead, he lifts me to my feet as Endogeny dissolves out of the windows, shattering the glass, leaving the floors entirely black as the only evidence there were ever hundreds of souls living in this space, and he grabs my wrist, only to find the single line that Goddess Sylvia left me.
"I'm not going back. There's no reason to go down to the lower city after this," I say.
He laughs. "Right, right."
Lyra stands up without a scar though her fingers are stained with the black streaks of Endogeny.

"So you ended up as a servant to the Vermillion," Ullrich tells her. "They were the top three greatest Merlotan families, so your friend should be proud.
