I allowed them to go peacefully as a final gift, though it looks like your province didn't want it." He's smiling despite everything, so happy that he might cry. "It's just that I've loved this moment every time. I enjoy that speech, but this, being here with my daughter, and..." He turns to look at me.
The Heiress approaches from behind him. She doesn't recognize me, or she refuses to, so saturated with the hate and hunger for blood it makes her shudder.

"The three of you withstood the trials of Endogeny. You are Essenced. And I believe you deserve a chance to prove yourself." He gestures to the unscathed Royal Guardsmen standing in the corner. "I will put you up in my statehouse until I can finish what I began, so I can ensure that I will succeed this time."
He turns to Valentina, so distraught with grief that she refuses to part from her sister's residue on the floor.
"What will we do with this one?" Ullrich asks, and the Heiress approaches her.
"No! She's with us," I say.
"So you got a girlfriend, son?" He asks.
"Y-yeah. I'm in love with her."

"Even with that fucked-up side of her face? What, are you gonna put a bag over her head?" He says, though the scarring is really not that bad. "Then prove it," he says, as the Heiress lifts her from the floor to her feet. "Prove it to me."
"You mean..." I say, but his expression is resolute, and he grows impatient.
"Fucking do it," Ullrich says. The Heiress sharpens her human arm into an obsidian lance.
I press my lips against Valentina's for a peck. They're soft, caked with lip gloss, and I dwell just a little longer, until I feel that I've been there for long enough.
"Convince me, damn it!"

I violate her mouth with my tongue, but she doesn't recoil, pulling herself in instead while she chokes on remorseful tears. My hand grasps behind her head and I stabilize her, like making out with a corpse.

"Alright! That's more like it," Ullrich says, turning to Vera. "Wasn't that great, Lyra? I wish you could find love like that. I had him all lined up for you, that was— before you abandoned this family." He expects a rebuttal, but instead she looks like she's about to throw up.

"Now go. You earned your chance to witness my work," he says, and the Heiress releases her. Valentina stumbles forward into my chest and buries herself there, her ears brushing my cheeks, continuing to sob as she wraps her arms weakly around my shoulders. Before we can answer, the Royal Guard usher us out from the blackened hall into the pearlescent foyer, leaving black footprints on the granite that will never wash away.

The Grandmaster General's loft is just a stone's throw away from the grand hall: its windows open to the plaza and the front of the building, so Valentina has no chance to escape that visceral loss. But she doesn't want to. She sits at the window for almost three hours, staring at the shadows as they crawl across the grass as if her sister's soul inches towards her, reaching out to take her to whatever purgatory exists between the living and the dead.
I finally find the courage to say something to her — anything, even though I know it will never be good enough.
"I'm sorry," I tell her.

"It's not your fault." Valentina draws a long breath. "You made a choice. And I should just be thankful that you made one. It's just . . . when a person dies and their soul leaves, you know that they're gone, right? There's one state and another. Alive or dead. But not Vera. She's . . ." Valentina presses her head against the window. Her fingers caress the scar her sister left on her face. "And I'm sorry I asked you to do that unspeakable thing."
"You were in pain, and for that, I can forgive you. Because I know exactly how you feel."

Lyra listens in from the room that used to be hers. "There will be so many more casualties if we don't act now. I don't even want to know the world that was left for Fletch... ...er, Titus all those other times. We need to support the Carmine.."
"I just don't get it," I say. "Why didn't he kill us? Or take us captive? Why did he just take us out of the fight and put us up in his loft?"
"I don't know. But maybe he left something important behind." She motions for me to follow her, and we walk down the narrow hall until we stop at the last door.

"Locked. It was always locked," she says, trying the handle though she knows it won't give, but then it does, and she stumbles into the room, taking a couple steps before she trips over a mass of fabric.

The smell of ozone hits as soon as the atmosphere settles. It's freezing. The cold air sucks the heat from the hall, and Valentina surprises me when her head bumps my shoulder. Lyra struggles to her feet, and it's dark until I throw open the curtains, casting light on shelves and shelves of colored spines. An ancient family painting stretches across the wall, opposite the windows: two ornately-dressed adults and four dark-haired children. I'm certain they're true royalty from the way they're all dressed.
Lyra lifts the purple mass of fabric from the floor, and it's a bag. One of the straps is torn off while the other hangs on by a thread.
Valentina connects its relevance before I can speak. "Ellie. That's her bag," She says. "But how did it get up here?"
I look closer at the framed pictures on the desk, and the faces glare back at me. "She disappears every time. That's because it's Ullrich that takes her."
"But why? She's just a child, what does she have to do with anything?"
"She has my Essence, my rightful blood, and no curse holding her back from becoming a Mask of the Gods. She is a Mask of the Humans and Chymaera. And she's the one that made Endogeny," I tell them.

Valentina is at a loss for words, and when Lyra tries to unroll the top of the bag, the last strap finally gives, crashing Ellie's tattered backpack to the ground, casting something metallic across the floor and under the desk. My circuits throb with Essence, and my head aches so strongly that my eyes rattle in their sockets. Lyra groans at the sudden impulse. Valentina jumps at the new sensation of Essence, feeling her skin to see if she suddenly runs a fever.

I don't have to reach for it to know what it is— the devastating potential it holds— and I wonder why Ullrich would leave it so easily unguarded, why he didn't give it to the Heiress to help in his harvest of Essenced souls.

The loft felt so empty until this moment. We wait with baited breath, listening to every creak of the floors below, wondering if they'll climb to our level and bash open the door, if maybe they're outside the window, if they're in the other rooms just waiting to bust in and execute us where we stand.

I find a familiar portrait on his desk when I hold my breath, and it makes me gasp for air, pulsing my heart with a panic stronger than the flux in my circuits. It's the graduation picture I never ordered, taken weeks before my speech with a single caption: FLETCHER.

"We need to get out of here. He knows who I am. He's known this whole time, but how? And why, why did he wait?" I ask, reaching beneath the desk to grasp the Amulet, despite how much it numbs my flesh and halts the blood in my veins.

"Because I wanted to believe that you'd stay," Ullrich says. "You'd tell me eventually. I only learned hours from now— yet I could still order your picture before it came. I was so elated to know my children can be alive during the time I struggle here. But that doesn't change what I have to do —for you, for us, and for everyone."
"What is he talking about?" Valentina asks. "Your father is Clint, Titus."

"Clint is my nephew, and old Everett is my brother. Gods, how much the lack of Essence aged him. Though he insisted to live the short rest of it atoning for his sins. How would it be different if he knew the child he let die was his grandson, alive and well? Would he still create that monster to try to take the Afterlife down?"

Ullrich steps in the foyer, accompanied by four Chymaeran guards as silent as a whisper. He drags a tall statue to the window without an explanation, as our backs press against the bookshelf, cornered like rats, as I hold the last piece of divinity left to Blackwater.

"I'm giving you a choice, my son— my daughter— and I'd like to believe there's free will, even if I know what you'll decide. Return it to me and we'll live a beautiful life up here. Your friend can stay. And when the time comes, you'll be born again to another life, a better life, free from the toil of these soul-crushing politics, and I'll do it right. You'll have a mother, a father, and if I gain enough Essence, the grandparents you never met. But you have to give it to me."
He catches me looking at the tattoo on his arm, but it's bumps that disfigure all the way down to both his wrists.

"I should show you now that you know the truth." He takes off his jacket, then unbuttons the top of his shirt. Across his chest are tens of thousands of fine threads of all sizes, as if a sweater were woven into his flesh. They all cowlick in a circle at the left-center of his chest where his heart is.

"I've counted them, over and over and over, and every single time, no matter how close I get, it's always an impasse— with you, or that annoying girlfriend of yours as tall as the sky, or your friends, or by accident, old age, even natural causes." His eyes are fanatical: a gambler addicted to the requited cycle of gain and loss. "But, Gods be damned, am I so close this time, like you wouldn't believe, and—"
He dodges.
I cast a fireball at his head.
A vision flashes and I duck right, just as both flaming orbs scald the corners of the room.
"You got me once like that. You thought you'd surprise me. Heck, I bet your friends here don't even know what you learned in some other cycle of life. But tell me, son: how did you know to duck?"
I say, "I . . I don't know, I . . ."
"Feel like you've—" He says.
"Been here before?" We both say.

Ullrich says, "Then why? Why is it that you can't remember? Shouldn't you have seen everything? Every reset? Why else do you think it is that you never remember killing me? And why do I never remember killing you?"
"It's because we're blocking each other."
"All we have left is a war of spirit and will, and right now, you have far too much to lose."
The guards grab Lyra as the fire catches the drapes.

"I've seen it all. You have no surprise, no avenue of escape. Our family died the minute this world took that terrible twist. And you're only it's long shadow. My real daughter, my real son— they're still back there."

"And that's exactly the kind of thinking that nearly destroyed me. You should have let go a long time ago!" I feel embers scald my neck. The bookshelf snaps from the weight of burned paper, but I don't dare turn around.
"What's it going to be this time? Are you going to leave your sister to die? I know every escape you'll try to make!"
I struggle to decide. I can't come up with anything. He's in my head, and every time another idea rises, it feels like I've seen it all play out before.

I grab Valentina's hand before the crossbeam snaps. We jump to the window to dodge the falling debris, yet Ullrich stands in the only safe space in the middle of the floor with his hand tightened on the fabric of Vera's collar.
"You do better when you rush the door, but either way, that piece of pure Essence is going to be mine, and I'm going all the way back this time."

I fail to remember the statue's right in front of me, and so I rack my left hand against its head, dropping the pendant on the floor. Our momentum is too strong to turn around. We shatter out the glass, breaking through the first boards of scaffolding before rolling across a flimsy bridge of wooden planks. Valentina's light enough to stop, but I'm too heavy, and so I barely catch the edge before I fall another two stories.

"I look forward to when you come back, Titus. You'll never reach as far as I can. You say you can deal with death and sacrifice, but can you deal with the disfigurement of your friends? Or will it crush your spirit?"
I watch helplessly from between the slats. Lyra begs for her life, though our father never intends to take it by his own hands.
He kicks her out the window.

She flails helplessly as she reaches for a bar to grab the scaffolding, but there's nothing there: not a board, a burlap sack, nothing but a single bar that resonates when her spine snaps, folding her in two for a brief second before she falls into the fountain below.

"All you had to do was stay, Titus. You can choose better next time," he says, and before my fear can stop me, I've already jumped into the murky fountain, along with Valentina, cradling my sister as she cries that she can't feel her legs.
The water was red before I made the second splash. She can barely breathe, and I have to forcibly raise her above the water, her useless legs floating in the water.
"It wasn't supposed to end this way, Lyra," I sob. "I can go back. I can fix this!"
"Don't," she whispers. "You've done the best you can. I'm so happy I can leave with everything I ever wanted. And look— I paid it back."

Her head bobs beneath the surface when the weakness flows out of her in plumes of crimson. I feel the energy rise in my circuits when she finally opens her hand, releasing the celestial stone of pure Essence that sinks to the bottom of the fountain.

There's no time before Ullrich will realize the twist he never expected. We make for the abandoned building next door. I refuse to let go, and with everything I can afford, I transfer my Essence just to stabilize her. She's losing blood fast, and I try to cauterize her wounds with the heat from my fingers.
It's when she doesn't react to the scalding heat that I realize she's gone.

The only choice we have is to go on, and once more, I can feel that breadth of time separate us from our last living moment together. I take Valentina's hand as we limp out from the crimson fountain, refusing to look back and watch as my dead sister sinks beneath the surface.

The dilapidated building is an old chapel dating back to the earliest days of Blackwater, surrounded in scaffolding, ready for demolition, as it might be the last organically gray building in the pure Afterlife. I bash my shoulder through the wooden double doors. The celestial stone is in my pocket, radiating my entire body with energy as if it were a hollow vessel filled with boiling water. The gothic windows are all boarded with planks. Half the statues are covered with cloth, as if they were messengers for the Gods that might tell of this temple's adulteration. Our boots crunch the stained glass on the floor to colored sand, and as lukewarm winds whistle through the slats, we search for anywhere we can escape, or at least, to hide.

I've seen so much death in all these cycles— enough that I convinced myself I was used to loss, unfazed by change when it could all be written over. But now I know the pain only comes when the cycle is refused, when I force myself to know it's the last chance. But is it?
I set down Lyra when we reach a patch of smooth ground. She curls in the letter 'c' when I rest her against the wall, and the feeling crushes me.

"Maybe this doesn't have to be the last one," I whisper to Valentina, as we limp through the lifeless corridors. "Maybe he's right. Maybe I can go back. I can get an advantage on him, it's the only way."
"No, you can't think like that," she says.

"I can't live with the weight. I thought I could accept it, but the entire world is my fault: my sister grievously hurt, your sister, dead, without honor for no reason at all, and this is only the beginning. I believed. I thought this would all turn out better, but it's all slipping . . . again . . . and I swear, to the stone Gods and Goddesses that listen in this temple, I can still hear their screams."

She grabs the hem of Romin's tattered suit jacket to stop me for a moment. "I spent my whole life telling myself that the world was my fault. That she hated me because I was a terrible daughter. In that cellar, I'd run the perfect string of words over and over, convinced if I just found the right combination I might break through, just get my foot in the door, that maybe the locks could come off."
"You thought there was a perfect answer."

"That's right, and no matter how good I got at studying people and reading their emotions, building my craft until I made it a profession, commanding enough to stir an audience to tears or make them laugh at imaginary characters in a script— I still couldn't do it."
"But why would you keep trying?"

"Because I was addicted to the vision of something I couldn't have, that I would never have. And you gave me a chance to see clearly for the first time. You gave me that courage to stand up for it, and let that impossible vision die before it hurt me any more."
"So then where do I draw the line? You can live in the comfort of knowing you made that choice and you can't go back, Val, but what if this is my life purpose?"
"Purpose is tied to meaning and concrete goals. My suffering was meaningless. And my goal was to make my family love me again. What is yours?"
"I don't even know what good enough looks like. I just know I'm not there yet," I tell her.
"And will you be? Will Ullrich ever be?"
The thread is still there on my wrist, the last line untethered unlike before. It might never show its frayed ends if I continue, but the promise to Ellie feels like shallow words of foolish passion.
Valentina says, "My sister died horrifically, stupidly, but after I spent a long time thinking about it, I realize that doesn't mean it wasn't meaningful."
It's so dark. When I close my eyes, I can still see the house I left, those last moments with the woman I love, and the mother I missed all those lonely years.
Valentina says, "I mean, I think so. It has to be, right?"
"I'm not sure anymore," I tell her.

The ancient halls open to a broad, central chapel, where fleeting rays of sunlight pour through the high windows like golden wax. What's left of the crushed pews tells they were meant to face us, away from the stage, towards the statues of nameless Gods replaced by mortals that think themselves their equal.
Spirits of azure flame begin to dance in the hollow space, harmless when they graze the fabric of our tattered clothes.

"You can take that piece of Pure Essence, but it brings you nowhere closer to anything. Give it to the daughter of Khiras, unable to harness Her power, and all of Blackwater will be destroyed. Use it yourself, and your threads will jettison all its power into the atmosphere. Give it to Lyra and nothing will happen. Only I can make anything of it."
His voice booms from the second floor. The flames coalesce into large shapes.
"What, are you going to burn us out?"
"I want to tell you a story. Because regardless of who lives or dies, only memory survives these loops for the two of us."

His hands raise past the railing. We stand in the center while Lyra leans against the wall. The flames congeal in glowing clouds of blue plasma, covering every edge of the circular sanctum until a flat plane obscures the floor, making our feet disappear.

"This timeline is all an illusion, Titus. I'm taking us back to them. The real you is back there, the real Lyra, before the incident in the house. I'm gonna raise you so you never end up alone. I'll raise you as the next Mask. I'll teach you everything I know. I'll say all the things you should have heard, that I was too late to ever tell you," he says. The luminescent smoke condenses into rugged bumps, and I recognize it as terrain: the landmarks he's committed to memory are sharp and distinct while the rest is fuzzy.

Valentina and I realize that we stand within the walls of Blackwater, and we're divided by the central peaks. Countless forested hills are scattered around the walls, and it feels as if I'm Sylvia's divine form, watching from high above the clouds.

The entire map translates somewhere long past the hills and trees, somewhere the ice stops, and we see it: the terrain dotted with shrubs and trees just like the Afterlife, but everywhere, and I wonder how much Essence it would take to ever have that much heat.

"This was the cradle of humanity. It was our birthright. And it was beautiful," he says. We shrink until we're as tall as the bordering mountains, and the landscape settles, so many boxes of buildings and stretches of open land coming into view. It's a massive city, far grander than anything I've ever seen, at least ten times the size of small Blackwater.
"We were so strong. We had true power in numbers, Essence, but all that was taken from us. A hundred years ago, the fall of Nordhaven crippled us, attacked by Chymaeran and Ahkvasan separatists."

It mystifies me how such a massive city could crumble to the will of any army in such a short time. But then I see it: volleys of Essence that eviscerate entire lines of the city at a time; divine agents I could only recognize as the Masks of other races; such a strength in numbers and formless familiars that civilians could stand no chance.

"You can't go back because you weren't around yet. Not even I can go back that far. But the Goddess gave me this thread as a secret mission, to restore humanity to its greatest state, to wipe the slate clean of everything that should have never come to exist. So can't you see, Titus? There is no guilt when none of this is real!"
"But it is, Ullrich, can't you see? This is the life that fate chose before you ever went back to reverse it."

"Then you're too complacent to know what it means to dream bigger. Your pathetic life below the clouds is all you've known, with what— that pathetic father that was too drunk to show at your graduation? Your dead mother? Thankless sister? Hunger and desperation and loneliness when you deserve to be raised right? I can take all of that away."

"It made me who I am. Sure, this world is torture. It hurts to exist, to be alive, to admit defeat and mourn all the ways life could have been different. But this is our world, meant for one shot. And I'll live with its joys, or be damned with it."

"Then I hope the next version of you is less blinded by that pathetic helplessness," Ullrich says, casting an explosive fire charge against the top of the chapel. "Now go back and give up. You can still save Lyra!"

The crack spreads across the ceiling. Gravel raps the top of my skull. We're in the middle of  the floor, and I know if I don't act now, we'll be buried in a mass stone grave, though I'm far more concerned of what it might do to the lone thread on my wrist.

The distant wall crumbles as Ullrich escapes out the top balcony. That same feeling of hopelessness I felt in past lives metastasizes in my muscles, freezing me entirely, and I panic, though I feel something ripped from my pocket as I turn around.

"We're not giving up. Their sacrifice was not in vain," she says, and when I open my eyes, I no longer hear the clatter of rubble cascading from the ceiling. She holds the piece of pure Essence in her hands with a devout look of determination, her radiant jade eyes piercing as the world decelerates around us.

She grabs me at the wrist, dragging me towards the entrance from whence we came, watching with panic as meteoric masses of stone shatter the aged tile, falling gracefully with the slowness of entropy until they nearly halt. The air feels thin when our momentum grows in the atrophy of time, and when I collide with the fractals of multicolor shattered, stained glass, they spin in place as if fixed to the ceiling by a piece of string, though with the slightest touch they still slice my clothes.

She tugs me in front of her, pushing behind me to make me go faster, and it frightens me when I remember how history might repeat itself again. We can still see the grand arch of the entry door intact because of its shape, the light of the reflective pool catching our eyes, casting a halo around the dark edges of debris, and when the boulders scrape away strands of my jet-black hair, crunching us down to a near crawl to avoid the crippling forces stronger than a hundred men apiece, we finally dive for the daylight, and in the last moment, Valentina pushes me.

I crash into the edge of the fountain, straining my back as the trickle of time returns to a full flood, filling the air with clouds of dust. I plunge into the bloody fountain, bashing into my sister that still floats there, helplessly, and I'm praying to whatever Gods may listen that I didn't lose another.

I feel something cold and wet grab my leg and it startles me. My mind jumps to the sickly tendrils of Endogeny, and so I kick my legs, driving my head against the edge of the fountain as it releases, sitting with my back turned to the desecrated chapel.
It's Lyra.

I see that her chest still rises and falls. She's lost a lot of blood, but she still hangs on to life, and I reach to ferry her across the pool. I surely lost a friend, and if my family still persists, I'm going to save her at any cost.
"Don't lift her," the voice says. Her feet splash in the shallow water, covering the distance of twenty meters in a matter of mere seconds, with the amulet still in her hand.
"Val, you made it," I say. My voice quavers. "You didn't . . . or, I thought you—"
"I have too much reason to live. I've got a life to avenge and family to protect. And you do, too," she replies, gesturing towards my sister as she hands me the Amulet.

We find two steel-poled flags between the wreckage of the chapel and the scaffolding, adorned with the pure white sigil of the Afterlife. I instruct Valentina to face them opposite each other, and we roll them in, forming a canvas stretcher we use to scoop Lyra from the fountain.
"I can't use this. No," Lyra says, when I give her the piece of pure Essence to stabilize her. "I would have died for a reason. I can't feel my legs, Titus. I'm useless! I'm not worth it!"
"No. Ullrich was right that the piece of pure Essence is useless to us. It's only useful to keep it from him."
"Why can't you use it?" Valentina asks.
"I can't become a Mask with this thread tethered to my arm."
"Then why don't you tear it?"
"Because I don't know the consequence. And if it does happen . . . who knows how long I'll have after that," I say.
She still hesitates to tap into its power. I'm still dumbstruck at its influence on Valentina.
"Use it," I tell her. "I'm telling you to go ahead."
"But what if—"
" What if, nothing, Lyra! I'm not losing you."

She inspects the celestial pebble within the amulet before she tensions her fingers on it. Valentina used just a little, but it's notably smaller in size, like peeling the skin off a grape. We can feel it's influence as I carry the front and Valentina lifts the back.
"What now?" Valentina asks.

"We pray our friends hold fast in the foothills," I tell her. "Ullrich knows that, if his consciousness continues, either I'm still alive or I followed my same series of choices. So all we can do is join the fight below."

I'm surprised that the Royal Guardsmen never show up to capture or kill us. I pray it's because they're occupied at the walls, trying to deter the city's full attack. I pray the Merlot listen to the Vermillion family's warning, though I doubt prayer will get me anywhere that raw effort can't.
"It will take forever to walk back," Valentina says. "She needs attention now."
"I'll be alright. Look, it's working, just a little bit, but it's working," Lyra says. I see her big toe distort the fabric of the flags as she tries to move it.

"That's great, Lyra. But we're not going to be able to take you that way—" I look past a section of wall that was crunched by a chapel column, finding nothing more than a mile of dense, un-traversable foliage dotted with bushes.
"Then how will we make it back?"
There's only one real option. "It depends on if you can drive without crashing," I tell her.
"I'm gonna crash!" She shouts.

"No, you're not! Just focus on the road," I insist, as I duck behind the tattered white fabric, scorched with burning holes from the three pearlescent touring cars chasing us. "Gods be damned, this is too fast to not be riding rails—"
"Just hold on. Keep targeting them," Valentina says.
"Ellie barely taught me to fire standing still!"

I couldn't find it in me to kill the guard that was sitting in the driver's seat. It was easy to choke him out since he was younger than me, just a twig: strong from the Essence, but his muscles weren't trained by poverty and hard labor. He must have ratted us off as soon as he came to.
Lyra tries to give me the Amulet, sprawled in the back between the flags.
"No, you need that," I tell her.
"Take it. Just don't let your blood touch it."

Valentina hits a large rock, casting us upwards, and Lyra gets a near second of air time. I nearly disappear out the top before I duck back in, missing a fire blast by the length of my hair. I regain my composure and tighten my hands around the pure Essence, feeling it flow through one arm and out the other.

"Hold steady, Val. Get us steady for a second!" I try to aim, but it's not like throwing a ball. More like peeing in a bush, except the bush is three moving cars with highly-trained, Essenced Guardsmen, and the hose is my arm, churning with such Essence I'm not sure if the next blast will throw me out towards the untreaded road faster than this stolen ride.

Valentina is trying. But the dirt back road snakes left and right. I'm not sure how precise I have to be, whether it will cone short and wide like a shotgun blast, or a direct line of ray energy. The three cars are never together. The only thing that's constant are the projectile flames pelting to the left and the right of us, and their aim is getting better.
"We're coming up on a straightaway," Valentina says. "They'll all have a direct shot!"

"And so will I," I tell her. "Straighten out, just for a second." I grasp it harder, almost enough to bend the outer shell, and I can feel the energy resonate my entire body at the same frequency, almost enough to make me vomit, aside from Valentina's reckless driving. I hold my breath try to aim, and then I trigger that imaginary muscle that Ellie taught me.

My arm buckles. I hit myself in the face as the Amulet slips from my grasp. For a moment I'm blind, and I consider so much Essence has flooded out of my body that my senses have been destroyed, but I still feel the feeling of inertia — no longer the rugged jostling of Valentina's erratic driving, but only the motion of wind blowing back at my body.

My body thrashes with no surface to ground myself, and when my vision recovers as my ears ring, I realize I'm in the air, at least twenty meters above the lush landscape, heading straight for a bank of pine trees on the side of the road, the flames still sputtering from my palm in stops and starts that shake me as I ragdoll in the air.

It feels as if I'm in an out-of-body experience, watching Valentina's stolen car screech its tires as it brakes for me. As my back crunches the branches, pine needles stabbing my back and scratching my flesh, I cascade down the canopy. The last sight I catch is the crater in the dirt road: three hunks of scorched metal burning as the occupants writhe on the ground.

I grab for a branch. It snaps, and after a face full of needles, I grab again, holding tightly to the stabbing end of whatever's there. The branch swings me downwards, turning all my falling motion into collision with the trunk.

It might have saved my life, but I see stars when my back slams into the rugged ground, bashing my head against the bark of the tree's roots. Despite the bloodied scratches, I'm lucky that I'm mostly unscathed, watching as Valentina approaches from the road to help me to my feet.

The worst pain I feel is my right shoulder socket, my arm thrown back by such tremendous force that it strains on torn muscles. Grasping that branch saved my feet, though I paid for that fall with the headache.

We make it to the end of the only road we know, and the landscape is far more desolate than we left it. Sreaklines of tar denote the path of mindless consumption Endogeny took towards the lower hills, fueling itself with whatever it could acquire in the absence of living flesh. Valentina drives the pearlescent touring car into the hub, directly into the Vermilion lift, and the squealing brakes echo through the vacant chamber lit only by the opposite balcony. When we exit, we find the only other black skid marks not left by Valentina's driving: the desperate last stand of the lowly-Essenced attendant, tatters of his clothes left behind while all his organic matter is elsewhere.

We descend the lift as we watch from the balcony, uncertain of where the Merlot and Carmine's calamitous push advances in the span of a day. The only evidence we have of change is the smell of sulfur — from either distant pockets of flames far across the civilian landscape; gunpowder; or Essence used as a potent replacement for saltpeter.

To the west, the sky flashes in what Valentina and I naively mistake as lightning. Barely able to support herself against the railing with the amulet in her hand, Lyra tells that they're volleys of Essenced Chymaeran energy.
"But that's near the Academy," Valentina says.
"Then that means they're at the first command point. We're getting off," I say.

It took almost an hour of untended, winding service roads before the amethyst lightning grew any larger, and sprawled across the back seat of the touring car, Lyra looked like she's throw up at any moment. If it wasn't for me holding her shoulders to the seat with her head in my lap, she would have popped out of the car through the tattered fabric as soon as we drove off the freight lift.

The ambient sounds of discharging rifles tell us we're getting closer to the front lines. Ahead, we watch as scouting parties cross the road like rabbits, disappearing in the trees before we can see where they went.

A twosome surprises us on the road, their rifles raised although our headlights aren't on to blind them. With such a posh motorcar, rolling like a polished pearl on ruddy trails — were it not for the gaping hole in the ceiling and bullet holes all across the chassis, they would have shot us right away. Valentina tries to brake slowly, but a rock catches the rigid wheel, jolting us upwards, and Lyra grunts at the sudden shift.
"What are you . . ." The first stranger squints while the second still steadies their rifle. "Who is that . . . Vera? Vera, is that you? Sweet Khiras above. And Titus!"
The voice is Jarrett's, and he's joined by Delvin.
"Isla's back at base camp. We need to get us all back together. Gods above, I didn't know when you were coming back."
"Jarrett," Delvin says.
"It was all such a shot in the dark, sending you all up there, and—"
"Jarrett, that's not Vera. That's Valentina," Delvin says. He looks at Lyra and I through the broken window. "What happened to Vera, Titus?"

We're in for a quiet ride after we tell them. Jarrett sits in the front with both their rifles. Delvin sits on the right seat, supporting Lyra's legs over his lap as he stares out the window, maybe hiding tears at the edge of exhaustion.
Jarrett says, "Despite everything, your fireteam did it. I still don't know how you managed to pull it off."
"Pull off what?" I ask.

"Most of the Merlot and Carmine in all the districts are allied together. They listened to Vincent's message. And we spread the message to the masses — some of the unaffiliated civilians have taken arms for our cause, while others are escaping towards the outer walls.  Romin and I just pray it buys enough time to stop whatever drives Endogeny."
"Then we have to get to the inner walls fast," I say.
"Why don't we take the lift?" Valentina asks.
"Because it will be crawling with Afterlife after our escape: plus, it's far too slow," I say. I turn to Delvin. "How are the others? Isla? Sylvia?"
"They're preparing their assault with the rest of the militia. If you're lucky, you'll catch them before they leave," he says.

It's only half an hour more, but every second on the winding roads make it feel so much longer. The other fireteam has no further words for their dead friend, and Valentina reflects their silent suffering, as if guilty that she's not her.

The car pulls into the Academy North campus, past the broken steel gates defended by Merlot and Carmine, and they wave to us. The campus is flooded with cadets, brave commoners, Merlotan guards, and Carmine brothers and sisters. The intercom repeats that THIS SPACE IS FOR ALLIED MILITIA ONLY — that all the other civilians are to egress towards the outer walls with all they can carry.
The one commonality is that all of them are walking the same way, towards the Foothills, and it's as if we drove through a cross-current of pink and crimson.

Surely enough, the Academy North administration building is the main operating base, well-furnished with supplies since they commandeered the gondola to carry all the munitions from the Carmine compound.

It's tremendous what the opposing factions can accomplish when they work together. I get a closer look at their members when I step out of the car, steadying Lyra as she heals herself with the Amulet. They wear the same clothes of their factions, but their membership patches are different. The whole base exchanged their faction's patch with the members of the other, giving all the militants a homogenous color scheme.
I ask one of the Merlotans. "What's going on here?"

"Is that a joke? Get your things together. The next wave is moving out," he says, before joining his fireteam as the mass exodus makes for the mountain. I start to walk in their direction, but a hand tensions around my mark before I can go.
"Whoa, there. Not you, buddy. We need you for later."
It's Romin.
"Our scouts saw you coming from afar. They were asking what a cloud was doing on the ground  and not in the air," he says.
Valentina embraces him with all her sorrow and he consoles her.
"We need a medical team to help Lyra," I tell him. "She's still in the car."

"Sure." Romin pulls aside two Carmine cadets walking past, ordering them to go to the medical bay. "You weren't gone for long. I was expecting to meet you on the other side of the wall. What happened up there?"
Valentina gives him the short of it.
"Gods above," he says, just as the medical team takes Lyra on our makeshift stretcher.
"But we got something. And it won't be useful to us until we make it to the other side of the wall, and I have my chance."
Lyra passes it off to me before the medics can carry her upstream. The same resonance flutters my circuits, and only now does it hit me that this is the final push.
"My father shared his Essence. I can feel that. What is it?"

"A fragment of Pure Essence. More than the First Red had in the Backwoods," I tell him. "This was supposed to be in the house beyond the walls. I stole it back. And now we can use it to gain an edge on the source of Endogeny."

Romin gestures to the flood of militiamen making for the hills. I never knew there were this many fighting spirits in Blackwater. "Let these fighters pave the way for our forces of destruction. We are all no longer divided. Between Merlot and Carmine, there is no other enemy beyond the false gods above the clouds. We will choke them out from all sides before Endogeny can extinguish us!"
The true Humans of Blackwater might strain their muscles climbing the foothills to approach the outer walls of the Upper City, but to them, it's a true downhill battle.

The Afterlife might have generations of Essence they stored for this very moment, but they don't have that feverish determinism of the ones that were poor, desperate, and weak their whole lives: the ones willing to give everything, including themselves, for their people to live on. They launch their volleys of Essence without aim at the foothills. The ground dissolves. Bodies dissolve. The dirt and rock launches into the air, trapping dusk in a thin, timeless orange haze, yet we continue to run towards the walls, getting closer and closer, our lungs screaming for breath as we scale the incline further and further, guns blasting, axe-rifles chopping, screams of only agony or determination christening the air.

The first three waves were fodder. They knew their purpose but acted anyway, with so much anger to release the pains of death were incomparable. The next two waves were the ones that broke through Endogeny, carving a path in the black rubber ring of rancid gore, holding it off long enough for the demolition it's teams to establish a foothold. And now — as the final waves of the three northern provinces pierce the black bile, the pearlescent walls grow closer and closer.

"Don't let it deceive you! There is nothing living left, not your friends, not your family, nothing," Romin shouts, as he slices through a tattered limb of Endogeny. Valentina's sister appeared to her three times, but each time she blew a hole through its chest, collapsing the Chymaeran chum to amorphousness.

Our team is immune to small patches of Endogeny. Though the great Chymaeran weapon churns cadets and combatants like toothless, cancerous gums, we wade through the middle passage, so close to the wall that Romin could throw a rock at it.

The Royal Guard are nervous atop the walls, exhausting their Essence to cast flames on the militiamen between the walls and Endogeny. I wonder how long we can hold the ring open. I wonder how the other partnered provinces fare in this grand campaign, whether they're just bait for the black bile, or if they're at their walls too, preparing the charges to crumble the walls.

The amulet is around my neck, sharing the same strong chain as my mother's Chymaeran marker. Romin's excitement climbs as we get closer. The central team carries the crates between the flank of human shields, keeping the precious cargo from the bile. It's when we make it halfway through the obsidian river that Romin huffs his orders.
"Keep Endogeny from the wall, clear a space— we're blowing it!"

They shim the boxes with boulders just to keep them upright. The Essenced explosives are packed with every last ounce of Essence the Merlotan families have, glowing bright crimson, waiting for a single spark to eviscerate everything.

"Plant the charges!" Romin barks, but they're already installing the explosives on the wall. The fighters behind us hold the line against suffocation in the bile. They cry under the force of odorous, decaying flesh and sinew reaching with uncanny hands to absorb them; chopping and slicing between heaving breaths just like we are; and the more it builds, the quicker we realize that the mass is conscious enough to understand what we're doing.

"Romin, get them to hurry up!" I say. Endogeny absorbs a Merlotan's hand when he slips on his swing, and the Merlotan soldier cries out in fear — though I know Endogeny's toxic make-up mutes all the pain.

"Almost there, just hold a little longer," Romin orders. The ring is closing on itself. Soon we'll separated from the fighters on the other side of Endogeny, enclaved between the tar and the pearlescent wall.

The demolitionists retreat with the detonation line just as Endogeny is about to close. We redouble our forces on the inner walls, parting the sea of tar like a bad haircut, just a little longer until we can clear the blast radius, back-to-back as Endogeny tries to repair itself.
Our muscles tense, and we cover our ears, prepares for the blast, just as Romin opens his mouth to issue the order.
"Blow it."

One of the Merlotan militants drives down the plunger. I close my eyes to save my sight from the blast, holding my breath as I take blind slashes at the mess of conscious black tar. But nothing happens.
The Merlotan frantically drives the plunger twice more. Jarrett pulls at the wire, and we realize that a chunk of Endogeny dissolved the cable, severing us from our deliverance.
"Gods damn it," Romin shouts.

"We can't hold much longer," Valentina insists, and my arms strain under the exhaustion. My back presses hard against another Carmine brother. Deterring flames bellow from my palms. We'll be compressed by the tar if we don't act immediately. Not even my threads could change this outcome.
"It's time, then," Romin says. His voice is calm and serene, despite everything.
"Time for what?" Jarrett asks.
"It's time to rush the wall," he says.
"But that's suicide!" Jarrett says.
"Not you. There's a higher mission here than any of us, and even if none of us survive to tell of it..."
I cast a ball of fire at the wall of Essenced explosives. The metal warms, but nothing happens. In response, Romin grasps my shoulder.
"It's been an honor to be your friend, Titus. I truly love you as a brother."
"You can't do this," I tell him. "We can find another way. Let me try again!"
"We both know there's no time to think," he says. Something feels so different in him: no longer the same child paralyzed by hubris; no longer shivering in the shadow of that great, bronze statue.

Valentina embraces him as another soldier takes her spot. She weeps into his chest for seconds until she's dragged back into the fight, because Endogeny is a thoughtless hivemind with no patience for altruism.

"Remember what I stood for," he tells us, letting out his raucous rallying cry as he charges the wall with the detonator. Endogeny binds itself together at his egress right before it can grab him, and as we continue to resist the black bile with tears wetting our eyes, the blast eviscerates the wall, casting chunks of pearlescent white stone, blowing a massive, searing hole though the layer Endogeny unintentionally guarded us with.

The plumes and smoke blow over. We cough at the white dust as Endogeny retreats, afraid of the Essenced flames scalding the ground. To the distant foothills, we can already see other massive chunks of the amorphous mass advancing into the city, gaining size with the plant life it rips from the ground: absorbing whole trees in a matter of seconds.

But through the smoke and dust, light shimmers through the vertical crater that Romin's sacrifice offers us. There is nothing left of him to mourn like all the times past, and in the shortness of time, our ears ringing as our lungs scorch on sparse air, we realize the only piece of him we have left to carry is the purpose that bonded the warring factions together.
"I loved him. I should have told him, Gods above, even at the end I couldn't say it." Valentina repeats it over and over. The insurgents rush into the vertical crater as we stand there in disbelief.

This is the first time the finality of this chance has imbued me with the weight of grief. My mind flickers to that small breadth of time separating me from Romin when he wasn't reduced to a bloody mist, relegated to nothing as if he never existed at all. I fall to my knees. I know if I went back that maybe, just maybe, we could make it work. I could move the line. we could blow it early. Gods above, we could do it all different!

I find the tears rolling down my face when I take Romin's axegun to my chin, just to feel it when everyone else is too preoccupied with their grief. Maybe Valentina was right to ask. I didn't feel the weight of personal connection — all the years that she and her sister feuded over title and family just to apologize later, maybe galvanizing their relationship with that continued strain.

"I can go back still. Just once," I whisper to myself. This is different than Ullrich's endless campaign for perfection. This is just a subtle, calculable detail in the vastness of the universe, one small wish to grant. And all it takes is one spasm of a finger.

It's then that I feel the arms around me as I weep, the barrel under my chin ready to blow my brain out the top in misted confetti, though I wouldn't be around to feel its power. They tighten themselves around me. They place their head above mine, right into the path of the last loaded slug.
"You have to believe this world can be enough," Sylvia says. "You told me this was it. You can be better than him."
"He's right there," I tell her. "One minute. One minute away from us..."

"I know," she says. Her embrace reminds me of my sister's gentle compassion in the other worldline. It reminds me of every emotional piece of the promise I made to her, to live smart, hard, and only once more. I check my wrist. Unlike Ullrich, this thread still has its frayed end. "This is all just the truth you told me, moments before you left. So wear his mission on your sleeve."

Though Valentina's grief paralyzes her, I goad her onwards towards the opening in the wall, along with Jarrett, Isla, and Delvin, both our fireteams missing an essential member. We let the current of combatants take us once we find the strength to let go, bidding the final farewell to our boisterous friend, without a physical form to bury.

In the upper lands, there's too much anger for looting. Arsonists take nothing and burn everything. If they have Essence, they incinerate the fabric and wood with their palms. For the rest with no power, they light matches, smash windows, and tear the decorative flags and landmarks to the ground.

We're running to the only place that Ullrich and the Heiress can escape to. We pass outwallers bashing brazen statues with sledgehammers. The unluckiest desperate denizens of the Afterlife are lynched in the streets, hung from trees, swinging in their bright colors as they're beaten with sticks, but all I can think of is Romin, and what my reaction means. If I can't shoulder the burden of a sacrifice that wasn't my fault, I'll never be able to do what's awaited me all this time.

The Royal Guard attempt to hold a line against us, but all they do is backpedal. The city was never designed for defense: the only weapon they have is their Essence and their skill with it, but when their adversary's lust for blood is this strong, the fear of death is meaningless.

I wonder when I should do it. My fingers grasp the frayed end of the thread, and I try to imagine what it will feel like to tear this divine curse from my flesh. I don't want to imagine how much my friends will suffer when I do it. Maybe deep down, I thought this was all an unreachable goal I'd die short of. Maybe I'd loop forever. Maybe I'd get used to the same span of days, over and over, but when the dream is only moments away, the hesitation is so strong.
"There's so few of them. It's like they just disappeared," Valentina says.
"You said you've been here before. Where did they go, Titus?" Jarrett asks.
I follow the same route I took when they shepherded me with the guards. None of these outwallers know where they're really hiding, because they'd never expect to ever be above them.
"Below us," I tell them.
"What," Isla says, "as in, back to the city?"
"Below the ground. In the hollow, lush caves carved by Humans and Chymaera long before us," I tell them.
"But how do we get there?"
"We have to—"
A shockwave pulses dirt into the air before I can finish. We're standing right across from the grate that took me to the depths.
"What was that?"

We look around. A loud sound in the distance repeats like rushing water. Something changed in the span of several seconds, but I just can't put my finger on it. The air is so quiet, and I can hear shouts, and for a minute, I wonder if Endogeny has liquidated its victims early.
But I look around. The other insurgents still rushi the central nexus that spawned Endogeny, just past the treeline and the garden wall, where...
"What is that over there? Snow?"
The ground trembles harder. It must be a fog, obscuring the view of all the taller buildings near the center of the peaks.
But then the furthest trees begin to disappear, too. It's only when the hardy buildings beside us crack and crumble that I realize what is happening.

The others already have a head start. I never expected Isla's short legs to carry her so fast. Valentina tries again to draw on the powers within her, maybe just enough, and as time slows for them, I pray to the Gods they have the chance to make it.

I'm too far from their pocket of influence to feel the effects. Time accelerates. The ground melts from stone to gravel to sand. This is it. I reach for the thread to pull whatever fleeting moment of power it can give me, clutching the remnants of Pure Essence to activate the birthright that was taken. But it's too late.
I slip. My feet catch nothing, and soon I'm weightless, falling headlong into the void of ash and dust, but I'm not alone.

Sylvia clutches to me. She tears the celestial pebble of Pure Essence from my neck and allows it to flood her divine circuits with the powers of the Goddess. Her hair glows white. I feel her shielding me with her body as she takes on a hundredth of that divine form, growing until I can barely fill her arms, still tucked around me with such radiant warmth it feels I've skipped the hard landing and made it straight to the true afterlife.
She's pelted with the falling debris, still holding me so tightly as ambient daylight diffuses through the clouds of dust. My head is below her chin, yet my feet can barely reach her waist.
We hit the bottom. I spring against her breastbone as cascading rock catches up with us. I can feel her wince at the impacts, though she still refuses to raise a hand or an arm.
The amulet's Essence is waning.
"Please, Sylvia, don't lose yourself this time," I beg her. If that side of her permeates, all of this struggle could be for naught.
"I won't. I just want to save the one I love."

We brace for the impact, but nothing can prepare us for when we stop falling with the rubble. I hear something pop when I spring against her breastbone. She tries so hard to protect me, hugging me tighter to her chest as the rubble pelts the two of us, and every blow she takes to her legs or side only dampens it the slightest bit.

Somewhere above, a house teetering on the edge gives in to the strain and crumbles half of itself off the shale. Sylvia begins to let up her grasp when it stops hailing, but she's too slow to react when the solid roof collides with her arm, shattering it. The last I feel is the glancing crumb that bashes into the back of my head, leaving us both limply sprawling across the pit.

I wake to breathless, wailing groans of the dying beneath the rubble. Somewhere a little deeper, the Afterlife is entombed by the ruins of their own city, along with all their decorative adornments, buried with their golden age.

Sylvia lays beside me in her human form, exhausted of Essence, barely able to breathe as she cradled her arm. The dust burns our eyes. I cover Sylvia's mouth with a tattered piece of fabric before I cover mine, looking up hundreds of feet to try and discern the distant edge, but the dust is too thick. We're trapped in the hollowed ribcage of the centermost peak, excised of its heart and all its entrails. I know there's only one person that could eviscerate everything without consequence, and as I lift myself to my feet, healed by Sylvia's divine Essence in those hours we laid unconscious at the furthest depths, I carry her.

This is the last cycle of the endless tirade between my estranged father and I. If I remember nothing of Ullrich's resets — and I refuse to live anything but this linear path from life to certain death in one shot — the final fated outcome is the only option that can rise from this.

Maybe he's reset a hundred times. Maybe this is the ultimate impasse he speaks of, and he knows everything, but with my final decision and determination to keep this life the way it plays out, his greatest strength is now his fatal flaw.

I take her towards where the capitol was. We find several caves in the sidewall of the great sinkhole, and head down the closest one, hoping they're all connected. If I try picking at random, it won't matter. Ullrich can't die because of the endless determinism of these cycles. I'm certain he's seen everything, and I feel his presence reel me forward in time from a different invisible tether: fate.

My eyes adjust to the darkness after I carry her inside. We hear the sound of wet squishing like stepping on saturated sod, and we realize the great Chymaeran weapon feasted between the cracks on the dying denizens of both sides.
My arms are tired. I limp with her in my arms, my clothes completely tattered and worn, showing through to smooth skin healed of its cuts, though the inside strains on sprains and possible shatters.
"Son," a voice calls. "Son, please save me," the voice says. Clint approaches me. "The tar, it consumed everything!"

"It left nothing for us. We could have had a chance at the end, after all this time, to be a family again," Moira says, crying streams of tar down her face from her blackened eyes. "We can have that. We can still have that!"
"You chose my sister and left me to die," Vera says.
"Only for me to suffer the same fate," Valentina says, "along with everyone! But you can still save us!"
"I never wanted to die. I wanted to live a full life with my cherished friend," Romin cries. "I wanted to fall in love with Valentina. Every moment you live tears me further from that dream!"
"You have to die, Titus," my mother says. "It's the only way. This is a dead end, and you'll leave this world with nothing!"
There's not enough tar for them to grow legs. They slosh along the floor as spectral snakes. But only one is fully formed, and he approaches in full color.

"Tie-bo," he says, shambling toward me. The amethyst floods his veins in spiderwebs just like the last time I saw him, when I was so young and afraid, so uncomfortable that I left before Clint could offer the last words to his father. Endogeny must have already made it to the graveyards. He was buried near the middle of the wide outer ring of Lower Blackwater.
I'm not sure how much this projection remembers. All the others approach us from behind, urging Sylvia and I to approach him.
"A life of regret was all that was left for me, when I hid in that room. But it seems my map took you to that petty thing I traded for my niece and nephew's life."
He sees the amulet around my neck, deterring the other endogenous phantoms of the living dead.
Everett continues. "Then you saw the result of it. You know . . . what happened, you were too young, for me, to explain, or . . . "
He struggles for the words. I only have time for a single question.
"The vials of my blood beneath your trade house. The daughter Clint never should have been able to have. The death of my mother — why did you do it?"
"Because, patience, couldn't hold my anger. And when I found out, in the end, that he staged it all..."
"What? What do you mean?" I ask. He'd fall apart if I dropped Sylvia and grabbed him with my hands.
"He was with the Afterlife, long before, that fateful night. Not believing he had it, in him, is the regret I carry with me, even through death."
"But why, Everett? Why would he do such a thing?"
"Because I had the threads before you were even born," Ullrich says.
He approaches with the estranged sister I never got to save in this timeline. His body is covered even further with the crimson twine.
He says, "If only you knew how many times I've explained this to you, but I have to."

Gentle Everett springs on an anger I never saw as a child. He turns around and drives a fist against his brother's face, but his hand splatters like pudding against a stone wall, lobbing off a whole chunk of his arm.
Ullrich doesn't flinch.
"As children of the original rulers of Blackwater, Everett and I couldn't have been more different. I was more proactive. That's why he's dead and I'm still here."
He looks at the tar-bound silhouettes of my friends and family.
"Every time you try, Fletcher, you never save them. Whether endogenous or not, can't you see they're all just an illusion? Your sister? Your friends? Your lover? They're ephemeral, see?"

He slams his hands together. Everett's head explodes in a column of black bile. The endogenous phantoms dissolve into the spaces between the rocks. It's just Sylvia, Ullrich and I, standing at the mouth of a great, cavernous room.
I say, "You killed the Afterlife, too. You never cared about a golden age."

"That's right. It took me a near hundred tries to climb their ranks, putting together the right strings of words, the right speeches, the right show of old-world Human magic, until I had the path set exactly as I needed it. Your grandfather— No, uncle, Everett, was right. I planned that strike. You were all supposed to die so you'd stop getting in my way," he says.
"Of your hunger for boundless power?"
"Of seeing it end the same way, over and over and over!"
I can see a part of him crack, and catch a glimpse at something sincere and so exhausted on the other side.

I can feel his white anger. "Power? You really look at all this and think it's about power? Gods below, Fletcher, do you think you can ever possibly understand what I left behind, what they took from me?"
"All I know is it wasn't enough," I tell him. "You should have stayed dead the first time."
I duck before he punches, and I can feel it, though I don't remember.
But he does.

The breadth of time I've spent in this chamber might be longer than all my life. The only weapon I have is the certainty that I won't ever die to live again. It means I'm headed towards a definite end.

I look back at Sylvia as she stands behind me. So much of this life I wished I could see through to the end — so many I wanted to save and cherish and love — but I can feel the sublimity of that purpose calling out to me along with everyone I lost waiting on the other side, beckoning for me to close this loop and play the last note of the grand symphony.

He grabs my wrist before I can tear the thread, stunning me when he punches me in the nose. My thread tangles with his, uprooting just enough fleshed for our Essenced blood to mix — and when it does, allowing the singularity of our endless paradox to coalesce at a single point, the great cavern floods with the presence of every past and future.
